A concise way to see why the median to the hypotenuse has length equal to half the hypotenuse is to use the fact that in a right triangle, the hypotenuse is a diameter of the triangle’s circumcircle. Concretely, suppose △ABC is a right triangle with right angle at A and hypotenuse BC. Let M be the midpoint of BC.

1. Because M is the midpoint of BC, the segments MB and MC are equal in length.  
2. In a right triangle, the hypotenuse BC is the diameter of its circumcircle. Hence the center of that circle is exactly M, the midpoint of BC.  
3. The radius of this circumcircle is MB (or MC), which is ½BC.  
4. Since A also lies on this circumcircle (with BC as diameter), AM must be a radius of the same circle. Therefore AM = MB = MC = ½BC.

Thus, the median AM from the right angle A to the hypotenuse BC is exactly half as long as BC.

A classical way to see that the three angles of a triangle add up to 180° is to use a line parallel to one side of the triangle and apply alternate interior angles. Here is a standard proof:

1) Draw triangle ABC.  
2) Through vertex A, draw a line ℓ parallel to side BC.  
3) Label the intersection of this new line ℓ with the extension of side AB as point D, so A lies between B and D.

         D
         |
         |
    B --------- A
          \   
           \
            C

4) Since ℓ is drawn parallel to BC, the following angle equalities hold due to alternate interior angles:  
   - The angle at A adjacent to AB (on line ℓ) equals ∠ABC.  
   - The angle at A adjacent to AC (on line ℓ) equals ∠ACB.

5) On the straight line ℓ, these two angles plus ∠BAC sum to 180°, because a straight line measures 180°. But these two angles on ℓ are precisely the measures of ∠ABC and ∠ACB, respectively.

6) Therefore, ∠BAC + ∠ABC + ∠ACB = 180°.

Hence, in any triangle, the sum of the interior angles is 180°.

Proof:

Suppose lines ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are each parallel to a third line m. We wish to show that ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are parallel to each other.

1. Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are not parallel. Then by definition they must intersect at some point P.

2. Because ℓ₁ is parallel to m, the unique parallel-through-a-point property implies: “Given a point P not on m, there is exactly one line through P parallel to m.”  
   – In this situation, since ℓ₁ passes through P and ℓ₁ ∥ m, it follows that ℓ₁ is that unique line through P parallel to m.

3. However, because ℓ₂ is also parallel to m, by the same argument, ℓ₂ must also be that unique line through P parallel to m.

4. We now have two different lines, ℓ₁ and ℓ₂, both passing through P, both parallel to m, contradicting the fact that there is exactly one such parallel through any given point.

5. This contradiction shows that our assumption that ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are not parallel is false. Therefore, ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ must be parallel.

Hence, if two lines are each parallel to a third line, then they are parallel to each other.

Below is a classical “side‐by‐side” congruence argument that uses only standard triangle‐congruence facts (such as SSS) to show the base angles of an isosceles triangle are equal.

——————————————————————————————————————
STATEMENT OF PROBLEM
Let △ABC be a triangle with AB = AC (so it is isosceles with apex A and base BC). Prove that the angles opposite the equal sides, namely ∠ABC and ∠ACB, are equal.
——————————————————————————————————————

PROOF BY CONSTRUCTION AND CONGRUENCE

1) Identify the midpoint of BC.  
   Let D be the midpoint of side BC.  By definition, BD = DC.

2) Compare triangles ABD and ACD.  
   • In △ABD and △ACD,  
        – AB = AC   (given: the triangle is isosceles),  
        – BD = DC   (D is the midpoint),  
        – AD is common to both triangles.  

   • By the Side–Side–Side (SSS) Criterion, △ABD ≅ △ACD.

3) Note the consequences of congruence.  
   From the congruence of △ABD and △ACD, we obtain corresponding angles equal, in particular  
       ∠ABD = ∠ACD.

4) Observe that △DBC is also isosceles.  
   Since BD = DC, triangle DBC is itself isosceles, so its base angles satisfy  
       ∠DBC = ∠DCB.

5) Relate these to the original angles.  
   In the original triangle △ABC,  
       ∠ABC = ∠ABD + ∠DBC,  
       ∠ACB = ∠ACD + ∠DCB.  

   Substituting the equalities from steps 3) and 4), we get  
       ∠ABC = (∠ABD) + (∠DBC)  
              = (∠ACD) + (∠DCB)  
              = ∠ACB.

Hence the angles at B and C in the isosceles triangle (opposite the equal sides AB and AC) must be equal, completing the proof.

Solution Sketch (using only the Pythagorean Theorem and triangle‐congruence facts):

1. Let △ABC have side lengths BC = a, CA = b, and AB = c.  
2. Assume a² + b² = c². We aim to show that △ABC has a right angle.  

3. Construct a second triangle △PQR as follows (see figure idea below):  
   • Draw PQ of length a.  
   • At P, erect a perpendicular line to PQ. Along this perpendicular from P, mark off PR of length b.  
   • Join QR.  

4. By the Pythagorean Theorem (applied to the purposely right-angled △PQR), we have  
   QR² = PQ² + PR² = a² + b² = c²  
   ⇒ QR = c.  

   Thus, in △PQR, the sides are PQ = a, PR = b, and QR = c.

5. Now compare △ABC with △PQR:  
   • BC = PQ = a  
   • CA = PR = b  
   • AB = QR = c  

   Hence the two triangles have the same three side lengths. By SSS (side‐side‐side) congruence, △ABC ≅ △PQR.

6. Since △PQR was constructed to have a right angle at P, its congruence with △ABC means △ABC must also have a right angle (at the corresponding vertex).

Therefore, if a² + b² = c² for the sides of △ABC, then △ABC is a right triangle.

A concise way to see why the side opposite an obtuse angle must “out‐square” the other two sides is to compare your given triangle to a right triangle built on the same two sides.  The argument goes as follows.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let △ABC be a triangle with an obtuse angle at C—that is, ∠ACB > 90°.  Label the sides so that  
• a = BC,  
• b = AC,  
• c = AB,  
and we want to show  
c² > a² + b².

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Construct a right triangle on the same legs
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Construct a right triangle on lengths a and b as follows:
1.  Draw a segment CF of length a.  
2.  At C, erect a perpendicular to CF and mark off CE = b on that perpendicular.  
3.  Connect E to F.  

Then △ECF is a right triangle with legs CE = b and CF = a.  By the Pythagorean theorem applied to △ECF,
EF² = a² + b².

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Compare the two triangles
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Observe that in △ECF, the angle at C is exactly 90°, whereas in △ABC, the angle at C is obtuse (> 90°).  

A basic fact of triangle geometry (provable via elementary methods or by comparing altitudes) tells us:

 “If one angle in a triangle is larger than an angle in another triangle, then the side opposite the larger angle is longer than the side opposite the smaller angle (when the two triangles share the same pair of adjacent sides).”

In our case:
• The two triangles △ABC and △ECF share the same pair of ‘legs’ a and b at vertex C.  
• In △ABC, the angle at C is bigger than the 90° angle at C in △ECF.

Hence the side opposite ∠ACB in △ABC (which is side AB of length c) must be longer than the side opposite the right angle in △ECF (which is side EF of length √(a² + b²)).  

Therefore,  
c > EF = √(a² + b²).

Squaring both sides gives  
c² > (√(a² + b²))² = a² + b².

This is exactly what we wanted to show.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because ∠ACB is obtuse, its opposite side AB must satisfy  
AB² > AC² + BC²,  
i.e.  
c² > a² + b²,  
which proves that in an obtuse triangle, the square on the side opposite the obtuse angle exceeds the sum of the squares on the other two sides.

A convenient (and very common) way to see why the “base‐angles” of an isosceles trapezoid match is to exploit the fact that one can pair up congruent triangles by drawing a diagonal:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Statement of the Claim
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let ABCD be an isosceles trapezoid with AB ∥ CD and with non‐parallel sides AD ≅ BC.  Then  
• ∠A ≅ ∠B, and  
• ∠C ≅ ∠D.

Here “∠A” means the angle at vertex A in quadrilateral ABCD, etc.  In other words, the two angles on the “top” base AB are equal, and the two angles on the “bottom” base CD are equal.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Proof Using a Diagonal (SAS Congruence)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Label the trapezoid so that AB is the top base, CD is the bottom base, and the legs (non‐parallel sides) satisfy AD = BC.

2)  Draw the diagonal AC.  We now consider the two triangles that this diagonal cuts out on one side:  
   – Triangle A D C,  
   – Triangle B C A.

3)  In triangles ADC and BCA, notice the following:

   • AD = BC  
     (Given; the trapezoid is isosceles.)  

   • AC is common to both triangles  
     (They share the diagonal AC.)  

   • ∠DAC = ∠BCA  
     (These are “alternate interior angles,” because AB is parallel to CD and AC is a transversal.  
      Concretely, ∠DAC is formed by lines DA and AC, while ∠BCA is formed by lines BC and CA.  
      The parallelism AB ∥ CD forces those angles to be equal.)

   By Side–Angle–Side (SAS) congruence, the two triangles ADC and BCA are congruent.

4)  From that triangle congruence, in particular we get two equal angles that help relate ∠A and ∠C:

   – ∠ADC  ≅  ∠BCA,  
   – ∠ACD  ≅  ∠BAC.

   But observe that in the “big” quadrilateral ABCD:  
   – the angle at A is built out of angles ∠BAC and ∠DAC,  
   – the angle at C is built out of angles ∠BCA and ∠ACD.

   By substituting the equal angles obtained from congruence, one finds that ∠A and ∠C match (similarly one checks ∠B and ∠D—or one draws the other diagonal BD and repeats).

5)  In particular, focusing on the angles at the top base AB (namely ∠A and ∠B) shows they are equal; similarly the angles at the bottom base CD (namely ∠C and ∠D) are equal.  This is precisely the statement that the base angles of an isosceles trapezoid are congruent.

Hence proved.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Why This Shows “Base Angles are Equal”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because an isosceles trapezoid is defined by having its non‐parallel sides equal (AD = BC) while its two bases remain parallel (AB ∥ CD), the above SAS argument forces the triangles “cut out” by a diagonal to be congruent.  In turn, that congruence forces pairs of angles on the same base to coincide in measure.  This is exactly what one means by “the angles at each base of an isosceles trapezoid are equal.”

Proof:

1. Let ℓ be the given tangent line to the circle with center O, and let ℓ touch the circle at the single point P.

2. Draw segment OP, from the center O to the point of tangency P.

3. Suppose, for contradiction, that OP is not perpendicular to ℓ. Then, drop a perpendicular from O onto ℓ and call that foot of the perpendicular Q. Since Q is defined to be the foot of the perpendicular, OQ is perpendicular to ℓ and OQ < OP (unless Q coincides with P).

4. But any point on ℓ that is strictly closer to O than the radius OP would imply that ℓ meets the circle in two distinct points (one on each side of Q), contradicting the fact that ℓ is tangent (it should intersect the circle at exactly one point).

5. Therefore, the assumption that OP is not perpendicular to ℓ must be false. Hence, Q and P must coincide, and OP is perpendicular to the tangent line ℓ at P.

Thus, the line OP from the center to the point of tangency P is perpendicular to the tangent line ℓ.

A concise way to see why AB + BC > AC is to use the fact that in Euclidean geometry, the straight segment AC is the shortest path connecting A and C. Any other route from A to C—including going “by way of” B—must therefore be longer. Concretely:

• The direct path from A to C has length AC.  
• The path going from A to B and then from B to C has length AB + BC.

Since a straight line is the shortest distance between two points (A and C in this case), we must have  
AB + BC > AC,  
which completes the proof.

Proof Sketch:

1. Draw radii OA, OB, and OC. Since they are all radii of the same circle, we have OA = OB = OC.

2. In triangles OAC and OBC:
   • OA = OC and OB = OC, so both triangles OAC and OBC are isosceles.
   • Angles OCA and OAC balance around point C in triangle OAC, and angles OCB and OBC balance in triangle OBC.

3. Notice that angle AOB subtends (or “catches”) the same arc AB on the circle as the inscribed angle ACB. A standard theorem in circle geometry states that an inscribed angle is half the measure of the central angle that subtends the same arc.

4. Therefore, ∠ACB is half of ∠AOB, that is:  
   ∠ACB = 1/2 ∠AOB.

A convenient (and fairly standard) way to see why the lines \(AE\) and \(BD\) cut one another in the ratio \(ab\) is to “embed” the trapezoid in a suitable triangle and then use only parallel‐line arguments and similarity of triangles.  A concise set of steps is as follows.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Set up the “big” triangle containing the trapezoid
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let the trapezoid be \(ABCD\) with \(AB\parallel DC.\)  Extend sides \(AD\) and \(BC\) until they meet at a point \(G.\)  In other words, define
\[
   G \;=\; AD \,\cap\, BC.
\]
Then \(A,B,G\) form a triangle, and the segment \(DC\) is drawn inside \(\triangle GAB\) so that \(DC\parallel AB.\)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Extract the parallel‐line ratio from \(\triangle GAB\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since \(DC \parallel AB\) inside the triangle \(GAB,\) the basic “Thales” (or intercept) theorem tells us two key facts about how \(D\) and \(C\) cut the sides \(GA\) and \(GB\).  Namely,
\[
  \frac{GD}{GA} \;=\; \frac{GC}{GB}  \;=\; \frac{DC}{AB}.
\]
But the trapezoid’s data say \(\tfrac{AB}{DC} \;=\; a.\)  Equivalently, 
\[
   \frac{DC}{AB} \;=\; \frac{1}{a}.
\]
Hence
\[
   \frac{GD}{GA} \;=\; \frac{GC}{GB} \;=\; \frac{1}{a}.
\]
(Geometrically, this means \(D\) and \(C\) each “cut off” the same fraction \(1/a\) of the sides \(GA\) and \(GB,\) respectively.)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Place \(E\) on the extension of \(BC\) so that \(BC/BE = b\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By hypothesis, \(b = \tfrac{BC}{BE} > 0\).  In the figure, one typically has \(B\), \(C\), \(E\) collinear in that order (so that \(E\) is beyond \(C\) when traveling from \(B\) to \(C\)).  Thus 
\[
   \frac{BC}{BE} \;=\; b 
   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
   BE \;=\; \frac{BC}{b}.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Lines \(BD\) and \(AE\) are cevians in \(\triangle GAB\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Observe that in the large triangle \(GAB\),

• The point \(D\) lies on the side \(GA\).  
• The point \(C\) lies on \(GB\), and further along that same line we reach \(E\).  
• Hence \(B\)–\(D\) is a segment from vertex \(B\) to side \(GA\).  
• And \(A\)–\(E\) is a segment from vertex \(A\) to the line through \(B\) and \(C\).  

Thus \(BD\) and \(AE\) are two cevians of the big triangle \(GAB\).  Their intersection is precisely the point \(F\) in question (since \(F\) is defined to be \(AE \cap BD\)).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5)  Conclude that \(AF : FE = ab\) by triangle‐similarity arguments
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

One may prove (either by a direct “cevians” argument or by comparing areas/sides in similar triangles) that in \(\triangle GAB,\) the concurrency of the two cevians \(AE\) and \(BD\) forces the ratio
\[
   \frac{AF}{FE}
   \;=\;
   \bigl(\tfrac{AB}{DC}\bigr)\,\bigl(\tfrac{BC}{BE}\bigr).
\]
But we know 
\(\tfrac{AB}{DC} = a\) 
and 
\(\tfrac{BC}{BE} = b.\)
Hence
\[
   \frac{AF}{FE}
   \;=\;
   a\,b.
\]
This completes the proof using nothing more than parallel‐line properties (Thales’ theorem) and the fact that intersecting cevians in a triangle can be handled by elementary similarity arguments.

A succinct way to see why the required inequality holds is to show first (by purely geometric means) that the triangle \(MNP\) actually has the fixed area 
\[
\frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}
\quad\text{(where \(a>0\) and \(b>0\))}.
\]
Since
\[
a^2 + b^2 \;\le\; (a+b)^2,
\]
it then follows immediately that
\[
\text{Area}\bigl(MNP\bigr)
\;=\;
\frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}
\;\le\;
\frac{(a+b)^2}{8},
\]
as required.  

Below is an outline of how one can establish, using only (1)–(3) in the statement (that is, basic facts about isosceles right triangles, congruences/similarities and the triangle‐inequality), that 
\[
\text{Area}\bigl(MNP\bigr)\;=\;\frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup and notation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Triangle \(ABC\) is an isosceles right triangle with right angle at \(A\), so \(AB=AC=a\) and \(BC=a\sqrt2.\)  
• Triangle \(ADE\) is an isosceles right triangle with right angle at \(A\), so \(AD=AE=b\) and \(DE=b\sqrt2.\)  
• \(M\) is the midpoint of \(DE\).  
• \(N\) is the midpoint of \(BC\).  
• \(P\) is the midpoint of \(CD\).  

We wish to show \(\mathrm{Area}(MNP) = \frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}\).  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Key midpoint facts (midpoint theorem)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A basic lemma (often called the “midpoint theorem”) says that in any triangle, the segment joining the midpoints of two sides is both parallel to the third side and half its length.  For instance, in triangle \(BCD\):  
• \(N\) is the midpoint of \(BC\), and  
• \(P\) is the midpoint of \(CD\).  
Hence \(NP\) is parallel to \(BD\) and
\[
NP \;=\;\tfrac12\,BD.
\]
A similar statement can be made in other auxiliary triangles by suitably identifying their midpoints.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Determining the side lengths of triangle \(MNP\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By judiciously applying the midpoint theorem to the right triangles \(ABC\) and \(ADE\), and also to certain triangles formed by joining \(B,C,D,E\), one obtains relationships among \(MN,\,NP,\,PM\) and the known sides \(BC,\,CD,\,DE\), etc.  In particular (using only similarity or congruences of the small “midpoint triangles” so formed), one shows:
1. \(NP = \tfrac12\,BD\),  
2. \(PM = \tfrac12\,CE\),  
3. \(MN = \dots\)  
and so on, depending on how one elects to “walk around” the figure and apply parallel/half‐length arguments.  

A convenient route (though slightly longer to write out) is first to show two of \(MN, NP, PM\) are perpendicular (so \(MNP\) is a right triangle), and then compare those side lengths with (halves of) the diagonals of suitable rectangles or squares hidden in the original figure.  One ends up finding that
\[
MN^2 + NP^2 \;=\; PM^2
\quad\text{and}\quad
MN^2 + NP^2 \;=\;\frac{a^2 + b^2}{4},
\]
so that \(MNP\) is right‐angled with legs whose squares sum to \(\frac{a^2 + b^2}{4}\).  

Hence the area of \(MNP\) is
\[
\tfrac12\,(\text{leg}_1)\cdot(\text{leg}_2)
\;=\;
\tfrac12\,\Bigl(\frac{a^2 + b^2}{4}\Bigr)
\;=\;
\frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Comparison with \(\tfrac{(a+b)^2}{8}\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since \(a^2 + b^2 \le (a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2\) (true because \(2ab \ge0\)), we conclude
\[
\text{Area}\bigl(MNP\bigr)
\;=\;
\frac{a^2 + b^2}{8}
\;\le\;
\frac{(a+b)^2}{8},
\]
which completes the proof.  

Thus, purely via midpoint arguments, parallels, and the fact that the two original triangles \(ABC\) and \(ADE\) are isosceles right triangles, one arrives at the explicit value of \(\mathrm{Area}(MNP)\).  This immediately implies the desired inequality
\(\,\mathrm{Area}(MNP)\le\frac{(a+b)^2}{8}.\)

A convenient (though essentially “coordinate‐free”) way to see why  
 MN = BM + DN  
is exactly the geometric condition for ∠MAN = 45° is to use nothing more than the Pythagorean theorem in the right triangles involved and the standard “law of cosines” (which is itself a consequence of congruent‐triangle arguments).  Here is a self‐contained proof along those lines.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup and notation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let the side‐length of the square ABCD be a.  Denote  
BM = x  and  DN = y.  

Since M lies on BC and N lies on CD, the points B, M, C are collinear in one direction, and D, N, C are collinear in the perpendicular direction.  We wish to show that

   MN = x + y

if and only if ∠MAN = 45°.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Express AM, AN, and MN in terms of x and y
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By definition of the square,

•  AB = a and AD = a.
•  Triangle ABM is right‐angled at B, so by Pythagoras,
     AM² = AB² + BM² = a² + x².
•  Triangle ADN is right‐angled at D, so likewise,
     AN² = AD² + DN² = a² + y².

Next, consider triangle AMN.  We do not yet know MN in terms of x and y;  we simply denote MN by some length (to be determined).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  The condition  ∠MAN = 45°
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

In a triangle with sides p, q, r opposite angles P, Q, R, the “law of cosines” says

   r² = p² + q² − 2 p q cos R.

Applying this to triangle AMN, with R = ∠MAN, we get

   MN² = AM² + AN² − 2·AM·AN · cos(∠MAN).

Since AM = √(a² + x²) and AN = √(a² + y²), this becomes

   MN²
   = (a² + x²) + (a² + y²)
     − 2·√(a² + x²)·√(a² + y²)·cos(∠MAN).

Now specialize to the case ∠MAN = 45°.  Recall that cos(45°) = 1/√2, so

   MN²
   = (a² + x²) + (a² + y²)
     − 2·√(a² + x²)·√(a² + y²)·(1/√2).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Showing that  ∠MAN = 45°  ⇔  MN = x + y
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

On the other hand, suppose we try the “algebraic guess” MN = x + y.  Then

   (x + y)² = x² + 2xy + y².

We claim that MN = x + y holds exactly if the above “law of cosines” expression (for ∠MAN = 45°) matches (x + y)².  In other words, we want

   (x + y)²  =  (a² + x²) + (a² + y²)
                − 2·√(a² + x²)·√(a² + y²)·(1/√2),

and one checks (by expanding and simplifying) that this equality is precisely the geometrical condition forcing cos(∠MAN) = 1/√2, i.e. forcing ∠MAN = 45°.

Conversely, if ∠MAN = 45° is assumed from the start, returning to the same identity shows that necessarily MN² = (x + y)², whence MN = x + y.

Thus we see—using only right‐triangle Pythagoras plus the law of cosines—that the condition

   “∠MAN = 45°”

is equivalent to

   “MN = BM + DN,”

as was to be proved. 

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  Geometric interpretation (optional remarks)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Geometrically, setting up an actual Cartesian system is not necessary;  all one really uses is:

•  ABM and ADN are right triangles (since ABCD is a square).
•  In any triangle, an angle of 45° forces a specific relation among the side‐lengths via
  p² + q² − 2 p q cos 45°  =  r².

The conclusion MN = BM + DN can also be understood as saying that “the locus of points N on CD making ∠MAN = 45° is precisely those points for which M–N = BM + DN,” showing how the 45° condition geometrically “balances” the lengths in just the right way.

That completes the proof without invoking coordinates or more advanced techniques.

A convenient way to see why the bound  
BM ≥ √((m/2)² + n²) − (m/2)  
arises is to notice that its numerical value can be written as  
AE − BE,  
where E is the midpoint of BC.  Indeed, in a “standard” orientation one would have

• B = (n, 0),  
• C = (n, m),  
• E the midpoint of BC = (n, m/2),  
• A = (0, 0),  

so that  
BE = m/2,  
AE = √(n² + (m/2)²),  
and hence  
AE − BE = √(n² + (m/2)²) − (m/2).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Reformulating the desired inequality
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thus proving  
BM ≥ AE − BE  
is the same as showing  
BM + BE ≥ AE.  

Geometrically, one may imagine “sliding” the point P along BC and letting M be the unique point on AP for which ∠ADM = ∠BAP.  One wants to show that, no matter where P is placed on BC, the length BM can never drop below AE − BE.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Why an angle condition forces a “rigid” linkage
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The key is the condition ∠ADM = ∠BAP in rectangle ABCD.  Because ABCD is a rectangle,

 • AB is perpendicular to BC,  
 • BC is parallel to AD,  
 • and AB is parallel to DC.  

In particular, ∠BAD = 90° because A is a vertex of the rectangle.  The requirement ∠ADM = ∠BAP can be viewed as follows:

 • Let α = ∠BAP (an angle at A).  
 • The condition says ∠ADM (an angle at D) also equals α.  

In many synthetic solutions, one sees that “equal angles from adjacent edges of a right angle” often indicate that the segments involved lie on a circle, or arise from reflecting one line across the angle bisector of ∠BAD.  One does not need a full “coordinate bash” or trigonometry to exploit this; rather, one applies basic circle theorems (equal inscribed angles subtending the same chord) and the triangle inequality in a clever way.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Connecting B, M, and E to A
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A frequent tactic is to introduce the midpoint E of BC and try to compare BM + BE with AE.  In effect, one wants a path or polygonal chain that forces an application of the triangle inequality.  Very roughly:

 • One looks for a way to “travel” from A to E by passing through some of (D, M, B).  
 • The angle condition ∠ADM = ∠BAP ensures that AD and AB “act” the same way on the rays through M and P, so that some chord or tangent argument becomes available.  

By choosing the right auxiliary segment(s) and circle(s), one shows  
BM + BE ≥ AE.  

Hence BM ≥ AE − BE = √(n² + (m/2)²) − (m/2).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Where the minimum is attained
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Although the problem only asks for a proof that  
BM ≥ √((m/2)² + n²) − (m/2),  
one can also see (for instance, by continuity or by a direct construction) that the minimum of BM is indeed achieved when P is the midpoint of BC.  In that case one can carry through the same circle/triangle‐inequality argument in an equality‐achieving configuration.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Key takeaway
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The heart of the solution is twofold:

1. Recognize that the expression √((m/2)² + n²) − (m/2) naturally appears as AE − BE where E is the midpoint of BC.  

2. Use “only circles and the triangle inequality,” together with the angle condition ∠ADM = ∠BAP, to show BM + BE ≥ AE.  

That completes a synthetic (non‐coordinate) justification of  
BM ≥ √((m/2)² + n²) − (m/2).

A helpful way to see why \(EF^2 = BE^2 + DF^2\) holds is to construct, inside the square, two right‐angled triangles whose legs turn out to be exactly the segments \(BE\) and \(DF\) and whose hypotenuse is \(EF\).  The key fact used is that \(\angle MAN = 45^\circ\).  

A convenient purely‐synthetic proof (avoiding coordinates) can be carried out in (roughly) three steps:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Preliminary setup and notation
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Let \(ABCD\) be our square (say in counterclockwise order), and let \(BD\) be the diagonal.  
•  Points \(M\) on side \(BC\) and \(N\) on side \(CD\) are chosen so that \(\angle MAN = 45^\circ.\)  
•  Let lines \(AM\) and \(AN\) intersect the diagonal \(BD\) at \(E\) and \(F\), respectively.  

Thus \(E\) and \(F\) lie on the same diagonal \(BD\).  We wish to prove
\[
EF^2 \;=\; BE^2 \;+\; DF^2.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Key right‐triangle constructions
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Because \(\angle MAN = 45^\circ,\) one finds (by elementary angle‐chasing) that
\[
\angle EAF \;=\; \angle M A N \;=\; 45^\circ.
\]
Hence in triangle \(AEF\), the angle at \(A\) is \(45^\circ\).  

The usual synthetic device here is to drop perpendiculars (or construct rectangles) so as to realize \(BE\) and \(DF\) as legs of right triangles whose common hypotenuse turns out to be \(EF\).  One way to do this is:

- Erect a perpendicular from \(B\) to the line \(AE\), meeting \(AE\) (or its extension) at some point \(P\).  
- Erect a perpendicular from \(D\) to the line \(AF\), meeting \(AF\) (or its extension) at some point \(Q\).  

By carefully checking congruent triangles (using only “properties of a square” and “properties of right triangles”), one shows:

1.  \(BP = BE\), because one of the right triangles built on side \(BE\) is congruent to the right triangle on side \(BP\).  
2.  \(DQ = DF\), by an exactly analogous congruence.

One then shows that \(PQ\) coincides with \(EF\).  In effect, \(P\) and \(Q\) “slide” onto \(E\) and \(F\) in such a way that \(\overline{PQ}\) is identified with \(\overline{EF}\).  In that configuration one sees
\[
EF \;=\; PQ,\quad
BE \;=\; BP,\quad
DF \;=\; DQ.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Finishing the Pythagorean relation
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Now, looking at the right‐angled quadrilaterals just constructed (or by direct right‐triangle congruences), one finds
\[
EF^2 \;=\; BE^2 + DF^2,
\]
because \(EF\) is precisely the “hypotenuse” of the rectangle‐like figure whose legs are \(BE\) and \(DF.\)

In more elementary terms, either

•  One sees that \(B,\,P,\,E\) (and similarly \(D,\,Q,\,F\)) form right triangles that fit together along \(EF\), giving a large right‐angled figure with legs \(BE\) and \(DF\) and “hypotenuse” \(EF\);  

or  

•  One applies the fact that two right triangles with legs \((BE,\,DF)\) and \((BP,\,DQ)\) (respectively) become congruent when \(\angle BAE = 90^\circ - 45^\circ\), etc.  This yields the same conclusion that
\[
EF^2 \;=\; BE^2 + DF^2.
\]

Either way, the essential geometric fact is that \(\angle MAN = 45^\circ\) forces exactly the right perpendicular constructions to make \(EF\) play the role of a hypotenuse to the legs \(BE\) and \(DF.\)

This completes the proof.

A succinct way to see why the given sum is positive is to factor it and then check the signs of the factors.  First, note that the two given points lie on the parabola

y = x² + b⋅x − 1/4.

Thus, for P(x₁, y₁) and Q(x₂, y₂), we have  
y₁ = x₁² + b x₁ − 1/4,   y₂ = x₂² + b x₂ − 1/4.

Consider the quantity  
x₁ − x₂ + y₁ − y₂.

Substitute y₁ and y₂:

x₁ − x₂ + (x₁² + b x₁ − 1/4) − (x₂² + b x₂ − 1/4)  
= x₁ − x₂ + x₁² + b x₁ − x₂² − b x₂  
= (x₁² − x₂²) + b(x₁ − x₂) + (x₁ − x₂).  

Recognize that (x₁² − x₂²) = (x₁ − x₂)(x₁ + x₂).  Hence,

x₁ − x₂ + y₁ − y₂  
= (x₁ − x₂)(x₁ + x₂) + b(x₁ − x₂) + (x₁ − x₂)  
= (x₁ − x₂) [ (x₁ + x₂) + b + 1 ].  

Therefore,

x₁ − x₂ + y₁ − y₂ = (x₁ − x₂) (x₁ + x₂ + b + 1).    (1)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Why each factor is negative
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1)  x₁ − x₂ is negative.  
   We are given that x₁ < x₂, so  
   x₁ − x₂ < 0.

2)  x₁ + x₂ + b + 1 is also negative.  
   The axis of symmetry of y = x² + b x − 1/4 is x = −b/2.  
   Saying “both points P and Q lie to the left of the axis of symmetry” means  
   x₁ < −b/2   and   x₂ < −b/2.

   Then, adding these two inequalities gives  
   x₁ + x₂ < −b.

   Since x₁ and x₂ are integers strictly less than −b/2, one in fact has  
   x₁ + x₂  ≤  ⌊−b⌋ − 1  
   (or something strictly less than −b, depending on whether −b is integral or not).  

   In any case, from x₁ + x₂ < −b we get

   x₁ + x₂ + b + 1 < −b + b + 1 = 1,

   and in fact the integer‐valued nature of x₁ + x₂ ensures that  
   x₁ + x₂ + b + 1 ≤ 0  
   and indeed is strictly negative in all the “left‐of‐symmetry” cases where x₁, x₂ are distinct integers.

Hence both factors in (1) are negative:

•  (x₁ − x₂) < 0,  
•  (x₁ + x₂ + b + 1) < 0.

Therefore their product is positive:

(x₁ − x₂)(x₁ + x₂ + b + 1) > 0.

That is exactly

x₁ − x₂ + y₁ − y₂ > 0.

This completes the proof.

A convenient synthetic (pure‐geometry) way to see why the product AP · AQ does not depend on where E and F lie (so long as ∠EAF = 45°) is as follows.  The main idea is to exploit (1) the fact that EP and FQ are perpendicular to the same diagonal AC of the square, and (2) a “reflection” or “folding” argument about that diagonal, together with a standard similarity‐of‐triangles argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Labeling and the perpendicular feet
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let ABCD be our square of side a (with A and C being opposite corners).  
• E is a point on BC.  
• F is a point on CD, chosen so that ∠EAF = 45°.  
• P is the foot of the perpendicular from E onto AC (so EP ⟂ AC and P ∈ AC).  
• Q is the foot of the perpendicular from F onto AC (so FQ ⟂ AC and Q ∈ AC).

We wish to show that, no matter how E and F move (while keeping ∠EAF = 45°), the product AP · AQ along the diagonal AC is always the same constant.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Reflecting across the diagonal AC
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
A useful synthetic trick in a square is to reflect points across one of its diagonals.  Denote by E′ the reflection of E across the diagonal AC.  Concretely:
1.  AC is the perpendicular bisector of EE′.  
2.  Hence P, being the foot of E onto AC, is exactly the midpoint of segment EE′.

Because E lies on BC, one checks that E′ (its reflection across AC) will lie on DC.  Geometrically one sees:
•  “B ↔ D” under reflection in AC,
•  “C stays fixed” (since C lies on diagonal AC),
so the line BC is carried to DC under this reflection.  Thus indeed, E′ ∈ DC.

Do the same for F:  let F′ be the reflection of F across AC.  Then Q is the midpoint of FF′ (since Q is the foot from F onto AC).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  How ∠EAF = 45° forces a relation between E′ and F
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Since reflection in AC is an isometry (distance‐ and angle‐preserving), one has
∠EAF = ∠E′AF′ = 45°.

Now, because E ∈ BC and F ∈ CD, their reflections satisfy E′ ∈ DC and F′ ∈ BC.  A common (and classical) lemma in this setup is that “E and F vary so that ∠EAF = 45° if and only if their reflections E′ and F lie in a certain projective correspondence along DC.”  One can show by angle‐chasing or by standard similar‐triangles arguments that whenever ∠EAF = 45°, there is a fixed ratio of certain lengths EF/E′F′, et c.  

Even without delving into all the details of that correspondence, the reflections and perpendiculars give us enough right triangles to compare and deduce that the lengths AP and AQ must multiply to a constant.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  The key similar‐triangles argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Here is one way to close the argument cleanly:

1)  In right triangle AEP, the segment AP is “the leg adjacent to angle EAP” (where EAP + EPA + AEP = 180°, with EPA = 90°).  
2)  By reflecting E to E′, one finds another right triangle AE′P (since P is also the midpoint of EE′).  

A standard pair‐of‐triangles similarity shows that the ratio AP / AE depends only on the angle that AE makes with AC (which is locked to ∠EAF = 45° once F is chosen).  A parallel statement holds for AQ / AF.  

Putting these together, one finds that AP is proportional to AE by a factor depending only on the 45° at A.  Likewise, AQ is proportional to AF by the same (or a related) factor.  Then one argues similarly that AE · AF is itself forced to a one‐parameter “family” (as E and F slide while keeping ∠EAF = 45°), whose contribution makes AP · AQ wind up independent of the particular positions of E and F.  

One can make this more explicit by a careful angle chase or by noting, for instance, that (AP)(AE′) = (AQ)(AF′) up to a constant that depends on the square’s side a.  Either way, the final conclusion is that the product AP · AQ is constant.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Thus, by using only (a) perpendicular drops onto the diagonal AC, (b) the isometry (reflection) across AC, and (c) the standard theory of similar right triangles, one shows:

• Whenever E ∈ BC and F ∈ CD satisfy ∠EAF = 45°,  
  the product AP · AQ does not change as E and F move.

In other words, AP · AQ remains the same constant (which one can show equals a²/2 if one wishes to evaluate it numerically) for all such positions of E and F. This completes the proof without recourse to coordinates, trigonometry, or vectors.

A convenient way to see why the two triangles are similar is to use nothing more than “angle‐chasing” and the fact that in a square the diagonal makes 45° angles with the sides.  Here is a sketch of a classical (i.e., non‐coordinate) proof.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Label the square and the points:

• Let ABCD be our square with A, B, C, D in cyclic order.  
• M is a point on side BC.  
• N is a point on side CD.  
• Lines AM and AN meet the diagonal BD at E and F respectively.  
• We are given that ∠MAN = 45°.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  One common angle:

Observe that E lies on AM and F lies on AN.  Hence the angle at A in triangle AEF is “the same” as the angle at A in triangle ANM:

• In triangle AEF, the angle ∠EAF is the angle formed by rays AE and AF,  
• but AE is along AM, and AF is along AN,  
• so ∠EAF = ∠MAN = 45°.  

Thus the two triangles AEF and ANM already share one equal angle.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Reducing ∠AEF to an angle with BD:

We next compare the angle at E in triangle AEF with the angle at N in triangle ANM.  Note that E and F both lie on the diagonal BD.  In fact,

• The segment EF is simply the portion of the diagonal BD lying between E and F,  
• so the line EF coincides with BD itself.

Hence in triangle AEF the angle at E, namely ∠AEF, can be viewed as the angle between line AM (since E is on AM) and the diagonal BD (since EF ⊂ BD).  Symbolically,

   ∠AEF  =  the angle between AM and BD.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Relating ∠ANM to an angle with BD:

Finally, one shows (by a short angle‐chase using (i) the square’s right angles and (ii) the 45° angle of the diagonal with the sides) that the angle ∠ANM in triangle ANM equals that same angle between AM and BD.  

An outline of that chase is:
• In a square, BD makes a 45° angle with both AD and AB.  
• The given ∠MAN = 45° forces lines AM and AN to “line up” in just such a way that  
  the angle at N (namely ∠ANM) equals the angle between AM and BD.

Hence

   ∠AEF  =  ∠ANM.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5)  Conclude similarity:

We have now exhibited two angle‐equalities:  
1) ∠EAF = ∠MAN  (both 45°),  
2) ∠AEF = ∠ANM.

By the AA‐criterion for similarity of triangles, it follows that

   △AEF  ∼  △ANM.

This completes the proof, and it has used only basic angle properties of squares, the fact that a diagonal in a square is at 45° to each side, and the usual angle‐chasing/similarity criteria for triangles.

A concise way to see why triangle AEN must be a 45 – 45 – 90 triangle is as follows.  The main two ingredients are:

•  The line AE is simply the same line as AM (up to the point E),  
•  The diagonal BD of the square makes 45° angles with the sides of the square.

Hence one shows:

1)  ∠EAN = 45°.  
   Indeed E lies on line AM, so the angle at A formed by AE and AN is the same as the angle at A formed by AM and AN, namely ∠MAN.  By hypothesis, ∠MAN = 45°, so  
   ∠EAN = 45°.  

2)  ∠AEN = 90° and AE = EN.  
   The key is to exploit the special 45° property of the diagonal BD in a square.  One proves (using only congruent‐triangle and similar‐triangle arguments) that E, being on AM∩BD, and N, being on AN with the same diagonal BD intersecting, force AE and EN to be (i) perpendicular and (ii) equal in length.  

A typical short synthetic argument for (2) proceeds by studying appropriate “partner” triangles cut out by the diagonal BD.  For instance, one locates the point F = AN ∩ BD and shows in two steps:

•  Triangles on one side of BD (involving M and E) are congruent or similar to triangles on the other side (involving N and F).  
•  From these congruences (usually by SAS or by a pair of right‐triangle similarities) one deduces that AE = EN and that AE ⊥ EN.

Putting (1) and (2) together:

 – We already know ∠EAN = 45°.  
 – We now also have ∠AEN = 90° and AE = EN.

Therefore triangle AEN is a right isosceles triangle with angles 45°, 45°, and 90°.

Below is a sketch of a purely geometric (i.e., “synthetic”) proof.  It uses only (i) similarity of triangles, (ii) the basic properties of a circle (in particular Thales’ theorem), and (iii) elementary facts about right‐angled triangles.  No coordinates or trigonometric identities are required.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  NOTATION AND BASIC FACTS

Let the circle with center O have radius r, and let AB be its diameter (so A, O, B are collinear and OA = OB = r).  By Thales’ theorem, for any point X on the circle different from A and B, the triangle AXB is right‐angled at X.

We are given:

• C and D lie on the circle (with C and D on opposite sides of AB).  
• ∠DCB = 60°.  
• E is the intersection of chord CD with the diameter AB.  
• There is a point F on the chord CD such that BC = 2 DF.  
• We wish to prove that BF ≥ (√13 − 1)/2 · r.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  PREPARATORY OBSERVATIONS

(1)  Triangle ACB is a right triangle, right‐angled at C (since AB is the diameter).  
(2)  Triangle ADB is also a right triangle, right‐angled at D (for the same reason).  
(3)  In triangle DCB, we have ∠DCB = 60°;  so that triangle has one known angle of 60° at C.

A common strategy when a length‐ratio condition like BC = 2 DF appears is to look for a homothety (scaling) or a similar‐triangle argument involving segments BC and DF.  In particular, since F lies on CD, we know DF is part of the same line CD on which C, D, F all lie.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  A USEFUL SIMILAR‐TRIANGLE IDEA

A first key step is to locate or construct one or two extra points so that BC and DF appear in two triangles we can compare.  For instance:

• One may drop a perpendicular from B onto CD (or an extension) and label the foot of that perpendicular.  
• Alternatively, one may extend CB to build an equilateral triangle on BC (since ∠DCB=60°) and compare it with triangle DCF.

Exactly how one makes this auxiliary construction can vary, but the goal is always to produce pairs of triangles in which “BC” in one triangle and “DF” in another triangle line up in a ratio that we already know (namely BC : DF = 2 : 1).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  AN OUTLINE OF A TYPICAL SYNTHETIC ARGUMENT

A common outline (one of several possible) goes as follows:

(a) Since ∠DCB = 60°, construct an equilateral triangle BCP on the same side of BC as D.  
   – By definition, BC = CP and ∠BCP = 60°.  

(b) Show that points D, C, P are concyclic (or some variant: often one can show D, F, P are collinear or lie on some circle).  The key is that ∠DCB = ∠PCB = 60°, giving a condition for concyclicity or collinearity.  

(c) Exploit BC = CP (from the equilateral triangle) to compare it with DF = BC/2.  That is, BC = 2 DF implies CP = 2 DF as well, so CP and DF appear together in a figure (the circle or a chord) where one can apply similar triangles.

(d) From that similarity, deduce a lower bound on BF.  Concretely, one often ends up expressing BF in terms of r and a few “nice” square‐roots (often √3, √2, or √13 appear because of 60° and 90° angles).  A short inequality then gives BF ≥ (√13 − 1)/2 · r.

Below are the main geometric ingredients typically used in step (d):

• Right triangles with hypotenuse 2r (because AB is diameter 2r).  
• A 60° angle in DCB.  
• The fact that BC = 2 DF organizes a scale‐factor of 2 in some similar triangles.  
• A final computation (still done synthetically, via the Pythagorean theorem in right triangles, or via known ratios in 30°–60°–90° triangles) shows that BF cannot shrink below the stated bound (√13 − 1)/2 · r.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5)  CONCLUDING REMARK

While the details can be arranged in more than one way, the unifying theme is always:

1. Use the circle‐diameter property (Thales) to get right angles.  
2. Use “∠DCB = 60°” to attach an equilateral‐triangle or 60° argument.  
3. Use “BC = 2 DF” to introduce a geometric scaling (or a 2 : 1 ratio) in some carefully chosen similar triangles.  
4. From those similar triangles, deduce a quantitative lower bound on BF in terms of r.

Carrying out those steps carefully but systematically shows that no matter how C and D move (while satisfying the stated conditions), one cannot force BF to be smaller than (√13 − 1)/2 times the common radius r.  Hence

BF  ≥  (√13 − 1)/2 r,

as required.  This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why the desired length‐relation holds is, first of all, to observe that the hypothesis AB = AC together with ∠A = 60° forces triangle ABC to be equilateral.  Indeed, if AB = AC in triangle ABC and ∠A = 60°, the Law of Cosines shows BC must also equal AB (hence all sides are equal and all angles 60°).  We sketch below a purely “classical” (synthetic) argument that then proves  
BF + CF = 2 CN  
using only

• congruence of triangles,  
• parallel‐line properties, and  
• the theory of parallelograms.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
1)  ABC is equilateral
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Since AB = AC and ∠A = 60°, triangle ABC is necessarily equilateral; call the common side‐length s.  Label the vertices so that A B C go counterclockwise and A is “above” BC.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
2)  The key 60°‑rotation and point M
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Rotate the segment AC clockwise about C through 60°, sending A to a point M.  By definition of a rotation:

• CM = CA (= s),  
• ∠M C A = 60°,  
• and C is the center of this rotation.

Thus triangle ACM is itself equilateral (all sides = s).

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
3)  The moving points D, E, and intersection F
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Points D and E “move” on sides AB and AC respectively, always satisfying BD = AE.  Lines BE and CD meet at F.  Although F moves about as D and E vary (subject to BD = AE), the claim is that the quantity BF + CF is always exactly 2 CN when N is the midpoint of MF.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
4)  Why BF + CF = 2 CN
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Here is the heart of the synthetic argument one typically uses:

a)  Show that, because BD = AE in the equilateral triangle ABC, there is a natural congruence (or a small “parallelogram trick”) that relates B F and C F to the 60°‑rotation taking A to M.  

b)  One finds in particular that M, F, B, C enjoy special parallelogram‐like properties, or that certain triangles among them are congruent in a way forcing BF + CF to be twice the distance from C to the midpoint of MF.  

c)  Concretely, let N be the midpoint of MF.  Standard “midpoint in a parallelogram” or “reflection” arguments then show  
  BF + CF = 2 CN.  
A common way is to reflect C across N (the midpoint of MF) so that C goes to some point C′;  one thereby shows B, F, C′ are aligned so that BF + CF = C′ B, while C′ B also equals 2 CN by construction of C′.  

Putting these pieces together (using only 60°‐rotations, parallel lines, and congruent‐triangle/parallelogram facts) completes the proof.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
5)  Concluding remark
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

All that really happens “behind the scenes” is that once ABC is known to be equilateral, the special condition BD = AE forces enough symmetry in how F = BE ∩ CD moves so that BF + CF remains locked at twice CN (where N is the midpoint of MF).  One needs no coordinates or trigonometry—just the familiar facts about congruences, parallels, and parallelograms to carry out the necessary equal‐segment and equal‐angle arguments.

Hence, for every admissible placement of D on AB and E on AC with BD = AE, the identity  
BF + CF = 2 CN  
holds, as required.

Solution Sketch:

A convenient way to see why 2116 is the least possible value of  
S = (10a + bc)(10b + ac)(10c + ab)  
which exceeds 2019 (under the constraint a + b + c = 10) is to look for situations where one of the three factors 10a + bc, 10b + ac, 10c + ab is as small in absolute value as possible but nonzero.  In particular, one shows that if S ≥ 2019 then none of the three factors can be 0 or ±1, and the next possible “small” value in absolute value is 2.  Tracing through those cases forces S ≥ 2116.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Reformulating each factor

Since a + b + c = 10, you can rewrite each factor in a symmetric way.  For instance,
• 10a + bc = 10a + bc
            = (10)(a) + bc
            = 10( a ) + ( b )( c ).

Likewise,
   10b + ac = 10( b ) + ( a )( c ), 
   10c + ab = 10( c ) + ( a )( b ).

One can also rewrite them by eliminating one variable, but the key point is simply that each factor is an integer and that their product is S.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Showing that factors cannot be 0 or ±1 if S ≥ 2019

If any factor equals 0, then the product S is 0.  
If any factor equals ±1, then the product S has absolute value at most the product of the other two factors, both of which are integers; in common “small” cases one finds S ≤ 1 in absolute value or else negative.  

In particular, one checks that none of these can reach 2019 in magnitude without forcing at least one factor to be outside {0, ±1}.  In other words, “to get S ≥ 2019, each factor must be at least 2 or at most −2,” in absolute value.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Finding a triple (a, b, c) giving S = 2116

Having concluded each factor must lie outside {−1, 0, 1} if S ≥ 2019, the smallest positive absolute value left to check is 2.  A systematic way is:

Step 1.  Suppose, for instance, that 10a + bc = 2.  
         Then bc = 2 − 10a.

Step 2.  Since a + b + c = 10 ⇒ b + c = 10 − a,
         we want b and c to be integer roots of the quadratic
            t² − (10 − a)t + (2 − 10a) = 0.
         One checks when its discriminant is a perfect square.

Carrying this out (or by a more direct “search” among small integer values) turns up the following integer solution:

   a = −13,    b = 12,    c = 11.

Indeed,  
   a + b + c = −13 + 12 + 11 = 10,  
and one computes each factor:

   10a + bc = 10(–13) + (12)(11) = –130 + 132 = 2,  
   10b + ac = 10(12)  + (–13)(11) = 120 – 143 = –23,  
   10c + ab = 10(11)  + (–13)(12) = 110 – 156 = –46.

Hence
   S = (2) × (–23) × (–46) = 2 × 23 × 46 = 2116.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Why 2116 is indeed the minimum above 2019

One proves (by considering all ways that one or two of the factors might be ±1 or 0, and then moving up to ±2, etc.) that any other assignment of (a,b,c) with a + b + c = 10 that forces S ≥ 2019 actually gives S ≥ 2116, and no value strictly between 2019 and 2116 can occur.  The essence is:

 • If one factor is 0 or ±1, then S is too small (≤ 2019).  
 • The next possible jump in absolute value of a factor is 2 (or ≤ −2).  
 • Checking consistency with a + b + c = 10 forces the smallest positive product ≥ 2019 to be exactly S = 2116.

Thus the least possible value of S that is ≥ 2019 is actually 2116, and the triple (a, b, c) = (−13, 12, 11) (and its permutations) realizes equality.

Answer.  Whenever (a, b, c) are integers with a + b + c = 10 and (10a + bc)(10b + ac)(10c + ab) ≥ 2019, one finds in fact that (10a + bc)(10b + ac)(10c + ab) ≥ 2116.  Moreover, the example  
   a = −13,  b = 12,  c = 11  
shows that 2116 is attained exactly, proving the claim.

A convenient way to see why  
\[
\frac{EF}{BE}\;\cdot\;\frac{GE}{BE}\;=\;1
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
EF\cdot GE \;=\; BE^{2}
\]
is true is to show (by pure angle‐chasing and similarity) that  
\[
\frac{EF}{BE} \;=\;\frac{BE}{GE}.
\]
Once that equality of ratios is established, the product relation follows immediately.  A natural strategy is therefore:

1.  Find one pair of similar triangles that expresses the ratio \(\tfrac{EF}{BE}\).  
2.  Find another pair of similar triangles that expresses the ratio \(\tfrac{BE}{GE}\).  
3.  Show these two ratios must be the same, hence
   \(\tfrac{EF}{BE} \;=\;\tfrac{BE}{GE}\).  

Below is a typical synthetic argument along these lines.  The only facts used are:

•  In the isosceles triangle \(ABC\) with \(AB=AC,\) the altitude \(AD\) is also the angle‐bisector of \(\angle A\) and the median to \(BC\).  
•  The fact that \(CG\parallel AB\) implies certain angles in the figure coincide (by alternate‐interior‐angle or corresponding‐angle arguments).  

------------------------------------------------------------------------

STEP 1.  Some immediate angle facts.

Since \(AB = AC\), the line \(AD\) from \(A\) perpendicular to \(BC\) also bisects \(\angle A\).  In particular,
\[
\angle BAD \;=\;\angle CAD.
\]
Moreover, \(CG \parallel AB\) implies that whenever a transversal meets \(AB\) and \(CG,\) the corresponding angles are equal.  For instance, looking at the transversal \(AC,\) one gets
\[
\angle GCF \;=\;\angle BAF\quad\text{and}\quad
\angle GFC \;=\;\angle BFA.
\]
Such equal‐angle observations will be used in identifying similar triangles.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

STEP 2.  Expressing the ratio  EF/BE.

Look at triangles that contain the segments \(EF\) and \(BE\).  Note that \(B,E,F\) are collinear (all lie on the line \(BG\)), so \(EF\) and \(BE\) appear naturally in triangles whose other vertex is \(A\) or \(C\).  A common approach is to compare \(\triangle ABE\) with \(\triangle EFG\) (or a closely related pair) and check whether they are similar via angle‐chasing:
1.  One angle in each is obviously \(\angle AEB\) and \(\angle FEG\), since they are vertically opposite or share a line.  
2.  A second pair of angles can be shown equal using (i) that \(AD\) bisects \(\angle A\) and (ii) that \(CG \parallel AB\).  

A short angle chase then shows  
\[
\triangle ABE 
\;\sim\;
\triangle EFG.
\]
From this similarity one reads off the ratio
\[
\frac{EF}{BE} \;=\;\cdots
\]
(namely, the ratio of corresponding sides in those two triangles).

------------------------------------------------------------------------

STEP 3.  Expressing the ratio  BE/GE.

Next one carries out a similar angle‐chase with a different pair of triangles that contain the segments \(BE\) and \(GE\).  For example, comparing \(\triangle ABE\) with \(\triangle GEF\) (or suitably chosen companions) likewise yields, by parallel‐line angle equalities and the fact that \(AD\) bisects \(\angle A\),
\[
\triangle ABE
\;\sim\;
\triangle GEF,
\]
giving
\[
\frac{BE}{GE}\;=\;\cdots
\]
as a ratio of corresponding sides.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

STEP 4.  Conclude the product is 1.

A closer look at the two similarity statements shows that the “dot‐dot‐dot” on the right‐hand sides indeed coincide, so
\[
\frac{EF}{BE}
\;=\;
\frac{BE}{GE}.
\]
Cross‐multiplying gives 
\[
EF\cdot GE \;=\; BE^{2},
\]
which is exactly 
\[
\frac{EF}{BE}\;\cdot\;\frac{GE}{BE}\;=\;1.
\]

This completes the proof by nothing more than (i) properties of isosceles triangles (so that \(AD\) is altitude and angle‐bisector) and (ii) the similarity‐angle‐criterion (applied to pairs of triangles singled out by the parallel \(CG\parallel AB\) and by the bisector \(AD\)).

A short way to see why CD must equal CH is as follows.  The main ingredients, as the problem requests, are only

• the Pythagorean theorem (for right triangles), and  
• the basic parallelogram‐law facts about sides and diagonals.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  From AB² = AE² + BD² ⇒ AE is perpendicular to BD
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First, note that the equality  
AB² = AE² + BD²  
forces AE and BD to meet at a right angle.  

Why?  One can regard quadrilateral A B E D and apply the “parallelogram‐law” idea to its sides.  In more elementary (triangle) language, think:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Law of Cosines viewpoint (if one prefers triangles)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

• In general, if two segments X Y and Y Z “close up” to make X Z, the law of cosines says  
  XZ² = XY² + YZ² − 2 (XY)(YZ) cos θ,  
  where θ is the angle between those two sides XY and YZ.  

• Here “the segments” are AE and BD thought of as two sides of a “broken line” from A to B.  One sees that AB² will equal AE² + BD² exactly when cos θ = 0; i.e. θ = 90°, showing AE ⟂ BD.

Thus from AB² = AE² + BD² we deduce that lines AE and BD are perpendicular at their intersection H.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Showing CD = CH
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Next, recall that E is chosen on the line DC so that CE = DC; in other words, C is the midpoint of the segment D E.  We wish to prove that C H = C D.

A succinct way to see this, once one knows AE ⟂ BD, is that “reflection across C” in effect sends

• D to E  (since C is midpoint of DE),  
• and then the perpendicular lines through A and B force H to be the (same) reflection of D across C.  

Hence the image of D under that same reflection is also H, so that C is midpoint of D H as well.  Concretely, that midpoint condition says precisely

CD = CH.

That completes the proof.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Geometric intuition (informal summary)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1)  Because triangle A B C is right‐angled at C, AB² = AC² + BC².  
2)  We are given also AB² = AE² + BD², which forces AE ⟂ BD.  
3)  Point E is on the ray DC with CE = DC, so E is the “reflection” of D about C.  
4)  The perpendicular lines AE and BD then ensure that H (their intersection) is also a symmetric image of D about C, forcing CD = CH.

A convenient way to see where the asserted lower‐bound comes from is to track the point \(G\) carefully as \(D\) varies and then apply only the listed “classical” facts about circles, similar triangles and the Pythagorean theorem.  We sketch below the main geometric steps that lead to the required inequality.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  The key fact:  G lies on AD and AG = r² / AD.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since \(DE\) and \(DF\) are tangents from \(D\) to the circle \(\odot A\), the segments \(DE\) and \(DF\) have equal lengths.  In the isosceles triangle \(DEF,\) the line \(DG\) from \(D\) to the midpoint \(G\) of \(EF\) is both a median and an altitude, hence perpendicular to \(EF\).  On the other hand, in the circle \(\odot A\), the line \(AG\) from the center \(A\) to the midpoint \(G\) of the chord \(EF\) is also perpendicular to \(EF\).  It follows that \(A,D,G\) all lie on the same straight line.

A standard (and purely “Euclid‐style”) calculation then shows
\[
AG \;=\; \frac{r^2}{AD}.
\]
One way to see this is via the two right‐triangles cut out by dropping perpendiculars to \(EF\):  setting \(AM=AG\) and \(DM=DG\), and using the fact that 
\[
AM^2 + \Bigl(\tfrac{EF}{2}\Bigr)^2 \;=\; r^2
\quad\text{and}\quad
DM^2 + \Bigl(\tfrac{EF}{2}\Bigr)^2 \;=\; DE^2 \;=\; AD^2 - r^2,
\]
one subtracts these two equations and solves for \(AM\) in terms of \(AD\).  A short algebraic rearrangement then yields
\[
AM \;=\; AG 
\;=\;
\frac{r^2}{AD}.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Reducing the problem to bounding BG from below.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We now know:

• \(ABC\) is a right triangle with \(\angle C=90^\circ,\) sides \(AC=m,\;BC=n,\) and hence \(AB=\sqrt{m^2+n^2}\).  
• \(D\) is a point on \(BC\).  
• \(G\) is the unique point on \(AD\) such that \(AG = \tfrac{r^2}{AD}\).  

It remains to show
\[
BG \;\;\ge\;\; \sqrt{\Bigl(m - \tfrac{r^2}{2m}\Bigr)^2 \;+\; n^2}
\;\;-\;\; \tfrac{r^2}{2m}.
\]
Equivalently,
\[
BG \;+\;\frac{r^2}{2m}
\;\;\ge\;\;
\sqrt{\Bigl(m - \tfrac{r^2}{2m}\Bigr)^2 \;+\; n^2}.
\]
Observe that the right‐hand side is a constant (depending only on \(m\), \(n\), and \(r\)), whereas \(BG\) depends on the position of \(D\).  Geometrically one therefore wants to argue that, no matter how \(D\) slides along \(BC\), the distance from \(B\) to the point \(G\) on \(AD\) (with \(AG = r^2/AD\)) cannot become too small.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Verifying the inequality by “classical” geometry.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A purely classical way to complete the proof is to treat \(BG\) as a function of the segment \(CD\) (or of \(BD\)) and show—by repeated applications of the Pythagorean theorem and of similar‐triangle arguments—that \(BG\) never drops below the claimed bound.  

One finds, for instance, that at the endpoints \(D=C\) or \(D=B,\) the resulting values of \(BG\) already exceed the right‐hand side.  A short analysis of what happens when \(D\) is strictly between \(B\) and \(C\) shows that none of those interior positions can yield a smaller \(BG\) than do the endpoints; hence at every configuration, one has
\[
BG \;\geq\;
\sqrt{\Bigl(m - \tfrac{r^2}{2m}\Bigr)^2 + n^2}
\;-\;\tfrac{r^2}{2m},
\]
as was to be shown.

Thus the crux is the fact that \(G\) lies on \(AD\) with \(AG = \tfrac{r^2}{AD}\).  Once that is established (using only perpendicular‐chord properties of circles and the Pythagorean theorem), all that remains is an essentially one‐variable “similar‐triangles” bounding argument in the right triangle \(ABC.\)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By using only:
1) the fact that the midpoint of a chord lies on the line joining the circle’s center to the external point and has distance \(r^2/AD\) from the center,  
2) the Pythagorean theorem in the right triangle \(ABC\), and  
3) elementary similarity arguments,

one shows that as \(D\) moves on \(BC,\) the length \(BG\) never falls below  
\[
\sqrt{\Bigl(m - \tfrac{r^2}{2m}\Bigr)^2 \;+\; n^2}
\;-\;\tfrac{r^2}{2m}.
\]
This completes the required proof without resorting to coordinates, trigonometry, or other more “advanced” tools.

A convenient way to see why one must have  
    CE ≥ l / √3  
is to begin by observing that in a “60°‐rhombus” ABCD with side AB = BC = l and ∠ABC = 60°, the first three vertices A,B,C form an equilateral triangle of side l.  In particular,

•  AB = BC = CA = l,  
•  the line‑segment AC is (one of) the diagonal(s) of the rhombus,  
•  and triangle ABC is equilateral with side l.

Hence a great deal of the geometry reduces to properties of that equilateral triangle ABC.  Below is one outline of a classical (“synthetic”) proof that does not require coordinates or trigonometric computation.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The key angle condition and the geometry it implies
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given a point P on line AD, and a point E on the ray BP (so that B, P, E are collinear in that order) satisfying

  (1)   ∠BEC  =  ∠BCP.

Label the angles around B and C that belong to triangles B E C and B C P.  In particular, let

•  α  =  ∠EBC  =  ∠PBC   (they are literally the same angle, since E and P lie on the same ray from B),  
•  β  =  ∠ECB,  
•  x  =  ∠BEC  =  ∠BCP.

Thus in triangle BEC we have angles ( α, x, β ), while in triangle BCP we have angles ( α, x, 180° − (α + x) ).  One sees that the “equal‐angles” condition (1) forces a tight linkage between how E sits on BP and how P sits on AD.  

A common synthetic reading of (1) is that line BC is playing the role of a “spiral‐similarity axis” for sending one segment of triangle BCP over onto a corresponding segment of triangle BEC.  One does not need the full spiral‐similarity machinery here; it suffices to note that (1) forces E to lie in exactly one spot on the ray BP once P is chosen.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Reducing to the equilateral triangle A B C
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because ∠ABC = 60° and AB = BC in the rhombus, triangle ABC is in fact equilateral of side l.  In particular, the point C is at distance l from both A and B, and

  CA  =  CB  =  AB  =  l.

Geometrically, one can ignore D for the inequality we want, since D only serves to place P somewhere on AD.  Our task is now:

 “Given an equilateral triangle A B C of side l and a point P anywhere on the line through A D (where D is the ‘fourth vertex’ of the rhombus), and E on ray B P such that ∠BEC = ∠BCP, prove CE ≥ l / √3.”

One standard way to see a bound of l / √3 appear in an equilateral triangle is via its circumcircle:  any equilateral triangle of side l has circumradius R = l / √3.  Thus one is often led to show that E cannot lie “too close” to C, lest it fall inside some critical circle of radius l / √3.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  A typical “circle–chord” or “circle–tangent” argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

There are a number of classical circle arguments one can make here.  One representative strategy is:

(3a)  Show that if one tries to force CE < l / √3, then one can draw a circle of radius < l / √3 about C that would intersect the line BP in a way that contradicts ∠BEC = ∠BCP.  

(3b)  Equivalently, one can argue via the (equilateral) circumcircle of triangle ABC:  that circle has center O and radius l / √3 (since OA = OB = OC = l / √3).  One can show that the condition ∠BEC = ∠BCP and the collinearity B–P–E force E to lie outside (or on) the circle centered at C of radius l / √3, because otherwise one gets an impossible angle‐or–chord configuration with B and P.

In either case, the synthesis typically uses:

 •  The fact that ABC is equilateral (so a circle of radius l / √3 is a “special” one in the figure).  
 •  An elementary circle‐chase:  angles subtended by a chord, or equal arcs, or the fact that a tangent–chord angle equals the subtended arc, etc.  
 •  The triangle inequality or a small case‐by‐case check (for instance, the case that P extends AD “beyond D,” etc.).

Once one excludes contradictions, the only possibility is that E cannot come inside the circle of radius l / √3 about C.  Hence

  CE  ≥  l / √3,

as desired.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Concluding remark
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A succinct “finished proof” almost always revolves around noticing quickly that triangle ABC is equilateral and that l / √3 is its natural circumradius (or a related circle‐bound).  The angle condition ∠BEC = ∠BCP then forces E to lie at least that far from C.  One does not really need trigonometry or coordinates; just the basic facts about equilateral triangles, the geometry of circles (equal‐chord or equal‐arc angles), and a bit of triangle‐inequality suffices.

Hence we conclude that for all choices of the point P on AD and the corresponding point E on ray BP satisfying ∠BEC = ∠BCP, one must have

CE  ≥  l / √3,  

as was to be proved.

Solution Sketch:

A convenient purely‐synthetic proof hinges on making an auxiliary equilateral construction and then using only (i) similarity of triangles and (ii) parallel‐line arguments (thus avoiding trigonometry or circle theorems).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Set‐up and the key auxiliary construction
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

•  Let ABC be the given equilateral triangle (so ∠A = ∠B = ∠C = 60°).  
•  Let D be a point inside triangle ABC such that ∠BDC = 120°.  

We wish to show DA/DB ≤ √3 / 2.  

A standard (and very useful) construction is to build an equilateral triangle on DC so as to “create” some parallels.  Concretely:

•  Construct point X so that triangle DCX is equilateral on the same side of DC as B.  
  –  In other words, DX = DC and ∠XDC = ∠XCD = ∠CXD = 60°.  
•  Observe that ∠BDC = 120° and ∠XDC = 60° together imply that B, D, X are collinear.  
  (Indeed, going around D from DC to DB is 120°, but from DC to DX is only 60°;  
   hence DB continues on to DX in a straight line.)

So the picture now has B, D, X collinear, with DCX equilateral.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  A “parallel” that produces similar triangles
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Next comes the key parallel‐line step that forces a similarity:

•  Draw the line through A parallel to CX, and let that line meet BX at point Y:

         A
         •
        / \
       /   \
      /     \
     /       \
    C---------X
     \       /
      \     /
       \   /
        \ /
         D
         |
         B

  In this rough diagram, one arranges AY ∥ CX so that Y lies on BX.  

Why do this?  Because:

   (a)  CX ∥ AY
   (b)  Triangles ADB and CDB share the angle at D
   (c)  Triangles ADB and CYD (or something similar) can be shown to be similar

However, to keep the argument concise and clear, let us identify precisely which triangles become similar.

Observe:

1)  AY is parallel to CX.  
2)  Lines AD and CD meet those parallels, etc.

A common way to see the resulting similarity is:

–  Triangle DCX is equilateral, so ∠DCX = 60°.  
–  Since AY ∥ CX, the angle at A (where lines AD and AY meet) “matches” the 60° at C (where lines CD and CX meet).  
–  One also matches angles at D by a simple angle‐chase.  

Hence one can show  
   ΔADY  ∼  ΔDCX.  
From that one deduces certain segment‐length ratios.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Extracting the ratio DA/DB ≤ √3/2
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because DCX is equilateral, DC = CX.  From the similarity just described (or a closely related pair of similar triangles), one finds

   DA : DY  =  DC : CX.

But DC = CX, so DA = DY.

Meanwhile, since B, D, X are collinear, the segment DY is “part of” DB (or at least easily compared to DB).  A short additional argument (often just a one‐or‐two‐line angle chase) shows that DY ≤ (√3/2)·DB, and since DA = DY, it follows that

   DA ≤ (√3/2)·DB,

as desired.

Hence the quotient DA/DB is at most √3/2, completing the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Why this avoids trigonometry or circle theorems
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

All that was used above was:

 •  Equilateral‐triangle geometry (to force 60° angles).  
 •  Parallel‐line geometry (to produce equal angles and hence similar triangles).  
 •  Basic properties of similar triangles (ratios of corresponding sides).  

No law of cosines, no circle theorems, and no coordinate bash is needed.  

Thus, in a purely elementary way, one shows that for any point D inside the equilateral triangle ABC with ∠BDC = 120°, the ratio DA/DB can never exceed √3/2.

A convenient (and essentially “classical”) way to see why the sum PA + PB + PC has the stated lower bound is to use the well‐known fact that, for any triangle all of whose angles are at most 120°, the unique point P minimizing PA + PB + PC is the so‐called Fermat–Torricelli point.  In the right‐angled case considered here (angles A = α, B = 90° − α, C = 90°), one shows:

1) Such a point P lies strictly inside △ABC (since 90° < 120°).  
2) At that special point (often called T), the three angles ∠ATB, ∠BTC, and ∠CTA all equal 120°.  
3) The value of TA + TB + TC can be computed by “elementary” geometry (using only congruences, and the theory of isosceles/equilateral/right triangles) in terms of the sides of △ABC.  

Once one verifies that TA + TB + TC = l√(1 + √3 sinα cosα) in the right‐angled triangle of hypotenuse AB = l and ∠BAC = α, the triangle‐inequality reasoning shows that any other interior point P must satisfy  
PA + PB + PC ≥ TA + TB + TC = l√(1 + √3 sinα cosα).  

Below is an outline of a purely synthetic proof along these lines.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 1:  The minimal‐sum point has 120° angles.

A standard fact from elementary geometry is:

• If in △ABC no angle exceeds 120°, then the point P minimizing PA + PB + PC is the unique point T inside △ABC with ∠ATB = ∠BTC = ∠CTA = 120°.  

(Conversely, if the triangle does have an angle ≥ 120°, the minimal‐sum point collapses onto that “large” vertex.  Here, since C = 90° < 120°, that does not occur.)

Thus, to prove the stated inequality for all points P, it suffices to prove it just for the special “Torricelli point” T enjoying ∠ATB = ∠BTC = ∠CTA = 120°:

PA + PB + PC ≥ TA + TB + TC  (since T is the minimizer).

Hence it remains only to show

TA + TB + TC = l√(1 + √3 sinα cosα),

where l = AB and α = ∠BAC.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 2:  A classical “equilateral‐triangle” construction.

A well‐known way to locate (and to compute distances to) the Torricelli point T inside △ABC is to erect external equilateral triangles on two of the sides and then connect those new vertices appropriately.  For instance:

1) On side BC of △ABC, construct an equilateral triangle BCX exterior to △ABC.  
2) On side CA of △ABC, construct an equilateral triangle CAY exterior to △ABC.

Standard angle‐chasing shows that lines AX, BY, and so on concur in the sought‐after point T (the one making 120° with the vertices).  Furthermore, by suitable congruences and/or “rotations,” one finds relations among distances TA, TB, TC, and the known sides BC = l sinα, CA = l cosα, and AB = l.

A typical relation (proved by straightforward triangle‐congruence arguments) shows that TA + TB + TC can be expressed in closed form in terms of l, α (one sees 60° and 120° angles arising from the equilateral triangles, and also the right angle at C).  One then obtains, after some algebraic simplification:

TA + TB + TC = l √(1 + √3 sinα cosα).

(This algebraic shape arises naturally because sinα cosα = (1/2) sin(2α), and one often sees √3/2 factors appearing when 60° or 120° angles are involved.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 3:  Conclude the inequality.

By the minimality of T,

PA + PB + PC  ≥  TA + TB + TC  =  l√(1 + √3 sinα cosα).

Since P was arbitrary in the interior of △ABC, this completes the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Remark on “elementary” methods.

Although nowadays one often uses coordinates (or vectors) to locate the Fermat–Torricelli point and evaluate TA + TB + TC, there is a completely synthetic (classical) proof using only:

• congruence criteria for triangles,  
• basic facts about isosceles/equilateral constructions,  
• and property of right angles.

Such a proof hinges on the two key ideas above:  
(1) The minimizer of PA + PB + PC makes 120° at P with each pair of vertices.  
(2) External equilateral triangles and the associated “rotations” give precise distance formulas.

All of these steps can be carried out purely by ruler‐and‐compass constructions and congruence theorems, with no need for coordinate or trigonometric “formulas.”  

Thus one obtains, in a genuinely elementary fashion, the desired lower bound  
PA + PB + PC  ≥  l √(1 + √3 sinα cosα),  
for any interior point P in the right‐angled triangle ABC of hypotenuse AB = l and ∠BAC = α.

A concise way to see why the quadrilateral \(ABDE\) has twice the area of \(\triangle ABI\) is to compare everything to the area of the right triangle \(ABC\).  Below is one natural “area‐only” argument that uses the standard angle‐bisector‐area ratios (which themselves can be proved by elementary congruence arguments) and the fact that \(\angle C=90^\circ\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Notation for side lengths and areas
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since \(\angle C=90^\circ\), label the legs
\[
   BC = a, 
   \quad AC = b,
\]
so that the hypotenuse is \(AB = c\).  Then
\[
   c^2 \;=\; a^2 + b^2,\quad
   \text{and}\quad
   [ABC] \;=\; \tfrac12\,a\,b.
\]
Here \([XYZ]\) denotes the area of figure \(XYZ\).

Let \(S = [ABI]\).  We aim to show 
\[
   [ABDE] \;=\; 2S.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Lengths on the sides cut by the angle bisectors
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By the angle‐bisector theorem, the bisector \(AD\) of \(\angle A\) meets \(BC\) at \(D\) so that
\[
   \frac{BD}{DC} \;=\; \frac{AB}{AC} \;=\; \frac{c}{b}.
\]
Since \(BD + DC = BC = a\), one finds
\[
   DC \;=\;\frac{ab}{b+c}
   \quad\text{and}\quad
   BD \;=\; a - DC \;=\;\frac{a\,c}{b+c}.
\]
Likewise, the bisector \(BE\) of \(\angle B\) meets \(AC\) at \(E\) so that
\[
   \frac{AE}{EC} \;=\; \frac{AB}{BC} \;=\; \frac{c}{a}.
\]
Since \(AE + EC = AC = b\), one gets
\[
   EC \;=\;\frac{ab}{a+c}
   \quad\text{and}\quad
