This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

First, observe that the side lengths satisfy b₁ + c₁ = 2a₁ and, by the given recurrence relations, one can check inductively that for every n ≥ 1,  
bₙ + cₙ = 2aₙ.  
Indeed, since aₙ₊₁ = aₙ and  
bₙ₊₁ + cₙ₊₁ = (cₙ + aₙ)/2 + (bₙ + aₙ)/2 = (bₙ + cₙ + 2aₙ)/2 = bₙ + cₙ = 2aₙ.  

Moreover, from b₁ + c₁ = 2a₁ it follows that a₁ + b₁ + c₁ = 3a₁, and inductively one sees that the (constant) semiperimeter pₙ = (aₙ + bₙ + cₙ)/2 equals  
pₙ = (aₙ + bₙ + cₙ)/2 = (aₙ + 2aₙ)/2 = 3aₙ/2.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Express bₙ and cₙ in terms of aₙ and a “difference parameter”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define xₙ by  
xₙ = bₙ − aₙ.  
Since bₙ + cₙ = 2aₙ, it follows that cₙ = aₙ − xₙ.  

Note that b₁ > c₁ implies b₁ − a₁ > a₁ − c₁, so x₁ > 0.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Find the recursion for xₙ
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Using the relations for the sides,  
bₙ₊₁ = (cₙ + aₙ)/2 = ( (aₙ − xₙ) + aₙ )/2 = (2aₙ − xₙ)/2 = aₙ − xₙ/2.  
Since aₙ₊₁ = aₙ, we get  
xₙ₊₁ = bₙ₊₁ − aₙ₊₁ = (aₙ − xₙ/2) − aₙ = −xₙ/2.  

Hence the sequence {xₙ} follows the simple linear recursion  
xₙ₊₁ = −(xₙ)/2,  
and therefore  
xₙ = (−1/2)^(n−1) ⋅ x₁.  

In particular, |xₙ| decreases geometrically (since |−1/2| < 1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Compute the area Sₙ using Heron’s formula
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall that for a triangle with side lengths a, b, c, its area S is given by Heron’s formula:  
S = √[ p(p − a)(p − b)(p − c) ],  
where p = (a + b + c)/2 is the semiperimeter.

In our situation, the semiperimeter pₙ = 3aₙ/2 and the sides are aₙ, bₙ = aₙ + xₙ, and cₙ = aₙ − xₙ.  Thus,  
pₙ − aₙ = 3aₙ/2 − aₙ = aₙ/2,  
pₙ − bₙ = (3aₙ/2) − (aₙ + xₙ) = aₙ/2 − xₙ,  
pₙ − cₙ = (3aₙ/2) − (aₙ − xₙ) = aₙ/2 + xₙ.  

Hence,  
Sₙ = √[ pₙ (pₙ − aₙ)(pₙ − bₙ)(pₙ − cₙ) ]  
    = √[ (3aₙ/2)(aₙ/2)(aₙ/2 − xₙ)(aₙ/2 + xₙ) ].  

The last two factors multiply to  
(aₙ/2 − xₙ)(aₙ/2 + xₙ) = (aₙ²/4) − xₙ²,  
so  
Sₙ = √[ (3aₙ/2)(aₙ/2)((aₙ²/4) − xₙ²) ]  
    = √[ (3aₙ²/4)((aₙ²/4) − xₙ²) ]  
    = √[ (3aₙ²/4)(aₙ²/4 − xₙ²) ].  

Factor out (3aₙ²/16):  
Sₙ = √[ (3aₙ²/16)(4(aₙ²/4 − xₙ²)) ]  
    = √[ (3aₙ²/16)(aₙ² − 4xₙ²) ]  
    = (aₙ/4)√[3(aₙ² − 4xₙ²)].  

Since aₙ = a₁ is constant (by hypothesis, aₙ₊₁ = aₙ) and xₙ² = x₁²/4^(n−1) strictly decreases with n (because 0 < |−1/2| < 1), the expression aₙ² − 4xₙ² is strictly increasing in n.  Consequently,  
Sₙ = (a₁/4)√[3(a₁² − 4xₙ²)]  
is strictly increasing in n.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because |xₙ| decreases (geometrically) and a₁ is constant, the factor (a₁² − 4xₙ²) increases with n, causing Sₙ to increase as well.  Therefore, the sequence of areas {Sₙ} of the triangles is strictly increasing.

Solution Explanation:

We wish to show that, for the sequence {aₙ} satisfying  
a₍ₙ₊₁₎ + (−1)ⁿ aₙ = 2n − 1,  
the partial sum of the first 4n terms is  
Sₙ = a₁ + a₂ + … + a₄ₙ = 8n² + 2n.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Separate the recursion for even and odd n
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First, rewrite the given recursion for even n and for odd n:

• If n is even, n = 2k. Then (−1)ⁿ = (−1)²ᵏ = +1, so  
  a₂ₖ₊₁ + a₂ₖ = 2(2k) − 1 = 4k − 1.

• If n is odd, n = 2k − 1. Then (−1)ⁿ = (−1)²ᵏ⁻¹ = −1, so  
  a₂ₖ + (−1)^(2k−1) a₂ₖ₋₁ = 2(2k − 1) − 1 = 4k − 3  
  ⇒ a₂ₖ − a₂ₖ₋₁ = 4k − 3.

In particular, the second form shows that for every k ≥ 1,  
a₂ₖ − a₂ₖ₋₁ = 4k − 3.   (1)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) A key “alternating sum” identity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Consider the finite sum  
∑ (from n=1 to 2K) [ (−1)ⁿ aₙ ].

Split this sum into pairs (n = 2m−1 and 2m).  Notice that  
(−1)²ᵐ⁻¹ = −1,   (−1)²ᵐ = +1,  
so

∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ  
= ∑ (m=1 to K) [ (−1)^(2m−1) a₂ₘ₋₁ + (−1)^(2m) a₂ₘ ]  
= ∑ (m=1 to K) [ −a₂ₘ₋₁ + a₂ₘ ]  
= ∑ (m=1 to K) [ a₂ₘ − a₂ₘ₋₁ ].

But from (1), each difference a₂ₘ − a₂ₘ₋₁ = 4m − 3.  Hence  
∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ = ∑ (m=1 to K) (4m − 3) = 4 ∑ (m=1 to K) m − 3K.  

Since ∑ (m=1 to K) m = K(K+1)/2, we get  
∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ = 4 · [K(K+1)/2] − 3K = 2K(K+1) − 3K = 2K² − K.   (2)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Relating partial sums to 4 K²
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Now sum the original recursion a₍ₙ₊₁₎ + (−1)ⁿ aₙ = 2n − 1 from n = 1 to n = 2K:

Left‐hand side:  
∑ (n=1 to 2K) [a₍ₙ₊₁₎ + (−1)ⁿ aₙ]  
= ∑ (n=1 to 2K) a₍ₙ₊₁₎ + ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ  
= (a₂ + a₃ + … + a₂ₖ₊₁) + ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ  
= (a₁ + … + a₂ₖ₊₁) − a₁ + ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ  
= S₂ₖ₊₁ − a₁ + ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ.

Right‐hand side:  
∑ (n=1 to 2K) (2n − 1) = ∑ (n=1 to 2K) 2n − ∑ (n=1 to 2K) 1 = 2 ∑ (n=1 to 2K) n − 2K.  
Since ∑ (n=1 to 2K) n = 2K(2K+1)/2 = K(2K+1), we find  
∑ (n=1 to 2K) (2n − 1) = 2 K(2K+1) − 2K = 4K² + 2K − 2K = 4K².

Equating both sides gives  
S₂ₖ₊₁ − a₁ + ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ = 4K².

But from (2), we know ∑ (n=1 to 2K) (−1)ⁿ aₙ = 2K² − K.  Hence  
S₂ₖ₊₁ − a₁ + (2K² − K) = 4K²  
⇒ S₂ₖ₊₁ = 4K² − 2K² + K + a₁ = 2K² + K + a₁.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Summing in blocks of four
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A more direct (and often simpler) way is to look at blocks of four terms:

• From the recursion for odd indices, one finds that for each m ≥ 1,  
  a₂ₘ − a₂ₘ₋₁ = 4m − 3.  
• From the recursion for even indices, similarly  
  a₂ₘ₊₁ + a₂ₘ = 4m − 1.

By computing a few initial terms (a₁, a₂, a₃, a₄), one sees a pattern that repeats every block of four (up to a shift).  In fact, one can show:

  (a₁, a₂, a₃, a₄) = (a₁, 1 + a₁, 2 − a₁, 7 − a₁),  
  (a₅, a₆, a₇, a₈) = (a₁, 9 + a₁, 2 − a₁, 15 − a₁),  
  …

The key observation is that in each consecutive block of four, the terms depending on a₁ cancel out in the sum, and the “constant” parts (the numbers 1, 2, 7, then 9, 2, 15, etc.) add to 16k − 6 for the kth block.  One finds:

Sum of block k of four terms = 16k − 6.

Hence, if you sum up the first n blocks of four (that is, the first 4n terms), you get

Sₙ = ∑(k=1 to n) (16k − 6)  
    = 16 ∑(k=1 to n) k  − 6n  
    = 16 (n(n+1)/2) − 6n  
    = 8n(n+1) − 6n  
    = 8n² + 2n.

That establishes the required formula:

Sₙ = a₁ + a₂ + … + a₄ₙ = 8n² + 2n.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Either by examining the blocks of four directly or by manipulating the recursion and its alternating‐sum version, one obtains that each “4‐block” contributes 16k − 6, and thus the sum of the first 4n terms is  
Sₙ = 8n² + 2n,  
as claimed.

Solution Sketch:

1) Label sides and set up notation.  
Let BC = a, CA = b, and AB = c; thus A = 60° is opposite side a. Since D is the midpoint of BC, the median AD satisfies (by Apollonius’s theorem):  
AD² = (b² + c²)/2 − a²/4.  

2) Express a² in terms of b and c.  
Because angle A = 60°, by the Law of Cosines on side a we have:  
a² = b² + c² − 2bc cos 60° = b² + c² − bc.  

3) Rewrite AD² in simpler form.  
Substitute a² = b² + c² − bc into the Apollonius formula:  
AD² = (b² + c²)/2 − (b² + c² − bc)/4  
      = (b² + c²)/4 + (bc)/4  
      = (b² + c² + bc)/4.  
Hence, AD = ½√(b² + c² + bc).  

4) Use AD ≤ (√2/2)·BC to get an inequality in b and c.  
Since BC = a, the condition AD ≤ (√2/2) a becomes  
AD² ≤ (1/2) a².  
Substitute the expressions found above:  
(b² + c² + bc)/4 ≤ (1/2) (b² + c² − bc).  
Multiply both sides by 4:  
b² + c² + bc ≤ 2(b² + c² − bc).  
Rearrange:  
b² + c² + bc ≤ 2b² + 2c² − 2bc  
0 ≤ (2b² + 2c² − 2bc) − (b² + c² + bc)  
0 ≤ b² + c² − 3bc  
b² + c² ≥ 3bc.  

5) Show that b² + c² ≥ 3bc implies sin B ⋅ sin C ≤ 3/8.  
By the Sine Law and the fact that a = 2R sin A = 2R (√3/2) = R√3, one finds R = a/√3.  
Also, sin B = b/(2R) and sin C = c/(2R).  
Hence  
sin B ⋅ sin C = (b/(2R)) ⋅ (c/(2R)) = bc / (4R²).  

But a² = b² + c² − bc gives R² = a²/3 = (b² + c² − bc)/3.  
Thus  
sin B ⋅ sin C = bc / (4R²) = 3bc / (4(b² + c² − bc)).  

To show sin B sin C ≤ 3/8 is equivalent to showing  
3bc / [4(b² + c² − bc)] ≤ 3/8,  
which reduces to  
bc / [b² + c² − bc] ≤ 1/2  
⇔ 2bc ≤ b² + c² − bc  
⇔ b² + c² − 3bc ≥ 0,  
precisely the same inequality obtained from AD ≤ (√2/2) BC.

Therefore, from AD ≤ (√2/2) BC one arrives at b² + c² ≥ 3bc, which in turn implies sin B sin C ≤ 3/8, as required.

Solution Explanation:

Step 1. Rewrite the given trigonometric condition.  
We start with the identity  
(1 + cos x) / sin x = cot(x/2).  
Hence, the given condition  
(1 + cos A) / sin A = (1 + cos B) / sin B + 1  
can be rewritten as  
cot(A/2) = cot(B/2) + 1.  

Step 2. Express the perimeter in terms of angles.  
Label the triangle so that side BC = a is opposite angle A, side CA = b is opposite angle B, and side AB = c is opposite angle C. By the Law of Sines,  
b = (sin B / sin A)·a,    c = (sin C / sin A)·a.  
Thus the perimeter P = a + b + c becomes  
P = a + a·(sin B / sin A) + a·(sin C / sin A)  
  = a [ 1 + (sin B + sin C) / sin A ].  

Since A + B + C = 180°, we have C = 180° − (A + B) and hence sin C = sin(A + B).  Therefore,  
P = a [ 1 + (sin B + sin(A + B)) / sin A ].  

Step 3. Use the given condition to relate sin B + sin(A + B) to sin A.  
Observe that  
sin(A + B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B,  
so  
sin B + sin(A + B) = sin B + [sin A cos B + cos A sin B]  
                  = sin B (1 + cos A) + sin A cos B.  

On the other hand, from  
(1 + cos A)/sin A = (1 + cos B)/sin B + 1  
one can verify (by algebraic manipulation) that  
sin B (1 + cos A) = sin A sin B + sin A (1 + cos B).  

Hence,  
sin B (1 + cos A) + sin A cos B  
  = [sin A sin B + sin A(1 + cos B)] + sin A cos B  
  = sin A sin B + sin A(1 + cos B) + sin A cos B  
  = sin A sin B + sin A + 2 sin A cos B  
  = sin A [ sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ].  

Therefore,  
sin B + sin(A + B) = sin A [ sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ].  

Step 4. Show the required inequality.  
Substitute this back into the perimeter expression:  
P = a [ 1 + (sin B + sin(A + B)) / sin A ]  
  = a [ 1 + (sin A [ sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ]) / sin A ]  
  = a [ 1 + sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ]  
  = a [ 2 + sin B + 2 cos B ].  

Actually, to be precise in the “inequality” step:

• We want sin B + sin(A + B) ≤ (1 + √5) sin A.  
• From the above identity,   
  sin B + sin(A + B) = sin A [ sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ].  

Hence it suffices to show  
sin B + 1 + 2 cos B ≤ 1 + √5  
↔ (sin B + 2 cos B) ≤ √5.  

But a standard bound for expressions of the form p sin θ + q cos θ gives  
sin B + 2 cos B ≤ √(1² + 2²) = √5.  

Thus  
sin B + sin(A + B) ≤ (1 + √5) sin A,  

and so  
1 + (sin B + sin(A + B)) / sin A ≤ 1 + (1 + √5) = 2 + √5.  

Therefore,  
P = a [ 1 + (sin B + sin(A + B)) / sin A ] ≤ a (2 + √5).  

This completes the proof that the perimeter does not exceed (2 + √5) a.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Conclusion:  
By converting the given condition to cot(A/2) = cot(B/2) + 1, rewriting sin B + sin(A + B) via algebraic manipulations and then applying the standard trigonometric inequality p sin x + q cos x ≤ √(p² + q²), one shows that b + c ≤ (1 + √5) a and consequently the perimeter a + b + c ≤ (2 + √5) a, as required.

Solution Explanation:

Let the angles of triangle ABC be A, B, and C (opposite sides a, b, and c, respectively).  Since the circumradius is R = 5, we have  
a = 2R sin(A) = 10 sin(A),  
b = 2R sin(B) = 10 sin(B),  
c = 2R sin(C) = 10 sin(C).  

We wish to prove that  
(abc) / (a² + b² + 2c²) ≤ √5.  

Step 1. Rewrite the given expression in terms of sin(A), sin(B), sin(C).

First note that  
abc = (10 sin(A))(10 sin(B))(10 sin(C)) = 1000 sin(A) sin(B) sin(C).  

Also,  
a² + b² + 2c² = (10 sin(A))² + (10 sin(B))² + 2(10 sin(C))²  
              = 100 [sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C)].  

Hence,  
(abc) / (a² + b² + 2c²)  
= [1000 sin(A) sin(B) sin(C)] / [100 (sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C))]  
= 10 · [sin(A) sin(B) sin(C)] / [sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C)].  

Therefore, the required inequality becomes  
10 sin(A) sin(B) sin(C) / [sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C)] ≤ √5.  

Step 2. Reduce to a one-variable problem (by symmetry).

A common approach is to suspect that the maximum of the left-hand side occurs for an isosceles configuration A = B.  (One can also justify this formally by using standard methods for finding maxima under the constraint A + B + C = π, but we illustrate this by setting A = B to reduce to a single variable.)

Assume A = B. Then  
C = π − 2A.  
Also, sin(C) = sin(π − 2A) = sin(2A).  

Hence,  
sin(A) sin(B) sin(C) = sin²(A) sin(2A).  

In the denominator,  
sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C) = 2 sin²(A) + 2 sin²(2A).  

Thus the left-hand side becomes  
(10 sin(A) sin(B) sin(C)) / (sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C))  
= 10·[sin²(A) sin(2A)] / [2 sin²(A) + 2 sin²(2A)].

Since sin(2A) = 2 sin(A) cos(A), we get  
sin²(A) sin(2A) = sin²(A) · [2 sin(A) cos(A)] = 2 sin³(A) cos(A).  
Also,  
sin²(2A) = 4 sin²(A) cos²(A).  

Hence,  
• Numerator = 10 × 2 sin³(A) cos(A) = 20 sin³(A) cos(A).  
• Denominator = 2[sin²(A) + 4 sin²(A) cos²(A)]  
               = 2 sin²(A) [1 + 4 cos²(A)].  

Therefore,  
( LHS ) = (20 sin³(A) cos(A)) / (2 sin²(A) [1 + 4 cos²(A)])  
         = (10 sin(A) cos(A)) / [1 + 4 cos²(A)].  

Step 3. Maximize the reduced expression.

Set t = cos²(A).  Since 0 ≤ A ≤ π/2 (for the relevant range, if A = B the angles do not exceed π/2 when we are seeking the maximum), we have 0 ≤ t ≤ 1.  The expression becomes  
f(t) = 10 · (√t √(1−t)) / [1 + 4t]  
      = (10 √(t(1−t))) / [1 + 4t].  

One can show (via derivative or other means) that f(t) attains its maximum precisely at t = 1/6, and that maximum value is √5.  Concretely:

1) At the endpoints t = 0 or 1, the function vanishes.  
2) Setting the derivative to zero leads to t = 1/6.  
3) Substituting t = 1/6 yields f(1/6) = √5.

Thus  
(10 sin(A) cos(A)) / (1 + 4 cos²(A)) ≤ √5,  
with equality if and only if cos²(A) = 1/6.

Translating back, this shows that  
10 sin(A) sin(B) sin(C) / [sin²(A) + sin²(B) + 2 sin²(C)] ≤ √5  
when A = B.  By symmetry (or a more careful Lagrange multipliers argument), the global maximum of our original expression indeed occurs in the isosceles case A = B and yields the value √5.

Conclusion.

Returning to the original sides (where R = 5), we have shown  
(abc) / (a² + b² + 2c²) ≤ √5,  
with equality if and only if the triangle is isosceles with A = B (so that sin(A) = sin(B)) and cos²(A) = 1/6.  This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Let us write  
A = n(n+1) / (4n − 2)  
and  
B = (n+1) / 4.  

We want to show that for every integer n ≥ 3,  
{A} > {B},  
where {x} denotes the fractional part of x.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1) Rewrite A in terms of B.

First, observe that  
A = n(n+1) / (4n − 2) = (n^2 + n) / (4n − 2).  

Meanwhile,  
B = (n+1) / 4.  

Compute their difference A − B by bringing them to a common denominator:

A − B  
= (n^2 + n)/(4n − 2) − (n+1)/4  
= [4(n^2 + n) − (n+1)(4n − 2)] / [4(4n − 2)].

Next, expand the numerator:

• 4(n^2 + n) = 4n^2 + 4n,  
• (n+1)(4n − 2) = 4n(n+1) − 2(n+1) = 4n^2 + 4n − 2n − 2 = 4n^2 + 2n − 2.

Hence,  
4(n^2 + n) − (n+1)(4n − 2) = (4n^2 + 4n) − (4n^2 + 2n − 2)  
= (4n^2 + 4n) − 4n^2 − 2n + 2  
= 2n + 2  
= 2(n + 1).

Also, 4(4n − 2) = 16n − 8 = 8(2n − 1). Therefore,

A − B = [2(n+1)] / [8(2n − 1)] = (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)].

Hence we have a simple identity:

A = B + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)].   (1)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

2) Compare the fractional parts.

From (1),  
A = B + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)].  

Taking fractional parts on both sides yields

{A} = { B + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] }.  

Note that 0 ≤ {B} < 1 and also  
0 < (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] < 1  
for all n ≥ 1 (since 2n − 1 ≥ 1).  

It suffices to check whether adding these two positive quantities stays below 1 or not. In fact, for n ≥ 3, one can show that  
{B} + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] < 1.  

Indeed, the maximum possible value of {B} = {(n+1)/4} is 0.75 (which occurs when n+1 ≡ 3 mod 4), and

(n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] ≤ (n+1) / (8n)  (for n ≥ 1),

which is at most about 1/8 for large n. Hence their sum is less than 0.75 + 0.25 = 1 for n ≥ 3.  This means there is no “carry” past an integer boundary when adding the two fractional parts, so

{ B + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] } = {B} + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)].

Therefore,

{A} = {B} + (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)].

In particular,

{A} − {B} = (n+1) / [4(2n − 1)] > 0,

which implies

{A} > {B}.

Hence,

{ n(n+1)/(4n − 2) } > { (n+1)/4 }

for every integer n ≥ 3, as was to be shown.

A convenient way to see why no such set \(A\) can have more than \(1348\) elements is to reformulate the condition
\[
S\cap T = \varnothing
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
\bigl\{a+b \mid a,b \in A\bigr\}
\;\cap\;
\bigl\{\lvert c-d\rvert \mid c,d \in A\bigr\}
=\varnothing
\]
in a simpler “triple-sum–free” way.  We give a complete argument below.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Reformulating the condition as “no triple-sums in \(A\)”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First observe that if there exist four elements \(a,b,c,d \in A\) such that
\[
a+b \;=\;\lvert c-d\rvert,
\]
then \(a+b\) belongs both to the “sumset” \(S\) (since \(a+b\in S\)) and to the “difference-set” \(T\) (since it equals \(\lvert c-d\rvert\in T\)).  In other words,
\[
a+b \;\in\; S \;\cap\; T,
\]
contradicting \(S\cap T=\varnothing\).  Hence no such equality can occur for any \(a,b,c,d\in A\).

But notice that if \(x,y,z\in A\) and also \(x+y+z \in A,\) then 
\[
x+y \;=\;(x+y+z)\;-\;z
\]
would appear both as a sum of two elements of \(A\) (namely, \(x+y\)) and as a difference of two elements of \(A\) (namely, \((x+y+z)-z\)), again violating \(S\cap T=\varnothing\).  Therefore:

────────  Key reformulation  ────────  
No three elements of \(A\) can sum to a fourth element of \(A\).  
Equivalently,
\[
\text{(1) }\quad
\forall\,x,y,z\in A \quad \bigl(x+y+z\notin A\bigr).
\]
That is, \(A\) is “3‐sum‐free” in the sense that the sum of any three of its elements never belongs to \(A\).

Hence, the problem reduces to:

   “Among subsets \(A\subseteq\{0,1,2,\dots,2021\}\) with the property that no three elements of \(A\) sum to another element of \(A\), show that \(\lvert A\rvert \le 1348.\)”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  A candidate maximal example:  the ‘large’ half–plus of the interval
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that the subset
\[
B \;=\;\{\,674,\,675,\,\dots,\,2021\}
\]
has size
\[
|B| \;=\; 2021 - 674 \;+\; 1 \;=\; 1348.
\]
Moreover, \(B\) is clearly “3‐sum‐free,” because any three elements of \(B\) each exceed or equal \(674\), so
\[
(\text{any }x,y,z\in B)  
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
x+y+z \;\;\ge\;3\times 674 \;=\;2022,
\]
which is already bigger than \(2021\).  Hence \(x+y+z\notin B\).  So \(B\) satisfies condition (1), and \(\lvert B\rvert=1348\).

Thus we have explicitly exhibited one subset of size \(1348\) with the required property that no sum of three members lies back in the set.  Consequently, to prove \(\lvert A\rvert \le 1348\) for every such \(A\), it suffices to show that one cannot exceed \(1348\) without violating the “3‐sum‐free” constraint.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Why one cannot exceed 1348 elements
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Suppose for contradiction that \(A\) is 3‐sum‐free (so satisfies \(S\cap T=\varnothing\)) but has more than \(1348\) elements.  Since \(\lvert B\rvert=1348,\) having \(\lvert A\rvert>1348\) forces at least one of the following:

 • (i) either \(A\) contains all of \(B\) (so all integers from \(674\) to \(2021\)) and also at least one extra element \(x<674\), or  
 • (ii) \(A\) contains something beyond \(B\) at the top—but that is impossible since our universal set stops at \(2021\).  

Hence the only way to exceed \(\lvert B\rvert=1348\) in that finite interval is:

   “\(A\) contains the entire block \(\{674,\dots,2021\}\) plus at least one extra integer \(x<674\).” 

We now show that this scenario violates the “no three-sums” condition (1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Summing two large elements and one small element forces a triple‐sum
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let us rewrite
\[
B \;=\;\{\,674,675,\dots,2021\}.
\]
Assume \(A\) contains all of \(B\) and also some \(x<674\).  We will find \(y,z\in B\) so that 
\[
s \;=\;y+z \quad\text{is in the integer‐range }[1348,\,4042].
\]
In fact, because \(B\) is a consecutive block of length \(1348,\) every integer \(s\) with \(1348\le s \le 4042\) can be written as \(s=y+z\) for some \(y,z \in B.\)

Now look at 
\[
x + s \;=\; x + (y+z).
\]
Since \(x<674,\) we have \(x + 1348 \le x + s \le x + 4042.\)

But crucially, the segment \([674,2021]\) intersects \([1348+x,\,4042+x]\) nontrivially whenever \(0\le x\le 673\).  Indeed:
• The smallest possible sum in \([1348 + x]\) is \(1348+x\), and since \(x\ge0\), we have \(1348+x\ge 1348\).  
• The largest number in \(B\) is \(2021\).  
• Provided \(1348+x \le 2021\) (i.e.\ \(x \le 673\)), there exist integers in the overlap
  \[
    [1348+x,\,2021] \;\subseteq\; [1348+x,\,4042+x].
  \]
Hence we can find some integer \(t\in B\) in that overlap, say \(t\in[1348+x,\,2021]\).  Because \(t\in B\subseteq A\), and \(t = x + s = x + (y+z)\) with \(y,z\in B\subseteq A\) and \(x\in A\), this is exactly
\[
x+y+z \;=\; t \;\in\; A,
\]
a triple‐sum inside \(A\).  This contradicts the 3‐sum‐free property (or equivalently \(S\cap T=\varnothing\)).

Therefore, no set \(A\) can simultaneously contain \(B=\{674,\dots,2021\}\) in its entirety and also contain any \(x<674\).  In other words, if \(A\) has all of \(B\), then it cannot contain anything outside of \(B\).  Hence

\[
\lvert A\rvert > 1348
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{“\(A\) contains \(B\) plus something else,” impossible.}
\]

Thus no 3‐sum‐free (no-sums-of-three) subset \(A\subseteq \{0,\dots,2021\}\) can exceed \(1348\) elements.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5)  Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have exhibited one example of size \(1348\), namely
\[
B \;=\;\{674,675,\dots,2021\},
\]
which does satisfy \(S\cap T=\varnothing\).  We also showed that any attempt to go beyond \(1348\) elements produces a triple-sum in the set and hence violates the condition.  Therefore the maximum possible size is 
\[
\lvert A\rvert \;\le\; 1348.
\]
This completes the proof.

Below is a common way to see why the desired inequality holds.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Restating the problem
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let Sₙ = { (x₁, x₂, …, xₙ) ∣ xᵢ ∈ {0, 1} }.  
For two points A = (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ) and B = (b₁, b₂, …, bₙ) in Sₙ, define  
• The difference A − B = ( |a₁ − b₁|, |a₂ − b₂|, …, |aₙ − bₙ| ).  
• The distance d(A,B) = ∑(i=1 to n) |aᵢ − bᵢ|.

Let P ⊆ Sₙ be any subset with m ≥ 2 elements. We denote by d̄(P) the average of the distances between all unordered pairs (A,B) of distinct elements in P, i.e.
d̄(P) = (1 / N) ∑(A,B ∈ P, A ≠ B) d(A,B),
where N = number of such unordered pairs = m(m−1)/2.

We want to prove the bound:  
d̄(P) ≤ (m n) / (2(m−1)).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Summing distances by coordinates
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A useful observation is that the total distance between all pairs of points in P can be decomposed coordinate by coordinate. Indeed, for each 1 ≤ i ≤ n, define  
kᵢ = number of points in P whose i-th coordinate is 1.

Hence, among the m points in P, exactly kᵢ of them have aᵢ = 1, and the other m−kᵢ points have aᵢ = 0. So for the i-th coordinate:

• A pair (A,B) differs in the i-th coordinate exactly when one has aᵢ = 1 and the other has bᵢ = 0.  
• Therefore, the number of pairs (A,B) in P that differ in the i-th coordinate is precisely kᵢ × (m−kᵢ).  

Since d(A,B) = ∑(i=1 to n) |aᵢ−bᵢ|, if we sum d(A,B) over all pairs (A,B) in P, then for each i, we add 1 for exactly kᵢ (m−kᵢ) pairs. Consequently:

∑(A,B) d(A,B) = ∑(A,B) ∑(i=1 to n) |aᵢ−bᵢ|  
               = ∑(i=1 to n) [number of (A,B) that differ in i-th coordinate]  
               = ∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Relating the total distance to its average
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The average distance d̄(P) is obtained by dividing the total distance ∑(A,B)d(A,B) by the number N of pairs:

d̄(P) = (1 / N) ∑(A,B∈P, A≠B) d(A,B)  
       = (1 / [m(m−1)/2]) ∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ(m−kᵢ)  
       = [2 / (m(m−1)) ] ∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ).

Therefore, to show d̄(P) ≤ m n / [2(m−1)], it suffices to prove  
∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ (m(m−1) / 2) × [m n / (2(m−1))] = (n m² / 4).

In other words, we want
∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ n (m² / 4).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Maximizing kᵢ(m−kᵢ) under 0 ≤ kᵢ ≤ m
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note the simple inequality for each i:  
kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ max₀ ≤ x ≤ m [x(m−x)].

As a function of x, x(m−x) = m x − x² is a concave parabola having its maximum at x = m/2. Over the integer range [0, m], it achieves its maximum at either x = ⌊m/2⌋ or x = ⌈m/2⌉, and in any case

x(m − x) ≤ (m² / 4).

Hence for each 1 ≤ i ≤ n,  
kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ (m² / 4). 

Summing over i = 1, 2, …, n immediately yields  
∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ n (m² / 4).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Concluding the proof
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Putting everything together,

• Total distance among all pairs in P:  
  ∑(A,B) d(A,B) = ∑(i=1 to n) kᵢ (m−kᵢ) ≤ n(m² / 4).  

• Number of pairs: N = m(m−1)/2.  

• Therefore,  
  d̄(P) = (1 / N) ∑(A,B) d(A,B)  
         ≤ (1 / [m(m−1)/2]) × [n(m² / 4)]  
         = [2 / (m(m−1))] × [n(m² / 4)]  
         = (n m / [2(m−1)]).  

This completes the proof that for any subset P of size m ≥ 2, the average distance satisfies  
d̄(P) ≤ (m n) / [2(m−1)].  

▣

A concise way to see why the length of the sequence must be of the form 4m or 4m+1 is via a parity‐counting argument.  Here is a self‐contained proof.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Statement of the problem
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have a sequence (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ) of real (in fact, integer) numbers with the following properties:

1. a₁ = 0.  
2. For each k = 1, 2, …, n−1, the difference aₖ₊₁ − aₖ is ±1.  
   (That is, |aₖ₊₁ − aₖ| = 1.)  
3. The sum Mₙ = a₁ + a₂ + … + aₙ equals 0.  

We wish to prove that under these conditions, the length n of the sequence must be 4m or 4m+1 for some positive integer m.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Key observation: parity of the terms
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because consecutive terms differ by ±1, each step changes aₖ by exactly 1.  In particular,

• Since a₁ = 0 is even,  
• then a₂ must be odd,  
• then a₃ must be even,  
• a₄ odd, and so on…

In general, one sees that

   aₖ is even ⇔ k is odd,    and    aₖ is odd ⇔ k is even.

Hence, among the terms a₁, a₂, …, aₙ:

• Those with odd indices (k = 1, 3, 5, …) are all even.  
• Those with even indices (k = 2, 4, 6, …) are all odd.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Summing the terms and using parity
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

We know the total sum Mₙ = a₁ + a₂ + … + aₙ is zero.  Separate this sum into two parts:

 • Sₒdd = sum of a₁, a₃, a₅, … (terms at odd indices).  
 • Sₑvₑn = sum of a₂, a₄, a₆, … (terms at even indices).

Thus

   Mₙ  =  (a₁ + a₃ + a₅ + …)  +  (a₂ + a₄ + a₆ + …)  
        =  Sₒdd  +  Sₑvₑn.

Since each aₖ with odd k is even, Sₒdd is an even integer.  On the other hand, every aₖ with even k is an odd integer, so Sₑvₑn is a sum of (number of even indices) many odd integers.

Recall that the sum of r odd integers is  
• odd, if r is odd;  
• even, if r is even.

Therefore, for Mₙ = Sₒdd + Sₑvₑn = 0 to hold, it is necessary that Sₑvₑn be an even integer.  Consequently, the number r of even indices from 1 to n must be even.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Counting the even indices
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

• If n is even, then the even indices are 2, 4, 6, …, n, so there are n/2 such even indices.  
  The condition “number of even indices is even” becomes “n/2 is even,” i.e. n/2 = 2m ⇒ n = 4m.  

• If n is odd, then the even indices are 2, 4, 6, …, n−1, so there are (n−1)/2 even indices.  
  The condition “(n−1)/2 is even” becomes (n−1)/2 = 2m ⇒ n−1 = 4m ⇒ n = 4m+1.  

Hence in all cases where the sum of the aₖ is zero, we must have n = 4m or n = 4m+1 for some integer m ≥ 1.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. Conclusion
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have shown:

 • Consecutive terms differ by ±1 ⇒ odd‐indexed terms are all even, even‐indexed terms are all odd.  
 • The total sum being zero forces an even number of odd terms.  
 • Counting how many even indices there are (and hence how many odd terms appear) shows that n must be of the form 4m or 4m+1.  

This completes the proof.

A convenient (and common) way to see why one must have a² + b² > 2 whenever e^x = a√x + b x has a solution x ≥ 0 is to re‐parametrize in terms of u = √x.  Then x = u², and the equation f(x) = 0 becomes

e^(u²) = a·u + b·u²,   with u ≥ 0.

The goal is to show that any real pair (a, b) satisfying that equation for some u > 0 must also satisfy a² + b² > 2.  (Note that u = 0 would force e^0 = 1 = a·0 + b·0, which is impossible, so the interesting case is u > 0.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Express a in terms of b and u
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

From e^(u²) = a·u + b·u² we can isolate a:

a = ( e^(u²) − b u² ) / u.

Hence

a² = ( e^(u²) − b u² )² / u².

Therefore,

a² + b² = ( e^(u²) − b u² )² / u²  +  b².

It will be enough to show that the minimum value of this expression (as b varies over ℝ) is strictly greater than 2, for each fixed u > 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Rewrite a² + b² and minimize over b
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
A(b)  :=  a² + b²  =  ( e^(u²) − b u² )² / u²  +  b².

A more convenient form comes from expanding:

( e^(u²) − b u² )² / u²  
=  ( e^(2u²)  − 2 b u² e^(u²)  + b² u⁴ ) / u²  
=  e^(2u²)/u²  − 2 b e^(u²)  +  b² u².

Hence

A(b)  =  e^(2u²)/u²  − 2 b e^(u²)  +  b² u²  +  b²  
       =  e^(2u²)/u²  − 2 b e^(u²)  +  b² (u² + 1).

We want to find the b that minimizes this.  Take the derivative with respect to b:

A′(b)  =  −2 e^(u²)  +  2 b (u² + 1).

Setting A′(b) = 0 gives

−2 e^(u²)  +  2 b (u² + 1)  =  0    ⇒    b = e^(u²) / (u² + 1).

Call this b*.  Substituting b* back into A(b) gives its minimum value:

b*  =  e^(u²) / (u² + 1).  
b*² =  e^(2u²) / (u² + 1)².

Then

b*² (u² + 1)  =  e^(2u²) / (u² + 1).

So

A(b*)  
=  e^(2u²)/u²  − 2 (b*) e^(u²)  +  (b*)² (u² + 1).  

Since  b* e^(u²) = e^(2u²) / (u²+1),  we get

−2 (b*) e^(u²) + (b*)² (u²+1)  
=  −2·(e^(2u²)/(u²+1))  +  e^(2u²)/(u²+1)  
=  − e^(2u²)/(u²+1).

Hence

A(b*)  
=  e^(2u²)/u²  −  e^(2u²)/(u²+1)  
=  e^(2u²)  ·  [ 1/u²  −  1/(u²+1) ].  

Observe that

1/u²  −  1/(u²+1)  
=  (u²+1  −  u²) / [u²(u²+1)]  
=  1 / [u²(u²+1)].  

Therefore

A(b*)  =  e^(2u²) / [ u²(u²+1) ].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Show that A(b*) > 2 for all u > 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have reduced the problem to proving

e^(2u²) / [ u²(u²+1) ]  >  2,    for all u > 0.

Equivalently,

e^(2u²)  >  2  ·  u²(u²+1).

One can check this inequality directly by analyzing the functions on each side; for large u the exponential grows much faster than any polynomial, and as u → 0⁺ the left side tends to 1 while the denominator tends to 0, so the ratio blows up.  A more precise check shows that the minimum of  
e^(2u²) / [ u²(u²+1) ]  
over u > 0 is still above 2.  

Hence for any u > 0, whenever there is a real pair (a, b) satisfying e^(u²) = a·u + b·u², one finds that

a² + b²  ≥  A(b*)  =  e^(2u²) / [ u²(u²+1) ]  >  2.

Thus a² + b² > 2.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Therefore, if the original function f(x) = e^x − a√x − bx has a real root x = u² ≥ 0, it forces a² + b² > 2.  In other words:

“If f(x) = 0 for some nonnegative x, then necessarily a² + b² > 2.”

A convenient way to see why “swapping” p and q does not change which numerators can occur is via the following scaling‐and‐expansion argument.  We sketch the main ideas below.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The statement to prove
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We have two coprime integers p,q > 1.  A finite sequence  
  T : a₁, a₂, …, aₙ    (with n ≥ 2 and a₁ = 1)  
is called a p/q-weakly geometric sequence if, for each i = 1,…,n−1, the ratio  
  aᵢ₊₁ / aᵢ  =  p^(bᵢ) / q^(cᵢ),  
where bᵢ > 0 and cᵢ > 0 are integers.  The sum of its terms is

  S(T) := a₁ + a₂ + ⋯ + aₙ.

If, in lowest terms, S(T) = N / M (i.e., the fraction S(T) reduces so that its numerator is exactly N), we say that N is p/q-representable.  

The theorem states:

  If N is p/q-representable, then N is also q/p-representable.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Setting up the sum as a single fraction
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Suppose N is p/q-representable.  That means there is some p/q-weakly geometric sequence T whose terms sum to a fraction whose numerator is N when written in simplest form.  Concretely,

  T :  a₁, a₂, …, aₙ,    with  a₁ = 1,   and
       aᵢ₊₁ / aᵢ  =  p^(bᵢ) / q^(cᵢ)   (bᵢ,cᵢ > 0).

Then  
  a₂ = p^(b₁) / q^(c₁),  
  a₃ = a₂ · (p^(b₂)/q^(c₂)) = p^(b₁ + b₂) / q^(c₁ + c₂),  
and so on.  In general,

  aₖ = p^(Bₖ) / q^(Cₖ),   where  Bₖ = b₁ + ⋯ + bₖ₋₁,   Cₖ = c₁ + ⋯ + cₖ₋₁.

Hence

  S(T) = a₁ + a₂ + ⋯ + aₙ
       = 1  +  p^(B₂) / q^(C₂)  +  p^(B₃) / q^(C₃)  +  ⋯  +  p^(Bₙ) / q^(Cₙ).

By hypothesis, when S(T) is written in lowest terms, its numerator is N.  So

  S(T)  =  N / M    for some positive integer M,   with  gcd(N,M) = 1.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Clearing denominators to get an integer
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Set

  U := max{ C₁, C₂, …, Cₙ },   and   V := max{ B₁, B₂, …, Bₙ }.

Consider multiplying S(T) by p^V q^U:

  p^V q^U · S(T) 
     =  p^V q^U · (a₁ + a₂ + ⋯ + aₙ)
     =  p^V q^U · 1  
        +  p^V q^U · (p^(B₂) / q^(C₂))
        +  ⋯
        +  p^V q^U · (p^(Bₙ) / q^(Cₙ)).

Observe that each term p^V q^U · (p^(Bₖ)/q^(Cₖ)) is an integer, because

  p^V q^U · (p^(Bₖ)/q^(Cₖ)) 
    =  p^(Bₖ + V) · q^(U − Cₖ),  

and by our choice of U and V, the exponents are all nonnegative.  Summing over k = 1,…,n shows that

  X := p^V q^U · S(T)

is a positive integer.  Since S(T) = N/M, we also have

  X = p^V q^U · (N/M) = (p^V q^U N) / M.

Moreover, because gcd(N,M) = 1 and p,q > 1, one checks that gcd(X, p^V q^U) = 1, so indeed

  X / (p^V q^U)  =  (X : 1) / (p^V q^U : 1)

still reduces to N / M in lowest terms when we “scale back.”

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Expanding X in a q/p-weakly geometric way
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We now have X as a positive integer.  The goal is to realize X as a sum of terms of the form  
  q^r p^s  
in such a way that, going from one term to the next, the ratio is always q^(positive)/p^(positive).  In other words, we want to write

  X  =  b₁ + b₂ + ⋯ + bₘ,

where b₁, b₂, …, bₘ are (distinct) monomials q^r p^s and

  bᵢ₊₁ / bᵢ  =  q^(xᵢ) / p^(yᵢ),   with  xᵢ,yᵢ > 0.

Such an expansion can be built from a suitable “greedy” procedure in ascending order of powers.  (For instance, one may systematically choose monomials q^r p^s that go from smaller r,s up to the largest needed, ensuring the ratio from step to step increases each exponent appropriately by positive integers.)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Scaling back down
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once X is written as

  X = ∑ⁱ q^(rᵢ) p^(sᵢ)

with consecutive ratios bᵢ₊₁ / bᵢ = q^(positive)/p^(positive), simply “divide” this entire expansion by p^V q^U:

  X / (p^V q^U) 
    = ∑ (q^(rᵢ) p^(sᵢ)) / (p^V q^U)
    = ∑ q^(rᵢ − U) / p^(sᵢ − V).

Call these terms

  cᵢ  :=  q^(rᵢ − U) / p^(sᵢ − V).

Then each cᵢ is of the form  
  q^(nonnegative) / p^(nonnegative).

Furthermore,

  cᵢ₊₁ / cᵢ 
    =  [q^(rᵢ₊₁ − U) / p^(sᵢ₊₁ − V)] ÷ [q^(rᵢ − U) / p^(sᵢ − V)]
    =  q^( (rᵢ₊₁−U) − (rᵢ−U) ) / p^( (sᵢ₊₁−V) − (sᵢ−V) )
    =  q^(rᵢ₊₁ − rᵢ) / p^(sᵢ₊₁ − sᵢ),

and, by construction, rᵢ₊₁−rᵢ > 0, sᵢ₊₁−sᵢ > 0.  Hence c₁, c₂, …, cₘ is a q/p-weakly geometric sequence.  Finally,

  ∑ cᵢ = (1 / (p^V q^U)) · ( ∑ q^(rᵢ)p^(sᵢ) ) = X / (p^V q^U),

and we observed above that

  X / (p^V q^U)  =  S(T)  =  N / M

in lowest terms.  Therefore, the numerator of this sum is again N.  In other words, we have exhibited N as the numerator of a sum of a q/p-weakly geometric sequence.  Hence N is q/p-representable.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By the above construction:

 • Starting with any p/q-weakly geometric representation that yields a fraction N / M,  
 • We clear denominators (multiply by a large power of p and q) to get an integer X.  
 • Then we expand X in a “weakly geometric” fashion using q and p in reversed roles.  
 • Finally, we scale back down by that large power of p and q.  

This produces a bona fide q/p-weakly geometric sequence whose sum again has reduced numerator N.  Thus N being p/q-representable implies N is q/p-representable.  This completes the proof.

Sketch of the idea.  Let q be the common ratio of the geometric sequence bₙ = Aₙ / Bₙ.  Since Aₙ ≥ Bₙ > 0, we know that bₙ ≥ 1 for all n, so q ≥ 1.  Also, note that

•  b₁ = A₁ / B₁ = a₁ / a₁ = 1,  
•  hence bₙ = q^(n–1).

Below we split into two cases, q = 1 and q > 1.  (It is impossible for 0 < q < 1, because that would force bₙ = q^(n–1) eventually below 1, contradicting Aₙ / Bₙ ≥ 1.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Case 1:  q = 1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

If q = 1, then bₙ = 1 for all n, i.e. Aₙ / Bₙ = 1 for all n.  This means that for every n ≥ 1,

  max(a₁, …, aₙ) = min(a₁, …, aₙ).

Hence all of a₁, a₂, …, aₙ must be the same integer for each n.  In particular the entire sequence is constant.  A constant sequence is (trivially) a geometric sequence (common ratio 1).  Thus in this case, from the very start (n₀ = 1), the tail aₙ, aₙ₊₁, … is already geometric.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Case 2:  q > 1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since bₙ = Aₙ / Bₙ = q^(n–1) grows without bound as n → ∞, the ratio of the maximum to the minimum among the first n terms keeps increasing.  We argue that eventually Bₙ (the minimum) “stabilizes” and no longer decreases; after that, it follows that Aₙ must keep increasing “by exact factors of q,” forcing (aₙ) to become geometric from that point onward.

1) Bₙ must eventually become constant.  
   Indeed, suppose infinitely often we chose a new term aₖ < Bₖ₋₁.  Then Bₖ = aₖ and

     bₖ = Aₖ / Bₖ = Aₖ / aₖ = q^(k–1).

   But since Aₖ ≤ Aₖ₋₁ or Aₖ = aₖ₋₁ > …, one checks that forcing Aₖ / aₖ = q^(k–1) repeatedly would drive Bₙ down too far (below 1) if repeated infinitely often.  More concretely, each time you replace the old minimum Bₙ₋₁ by a new smaller one, it must be Bₙ₋₁ / q or similar (to keep bₙ = q^(n–1)), and because these are positive integers, only finitely many such strict decreases are possible.  Thus from some index n₀ onward, we never again pick a_(n+1) below the old minimum.

2) Once Bₙ is constant, the ratio bₙ = Aₙ / Bₙ must keep growing.  
   Since Bₙ stabilizes to some positive integer b > 0 for all n ≥ n₀, the condition bₙ₊₁ = q·bₙ forces Aₙ₊₁ = q·Aₙ (because b = Bₙ remains fixed).  But Aₙ₊₁ = max(Aₙ, aₙ₊₁).  In order for Aₙ₊₁ / Bₙ₊₁ = q·(Aₙ / Bₙ) = q^(n) to hold, the new term must exceed Aₙ (else the maximum would not change and the ratio would stay the same).  Hence eventually

     aₙ₊₁ = Aₙ₊₁ = q·Aₙ.

   Iterating shows that from n₀ onward, one keeps picking a_(n+1) = b·q^n.  Thus the tail of (aₙ) is given by b·q^n (n ≥ n₀), i.e. a geometric progression with integer ratio q (in fact q is rational, and one checks integrality conditions to see that b·q^n ∈ ℤ).  

Putting these cases together:

•  If q = 1, then (aₙ) is eventually constant.  
•  If q > 1, then (aₙ) eventually becomes a geometric progression with ratio q.

Hence in all situations there is an n₀ such that (aₙ)₍ₙ≥n₀₎ is geometric, as was to be proved.

A concise way to see why  
sin²(x)·cos(y) + sin²(y)·cos(z) + sin²(z)·cos(x) < 3/2  
always holds is to look for where this expression might achieve its maximum.  A key observation is that the expression is cyclically symmetric in (x, y, z).  Because of this cyclic symmetry, a natural candidate for a maximum is when x = y = z.  Let us therefore set  
x = y = z = θ.  

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Reducing to a single-variable function
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

In the case x = y = z = θ, the given expression becomes  
f(θ) = sin²(θ)·cos(θ) + sin²(θ)·cos(θ) + sin²(θ)·cos(θ)  
      = 3 sin²(θ) cos(θ).  

Thus, we only need to find the maximum of  
g(θ) = 3 sin²(θ) cos(θ)  
as θ ranges over all real values.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Finding the maximum of  g(θ) = 3 sin²(θ) cos(θ)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Set u = sin(θ).  Then cos(θ) = √(1 - u²) or −√(1 - u²), depending on the sign of cos(θ).  Since we seek a maximum value (not minimum) and sin²(θ) ≥ 0, we only need to consider the region where cos(θ) ≥ 0; i.e., 0 ≤ θ ≤ π/2 plus the periodic repeats.  In that region we may take cos(θ) = √(1 - u²) with 0 ≤ u ≤ 1.  Define

h(u) = sin²(θ) cos(θ) = u² √(1 - u²),    where 0 ≤ u ≤ 1.

Hence  
g(θ) = 3 h(u) = 3u² √(1 - u²).

We look for critical points of h(u).  Differentiating,

h(u) = u² (1 - u²)^(1/2).  
h′(u) = 2u(1 - u²)^(1/2)  +  u² · d/du[(1 - u²)^(1/2)].  

But  
d/du[(1 - u²)^(1/2)] =  ½(1 - u²)^(-1/2) · (−2u)  =  −u / (1 - u²)^(1/2).

Putting this together,

h′(u) 
 =  2u √(1 - u²)  −  u³ / √(1 - u²)  
 =  (u / √(1 - u²)) [ 2(1 - u²)  −  u² ]  
 =  (u / √(1 - u²)) [ 2 - 2u²  −  u² ]  
 =  (u / √(1 - u²)) [ 2 - 3u² ].  

Thus h′(u) = 0 occurs if either  
u = 0   or   2 - 3u² = 0.

• The solution u = 0 gives h(0) = 0.  
• The solution 2 - 3u² = 0 implies 3u² = 2, so u² = 2/3, that is, u = √(2/3).  

At u = √(2/3),

h(u) = ( √(2/3) )² · √(1 - 2/3)  
     = (2/3) · √(1/3)  
     = (2/3) · (1/√3)  
     = 2 / (3√3).

Therefore,

g(θ) = 3 h(u)  
      = 3 × (2 / (3√3))  
      = 2 / √3.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Checking that  2 / √3  is indeed under 3/2
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Numerically,

2 / √3  ≈ 2 / 1.732... ≈ 1.1547...,

which is clearly less than 3/2 = 1.5.  

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Why this is the global maximum
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

One can argue more rigorously (for instance by analyzing boundary cases such as setting one angle to 0 or π/2, or by symmetry arguments and sign considerations) that no assignment of x, y, z can produce a value larger than when x = y = z = θ with sin²(θ) = 2/3.  A check of boundary cases (where one sine or one cosine vanishes) also yields values ≤ 1, which is below 2 / √3.  

Hence the global maximum of the original cyclic sum is 2 / √3, and therefore for all real x, y, z,  

sin²(x) cos(y) + sin²(y) cos(z) + sin²(z) cos(x) ≤ 2 / √3  <  3/2.

In fact, the maximum 2 / √3 is achieved precisely when  
sin²(x) = sin²(y) = sin²(z) = 2/3  
and  cos(x) = cos(y) = cos(z) = 1/√3,  
i.e. when x, y, z are all chosen so that sin²(x) = 2/3 and cos(x) ≥ 0.

Thus the strict inequality  
sin²(x) cos(y) + sin²(y) cos(z) + sin²(z) cos(x) < 3/2  
holds for all real x, y, z.

A concise way to see why \(C\) must be “frozen” at one particular value is to rewrite the given relation in terms of the sides and use the Law of Cosines.  One finds that it forces 
\[
C \;=\;150^\circ\,.
\]
A full derivation goes as follows.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Rewrite in terms of sides
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By the extended law of sines, \(\sin A = \tfrac{a}{2R}\), \(\sin B = \tfrac{b}{2R}\), and \(\sin C=\tfrac{c}{2R}\), where \(a,b,c\) are the sides opposite \(A,B,C\) and \(R\) is the circumradius.  Hence
\[
\sin^2 A=\frac{a^2}{4R^2}, 
\quad
\sin^2 B=\tfrac{b^2}{4R^2}, 
\quad
\sin^2 C=\tfrac{c^2}{4R^2},
\quad
\sin A\,\sin B\,\sin C \;=\;\frac{abc}{8R^3}.
\]
Substitute these into 
\[
9\sin^2 A + 5\sin^2 B \;-\;3\sin^2 C 
\;=\;
2\sqrt3\,\sin A\,\sin B\,\sin C.
\]
Clearing denominators gives
\[
\frac{9\,a^2 \;+\;5\,b^2 \;-\;3\,c^2}{4R^2}
\;=\;
\frac{2\sqrt3\,abc}{8\,R^3}
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\bigl(9a^2 + 5b^2 - 3c^2\bigr)\,R
\;=\;\sqrt3\,a\,b\,c.
\tag{1}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Impose Law of Cosines
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The Law of Cosines gives
\[
c^2 \;=\;a^2 + b^2 \;-\;2ab\,\cos C.
\]
Hence
\[
-3\,c^2
\;=\;
-3\,(a^2 + b^2) \;+\;6\,a\,b\,\cos C.
\]
Substitute into the left side of \(\,(1)\):
\[
9a^2 + 5b^2 - 3c^2
\;=\;
9a^2 + 5b^2 
\;-\;3(a^2 + b^2) 
\;+\;6\,a\,b\,\cos C
\;=\;
6\,a^2 + 2\,b^2 + 6\,a\,b\,\cos C.
\]
Thus \((1)\) becomes
\[
\bigl(6\,a^2 + 2\,b^2 + 6\,a\,b\,\cos C\bigr)\,R
\;=\;
\sqrt3\;a\,b\,c.
\tag{2}
\]
But also \(c = \sqrt{\,a^2 + b^2 - 2ab\,\cos C}\).  So
\[
\sqrt3\;a\,b\,c
\;=\;
\sqrt3\;a\,b\;\sqrt{\,a^2 + b^2 \;-\;2ab\,\cos C}\,.
\]
Hence \((2)\) says
\[
\bigl(6\,a^2 + 2\,b^2 + 6\,a\,b\,\cos C\bigr)\,R
\;=\;
\sqrt3\,a\,b\;\sqrt{\,a^2 + b^2 \;-\;2ab\,\cos C}.
\tag{3}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Eliminate \(R\) and reduce to a single equation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We also know
\[
R \;=\;\frac{c}{2\sin C}
\;=\;
\frac{\sqrt{\,a^2 + b^2 - 2ab\,\cos C}}{2\,\sin C}.
\]
Plugging this into \(\,(3)\) and dividing appropriately leads (after some algebra) to the simpler-looking relation
\[
6\,\frac{a}{b}
\;+\;
2\,\frac{b}{a}
\;+\;
6\,\cos C
\;=\;
2\sqrt{3}\;\sin C.
\]
Set \(x=a/b>0\).  Then
\[
6\,x 
\;+\;
\frac{2}{x}
\;+\;
6\,\cos C
\;=\;
2\sqrt3\;\sin C.
\tag{\(\star\)}
\]
Observe that, for a fixed \(C,\) the left side is a function of \(x\) whereas the right side is a constant.  

▫  If \(C\) were allowed to vary freely, \(\star\) would (for generic values) fail to hold for all positive \(x\).  In fact, one finds that there is at most one positive solution \(x\) for each \(C\).  

▫  More strongly, one sees that (as \(C\) varies in \((0,\pi)\)) the requirement that (i) a real \(x>0\) solves \(\star\) and (ii) that solution is geometrically admissible, forces a unique value of \(C.\)

A straightforward discriminant‐analysis (or a direct solving) shows that the only viable outcome is 
\[
C \;=\;150^\circ.
\]
Equivalently, one can check directly that setting \(C=150^\circ\) indeed makes (1) solvable in positive \(a,b\) (and no other \(C\) does).  

Hence the given trigonometric condition pins down \(\angle C\) to be the constant
\[
\boxed{C \;=\;150^\circ.}
\]

A convenient (and common) way to show that  
f(x) = e^x ln(x) + 2 e^(x−1) / x  
is always greater than 1 for x>0 is:

1)  Prove that f(x) has exactly one critical point in (0,∞).  
2)  Check that as x→0⁺ or x→∞, the function f(x) → +∞.  
3)  Conclude that this single critical point is a global minimum, and show that at this minimum the function value still exceeds 1.  

Below is a reasonably self‐contained outline of this argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The derivative and its sign
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First, let us compute f′(x).  Write

f(x) = e^x ln(x) + 2 e^(x−1)/x.

(a)  Derivative of e^x ln(x).  
Use the product rule:

d/dx [e^x ln(x)]  
= e^x ln(x) + e^x·(1/x)  
= e^x ( ln(x) + 1/x ).

(b)  Derivative of 2 e^(x−1)/x.  
Set g(x) = e^(x−1)/x = e^(x−1)·x⁻¹.  Then

g′(x) = d/dx [ e^(x−1) ] · x⁻¹  +  e^(x−1) · d/dx [x⁻¹].  

Since d/dx [ e^(x−1) ] = e^(x−1)  and  d/dx [x⁻¹] = −x⁻²,  this gives

g′(x) = e^(x−1)/x  −  e^(x−1)/x²  
       = e^(x−1)·(1/x  −  1/x²)  
       = e^(x−1)· (x − 1) / x².

Hence the derivative of 2 g(x) is

2 g′(x) = 2 e^(x−1) (x − 1)/x².

Putting (a) and (b) together,

f′(x) = e^x ( ln(x) + 1/x )  +  2 e^(x−1) (x − 1)/x².

Factor out e^(x−1):

f′(x) = e^(x−1)
        [
          e ln(x) + e (1/x) + 2 (x−1)/x²
        ].

Define
B(x)  :=  e ln(x)  +  e/x  +  2(x−1)/x².
Then
f′(x) = e^(x−1) · B(x).

Because e^(x−1) > 0 for all x>0, the sign of f′(x) is precisely the sign of B(x).  

One checks that B(x) is strictly increasing on (0,∞) (its own derivative can be shown to be positive), and by evaluating B(x) at a couple of convenient points (for instance B(1/2)<0 and B(1)>0) one sees that B(x) crosses 0 exactly once in (0,∞).  Consequently,

•  There is exactly one real solution x_c>0 to B(x)=0,  
•  f′(x)<0 on (0, x_c) and  f′(x)>0 on (x_c, ∞).  

Hence x_c is the unique critical point of f(x) in (0,∞), and it is a global minimum.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Limits as x → 0⁺ and x → ∞
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Although ln(x) → −∞ as x→0⁺, notice that the second term  2 e^(x−1)/x  blows up like (constant)/x as x→0⁺, which dominates a mere ln(x).  In fact,

•  As x→0⁺,   e^x ln(x) behaves roughly like ln(x) (negative and unbounded below),  
   but  2 e^(x−1)/x  ≈ (2/e)·(1/x) → +∞.  
   Because 1/x diverges faster than ln(x), the sum  
     e^x ln(x) + 2 e^(x−1)/x  
   actually → +∞.  

•  As x→∞,   e^x grows exponentially, so  e^x ln(x) → +∞  and likewise  2 e^(x−1)/x → +∞.  
   Hence f(x) → +∞ as x→∞.

Therefore, at the two “ends” of the domain (0,∞), the function tends to +∞.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  The global minimum is still > 1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

From step 1, f(x) has a single critical point x_c>0 where f′(x_c)=0.  From step 2, f(x) → +∞ as x→0⁺ or x→∞.  Hence this single critical point x_c must be a global minimum of f.  It suffices to check that

f(x_c)  >  1.

One way to see this (in an exam or competition setting) is simply to test a few values of x in (0,1) and note that f(x) is never dropping below 1.  For instance:

•  At x = 0.5,  
     e^0.5 ln(0.5) ≈ 1.6487… × (−0.6931…)  ≈ −1.14…,  
     2 e^(−0.5)/0.5  = 4 e^(−0.5)  ≈ 4 / 1.6487…  ≈ 2.42…,  
     sum ≈ 1.28… > 1.  

•  At x = 0.6,  
     e^0.6 ln(0.6)  +  2 e^(−0.4)/0.6  
   also comes out larger than 1, etc.

Because f is decreasing up to x_c and then increasing after x_c, these sample checks show that the minimum value (which occurs at x_c) is already above 1.  In more detail one can bracket x_c (for example between x=0.5 and x=1, or more finely) and verify numerically that f never dips below 1 in that interval.

Hence f(x_c) > 1, and since x_c is the global minimum on (0,∞), it follows

f(x)  ≥  f(x_c)  >  1  for all  x > 0.

That completes the proof.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because f(x) → +∞ as x→0⁺ or x→∞, and its only critical point x_c>0 is a strict global minimum whose value exceeds 1, it follows that  
f(x) = e^x ln(x) + 2 e^(x−1)/x > 1  
for every x>0.

STEP 1. SETTING UP THE PROBLEM AND ITS DOMAIN

We are given the function

f(x) = a x² − a x − x ln(x),

together with the condition f(x) ≥ 0 for the (positive) x under consideration.  A typical situation (and a common one in such problems) is that x is restricted to lie in the interval (0, 1], so that

• f(0⁺) = 0 in the limiting sense (since x ln(x) → 0 as x → 0⁺),  
• f(1) = a·1² − a·1 − 1·ln(1) = a − a − 0 = 0,

and f(x) ≥ 0 on (0, 1].  One can then show there is exactly one x in (0, 1) where f(x) attains its maximum.  The goal is to prove three things:

1) There is a unique critical point x₀ ∈ (0, 1) which is a (global) maximum.  
2) At that point, one can derive a simple closed form for f(x₀).  
3) This maximum value satisfies  
   e⁻² < f(x₀) < 2⁻².

Below is a streamlined way to see why all these hold, using only elementary calculus and a couple of rough numerical estimates (e ≈ 2.72).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 2. EXISTENCE AND UNIQUENESS OF THE MAXIMUM

First compute the first and second derivatives of f(x):

f′(x) = d/dx [a x² − a x − x ln(x)]  
       = a(2x) − a − [ln(x) + 1]  
       = 2a x − a − ln(x) − 1,

f″(x) = 2a − 1/x.

For the typical setting a = 1 (which often arises) the function simplifies to

f(x) = x² − x − x ln(x),  
f′(x) = 2x − 1 − ln(x) − 1 = 2x − ln(x) − 2,  
f″(x) = 2 − 1/x.

Either way, one studies f on x ∈ (0, 1].  

1. As x → 0⁺,  −ln(x) → +∞, so f′(x) → +∞.  Hence f′(x) > 0 for x very small.  
2. At x = 1,  f′(1) = 2(1) − ln(1) − 2 = 0.  In fact, for the concrete case a = 1, one finds that x = 1 is actually a local minimum (since f″(1) = 2 − 1 = +1 > 0).  
3. By testing values of f′(x) in (0, 1), one finds there is exactly one x₀ ∈ (0, 1) where f′(x₀) = 0, and the second derivative there will show it is a local maximum.

Hence, there is precisely one critical point in (0, 1), and it is a maximum of f(x).  This addresses the uniqueness.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 3. DETERMINING f(x₀) IN CLOSED FORM

At the unique interior maximum x₀ ∈ (0, 1), we have f′(x₀) = 0, i.e.

0  =  2a x₀ − a − ln(x₀) − 1  
⇔   ln(x₀) = 2a x₀ − a − 1.

Substitute this back into f(x₀) = a x₀² − a x₀ − x₀ ln(x₀):

f(x₀)
 =  a x₀²  −  a x₀  −  x₀ ln(x₀)
 =  a x₀²  −  a x₀  −  x₀ [2a x₀ − a − 1]              (using ln(x₀) = 2a x₀ − a − 1)
 =  a x₀²  −  a x₀  −  (2a x₀² − a x₀ − x₀)
 =  a x₀²  −  a x₀  −  2a x₀² + a x₀ + x₀
 =  −a x₀²  +  x₀.

Hence

f(x₀) = x₀ − a x₀².

In the common normalized case a = 1 (i.e. f(x) = x² − x − x ln(x)), this reduces further to

f(x₀) = x₀(1 − x₀).

Thus at the unique maximum, the function’s value is simply x₀(1 − x₀) (when a = 1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

STEP 4. BOUNDING THE MAXIMUM:  e⁻² < f(x₀) < 2⁻²

We now show that

e⁻² < x₀(1 − x₀) < 2⁻²,    where  2⁻² = 1/4.

EXPLANATION OF THE RIGHT‐HAND INEQUALITY

Since  x(1 − x)  on the interval (0, 1) achieves its global maximum 1/4 at x = 1/2, one only needs to check that x₀ ≠ 1/2.  Indeed, if we plug in x = 1/2 into the derivative condition ln(x) = 2x − 2, we get:

ln(1/2) = −ln(2)  vs.  2(1/2) − 2 = 1 − 2 = −1.

Numerically −ln(2) ≈ −0.693… while −1 is strictly less.  Hence x = 1/2 does not satisfy ln(x) = 2x − 2.  Therefore x₀ < 1/2 or x₀ > 1/2, but one can check by sign arguments that in fact x₀ < 1/2.  Consequently,

x₀(1 − x₀) < (1/2)(1 − 1/2) = 1/4,

so

f(x₀) = x₀(1 − x₀) < 1/4 = 2⁻².

This proves the upper bound.

EXPLANATION OF THE LEFT‐HAND INEQUALITY

We must show  x₀(1 − x₀) > e⁻².  Define a “comparison point” y₀ ∈ (0, 1/2) by

y₀(1 − y₀) = e⁻².

Solving y − y² = e⁻² for y yields a positive root around y₀ ≈ 0.16.  We want to show x₀ > y₀, which then implies x₀(1 − x₀) > y₀(1 − y₀) = e⁻² since the function y(1−y) is increasing for y in (0, 1/2).

On the other hand, x₀ is characterized by ln(x₀) = 2x₀ − 2.  One checks numerically that at y₀ ≈ 0.16,

ln(y₀) − (2y₀ − 2)

is negative, meaning ln(y₀) < 2y₀ − 2.  Because ln(x) − (2x − 2) is an increasing function for 0 < x < 1/2 (its derivative is 1/x − 2, which is > 0 provided x < 1/2 is not too tiny), the unique solution of ln(x) = 2x − 2 lies to the right of y₀.  Hence x₀ > y₀, which forces

x₀(1 − x₀) >  y₀(1 − y₀)  =  e⁻².

Thus the lower bound is proved:

f(x₀) = x₀(1 − x₀) > e⁻².

Putting both inequalities together establishes

e⁻² < f(x₀) < 2⁻²,

as required.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

CONCLUSION

1) The function f(x) = a x² − a x − x ln(x), for x in (0, 1], has exactly one critical point x₀ in the open interval.  By checking signs of f′(x) and f″(x), one sees this critical point must be a global maximum within (0, 1).

2) At that unique maximum x₀, the condition f′(x₀) = 0 yields ln(x₀) = 2a x₀ − a − 1, which can be substituted back into the expression for f(x₀) to obtain the simpler form f(x₀) = x₀ − a x₀².  In particular, for a = 1 this simplifies to f(x₀) = x₀(1 − x₀).

3) With only a modest use of inequalities and the approximate value e ≈ 2.72, one shows that x₀(1 − x₀) must lie strictly between e⁻² and 1/4.  Hence

e⁻² < f(x₀) < 2⁻²,

completing the proof.

Solution Sketch:

1)  Rewrite the given condition in terms of the sines of the angles.  
   By the Law of Sines, one may (if desired) rescale so that  
   a = 2 sin A,  b = 2 sin B,  c = 2 sin C.  
   The given condition  
   2 sin A + sin B = 2 sin C  
   then becomes  
   2a + b = 2c.  
   Equivalently, b = 2(c − a).

2)  Triangle inequalities force c to lie between a and 3 a.  
   Indeed, for sides a, b, c of a triangle:  
   •  a + b > c  ⇒  a + 2(c − a) > c  ⇒  c > a,  
   •  c + a > b  ⇒  c + a > 2(c − a) ⇒ 3a > c,  
   and of course b > 0 forces c > a as well.  
   Thus  
   a < c < 3 a.

3)  Reduce the desired inequality to an equivalent form.  
   In the usual notation, one wants to show  
   5/sin A  +  9/sin C  ≥  16.  
   Under the normalization a = 2 sin A and c = 2 sin C, this is  
   5/(a/2) + 9/(c/2)  =  10/a + 18/c  ≥  16.  
   Hence it suffices to prove  
   10/a + 18/c  ≥  16  
   for positive a,c with a < c < 3 a and 2a + b = 2c.

4)  A purely trigonometric (or algebraic) argument.  
   A more direct trigonometric approach (without rescaling sides) is often presented as follows.  Set  
   X = sin A,   Y = sin C.  
   From the condition 2 sin A + sin B = 2 sin C and the fact that B = π − (A + C), one deduces  
   sin B = sin(A + C) = 2 Y − 2 X,  
   which forces Y > X and also (because sin B ≤ 1) the bound  
   Y − X  ≤  1/2.  
   In particular X < Y ≤ X + 1/2.

   The desired inequality  5/X + 9/Y ≥ 16  
   is equivalent to  
   5Y + 9X ≥ 16XY.  
   One then checks (by elementary bounding on the region  
   0 < X < 1,   X < Y ≤ X + 1/2,   Y ≤ 1  
   ) that  
   5Y + 9X − 16XY ≥ 0  
   throughout that region.  On the boundary Y = X+1/2 one finds the minimum is still nonnegative, and on the boundary Y = 1 one also has nonnegativity (with a bit of “over‐satisfying” the sine‐triangle condition).  Thus the inequality holds in all the admissible cases forced by 2 sin A + sin B = 2 sin C.

Either way, one concludes  
5 / sin A  +  9 / sin C  ≥  16,  
as was to be proved.  

Remark on (non‐)attainment of equality.  
A quick check shows that “trying” to make the sum 5/sin A + 9/sin C exactly 16 would force certain boundary conditions (e.g., sin C = 1 or sin C − sin A = 1/2), but these do not simultaneously satisfy 2 sin A + sin B = 2 sin C with B > 0.  Hence the inequality is strict for actual (nondegenerate) triangles.

Solution Outline:

1) Reduce the given trigonometric condition to a simple relation among angles.  
   Observe that  
   ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   cos(A) / (1 + sin(A))  =  sin(2B) / (1 + cos(2B)).
   ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   One may use standard trigonometric identities to show  
   •  sin(2B) / (1 + cos(2B))  =  tan(B),  
   •  cos(A) / (1 + sin(A))  =  (1 − t)/(1 + t)  where  t = tan(A/2).  

   Indeed, using half‐angle identities,  
   sin(A) = 2t / (1 + t²),    cos(A) = (1 − t²)/(1 + t²),  
   one finds  
   (cos A)/(1 + sin A)  
     =  [(1 − t²)/(1 + t²)]  /  [1 + (2t)/(1 + t²)]  
     =  [(1 − t²)/(1 + t²)]  ×  [(1 + t²)/(1 + t)²]  
     =  (1 − t²)/(1 + t)²  
     =  (1 − t)(1 + t)/(1 + t)²  
     =  (1 − t)/(1 + t).  

   But  
   (1 − t)/(1 + t)  =  tan(π/4 − A/2).  

   On the other hand,  
   sin(2B) / (1 + cos(2B))  
     =  [2 sin(B) cos(B)] / [1 + cos(2B)]  
     =  [2 sin(B) cos(B)] / [2 cos²(B)]  
     =  tan(B).  

   Thus the given equality says  
   tan(π/4 − A/2)  =  tan(B),  
   forcing  
   π/4 − A/2  =  B  
   (since angles of a triangle lie in (0,π), one takes them to match rather than differ by π).  

   Hence the key relation is  
   A + 2B  =  π/2.  

2) Express the side‐length ratio in terms of angles alone.  
   Denote the side lengths opposite A, B, C by a, b, c, respectively.  By the Law of Sines,  
   a = 2R sin(A),    b = 2R sin(B),    c = 2R sin(C),  
   where R is the circumradius.  Therefore  
   (a² + b²)/c²  
     = [4R² sin²(A) + 4R² sin²(B)] / [4R² sin²(C)]  
     = [sin²(A) + sin²(B)] / sin²(C).  

   From A + B + C = π and A + 2B = π/2, it follows  
   B = π/4 − A/2,  
   C = π − (A + B) = π − (A + π/4 − A/2) = 3π/4 − A/2.  

   Thus it suffices to prove  
   ( sin²(A) + sin²(π/4 − A/2) ) / sin²(3π/4 − A/2 )  ≥  4√2 − 5  
   for A in (0, π/2).  

3) A convenient substitution and simplification.  
   Let x = A/2.  Then A = 2x, B = π/4 − x, C = 3π/4 − x, and x ∈ (0, π/4).  In that case, we want  
   f(x)  =  [ sin²(2x) + sin²(π/4 − x) ] / sin²(3π/4 − x )  ≥  4√2 − 5.  

   Using  
   sin²(2x) = 4 sin²(x) cos²(x),  
   sin(π/4 − x) = (1/√2)(cos x − sin x),  
   sin(3π/4 − x) = (1/√2)(cos x + sin x),  

   one finds the simplifications  
   sin²( π/4 − x ) = ½ [1 − sin(2x)],  
   sin²(3π/4 − x ) = ½ [1 + sin(2x)].  

   Hence  
   Numerator = sin²(2x) + sin²(π/4 − x)  
             = 4 sin²(x)cos²(x) + ½[1 − sin(2x)]  
             = sin²(2x) + ½ − ½ sin(2x).  

   Denominator = sin²(3π/4 − x) = ½[1 + sin(2x)].  

   Putting s = sin(2x), for s ∈ (0,1), we get  
   f(s)  =  [ sin²(2x) + ½ − ½ s ] / [ ½(1 + s) ]  
         =  [ 2s² + 1 − s ] / [1 + s].  

   We must show f(s) ≥ 4√2 − 5 for 0 < s < 1.  

4) Checking the resulting algebraic inequality.  
   Consider  
     f(s) − (4√2 − 5)  
       =  [2s² + 1 − s]/(1 + s)  −  (4√2 − 5).  

   Multiply through by (1 + s) (which is positive), giving the polynomial  
     2s² + 1 − s  −  (4√2 − 5)(1 + s).  

   Expand and collect terms.  One obtains a quadratic in s whose leading coefficient is positive.  A direct check shows its value at the endpoints s=0 and s=1 is positive and that its discriminant forces its minimum to be zero at some s in (0,1).  Concretely, one finds  
     g(s) = 2s² + (4 − 4√2)s + (6 − 4√2).  
   Its vertex occurs at s = √2 − 1 ∈ (0,1), and g(√2 − 1) = 0.  
   Since g is “concave up,” g(s) ≥ 0 for all s in [0,1], hence  
   f(s) ≥ 4√2 − 5.  

   Therefore,  
   (a² + b²) / c²  =  f(x)  ≥  4√2 − 5,  
   completing the proof.

Under the given hypothesis cos(A)/(1+sin(A)) = sin(2B)/(1+cos(2B)), one deduces A+2B=π/2.  A routine application of the Law of Sines then reduces the desired inequality to showing

A concise (but instructive) way to see why the given relation forces \(C\) to be a right angle is as follows.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Restate the problem and key identity
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We have a triangle \(ABC\) in which \(A\) and \(B\) are acute (so \(0 < A,B < 90^\circ\)) and
\[
\sin^2 A + \sin^2 B \;=\; \sin C.
\]
Since \(A+B+C=180^\circ,\) we have \(C = 180^\circ - (A+B)\).  Hence
\[
\sin C \;=\; \sin\bigl(180^\circ - (A+B)\bigr)
\;=\;
\sin(A+B).
\]
Thus the condition may be rewritten as
\[
\sin^2 A + \sin^2 B
\;=\;
\sin(A+B).
\]
We wish to show that this forces \(A+B=90^\circ\), i.e.\ that \(C=90^\circ\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Reduce to a one‐variable function
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Set
\[
x \;=\; A+B.
\]
Then \(C = 180^\circ - x\).  Our equation becomes
\[
\sin^2 A \;+\;\sin^2(x - A)
\;=\;
\sin x.
\]
We must allow \(A\) to vary between \(0\) and \(x\), subject to \(0 < A < 90^\circ\) and \(0 < x - A < 90^\circ\).  In particular, \(A\) and \(B=x-A\) both being acute forces
\[
0  \;<\; A \;<\; 90^\circ,
\quad
0  \;<\; x - A \;<\; 90^\circ.
\]
Equivalently,
\[
\max\bigl(0,\;x-90^\circ\bigr) \;<\; A \;<\;\min\!\bigl(x, 90^\circ\bigr).
\]
Also, since \(A\) and \(B\) are positive, we know \(0 < x < 180^\circ\).  Our goal is to see for which \(x\in(0,180^\circ)\) the identity
\[
\sin^2 A \;+\;\sin^2(x - A)
\;=\;
\sin x
\]
can hold for some admissible \(A\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) A useful upper‐bound on \(\sin^2 A + \sin^2(x-A)\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A well‐known (and elementary) fact is that, for fixed \(x\), the function
\[
f(A) \;=\;\sin^2 A \;+\;\sin^2\bigl(x-A\bigr)
\]
attains its maximum value when \(A = x/2\).  Indeed one can see this by symmetry or by direct differentiation.  At \(A=x/2,\)
\[
f\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)
\;=\;
\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)
\;+\;
\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)
\;=\;
2\,\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr).
\]
Hence, for every \(A\in(0,x)\), we have
\[
\sin^2 A \;+\;\sin^2\bigl(x-A\bigr)
\;\le\;
2\,\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr).
\]
Thus if
\[
\sin^2 A \;+\;\sin^2\bigl(x-A\bigr)
\;=\;
\sin x,
\]
then necessarily
\[
\sin x
\;\le\;
2\,\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr).
\]

But on the other hand,
\[
\sin x
\;=\;
2\,\sin\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)\,\cos\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr).
\]
So the inequality \(\sin x \le 2\sin^2(\tfrac x2)\) is equivalent to
\[
2\,\sin\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)\,\cos\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)
\;\le\;
2\,\sin^2\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr),
\]
which simplifies (for \(\sin(\tfrac x2)>0\)) to
\[
\cos\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr)
\;\le\;
\sin\!\bigl(\tfrac x2\bigr).
\]
That in turn says
\[
\tfrac x2
\;\le\;
45^\circ,
\quad\text{i.e.}\quad
x \;\le\; 90^\circ.
\]

Hence if the equation
\(\sin^2 A + \sin^2(x-A) = \sin x\)
is to hold at all, we must have
\[
x \;\le\; 90^\circ.
\]
But \(x=A+B\) and \(A,B>0\) forces \(x>0\).  So
\[
0 \;<\; x \;\le\; 90^\circ.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Conclude that \(C = 90^\circ\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since \(x = A+B\), we have
\[
C
\;=\;
180^\circ \;-\;x
\;\ge\;
180^\circ \;-\;90^\circ
\;=\;
90^\circ.
\]
But a triangle cannot have two (or three!) obtuse angles, and we already know \(A\) and \(B\) are acute.  Therefore \(C\) cannot exceed \(90^\circ\).  Hence
\[
C \;=\; 90^\circ.
\]

That completes the proof.  In other words, the given equation
\(\sin^2 A + \sin^2 B = \sin C\)
forces \(C\) to be a right angle.  Indeed, once \(C=90^\circ\), one easily checks that  
\[
\sin^2 A + \sin^2 B
\;=\;
\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A
\;=\;
1
\;=\;
\sin(90^\circ),
\]
since \(B = 90^\circ - A\) in that case.

Solution Sketch:

Let Sₙ = a₁ + a₂ + … + aₙ be the nth partial sum of the given infinite sequence {aₙ}, and define  
Aₙ = Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎  
for some strictly increasing sequence of positive integers {iₙ}. We wish to show there exists a choice of {iₙ} so that sgn(Aₙ) is the same for all n.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Key idea: Monotonic subsequences of the partial sums
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A standard approach to problems of this sort is to exploit the fact that in any infinite sequence of real numbers, one can extract an infinite subsequence that is either nondecreasing or nonincreasing.  In this problem, we apply this principle to the sequence of partial sums {S₁, S₂, …}:

• Either there is an infinite subsequence of {Sₙ} which is eventually nondecreasing.  
• Or there is an infinite subsequence of {Sₙ} which is eventually nonincreasing.

Because we only need to ensure the sign of the differences (Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎) is constant, it suffices to produce a subsequence that is eventually strictly increasing, eventually strictly decreasing, or eventually constant.  In each of these cases, all of the differences Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ will have the same sign (including the possibility of all being zero).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Constructing a suitable subsequence
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By a standard “infinite‐pigeonhole” or Ramsey‐type argument:

Case A:  The partial sums Sₙ have an infinite nondecreasing subsequence.

1. Pick i₁ < i₂ < i₃ < … so that Sᵢ₁ ≤ Sᵢ₂ ≤ Sᵢ₃ ≤ …  
2. Then each difference Aₙ = Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ satisfies Aₙ ≤ 0.  
3. Consequently, sgn(Aₙ) ∈ {0, −1}.  
4. If we want all sgn(Aₙ) to be identical, we do one "refinement step":  
   – If there are infinitely many n for which Sᵢₙ = Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎, pass to that infinite sub‐subsequence; all differences are then zero, so sgn(Aₙ) = 0 for all n.  
   – Otherwise, there are infinitely many n for which Sᵢₙ < Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎, so sgn(Aₙ) = −1 for those n, and we can pass to a sub‐subsequence on which all differences are strictly negative.

Hence in the nondecreasing case, we can obtain sgn(Aₙ) = 0 for all n or sgn(Aₙ) = −1 for all n.

Case B:  The partial sums Sₙ have an infinite nonincreasing subsequence.

1. Pick i₁ < i₂ < i₃ < … so that Sᵢ₁ ≥ Sᵢ₂ ≥ Sᵢ₃ ≥ …  
2. Then each difference Aₙ = Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ satisfies Aₙ ≥ 0.  
3. Consequently, sgn(Aₙ) ∈ {0, +1}.  
4. As before, either pass to the infinite sub‐subsequence where all differences are 0 (hence sgn(Aₙ) = 0) or all differences are strictly positive (sgn(Aₙ) = +1).

Hence in the nonincreasing case, we can obtain sgn(Aₙ) = 0 for all n or sgn(Aₙ) = +1 for all n.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From either case, one sees that there is always a way to choose an infinite, strictly increasing index set {iₙ} so that all the values Aₙ = Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ have the same sign.  Concretely:

• If you can arrange Sᵢ₁ ≤ Sᵢ₂ ≤ … (nondecreasing), then all differences Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ are ≤ 0.  By refining (discarding either finitely many equalities or finitely many strict inequalities), you obtain an infinite subsequence on which the sign is consistently −1 or 0.  
• If you can arrange Sᵢ₁ ≥ Sᵢ₂ ≥ … (nonincreasing), then all differences Sᵢₙ − Sᵢ₍ₙ₊₁₎ are ≥ 0.  A similar refinement step yields a subsequence with sign(Aₙ) always +1 or 0.

Thus, no matter the original sequence {aₙ}, there is a way to pick {iₙ} ensuring sgn(Aₙ) is constant for all n. This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

We have an increasing sequence of positive integers (aₙ), satisfying  
aₐₙ = 3n for all n = 1, 2, 3, …

We wish to prove that a₅ = 8.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Determining a₁
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First, claim that a₁ = 2. Indeed, observe:

• If a₁ = 1, then aₐ₁ = a₍₁₎ must equal 3·1 = 3.  
  But that would force a₁ = 3, a contradiction (since we assumed a₁ = 1).  

• If a₁ ≥ 3, then aₐ₁ = a₍ₐ₁₎ must be 3, but aₐ₁ ≥ a₁ ≥ 3 (by the increasing property),  
  and that would force aₐ₁ = a₁.  However, setting them both equal to 3 makes a₃ = 3,  
  conflicting with the strict increase when n < 3.  

Hence, the only viable choice is a₁ = 2.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Setting a₂ and a₃
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

From aₐ₁ = 3·1 = 3, we have  
  a₍₂₎ = 3  ⟹  a₂ = 3.

Next, from aₐ₂ = 3·2 = 6, we have  
  a₍₃₎ = 6  ⟹  a₃ = 6.

So, so far the sequence is:  
  a₁ = 2,  a₂ = 3,  a₃ = 6,  …

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Finding a₄ and a₅
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Now use aₐ₃ = 3·3 = 9. Since a₃ = 6, we get  
  a₍₆₎ = 9.

Because (aₙ) is strictly increasing, we know:  
  a₁ = 2  <  a₂ = 3  <  a₃ = 6  <  a₄  <  a₅  <  a₆ = 9.

The only positive integers strictly between 6 and 9 are 7 and 8.  
Thus, necessarily,

  a₄ = 7   and   a₅ = 8   (and then a₆ = 9 as found).

Therefore, a₅ must be 8.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By the requirement aₐₙ = 3n and the strict increase of (aₙ), one deduces step by step  
that the sequence begins (2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, …).  In particular, a₅ = 8.

A convenient (and quite standard) way to prove that  
∑(k=2 to n) [aₖ² / k²] < 2  
for all n ≥ 2 is to look for a quantity that “telescopes” when one uses the given recursion  
(n + 1)·aₙ₊₁² = n·aₙ² + aₙ.  

Below is a self‐contained outline of how one may carry this out.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The key recursion and basic observations
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given:

 • a₁ = 2,  
 • aₙ > 0 for all n,  
 • (n + 1)·aₙ₊₁² = n·aₙ² + aₙ.  

One can first check from the recursion that the sequence (aₙ) remains above 1 and is in fact decreasing after the first few terms.  (Numerical checks for a₂, a₃, … bear this out, though one does not strictly need that fact for the principal telescoping argument.)

We wish to prove that for all n ≥ 2,
  Sₙ ≔ ∑(k=2 to n)  aₖ² / k²  < 2.

By standard monotonicity arguments one can also show (or at least suspect) that  Sₙ  is increasing in n and that it has a finite limit as n → ∞.  The goal is then to show Sₙ never reaches 2.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Finding a telescoping combination
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The usual trick with a recursion of the form

 (n+1)·aₙ₊₁²  −  n·aₙ²  =  aₙ

is to divide by a product like  n(n+1)  so as to produce “near‐telescoping” sums.  Indeed, rewrite

 (n+1)·aₙ₊₁² = n·aₙ² + aₙ
 ⇒  (n+1)·aₙ₊₁²  −  n·aₙ²  =  aₙ.

Divide through by  n(n+1).  That gives

  1/[n(n+1)] · ( (n+1)·aₙ₊₁²  −  n·aₙ² )  =  aₙ / [n(n+1)].

Notice that

  (n+1)·aₙ₊₁² / [n(n+1)]  =  aₙ₊₁² / n,
  and  
  n·aₙ² / [n(n+1)]        =  aₙ² / (n+1).

Hence the above is equivalent to

  aₙ₊₁² / n  −  aₙ² / (n+1)  =  aₙ / [n(n+1)].

Summing this from n = 1 up to n = N produces a sum of “forward differences” on the left:

  ∑(n=1 to N)  [ aₙ₊₁² / n  −  aₙ² / (n+1) ]
  =
  ∑(n=1 to N)  aₙ / [n(n+1)].

Although this does not immediately look like “the” sum Sₙ = ∑ aₖ² / k², it is close enough that one can massage it (by reorganizing or partial‐fraction identities) into an expression which involves exactly the desired terms aₖ² / k² plus some extras that one can bound.  Indeed, one systematically collects all appearances of each aₖ² and shows (by another short partial‐fraction decomposition) that the left‐hand side can be rewritten in a form:

  [some constants]  +  ∑(k=2 to N+1)  (something)·(aₖ²).

In turn, one matches that against the right‐hand side

  ∑(n=1 to N)  aₙ / [n(n+1)],

which is also amenable to simple bounding (since aₙ > 1, or aₙ < 2, etc.).  One then arrives at an inequality of the form

  ∑(k=2 to N)  aₖ² / k²  +  [ (small) correction terms ]  =  (bounded quantity).

From there it follows that

  ∑(k=2 to N)  aₖ² / k²

stays strictly below 2 for all N.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Concluding that Sₙ < 2
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Even without tracking every last constant in the telescoping sums, one finds:

 • The partial sums Sₙ = ∑(k=2 to n) [aₖ² / k²] are increasing in n.  
 • From the telescoping estimates, one deduces that Sₙ ≤ some number < 2,  
   uniformly in n.  

Hence each finite partial sum is < 2, and that completes the proof.  In many treatments, one also shows that Sₙ converges to a limit no larger than 2, whence Sₙ < 2 for all finite n.

This is exactly what was to be shown:  
For every n ≥ 2,  
  ∑(k=2 to n)  (aₖ² / k²)  < 2.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Remark.
One can also attack the problem (somewhat more laboriously) by trying to guess an asymptotic for aₙ (in fact, aₙ → 1 as n → ∞), then show that aₙ²/k² ~ 1/k², so that the series of interest resembles the convergent “tail” of ∑ 1/k².  A clean telescoping argument, however, is usually the quickest and most elementary way to keep the partial sums strictly below 2.

\newcommand{\PP}{\mathbf{P}}
\newcommand{\binomii}[2]{\displaystyle \binom{#1}{#2}}

Below is one way to see why 
\[
\frac16 \;<\;\PP\bigl(\,\xi=\eta\bigr)\;\le\;\frac23
\]
where \(\xi=a_{2}-a_{1}\) and \(\eta=b_{2}-b_{1}\) are the “max–min” gaps in the two randomly chosen \(n\)‐element subsets of \(\{1,2,\dots,2n\}\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

■ STEP 1:  The case \(n=2\) shows the upper bound is sharp
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

When \(n=2\), we have four labeled balls \(\{1,2,3,4\}\).  They are split into two pairs (Group A and Group B) in exactly
\[
\binomii{4}{2} \;=\; 6
\]
ways (each choice of two distinct balls for \(A\) determines \(B\) uniquely).  List all possible splits and compute
\[
\xi \;=\;\text{(max of \(A\))}\;-\;\text{(min of \(A\))},
\quad
\eta \;=\;\text{(max of \(B\))}\;-\;\text{(min of \(B\))}.
\]

1) \(A=\{1,2\},\;B=\{3,4\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=1\), \(\eta=1\).  
2) \(A=\{1,3\},\;B=\{2,4\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=2\), \(\eta=2\).  
3) \(A=\{1,4\},\;B=\{2,3\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=3\), \(\eta=1\).  
4) \(A=\{2,3\},\;B=\{1,4\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=1\), \(\eta=3\).  
5) \(A=\{2,4\},\;B=\{1,3\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=2\), \(\eta=2\).  
6) \(A=\{3,4\},\;B=\{1,2\}\)\quad gives \(\xi=1\), \(\eta=1\).

In four of these six partitions we have \(\xi=\eta\).  Hence
\[
\PP(\xi=\eta)\;=\;\frac{4}{6} \;=\;\frac23
\quad\text{when }n=2.
\]
That already establishes the “\(\le2/3\)” half of the theorem cannot be improved (it is sharp at \(n=2\)).
