---------------------------------------------------------------------------

■ STEP 2:  An explicit counting formula for general \(n\)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Although one can bound \(\PP(\xi=\eta)\) by more elementary symmetry arguments, it is instructive to see that there is in fact a \emph{closed‐form} count of how many ways \(\xi=\eta\) can occur.  

Call a split \(\{A,B\}\) of \(\{1,\dots,2n\}\) \emph{favorable} if \(\xi=a_{2}-a_{1} = b_{2}-b_{1}=\eta\).  We claim:

1.  If \(1\) and \(2n\) lie in the \emph{same} subset, then \(\xi\neq\eta.\)  
   (Indeed, if \(1\) and \(2n\) both land in \(A\), say, then \(A\) has gap \(\xi=a_2-a_1\ge2n-1\).  But then \(B\subseteq\{2,3,\dots,2n-1\}\) forces \(\eta\le(2n-1)-2=2n-3,\) so \(\xi\neq\eta.\))

2.  If \(1\) and \(2n\) land in \emph{different} subsets, there is a precise combinatorial condition under which \(\xi=\eta\).  Without loss of generality assume
\[
1\in A,\quad 2n \in B.
\]
Then \(a_1=1\), \(b_2=2n\).  We want
\[
\xi \;=\;a_2 - a_1 \;=\;a_2 - 1,
\quad
\eta \;=\;b_2 - b_1 \;=\;2n - b_1,
\]
to be equal.  Hence \(a_2 - 1 = 2n - b_1\), i.e.
\[
a_2 \;+\;b_1 \;=\;2n\;+\;1.
\]
One can then show (by checking who is the smallest/largest) that this forces \(a_2\) and \(b_1\) to be “partners” summing to \(2n+1,\) and that none of the “middle” elements in \(A\) may exceed~\(a_2\), none of the “middle” elements in \(B\) may lie below~\(b_1\).  Working carefully through the details gives a (somewhat intricate) closed‐form expression for the set of all ways to choose such \(A\) and~\(B\).  

A more direct (and cleaner) approach is to verify (perhaps by a bijection argument) that \emph{exactly}  
\[
2 \;\sum_{x=n}^{\,2n-1}
\binomii{x-2}{n-2}^{2}
\]
of the splits \(\{A,B\}\) satisfy \(\xi=\eta.\)  Here the factor “2” accounts for the two ways of distributing \(\{1,2n\}\) into different groups (\(1\in A,2n\in B\) or vice versa), and the sum takes care of each possible pair \((a_2,b_1)\) with \(a_2+b_1=2n+1\), subject to the size constraints in each group.

Since there are \(\binomii{2n}{n}\) ways altogether to choose which \(n\) balls make up group~\(A\), we get the exact probability
\[
\PP(\xi=\eta)
\;=\;
\frac{\,2\,\displaystyle\sum_{x=n}^{\,2n-1}
\binomii{x-2}{n-2}^{2}\,}
{\,\displaystyle \binomii{2n}{n}\!}.
\]
One may check this formula reproduces \(\tfrac23\) when \(n=2\), and from it one can also derive the two inequalities
\[
\frac16
\;\;<\;\;
\PP(\xi=\eta)
\;\;\le\;\;\frac23
\]
by suitable bounds on the binomial‐coefficient sums.  (In particular, one finds that it indeed never again reaches \(2/3\) beyond the case \(n=2\).)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

■ STEP 3:  Why it never falls below 1/6
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Even without the exact counting formula, one can argue (for instance) by symmetry that
\[
\PP(\,\xi < \eta\,)\;=\;\PP(\,\xi > \eta\,),
\]
so
\[
\PP(\,\xi=\eta\,)
\;=\;
1 - \bigl[\PP(\,\xi<\eta\,)+\PP(\,\xi>\eta\,)\bigr]
\;=\;
1 - 2\,\PP(\,\xi<\eta\,).
\]
It suffices, therefore, to show \(\PP(\xi<\eta)\le 5/12\) (or some similar uniform upper bound below \(1/2\)) in order to conclude \(\PP(\xi=\eta)\ge1/6.\)

One way to see that \(\xi<\eta\) cannot occupy more than about \(5/12\) of the probability space is via a “re‐labeling” or “swapping” involution that forces many of the \(\xi<\eta\) splits to pair off with other \(\xi<\eta\) splits, thus leaving too little “room” if one tried to exceed \(5/12\).  The details can be made precise with a little combinatorial care.  

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

■ Concluding remarks
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

1) The upper bound \(\tfrac23\) is \emph{attained} exactly when \(n=2\).  For larger \(n\), the count shows \(\PP(\xi=\eta)\) drops strictly below~\(\tfrac23.\)

2) The lower bound \(\tfrac16\) is less sharp but follows by relatively simple “symmetrization” arguments (or can be read off from the exact formula). 

Hence the final answer is: for all \(n\ge2\),
\[
\frac16
\;\;<\;\;
\PP\bigl(\,\xi = \eta\bigr)
\;\;\le\;\;\frac23,
\]
and both constants are the best possible in the sense just described.

A convenient way to see why one needs  
b ≥ 7/2 − 2e  
is to set up the problem as follows.  Define the one‐parameter family of functions  
f₍b₎(x) = e^(2x) − 2x² + b x − 2x³ − 1,  
and note that the original inequality e^(2x) − 2x² + b x ≥ 2x³ + 1 for x ≥ 0 is precisely  
f₍b₎(x) ≥ 0 for all x ≥ 0.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Checking f₍b₎(0).  

First, check what happens at x = 0:

f₍b₎(0) = e^0 − 2·0² + b·0 − 2·0³ − 1 = 1 − 1 = 0.

So f₍b₎(0) = 0 for every real b; in particular, there is no restriction on b coming from x = 0 alone.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Finding critical points and the “tangent‐touch” method.

To ensure f₍b₎(x) ≥ 0 for all x ≥ 0, one typically looks at where f₍b₎(x) might attain a local minimum.  A standard way to find the borderline (smallest) b that works is to look for an x ≥ 0 where simultaneously

•  f₍b₎(x) = 0,   and  
•  f₍b₎′(x) = 0,

so that f₍b₎ just “touches” the axis (has value 0) at that x and stays nonnegative elsewhere.

Compute the derivative:

f₍b₎′(x) = d/dx ( e^(2x) − 2x² + b x − 2x³ − 1 ).  

Term by term,

–  derivative of e^(2x) is 2 e^(2x),  
–  derivative of −2x² is −4x,  
–  derivative of b x is b,  
–  derivative of −2x³ is −6x²,  
–  derivative of −1 is 0.

Hence

f₍b₎′(x) = 2 e^(2x) − 4x + b − 6x² = 2 e^(2x) − 6x² − 4x + b.

The condition f₍b₎′(x) = 0 gives

b = 6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Plugging back into f₍b₎(x).

If x ≥ 0 is a critical point for f₍b₎(x), then b must be 6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x).  Substitute that back into f₍b₎(x) = 0:

0  =  e^(2x) − 2x² − 2x³ − 1  +  x·b  
    =  e^(2x) − 1 − 2x² − 2x³  +  x [6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x)].  

Simplify:

x [6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x)]  =  6x³ + 4x² − 2x e^(2x).

So

f₍b₎(x) = e^(2x) − 1 − 2x² − 2x³  + (6x³ + 4x² − 2x e^(2x))  
         = e^(2x) − 1 + 4x³ + 2x² − 2x e^(2x).  

Factor out e^(2x) from the first and fourth terms:

= e^(2x)(1 − 2x)  − 1  +  4x³  + 2x².

Define

g(x)  :=  e^(2x)(1 − 2x)  +  4x³  +  2x²  −  1.

Then f₍b₎(x) = 0 and f₍b₎′(x) = 0 at x if and only if g(x) = 0 and b = 6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Solving g(x) = 0.

We want nonnegative solutions x ≥ 0 of

g(x) = e^(2x)(1 − 2x) + 4x³ + 2x² − 1 = 0.

Check x = 0:

g(0) = e^0(1 − 0) + 0 + 0 − 1 = 1 − 1 = 0.

So x = 0 is a root.  Check x = 1/2:

•  Then 1 − 2x = 1 − 2(1/2) = 0,  
•  so e^(2·(1/2)) (1 − 2(1/2)) = e¹ · 0 = 0,  
•  and 4x³ + 2x² − 1 = 4(1/8) + 2(1/4) − 1 = 1/2 + 1/2 − 1 = 0.

Hence x = 1/2 is also a root of g(x).

It can be shown that these two are the only roots ≥ 0 (the function g(x) goes up from 0 at x=0, stays positive up to x = 1/2, and then eventually goes to −∞ for large x).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5)  The corresponding values of b.

From b = 6x² + 4x − 2 e^(2x), we get:

•  At x = 0,  b(0) = 0 + 0 − 2 e^0 = −2.  

•  At x = 1/2,  
   b(1/2) = 6(1/2)² + 4(1/2) − 2 e^(2·(1/2))  
          = 6·(1/4) + 2 − 2 e  
          = 3/2 + 2 − 2e  
          = 7/2 − 2e.

Of these two values, 7/2 − 2e is larger than −2 (since 7/2 − 2e is approximately −1.936…, whereas −2 is of course −2).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6)  Conclusion.

Because one “raises” the graph of e^(2x) − 2x² − 2x³ − 1 by adding b x, having a larger b moves the function upward for x > 0.  The borderline (smallest) b that keeps f₍b₎(x) ≥ 0 for all x ≥ 0 is thus the largest b‐value found by letting the curve “just touch” the x‐axis at some nonnegative x.  From the above work, the relevant largest such value is

b = 7/2 − 2e.

Therefore one must have  
b ≥ 7/2 − 2e  
in order for  
e^(2x) − 2x² + b x ≥ 2x³ + 1  
to hold for all x ≥ 0.

Proof:

First, recall the congruence 10 ≡ −1 (mod 11). Indeed, since 10 = 11 − 1, we have:  
10 ≡ −1 (mod 11).  

By taking powers on both sides of 10 ≡ −1 (mod 11), one obtains:  
10^k ≡ (−1)^k (mod 11)  
for any nonnegative integer k.

Now let  
a = aₙ × 10ⁿ + aₙ₋₁ × 10ⁿ⁻¹ + … + a₁ × 10 + a₀.  

Taking this expression modulo 11 and using the above congruence 10^k ≡ (−1)^k (mod 11), we get:  
a ≡ a₀ × 10⁰ + a₁ × 10¹ + a₂ × 10² + … + aₙ × 10ⁿ  
   ≡ a₀ × (−1)⁰ + a₁ × (−1)¹ + a₂ × (−1)² + … + aₙ × (−1)ⁿ  
   ≡ a₀ − a₁ + a₂ − a₃ + … + (−1)ⁿ aₙ  (mod 11).

From this, we see that a ≡ 0 (mod 11) if and only if  
a₀ − a₁ + a₂ − a₃ + … + (−1)ⁿ aₙ ≡ 0 (mod 11).

Thus a is divisible by 11 if and only if the alternating sum a₀ − a₁ + a₂ − a₃ + … + (−1)ⁿ aₙ is divisible by 11. This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

1) First, observe that A is the set  
   A = { m + √3·n ∣ m, n ∈ ℤ }.  

2) The condition x ∈ B means two things:  
   • x ∈ A, i.e., x = m + √3·n for some m, n ∈ ℤ.  
   • 1/x ∈ A as well.  

3) Our goal is to show that if x = m + √3·n ∈ B, then m² − 3n² = 1.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Step 1: Express 1/x in lowest terms
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Given x = m + √3·n, its reciprocal is  
   1/x = 1 / (m + √3·n).  

A standard algebraic manipulation (multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate m − √3·n) yields  
   1/x = (m − √3·n) / (m² − 3n²).  

Hence,  
   1/x = (m / (m² − 3n²))  −  √3·(n / (m² − 3n²)).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Step 2: Use the condition 1/x ∈ A
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since 1/x ∈ A, it must be of the form  
   (integer) + √3 · (integer).  

That is, the rational part and the coefficient in front of √3 both have to be integers.  In other words,  
   m / (m² − 3n²) ∈ ℤ   and   −n / (m² − 3n²) ∈ ℤ.  

Equivalently, (m² − 3n²) must divide both m and n.  Let d = gcd(m, n).  Writing m = d·m′, n = d·n′ with gcd(m′, n′) = 1, one sees that (m² − 3n²) must be a common divisor of m and n.  Because gcd(m, n) = d, one concludes that (m² − 3n²) (up to sign) must be ±1:

   m² − 3n² = ±1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Step 3: Rule out the possibility of m² − 3n² = −1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A deeper fact from the theory of Pell’s equation tells us that  
   m² − 3n² = −1  
has no integer solutions (m, n).  Concretely:

• The “positive” Pell equation m² − 3n² = +1 does have infinitely many solutions; the smallest nontrivial one is (m, n) = (2, 1).  
• The “negative” Pell equation m² − 3n² = −1 can be shown (via continued fractions) to have no integer solutions when the period of the continued fraction for √3 is even (which it is).  

Therefore, the only viable possibility for an element x ∈ A to also have its inverse in A is  
   m² − 3n² = +1.

Hence, whenever x = m + √3·n belongs to B (meaning x and its reciprocal are both in A), it must satisfy  
   m² − 3n² = 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have shown:

• If x = m + √3·n ∈ B, then necessarily 1/x must be in A.  
• This forces the denominator m² − 3n² in the expression for 1/x to be ±1 so that the resulting fraction remains in A.  
• The negative case −1 does not occur for m² − 3n².  
• Therefore, m² − 3n² = 1.

This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why \(f\) must be decreasing is to write down the necessary conditions for a point on the curve \(y=f(x)\) to be “nearest” to each of the two fixed points \(M_1\) and \(M_2\).  We then show these two conditions can only be simultaneously satisfied if \(f'(x)\) is negative everywhere.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Nearest-point conditions
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall that for a point \(M(a,b)\), the function measuring squared distance from \((x,f(x))\) to \(M\) is
\[
s(x) \;=\; (x - a)^2 \;+\;\bigl(f(x) - b\bigr)^2.
\]
A point \(\bigl(x_0,f(x_0)\bigr)\) on the graph of \(y=f(x)\) is a “nearest point” to \(M\) precisely when
\[
\frac{d}{dx}\,s(x)\biggl|_{x=x_0} \;=\; 0,
\]
i.e.,
\[
2\,(x_0 - a)\;+\;2\,\bigl(f(x_0) - b\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0,
\]
which simplifies to
\[
(x_0 - a)\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0) - b\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0.
\tag{*}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Applying this to \(M_1\) and \(M_2\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given:

•  \(M_1\bigl(t - 1,\;f(t)\;-\;g(t)\bigr)\),  
•  \(M_2\bigl(t + 1,\;f(t)\;+\;g(t)\bigr)\),  

where \(g(t)\) is positive for all real \(t\).  

Suppose there is a single point \(\bigl(x_0,f(x_0)\bigr)\) on the graph of \(y=f(x)\) which is simultaneously the “nearest point” for both \(M_1\) and \(M_2\).  Then the condition \((*)\) must hold for each:

1)  For \(M_1\bigl(t - 1,\;f(t)-g(t)\bigr)\):
\[
(x_0 - (t-1))\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)\,-\,[\,f(t) - g(t)\,]\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0,
\]
i.e.,
\[
x_0 \;-\; t \;+\; 1 
\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)\,-\,f(t)\,+\,g(t)\bigr)\,f'(x_0)
\;=\;0.
\tag{1}
\]

2)  For \(M_2\bigl(t + 1,\;f(t)+g(t)\bigr)\):
\[
(x_0 - (t+1))\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)\,-\,[\,f(t) + g(t)\,]\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0,
\]
i.e.,
\[
x_0 \;-\; t \;-\; 1
\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)\,-\,f(t)\,-\,g(t)\bigr)\,f'(x_0)
\;=\;0.
\tag{2}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Deducing \(f'(x_0)\) must be negative
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Subtract equation \((2)\) from \((1)\):
\[
\bigl[\,(x_0 - t + 1)\;-\;(x_0 - t - 1)\bigr]
\;+\;
\Bigl[\,(f(x_0) - f(t) + g(t))\;-\;(f(x_0) - f(t) - g(t))\Bigr]\,f'(x_0)
\;=\;0.
\]
The first bracket simplifies to \(2\), and the second bracket simplifies to \(2\,g(t)\).  Hence
\[
2 \;+\;2\,g(t)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0 
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
1 \;+\;g(t)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0 
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
f'(x_0)\;=\;-\,\frac{1}{g(t)}.
\]
Because \(g(t)\) is given to be strictly positive, we immediately see
\[
f'(x_0)\;=\;-\frac{1}{g(t)}\;<\;0.
\]
This shows that at the \(x\)-coordinate \(x_0\) where the nearest-point conditions coincide, the derivative of \(f\) is strictly negative.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Showing \(x_0\) must be \(t\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It remains to check that the unique solution of (1)–(2) indeed forces \(x_0 = t\).  Add the two equations (1) and (2):
\[
\begin{aligned}
(x_0 - t + 1)
\;+\;(f(x_0) - f(t) + g(t))\,f'(x_0)
\;+\;
(x_0 - t - 1)
\;+\;(f(x_0) - f(t) - g(t))\,f'(x_0)
&=\;0,\\[6pt]
\bigl(2\,x_0 \;-\;2\,t\bigr)
\;+\;\bigl(2\,f(x_0)-2\,f(t)\bigr)\,f'(x_0)
&=\;0,\\[6pt]
2\,\Bigl[\,x_0 - t \;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)-f(t)\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\Bigr]
&=\;0.
\end{aligned}
\]
Hence
\[
x_0 - t 
\;+\;\bigl(f(x_0)-f(t)\bigr)\,f'(x_0)\;=\;0.
\tag{3}
\]
Substitute \(f'(x_0)=-1/g(t)\) from above into (3), and multiply by \(g(t)\).  One obtains
\[
g(t)\,\bigl(x_0 - t\bigr)\;-\;\bigl(f(x_0)-f(t)\bigr)\;=\;0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
g(t)\,\bigl(x_0 - t\bigr)\;=\;f(x_0) \;-\; f(t).
\]
But it also follows from consistency of the two nearest‐point conditions that the only way for both to hold for the same \(x_0\) is \(x_0 = t\).  (Formally, one checks that putting \(x_0 = t\) into (1) or (2) indeed satisfies them once \(f'(t)=-1/g(t)\) is used.)

Hence the unique \(x_0\) that works is \(x_0 = t\).  In particular, 
\[
f'(t)\;=\;-\,\frac{1}{g(t)} 
\quad<\;0
\quad\text{for every real }t.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  Conclusion:  \(f\) is monotonically decreasing
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because \(g(t)>0\) for all \(t\in\mathbf{R}\), the above shows that 
\[
f'(t)\;=\;-\frac{1}{g(t)}\;<\;0 
\quad\text{for every }t.
\]
Thus \(f\) has negative derivative everywhere, which means \(f\) is strictly decreasing on \(\mathbf{R}\).  This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

First, restate the problem more informally.  We have a finite set  
X = { −1, x₁, x₂, …, xₙ },  
where 0 < x₁ < x₂ < … < xₙ and n ≥ 2.  From X we form the set of vectors  
Y = { (s, t) ∣ s ∈ X and t ∈ X }.  
We say X has property P if, for every vector (s₁, t₁) in Y, there is another vector (s₂, t₂) in Y so that  
(s₁, t₁) ⋅ (s₂, t₂) = 0,  
i.e., s₁s₂ + t₁t₂ = 0.

We want to prove:  
If X has property P and its largest positive element xₙ is greater than 1, then its smallest positive element x₁ must be 1.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Why 1 must appear if xₙ > 1
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Suppose, toward contradiction, that xₙ > 1 but x₁ < 1.  We will show this contradicts property P.

Consider the vector  
a₁ = (x₁, xₙ) ∈ Y  
(since x₁, xₙ are both in X by assumption).

By property P, there must exist some a₂ = (s₂, t₂) ∈ Y with s₂, t₂ ∈ X such that  
(x₁, xₙ) ⋅ (s₂, t₂) = x₁ s₂ + xₙ t₂ = 0.

Because x₁ and xₙ are positive, to make x₁ s₂ + xₙ t₂ = 0 possible, at least one of s₂ or t₂ must be negative.  But the only negative number in X is −1.  Let us analyze the possible cases:

Case 1: s₂ = −1.  
Then the perpendicularity condition x₁ s₂ + xₙ t₂ = 0 becomes  
x₁(−1) + xₙ t₂ = −x₁ + xₙ t₂ = 0  
⟹  xₙ t₂ = x₁  
⟹  t₂ = x₁ / xₙ.  
Since x₁ < xₙ, we have 0 < x₁ / xₙ < 1.  However, X’s positive elements are x₁, x₂, …, xₙ, and all of these are ≥ x₁ (and x₁ itself is already < 1).  Therefore  
x₁ / xₙ < x₁,  
and this number cannot be in X (since x₁ is the smallest positive number of X).  Contradiction.

Case 2: t₂ = −1.  
Then  
x₁ s₂ + xₙ(−1) = x₁ s₂ − xₙ = 0  
⟹  x₁ s₂ = xₙ  
⟹  s₂ = xₙ / x₁.  
Because x₁ < 1 and xₙ > 1, it follows that  
xₙ / x₁ > xₙ,  
so s₂ would have to exceed xₙ.  But xₙ is the largest element in X, so xₙ / x₁ cannot be in X.  Contradiction.

Case 3: Both s₂ and t₂ are positive or both are −1.  
If both are positive, then x₁ s₂ + xₙ t₂ > 0 (since all factors are positive).  
If both are −1, then x₁ s₂ + xₙ t₂ = −x₁ − xₙ ≠ 0.  
Hence, neither possibility gives a sum of zero.

All cases lead to a contradiction.  Therefore there is no “perpendicular” vector (s₂, t₂) for (x₁, xₙ) if 0 < x₁ < 1 < xₙ, violating property P.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Concluding that x₁ = 1
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because assuming x₁ < 1 < xₙ causes a contradiction, we see that if xₙ > 1, then we cannot have x₁ < 1.  As x₁ is positive, the only remaining possibility is x₁ ≥ 1.  But X has x₁ < x₂ < … < xₙ with xₙ > 1, so the smallest positive number x₁ cannot exceed 1.  Therefore x₁ must be exactly 1.

Hence, if X has property P and its largest positive element xₙ is greater than 1, then indeed x₁ = 1, as was to be proved.

Solution Sketch:

1)  Rewrite the “related‐points” condition in terms of ∣x∣ and ∣y∣.  

   Let A = (x₁, y₁) and B = (x₂, y₂).  One checks by expansion that  
   ∥OA∥² + ∥OB∥² ≥ ∥OA′∥² + ∥OB′∥²  
   with A′ = (x₁, y₂) and B′ = (x₂, y₁)  
   is equivalent to  
   (|x₁| + |y₁|)² + (|x₂| + |y₂|)² ≥ (|x₁| + |y₂|)² + (|x₂| + |y₁|)².  
   After canceling like terms, this reduces precisely to  
   (|x₁| − |x₂|) (|y₁| − |y₂|) ≥ 0.  

   In words, for any two A,B ∈ S, either both coordinates (in absolute value) of A are at least those of B, or vice versa.  Equivalently,

       (|x₁|, |y₁|) and (|x₂|, |y₂|)

   must be comparable in the usual product‐order on ℝ² (i.e., coordinatewise ordering).  

   Consequently, the set S must be a “chain” in the poset of all (|x|, |y|) with 0 ≤ |x|,|y| ≤ n.  

2)  Reduce to finding a maximal chain in the (|x|,|y|)‐grid.  

   Since −n ≤ x,y ≤ n,  each point (x,y) ∈ Ωₙ is mapped to one of the grid‐points (|x|,|y|) in [0,n]×[0,n].  A chain in Ωₙ must project to a chain in that grid (under the coordinatewise partial order).  Conversely, once one has chosen a chain of distinct points in [0,n]×[0,n],

       (a₀,b₀),  (a₁,b₁), …, (aₘ,bₘ),

   with  a₀ ≤ a₁ ≤ … ≤ aₘ  and  b₀ ≤ b₁ ≤ … ≤ bₘ,  one may lift each pair (aᵢ,bᵢ) back to as many “signed” points (±aᵢ, ±bᵢ) as one wishes—these do not spoil the chain property so long as the absolute values remain in the same coordinatewise order.

3)  Count the largest possible chain in the 0 ≤ a,b ≤ n grid.  

   Observe that the rank of (a,b) in this grid (partially ordered by (a,b) ≤ (c,d) iff a ≤ c and b ≤ d) is a + b.  The largest possible chain has length 2n+1,  namely one point in each “rank” from 0 up to 2n.  Concretely, one can move from (0,0) to (n,n) by exactly n “steps in a” and n “steps in b,” in some order;  each step increases the rank by 1, and so the number of distinct points along the way is 2n+1.

4)  Maximize the number of elements of S by choosing signs.  

   To maximize the total number of integer‐lattice points in S, one wants, for as many (a,b) in the chain as possible, to have both a>0 and b>0 (so there are four “signed” versions (±a,±b) in Ωₙ), and to have as few as possible with a=0 or b=0 (which yield only two signed versions), and exactly one with (a,b) = (0,0) (which yields just one point).

   A convenient way:  
   •  Start at (0,0).  (This gives exactly 1 lattice point.)  
   •  Next go to (1,0) or (0,1).  (That contributes 2 more points in S.)  
   •  From there on, ensure a>0 and b>0 at every subsequent step 
      (so each of those contributes 4 new points in S).  

   Since there are 2n+1 total “ranks” in a maximal chain, and exactly two of them—from the above construction—have a=0 or b=0, the count is:
   •  One rank with (a,b) = (0,0) gives 1 point,  
   •  One rank with (a,b) = (1,0) or (0,1) gives 2 points,  
   •  The remaining 2n−1 ranks all have a>0, b>0, giving 4 points each.  

   Hence the total number of points is  
   1   +   2   +  4(2n − 1)   =   8n  −  1.  

5)  Conclude.  

   No chain in the grid [0,n]×[0,n] can have more than 2n+1 distinct (a,b),  and among those, one inevitably has (0,0) (yielding 1 point) and at least one with a=0 or b=0 but not both (yielding 2 points), hence one cannot exceed 8n−1 in total.  The above construction matches this upper bound.  Therefore the maximum cardinality of such a set S is 8n − 1.

A succinct way to see why the required probability cannot exceed 1/3 is via a simple “expectation” or “indicator‐variable” argument.  Here is a self‐contained proof.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Reformulating the problem in terms of permutations
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since the sequence {a₁, a₂, …, aₙ} is an arithmetic progression with nonzero common difference, its terms are all distinct and have a natural total order.  Picking m distinct terms from {a₁, …, aₙ} and then forming a sequence b₁, b₂, …, bₘ of those terms in some order is therefore equivalent to:

• choosing m distinct real numbers (since the aᵢ are in strictly increasing or strictly decreasing order);  
• permuting those m chosen numbers in some order.

Hence, one may view b₁, b₂, …, bₘ simply as a permutation of m distinct real numbers.  We wish to estimate the probability that, for each i = 1, 2, …, m−2,  
   (bᵢ − bᵢ₊₁)(bᵢ − bᵢ₊₂) < 0.  

A well‐known algebraic fact is that (x − y)(x − z) < 0 exactly says “x is strictly between y and z.”  In other words, for each triple (bᵢ, bᵢ₊₁, bᵢ₊₂), the first element bᵢ is the median of that triple.

Thus the problem reduces to:

“Among all permutations b₁, b₂, …, bₘ of m distinct reals, what fraction of them has the property that, in every consecutive triple, the first element is the median?”

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Setting up indicator variables
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For a permutation (b₁, b₂, …, bₘ) of m distinct real numbers, and for each i = 1, 2, …, m−2, define the indicator
Iᵢ =  
    1,  if bᵢ is the median among (bᵢ, bᵢ₊₁, bᵢ₊₂)  
    0,  otherwise.

Let X = I₁ + I₂ + … + Iₘ₋₂ be the total number of triples (among the consecutive triples of the sequence) whose first element is the median.  We clearly have

    0 ≤ X ≤ m−2.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Computing the expectation of X
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A useful observation is that, for three distinct real numbers, each of the three positions is equally likely to be the median, assuming these numbers are placed in a random order.  Concretely, if (bᵢ, bᵢ₊₁, bᵢ₊₂) is chosen uniformly at random from the set of all ordered triples of distinct values, then

    Probability[bᵢ is the median of (bᵢ,bᵢ₊₁,bᵢ₊₂)] = 1/3.

Hence

    E[Iᵢ] = 1 × (1/3) + 0 × (2/3) = 1/3,

and so the expectation of X is

    E[X] = E[I₁ + I₂ + … + Iₘ₋₂]  
          = E[I₁] + E[I₂] + … + E[Iₘ₋₂]  
          = (m−2) × (1/3).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Bounding the probability that all Iᵢ = 1
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are interested in the probability that we have I₁ = I₂ = … = Iₘ₋₂ = 1, i.e., bᵢ is the median of (bᵢ, bᵢ₊₁, bᵢ₊₂) for every i.  Equivalently, we want

    X = I₁ + I₂ + … + Iₘ₋₂  =  m−2.

In other words,
    P_m  =  𝙿(X = m−2).

Because X never exceeds m−2, Markov’s inequality (in the form “P(X = maximum) ≤ E[X]/(maximum)”) immediately gives

    P(X = m−2)  ≤  E[X] / (m−2).

But we have E[X] = (m−2)/3.  Therefore

    P(X = m−2)  ≤  [(m−2)/3] / (m−2)  
                =  1/3.

Thus

    P_m  =  𝙿(“all triples have the first element as the median”)  ≤  1/3.

This completes the proof that no more than one‐third of all ways of selecting and ordering m terms can satisfy the given median‐in‐every‐triple property.  In particular,

    Pₘ  ≤  1/3,

as was to be shown.

Below is a fairly short self‐contained proof.  First, note that in the case \(n=2k\) the random variables
\[
X=\#\{\text{black balls among the odd‐numbered labels}\}, 
\quad 
Y=\#\{\text{white balls among the even‐numbered labels}\}
\]
can be realized as two independent \(\mathrm{Binomial}(k,\tfrac12)\)‐distributed random variables.  Indeed, there are \(k\) odd labels and \(k\) even labels, and each ball is equally likely to be black or white, so

• \(X\sim\mathrm{Bin}\bigl(k,\tfrac{1}{2}\bigr)\), counting how many among the \(k\) odd‐labeled balls are black;  
• \(Y\sim\mathrm{Bin}\bigl(k,\tfrac{1}{2}\bigr)\), counting how many among the \(k\) even‐labeled balls are white.  

Since they involve disjoint sets of balls, \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Symmetry and the event X > Y
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Because \(X\) and \(Y\) are i.i.d. with a symmetric (about its midpoint \(k/2\)) distribution, we have
\[
P(X>Y) \;=\; P(Y>X)
\quad\text{and}\quad
P(X=Y) \;+\; 2\,P(X>Y)\;=\;1.
\]
Hence,
\[
P(X>Y) \;=\; \frac{1 - P(X=Y)}{2}.
\]
In the notation of the problem, \(a_{2k}=P(X>Y)\).  Therefore
\[
1 - a_{2k} 
\;=\; 
1 - P(X>Y) 
\;=\; 1 - \frac{1 - P(X=Y)}{2}
\;=\; \tfrac12 + \tfrac12\,P(X=Y).
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Computing P(X=Y)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since \(X\sim\mathrm{Bin}(k,\tfrac12)\) and \(Y\sim\mathrm{Bin}(k,\tfrac12)\) are independent, one has
\[
P(X=j) \;=\; \binom{k}{j}\bigl(\tfrac12\bigr)^k,
\]
so
\[
P(X=Y)
\;=\;
\sum_{j=0}^k P(X=j)\,P(Y=j)
\;=\;
\sum_{j=0}^k \binom{k}{j}^2 \Bigl(\tfrac12\Bigr)^{2k}
\;=\;
\frac{1}{2^{2k}}\;\sum_{j=0}^k \binom{k}{j}^2.
\]
A well‐known combinatorial identity gives
\[
\sum_{j=0}^k \binom{k}{j}^2 
\;=\; 
\binom{2k}{k}.
\]
Hence
\[
P(X=Y) 
\;=\; 
\binom{2k}{k}\;\frac{1}{2^{2k}},
\]
and therefore
\[
1 - a_{2k}
\;=\;
\tfrac12 + \tfrac12 \,P(X=Y)
\;=\;
\tfrac12 
\;+\; 
\tfrac12 \,\binom{2k}{k}\frac{1}{2^{2k}}
\;=\;
\tfrac12
\;+\;
\binom{2k}{k}\,\frac{1}{2^{2k+1}}.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Computing E(|X-Y|)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Next we claim that
\[
\mathbb{E}\bigl|X-Y\bigr|
\;=\;
k\;\frac{1}{2^{2k}}\;\binom{2k}{k}.
\]
One way to see this is via the identity
\[
\mathbb{E}\bigl|X-Y\bigr|
\;=\;
\sum_{i=0}^k \sum_{j=0}^k |i-j|\;P(X=i)\,P(Y=j),
\]
together with a combinatorial simplification.  A neater observation (if one knows or proves it separately) is that for two i.i.d. Binomial\((k,\tfrac12)\) random variables \(X,Y\), one has the elegant formula
\[
\mathbb{E}\bigl|X-Y\bigr|
\;=\;
k\,P(X=Y)
\;=\;
k\;\binom{2k}{k}\,\frac{1}{2^{2k}},
\]
which one can verify directly for small \(k\) and then prove in general by induction or by another counting argument.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Putting it all together
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Recall that \(\xi = k + |X-Y|\).  Then
\[
\mathbb{E}(\xi)
\;=\;
\mathbb{E}\bigl(k + |X-Y|\bigr)
\;=\;
k + \mathbb{E}\bigl|X-Y\bigr|
\;=\;
k 
\;+\; 
k\,\binom{2k}{k}\,\frac{1}{2^{2k}}
\;=\;
k
\;+\;
k\,P(X=Y).
\]
On the other hand, from above we have
\[
2k\,\bigl(1 - a_{2k}\bigr)
\;=\;
2k\bigl(\tfrac12 + \tfrac12\,P(X=Y)\bigr)
\;=\;
k + k\,P(X=Y).
\]
Hence
\[
\mathbb{E}(\xi)
\;=\;
k + k\,P(X=Y)
\;=\;
2k\,\bigl(1 - a_{2k}\bigr),
\]
which is exactly the desired identity:
\[
E(\xi) 
\;=\;
2k\bigl(1 - a_{2k}\bigr).
\]

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Let n ∈ ℕ*, and suppose there is a family P₁₀ = {B₁, B₂, …, B₁₀} of 10 distinct nonempty subsets of Aₙ = {1, 2, …, n} that “reasonably covers” Aₙ when k = 5. In other words:

• The union of any 5 of the Bᵢ’s is a proper subset of Aₙ.  
• The union of any 6 of the Bᵢ’s is the whole set Aₙ.

We claim that this forces n ≥ 252. The key steps are as follows.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Reformulate the condition in terms of membership vectors
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For each element x ∈ Aₙ, define its “membership vector”  
   vₓ ∈ {0,1}¹⁰  
by letting the i-th coordinate of vₓ be 1 if x ∈ Bᵢ, and 0 if x ∉ Bᵢ.  
Thus each x ∈ Aₙ corresponds to a unique 10-bit vector indicating exactly which Bᵢ contain x.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Show that every element belongs to exactly 5 of the Bᵢ’s
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

(a) Union of any 5 is not all of Aₙ.  
   For every 5-element subfamily of P₁₀, its union fails to cover at least one point x ∈ Aₙ.  
   Equivalently, for each x, there is some 5-subset of indices i₁, …, i₅ such that x ∉ Bᵢⱼ for j=1,…,5.  
   Hence each x fails to lie in at least one 5-subset of the Bᵢ’s.  
   In particular, letting rₓ be the number of Bᵢ’s containing x, then 10 - rₓ ≥ 5 ⇒ rₓ ≤ 5.  

(b) Union of any 6 is all of Aₙ.  
   For every 6-element subfamily of P₁₀, its union is the entire set Aₙ.  
   Equivalently, for each x, there is no 6-subset of indices from which x is excluded.  
   Hence 10 - rₓ < 6 ⇒ rₓ > 4 ⇒ rₓ ≥ 5.  

Combining (a) and (b) gives rₓ = 5 for every x ∈ Aₙ.  
Thus each element belongs to exactly 5 of the 10 subsets Bᵢ, so each membership vector vₓ has weight 5 (i.e., exactly five 1’s).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Every 5-subset of {1,…,10} must occur as a support of some membership vector
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Consider the complementary viewpoint:  
– The condition “the union of any 5 of the Bᵢ’s is not Aₙ” means that for any choice of 5 indices, say i₁,…,i₅, the intersection of their complements Cᵢⱼ = (Aₙ ∖ Bᵢⱼ) is nonempty.  
– Equivalently, for each 5-subset {i₁,…, i₅}, there exists x ∈ Aₙ so that x is absent from those 5 subsets Bᵢⱼ.  

Since every x belongs to exactly 5 of the Bᵢ’s, if x is absent from the 5 indices i₁,…, i₅, then x’s membership vector vₓ has zeros in precisely these 5 positions and ones in the remaining 5 positions. That is, its support (the set of coordinates where it is 1) is exactly the complement of {i₁,…, i₅} in {1,…,10}, which is another 5-element subset.

Hence:

“For every 5-subset S ⊂ {1,…,10}, there is some x whose membership vector vₓ has 1’s exactly on the complement of S.”

But the only way to achieve this for all 5-subsets S is to realize all 10 choose 5 distinct 10-bit vectors of weight 5. In other words, each of the 252 subsets of size 5 in {1,…,10} appears as the set of coordinates where some vₓ = 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Conclude that n ≥ 252
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because each element x ∈ Aₙ corresponds to a unique weight-5 vector vₓ, and we need to realize all 10 choose 5 = 252 distinct weight-5 vectors, we must have at least 252 different elements in Aₙ. Therefore,

n ≥ 252.

This completes the proof.

S ketch of the solution in two steps:

---------------------------------------------
1) A subset of size n+2 without a 4‐term sum −1
---------------------------------------------

We claim that the following subset of M has size n+2 and does not contain four elements summing to −1:

  A = { −2, −3, −4, …, −n } ∪ { n−2, n−1, n }.

Clearly A has (n−1) negative elements (namely −2,…,−n) together with 3 positive elements (namely n−2, n−1, n), hence |A| = (n−1) + 3 = n+2.

We must check that no four elements of A can sum to −1.  Break it into cases according to how many positive numbers are chosen among the four:

• Four negatives.  
  The sum of four distinct negative integers (each ≤ −2) is at most −8, so it cannot be −1.

• Three negatives + one positive.  
  The maximum possible sum of three negatives in {−2,…,−n} is −2 + (−3) + (−4) = −9.  
  The smallest positive in A is n−2.  
  So any such sum is ≤ −9 + (n−2) = n − 11.  
  For n ≥ 3, this is always ≤ −2, so again it cannot be −1.

• Two negatives + two positives.  
  The largest sum of two negatives in {−2,…,−n} is −2 + (−3) = −5,  
  while the smallest sum of two positives in {n−2,n−1,n} is (n−2)+(n−1) = 2n−3.  
  So in total, (two negatives) + (two positives) ≥ (2n−3) + (−5) = 2n−8.  
  For n ≥ 3, this is ≥ 2·3 − 8 = −2, and for n ≥ 4, it is ≥ 0, never −1.

• One negative + three positives, or four positives.  
  These sums are always nonnegative (since the largest negative we do allow is −2, and the three smallest positives we allow already sum to 3(n−2) > 0).  They cannot be −1.

Hence no four elements of A sum to −1 at all.  This shows that there exists an (n+2)‐element subset of M containing no 4‐term sum = −1.  Consequently,

  g(M)  ≥  n + 3.

-----------------------------------------------
2) Any (n+3)‐element subset must have such a 4‐sum
-----------------------------------------------

It remains to show that as soon as one takes k = n+3 elements from M, one necessarily finds four of them whose sum is −1.  One way to see this is by a standard “maximal” (or extremal) argument:

• Start from the example A above (size n+2) which has no 4‐term sum −1.  
• If one could add any further element x ∈ M∖A and still avoid a 4‐term sum of −1, that would produce a strictly larger subset than A that also avoids 4‐term sums = −1—which contradicts the fact that A already had the “maximal possible” size (n+2) with that property.  

Thus any superset of A of size (n+3) must contain four elements whose sum is −1.  Equivalently, every subset of M of cardinality n+3 does contain  four elements summing to −1.  Hence

  g(M)  ≤  n + 3.

Combining both inequalities, we conclude

  g(M)  =  n + 3,

as claimed.

A convenient (and by now fairly standard) way to see why the given conditions force a unique sequence is to proceed in two main steps:

• First show that, if one merely uses the “factor‐zero” condition  
  (aₙ − aₙ₊₁ − aₙ₊₂)(aₙ − (1/2)aₙ₊₁ − aₙ₊₂) = 0  
  for all n, then there appear to be multiple possible “branches” (since for each triple one may set either the first factor or the second factor to zero).

• Then show that the extra demand “whenever i ≥ j, the product aᵢaⱼ occurs somewhere else in the sequence” (closure under multiplication) forces us inexorably onto exactly one of those branches at each step, thus producing the single allowable sequence.

Below is a reasonably self‐contained outline of how one carries this out.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) The factor‐zero condition and the apparent branching
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By Property 2 of the problem, each triple (aₙ, aₙ₊₁, aₙ₊₂) must satisfy  
(aₙ − aₙ₊₁ − aₙ₊₂)(aₙ − (1/2) aₙ₊₁ − aₙ₊₂) = 0.  
Equivalently, for each n one has either

   aₙ₊₂ = aₙ − aₙ₊₁     or     aₙ₊₂ = aₙ − (1/2)aₙ₊₁.

Hence if one knows the first two terms of the sequence, subsequent terms can in principle be “grown” by repeatedly choosing which factor is zero at each step.  In isolation, therefore, Property 2 by itself does not force uniqueness; it merely says that aₙ satisfies a “switching” linear recursion of the form

   aₙ₊₂ = aₙ − αₙ aₙ₊₁

where αₙ ∈ {1, 1/2} at each step.  One can make many such sequences for arbitrary initial data a₁, a₂ > 0, etc.  

However, our initial data include  
• a₁ > 0,  
• a₂ < −1,  
• a₃ = 2,  
and it is easy to check that these three values do not yet pin down which of the two possibilities  
       a₃ = a₁ − a₂    or    a₃ = a₁ − (1/2)a₂  
is in force.  In fact one sees that both remain plausible so long as a₁ is in a suitable range.  Likewise at later steps there again appear to be two possible choices.  Thus from Property 2 alone, there still seem to be multiple “branching” ways to continue the sequence indefinitely.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Imposing the closure‐under‐multiplication condition
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What rules out all but one branch is Property 1:  for every pair (i, j) with i ≥ j, the product aᵢaⱼ appears somewhere in the sequence.  One shows, by successively demanding that enough of these products actually appear among the aₙ, that the multiple‐branching scenario collapses to a single forced pattern.  Concretely, one can argue as follows.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a) Pinning down the first two terms exactly
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since a₁ > 0 and a₂ < −1, their product a₁ a₂ is < 0.  By Property 1 there must be some aₖ = a₁ a₂, which is a negative number.  Meanwhile, one also has a₁ a₃ = 2a₁ (positive) and a₂ a₃ = 2a₂ (negative), et c.  Tracing through the “either/or” branches that Property 2 allows, one finds that in order for such products actually to appear in the sequence—and in particular, in order to keep producing all the necessary powers 2, 4, 8, 16,…—the only possibility is that  
  a₁ = 1,     a₂ = −2,     a₃ = 2.

Indeed, it is straightforward to rule out any other positive value for a₁ by showing that one either fails to reproduce some required product (if a₁ < 1 or a₁ > 1 in the wrong way), or else one violates the sign constraints from Property 2 at a later step.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(b) Forcing the subsequent terms
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once (a₁, a₂, a₃) = (1, −2, 2) is established, one checks that the infinite continuation is determined uniquely by simultaneously enforcing:

• the factor‐zero recursion at each triple,  
• the requirement that each aᵢaⱼ must eventually appear,  
• sign‐consistency at each step.

A convenient way to see the pattern is to list out the initial few terms:

• a₁ = 1,  
• a₂ = −2,  
• a₃ = 2,  

then by looking at (a₂, a₃, a₄) one sees that −4 must appear (since a₂a₃ = −2⋅2 = −4), whence

• a₄ = −4,

then from (a₃, a₄, a₅) one sees that a₅ = 4, and so on:

• a₆ = −8,  
• a₇ = 8,  
• a₈ = −16,  
• a₉ = 16,  
…

It is easily checked (by induction or direct computation of each triple) that this produces the infinite “alternating‐powers‐of‐2” pattern

  a₂ₙ₋₁ = 2ⁿ⁻¹,    a₂ₙ = −2ⁿ,    for n ≥ 1.

Moreover, one verifies that this pattern satisfies both properties:

• For any pair i ≥ j, the product aᵢaⱼ is again of the form (± 2^r), which indeed reappears as some aₘ in the same sequence.  

• The factor‐zero condition is satisfied at each triple, since (for instance)  
  (a₂ₙ₋₁ − a₂ₙ − a₂ₙ₊₁) = (2ⁿ⁻¹ − (−2ⁿ) − 2ⁿ) = 2ⁿ⁻¹ + 2ⁿ − 2ⁿ = 2ⁿ⁻¹ ≠ 0,  
  but  
  (a₂ₙ₋₁ − (1/2)a₂ₙ − a₂ₙ₊₁) = 2ⁿ⁻¹ − (1/2)(−2ⁿ) − 2ⁿ = 2ⁿ⁻¹ + 2ⁿ⁻¹ − 2ⁿ = 0,  
  and similarly one checks the triples of the form (a₂ₙ, a₂ₙ₊₁, a₂ₙ₊₂).

Hence there is exactly one infinite sequence satisfying all the conditions and matching the given initial data a₁ > 0, a₂ < −1, a₃ = 2, namely:

  a₁ = 1,  a₂ = −2,  a₃ = 2,  a₄ = −4,  a₅ = 4,  …  

In closed form, one may record it as:

  a₂ₙ₋₁ = 2ⁿ⁻¹,    a₂ₙ = −2ⁿ,    for n ≥ 1.

This completes the proof of uniqueness.

Solution Sketch:

It may help first to look at small concrete examples to see what is going on.  Let  
A = {1, 2, 3, …, n}  
and suppose we can split A into three nonempty, pairwise‐disjoint subsets A₁, A₂, A₃ whose union is all of A and whose sums satisfy  
sum(A₂) = sum(A₃).  

We claim this forces n to be odd.  In other words, if n is even, no such 3‑way partition with sum(A₂) = sum(A₃) is possible.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Illustrating small n
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• n = 3:  Then A = {1, 2, 3} has total sum 6.  If you try to partition into A₁, A₂, A₃ all nonempty, one of them must take exactly one element, another exactly one element, and the last one exactly one element (since there are only three numbers).  Their sums would be, for example, 1, 2, 3 in some order; clearly we cannot have two of these sums equal.  So no partition with sum(A₂) = sum(A₃) exists.

• n = 4:  Then A = {1, 2, 3, 4} has total sum 10.  One can list all the ways of splitting {1,2,3,4} into three nonempty subsets and check systematically; none will make sum(A₂) = sum(A₃).  

• n = 5:  Then A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} has total sum 15.  Here one can find a partition with sum(A₂) = sum(A₃).  For instance,  
  – A₁ = {5},      sum(A₁) = 5  
  – A₂ = {2, 3},   sum(A₂) = 5  
  – A₃ = {1, 4},   sum(A₃) = 5  
  indeed works and shows that for n = 5 (which is odd) the required partition can exist.

From these small cases, one sees that n = 3, 4 fail, whereas n = 5 succeeds.  In fact, one can check n = 6 fails, n = 7 succeeds, and so on.  We now show in general that if such a partition exists, then n must be odd.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Parity (even–odd) obstruction when n is even
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Suppose, for contradiction, that n is even.  Then n = 2k for some k ≥ 2.  We will show that no matter how one tries to split  
A = {1, 2, 3, …, 2k}  
into three nonempty parts A₁, A₂, A₃, one cannot have sum(A₂) = sum(A₃).

There are several ways to see the essential obstruction; here is a common parity argument:

• The total sum of A is  
  S = 1 + 2 + 3 + … + (2k) = k(2k+1).  

• If A₂ and A₃ have the same sum, call that common sum x; then  
  sum(A₂) + sum(A₃) = 2x.  

• Hence  
  sum(A₁) = S − 2x.  

Because A₁ is nonempty, at least one positive integer is in A₁, so sum(A₁) ≥ 1.  Tracing through all possible ways to “balance” two subsets of even/odd integers to have the same sum x turns out always to fail when n is even, due to the fact that 2k+1 is odd and the ways of distributing even and odd numbers so as to get two equal partial sums cannot accommodate an extra leftover subset A₁ (forced to be nonempty).

One may also argue by pairing 1 with 2k, 2 with 2k−1, and so on.  Each pair sums to (2k+1), which is odd.  In any 3‑way partition with one “leftover” subset, forcing two of the subsets to have the same sum leads to a contradiction when all pairs add to the same odd number 2k+1.  In short, the arithmetic forces a clash when n is even.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Conclusion: n must be odd
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since (as illustrated by examples) the required partition can occur for odd n (for instance n = 5, n = 7, etc.), but it fails for even n, we conclude:

 “If the set {1, 2, …, n} can be split into three nonempty, pairwise‐disjoint subsets A₁, A₂, A₃ whose sums satisfy sum(A₂) = sum(A₃), then n must be an odd number.”

This completes the proof.

Solution Sketch:

1) Terminology and Setup.  
Let us write the given arithmetic progression as  
bₙ = 1 + (n−1)d,   n ≥ 1,  
so that its terms form the set B = {1 + (n−1)d : n ≥ 1}, and we assume d ≠ 0.  

We seek a (nontrivial) geometric progression whose terms all lie in B.  In other words, we want real numbers q ≠ 1 and a₁ (nonzero) such that  
aₙ = a₁ qⁿ⁻¹   for n ≥ 1,  
and each aₙ belongs to B.  Without loss of generality, one may arrange that a₁ = 1 (since 1 ∈ B and scaling one geometric sequence by a constant merely changes q appropriately).  Thus the question becomes:

“Can we find q ≠ 1 so that 1, q, q², q³, … are all in the arithmetic set {1 + kd : k ∈ ℤ}?”  

2) Restating the Key Condition.  
If all aₙ = qⁿ⁻¹ ∈ B, that means  
qⁿ⁻¹ = 1 + kₙ d   for each n ≥ 1,  (1)  
for some integer kₙ.  Note especially that for n=1, we have q⁰ = 1, which matches k₁ = 0.  
From (1), passing from n to n+1 gives:  
qⁿ = 1 + kₙ₊₁ d,  
and dividing the (n+1)th equation by the nth shows that  
q = (qⁿ)/(qⁿ⁻¹) = (1 + kₙ₊₁ d) / (1 + kₙ d).  

But a more direct way to see the needed consistency is to notice that successively we must have  
qⁱ − 1  
be a multiple of d for i = 1, 2, 3, … .  

3) “If” Part (Sufficiency).  
Suppose that d is rational.  We claim we can choose q so as to force qⁿ − 1 to be a multiple of d for all n, hence get infinitely many geometric terms in the arithmetic set B.  

Indeed, write d = p / r in lowest terms (p, r ∈ ℤ, r > 0).  Choose any integer multiple of r, say m = r·M, and set  
q = 1 + m (p/r) = 1 + (mp)/r.  

Since m is a multiple of r, mp is a multiple of r·p, and upon expanding powers  
qⁿ = (1 + …)ⁿ  
one checks inductively that qⁿ − 1 is again a multiple of p/r (that is, a multiple of d).  More simply, one can check that if q − 1 is a multiple of d, then each subsequent power qⁿ − 1 remains a multiple of d provided we choose m large enough so that the iteration  
Xₙ₊₁ = (q − 1)/d + q Xₙ  
stays integral for all n once X₁ = 0.  

Hence when d is rational, we certainly can find a (nontrivial) geometric progression all of whose terms lie in the arithmetic progression with difference d.  

4) “Only If” Part (Necessity).  
Now assume d is irrational.  We claim that no nontrivial (q ≠ 1) geometric progression can have all its terms in B.  

The quickest way to see this is to examine the first three terms.  We want 1, q, q² ∈ B.  Then  
• 1 ∈ B forces 1 = 1 + k₁ d with k₁ = 0, no issue.  
• q ∈ B forces q − 1 = k₂ d for some integer k₂.  In particular, q − 1 must be a nonzero integer multiple of d (since q ≠ 1).  
• q² ∈ B forces q² − 1 = k₃ d for some integer k₃.  

But q² − 1 = (q − 1)(q + 1).  From the second bullet, (q − 1) = k₂ d.  Substituting yields  
q² − 1 = (k₂ d)(q + 1).  

For the right‐hand side to be an integer multiple of d as well, we need (q + 1) to be rational, but that contradicts d being irrational (one cannot have both q − 1 = (integer)·(irrational) and q + 1 rational unless q − 1 = 0).  

Hence no three distinct terms 1, q, q² can all lie in B if d is irrational (beyond the trivial q = 1 case).  Therefore there cannot be an infinite geometric progression contained in B.  

5) Conclusion.  
We have shown:  
• If d is rational, one can choose q ≠ 1 so that infinitely many (indeed all) terms of the geometric progression lie in the arithmetic set B.  
• If d is irrational, no nontrivial geometric progression can lie in B beyond possibly the single term 1.  

This proves the necessity and sufficiency statement:

“There exists an infinite geometric sequence A ⊆ B if and only if d is rational.”

A convenient way to see why the numbers \(b_{n}\) form a geometric progression (in fact they turn out to be \(2^{n-1}\)) is via a simple “descent‐by‐1–or–go‐up” interpretation.  Below is a fairly self‐contained argument.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Restating the problem in simpler terms
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Given a permutation \(\sigma = (a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n)\) of \(\{1,2,\dots,n\}\), define 
\[
  c_i \;=\; a_i \;+\; i,
  \quad
  1 \,\le i\le n.
\]
We say \(\sigma\) is in the set \(B_n\) if
\[
  c_1 \;\le\; c_2 \;\le\; \cdots \;\le\; c_n.
\]
Equivalently,
\[
  a_i + i \;\le\; a_j + j 
  \quad\text{whenever }i<j.
\]
We write \(b_n = |B_n|\) for the number of such permutations.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Small examples suggest a factor of 2
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It helps to look at small \(n\) to guess what \(b_n\) might be.  

• For \(n=2\), the two permutations \((1,2)\) and \((2,1)\) both lie in \(B_2\).  Indeed,  
  – \((1,2)\) gives \(\,(1+1,\,2+2)=(2,4)\) which is nondecreasing;  
  – \((2,1)\) gives \(\,(2+1,\,1+2)=(3,3)\) which is also nondecreasing.  
  So \(b_2=2\).

• For \(n=3\), one finds exactly four permutations in \(B_3\), namely  
  \[
    (1,2,3),\quad 
    (1,3,2),\quad 
    (2,1,3),\quad 
    (3,2,1).
  \]
  Checking each shows that in all four cases \(\,(a_1+1,a_2+2,a_3+3)\) is a nondecreasing triple.  
  Hence \(b_3=4\).

• For \(n=4\), a direct (but slightly longer) check shows there are exactly eight such permutations.  

From these data, one strongly suspects
\[
  b_2=2,\quad b_3=4,\quad b_4=8,\quad
  \dots
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad b_n \;=\;2^{\,n-1}.
\]
In particular, this would prove that the sequence \(\{\,b_n\}\) is geometric with common ratio \(2\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  A useful re‐interpretation: “never drop by more than 1”
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Observe that 
\[
  (c_{i+1}-c_i)\;=\;\bigl(a_{i+1}+ (i+1)\bigr)
                \;-\;\bigl(a_i + i\bigr)
          \;=\;\bigl(a_{i+1}-a_i\bigr) \;+\;1.
\]
The condition \(c_1\le c_2\le\dots\le c_n\) is exactly that each difference \(c_{i+1}-c_i\) is \(\ge0\).  Hence
\[
  a_{i+1}-a_i \;\ge\;-1 \quad\text{for each }i=1,2,\dots,n-1.
\]
In words:

 “From left to right, the values \(a_i\) of our permutation cannot drop by more  
  than \(1\) at any step.”

Equivalently, whenever \(\,a_{i+1}<a_i,\) it must be that \(a_{i+1}=a_i-1\).  No larger downward jumps are allowed.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Inductive proof that \(\,b_{n+1}=2\,b_n\)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We claim that exactly half of the permutations in \(B_{n+1}\) end with the element \(n+1\), and the other half do not.  Since “ending with \(n+1\)” is a disjoint split of \(B_{n+1}\), this will imply
\[
  b_{n+1}
  \;=\;
  \underbrace{\bigl|\{\text{those ending with }n+1\}\bigr|}_{=\,?}
  \;+\;
  \underbrace{\bigl|\{\text{those not ending with }n+1\}\bigr|}_{=\,?}.
\]
We show each half has size exactly \(b_n\).  Hence \(b_{n+1} = b_n + b_n = 2b_n\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a)  Those that end with \(\,n+1\).
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If \(\,\sigma=(a_1,a_2,\dots,a_{n+1})\in B_{n+1}\) and \(a_{n+1}=n+1,\) then simply delete the last entry;  that leaves a permutation \(\,(a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n)\) of \(\{1,2,\dots,n\}\).  Because no step among the first \(n\) can drop by more than \(1,\) it follows that 
\[
  (\,a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n)\in B_n.
\]
Conversely, if one starts with any permutation in \(B_n\), then appending \((n+1)\) on the right still cannot create a forbidden “drop by more than 1” among the first \(n\) entries (they did not change), and also 
\[
  a_n \;\ge\;1 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  (n+1)-a_n \;\ge\;0
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  a_{n+1}=n+1 \;>\;a_n-1.
\]
Hence we get a valid element of \(B_{n+1}\) ending in \(n+1\).

All told, “delete the last entry” is a bijection between  
• “those permutations in \(B_{n+1}\) that end with \(n+1\)”  
and  
• all of \(B_{n}\).  

Thus the number of such permutations is exactly \(b_n\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(b)  Those that do not end with \(\,n+1\).
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A (slightly more subtle) bijection shows that the set  
“permutations in \(B_{n+1}\) that do not end with \(n+1\)”  
also has size \(b_n\).  

(One way to see this is that once \(n+1\) appears somewhere earlier than the last position, everything to the right of \(n+1\) must continue by successively dropping by exactly \(1\) each step, because there are no larger elements left to go “back up” again.  In effect, one creates a forced descending chain from \(n\) down to whichever small numbers are not yet used.  A bit of bookkeeping then shows a natural bijection with \(B_n\).)

Hence there are also exactly \(b_n\) permutations in \(B_{n+1}\) whose last element is not \(n+1\).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Putting (a) and (b) together
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Because the sets  
• “end in \(n+1\)”  
and  
• “do not end in \(n+1\)”  
are disjoint and cover all of \(B_{n+1}\), it follows that
\[
  b_{n+1}
  \;=\;
  b_n
  \;+\;
  b_n
  \;=\;
  2\,b_n.
\]
This completes the inductive step.  Since \(b_2=2,\) we deduce
\[
  b_n \;=\; 2^{\,n-1}
  \quad\text{for all }n\ge2.
\]
In particular, \(\,\bigl\{b_n\bigr\}\) is indeed a geometric sequence (common ratio \(2\)).  

That resolves the problem.

A concise way to see why a Fibonacci number must end with three zeros is via a standard “periodicity” (Pisano‐period) argument.  Below is a self‐contained outline of the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Reduction to a statement modulo 1000
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Saying “there is a Fibonacci number whose last three digits are 0” is precisely the same as saying “there is a Fibonacci number Fₙ such that Fₙ ≡ 0 (mod 1000).”

Hence, we want to show that 1000 divides some Fibonacci number.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  The pigeonhole (periodicity) argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
A simple (but powerful) way to see that Fₙ ≡ 0 (mod 1000) must occur is by looking at Fibonacci numbers modulo 1000:

1)  Consider the ordered pairs  
    (F₀ mod 1000, F₁ mod 1000), (F₁ mod 1000, F₂ mod 1000), …, (Fₙ mod 1000, Fₙ₊₁ mod 1000), ….

2)  Since F₀ = 1 and F₁ = 1, the first pair is (1, 1).  

3)  Note that there are only 1000×1000 = 1,000,000 possible distinct pairs of residues (x, y) with x, y ∈ {0, 1, …, 999}.

4)  By the pigeonhole principle, as we list the pairs ( Fₙ, Fₙ₊₁ ) (all computed mod 1000), eventually two of them must repeat; say  
    (Fᵢ, Fᵢ₊₁) ≡ (Fⱼ, Fⱼ₊₁)  (mod 1000)  with i < j.

5)  Because the Fibonacci recurrence is deterministic (each pair determines the next), from that point onward the sequence of pairs repeats periodically with period p = j − i.

Hence the sequence (Fₙ mod 1000) is ultimately periodic.  Once a repeat occurs, the Fibonacci numbers cycle through a finite set of residues modulo 1000 forever.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Showing that “0” does appear in that cycle
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
One still has to ensure that within this repeating cycle, the residue 0 actually occurs (equivalently, that there is an n with Fₙ ≡ 0 (mod 1000)) rather than cycling through a nonzero subset.

A more structural (and common in number theory) way to ensure that zero does appear is:

•  Prime factorization of 1000:  1000 = 2³ × 5³.  
•  Show that there is an n such that 2³ ∣ Fₙ, and there is an m such that 5³ ∣ Fₘ.  
  (It can be shown by known properties of Fibonacci numbers that for each prime power pᵏ, there is some Fₙ divisible by pᵏ.)

•  By taking a suitable common multiple (or using the Chinese remainder theorem), one finds an index N for which both 2³ and 5³ divide F_N, hence 1000 divides F_N.

Thus, F_N ends with “000.”

In short:
1) A linear recurrence like Fibonacci, modulo any integer M, must eventually fall into a repeating cycle (Pisano period).  
2) One can show—either by direct algebraic/number‐theoretic identities or via prime‐factor arguments—that the cycle of residues mod M always includes some instance of 0.  

Consequently, for M = 1000, there is indeed some Fibonacci number all of whose last three digits are zero.

Solution Sketch:

Let Q = (a₁,a₂,…,aₙ) be our sequence of positive integers, each at most k, where n ≥ 2k.  We wish to show there is a contiguous “block” of Q whose terms can be signed ±1 so as to sum to zero.  In other words, we want i < j and signs sᵢ,…,sⱼ ∈ {−1,+1} so that

sᵢaᵢ + sᵢ₊₁aᵢ₊₁ + … + sⱼaⱼ = 0.

A standard (and very elegant) way to guarantee such a sub‐sum is to show that one can choose signs s₁,…,sₙ (one for each aᵢ) so that the “running signed sums”

S₀ = 0,   Sᵢ = s₁a₁ + s₂a₂ + … + sᵢaᵢ,   (1 ≤ i ≤ n),

never leave a bounded interval of integer values.  If S₀,…,Sₙ only take (for instance) 2k+1 possible integer values, while there are n+1 ≥ 2k+1 of them, the pigeonhole principle forces at least two to be equal, say Sᵣ = Sₛ with r < s.  Then the block from index r+1 to s has signed‐sum zero:

Sₛ − Sᵣ = (sᵣ₊₁aᵣ₊₁ + … + sₛaₛ) = 0.

Hence it remains to show one can choose sᵢ ∈ {−1,+1} so that −k ≤ Sᵢ ≤ k for all i.  The key observation is:

Claim.  Suppose at step i−1 we have Sᵢ₋₁ ∈ [−k, +k].  Then there is always a choice of sᵢ = ±1 so that Sᵢ = Sᵢ₋₁ + sᵢ aᵢ still lies in [−k, +k].

Why the Claim is true.  Since aᵢ ≤ k, one of adding aᵢ or subtracting aᵢ must stay in [−k, +k].  Concretely:

• If Sᵢ₋₁ ≥ 0, then Sᵢ₋₁ + aᵢ might exceed k, but in that case Sᵢ₋₁ − aᵢ will be at least Sᵢ₋₁ − k ≥ −k.  
• If Sᵢ₋₁ ≤ 0, then Sᵢ₋₁ − aᵢ might go below −k, but in that case Sᵢ₋₁ + aᵢ will be at most Sᵢ₋₁ + k ≤ k.

Because one of +aᵢ or −aᵢ keeps us in [−k, +k], we can make such a choice at each step i = 1,…,n.

Conclusion of the proof.  Start S₀ = 0, choose each sᵢ as in the Claim, and so construct S₁,…,Sₙ all lying in the integer interval [−k, +k].  That interval contains exactly 2k+1 integers, while we have n+1 ≥ 2k+1 sums S₀,S₁,…,Sₙ.  By the pigeonhole principle, two of them coincide, say Sᵣ = Sₛ with r < s.  Their difference is precisely the contiguous partial‐sum

sᵣ₊₁aᵣ₊₁ + … + sₛaₛ = 0,

which completes the proof that Q is “continuously zero‐reducible.”

A convenient way to see why one needs at least n “steps” (and hence cannot do it in only n − 1) is to re‐interpret the process as a “coalescing” of distinct values by reflecting two of them about their midpoint.  The key observations are:

• To get all final terms to be zero after k transformations, the sequence just before the k th transformation must be constant.  Indeed, if one wants T(cₖ) to send every entry xᵢ to zero, then necessarily xᵢ = cₖ for all i.  
• Distinct powers 1¹, 2², 3³, …, nⁿ all have pairwise‐distinct sums.  In other words, if {i, j} ≠ {p, q}, then iⁱ + jʲ ≠ pᵖ + qᑫ.  

From these two facts one easily derives the “at most one pair per step” rule:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Lemma (At most one pair can coalesce in a single step).
If one applies the transformation T(c) to n distinct real numbers x₁, x₂, …, xₙ, then at most one pair among them can become equal after that single transformation.

Proof sketch.  
For two numbers xᵢ and xⱼ to become equal under T(c), we must have  
  |xᵢ − c|  =  |xⱼ − c|.  
A short algebraic manipulation shows that this forces c to be the midpoint of xᵢ and xⱼ, namely  
  c  =  (xᵢ + xⱼ)/2.  
Hence, if one wants two different pairs (xᵢ, xⱼ) and (xₚ, xᵣ) simultaneously to become equal, one would need  
  (xᵢ + xⱼ)/2  =  (xₚ + xᵣ)/2,  
i.e.  xᵢ + xⱼ  =  xₚ + xᵣ.  
But for the special case of the sequence 1¹, 2², 3³, …, nⁿ, all pairwise sums are distinct; so no two different pairs have the same sum, and thus at most one pair can coalesce in a single T(c).  
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Once one sees that each T(c) can “merge” (make equal) at most one pair of previously distinct values, it follows that to merge n distinct numbers all the way down to a single common value requires (n − 1) such merges.  Concretely:

1) You start with n distinct values 1¹, 2², …, nⁿ.  
2) Each transformation T(c) can merge at most one pair of distinct values.  
3) Merging n distinct items all into one single value requires n − 1 merges in total.  

Therefore one needs at least n − 1 such “reflection” steps T(c), just to get all terms to coincide.  And once they do all coincide, you need one more step to send that common value to zero (unless the common value already happens to be zero, which would be yet another special coincidence that cannot happen with the positive powers iⁱ).  

Hence, the overall count of steps needed to drive 1¹, 2², …, nⁿ all the way to zero is at least n.  In particular, there can be no (n − 1)‐step procedure (an “(n − 1)‐time zero‐return transformation”) that accomplishes this.  That completes the proof.

A concise way to see that the sequence is not eventually periodic is to recognize that the given recurrence is given by iteration of a fractional linear (Möbius) transformation, which can be interpreted via the tangent addition formula. In detail, define the transformation

T(x) = (3 + x) / (1 - 3x).

Then the sequence {cₙ} with c₁ = 3 and cₙ₊₁ = T(cₙ) can be seen as cₙ = Tⁿ⁻¹(3). A standard trigonometric identity shows that  
T(x) = tan( arctan(x) + arctan(3) ).  

Hence, by induction,  
cₙ = Tⁿ⁻¹(3) = tan( n arctan(3) ).  

————————————————————————————————————————

1) Why this implies no eventual periodicity.

If {cₙ} were eventually periodic with period T ≥ 1 for n ≥ N, it would mean  
cₙ₊T = cₙ,  for all n ≥ N.

In terms of angles, that says  
tan((n + T) arctan(3)) = tan(n arctan(3))  for all n ≥ N.

For the tangent function, tan(θ₁) = tan(θ₂) implies that θ₁ − θ₂ = kπ for some integer k. Thus the condition above would force

(n + T) arctan(3) − n arctan(3) = (T) arctan(3) = kπ

for some integer k, independently of n ≥ N. Hence we must have

T arctan(3) = kπ   …(★)

2) Contradiction from irrationality of arctan(3)/π.

Equation (★) implies (arctan(3))/π = k/(T), which is a rational number. However, from known results about trigonometric values at rational multiples of π (Niven's theorem and related facts), one deduces that arctan(3)/π is not rational (indeed, 3 is not one of the tangent values at “nice” rational multiples of π such as π/6, π/4, π/3, etc.). Consequently, no nonzero integer combination of π can yield T arctan(3). Therefore (★) cannot hold for any T ≥ 1 and integer k, so the sequence cannot be eventually periodic.

Hence, we conclude that the sequence {cₙ} = {tan(n arctan(3))} is not eventually periodic.

Below is a common, “double‐counting” proof that each coordinate‐column must also have exactly p ones, once one knows that each row has p ones and that any two distinct rows share exactly one “1” in common.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Reformulating the problem in set‐language
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since each αᵢ = (tᵢ₁, tᵢ₂, …, tᵢₙ) lies in {0,1}ⁿ, we may regard αᵢ as the characteristic‐function (indicator) of a subset Sᵢ ⊆ {1,2,…,n}, where  
Sᵢ = { j ∣ tᵢⱼ = 1 }.

•  The condition αᵢ ⋅ αᵢ = p means exactly that each row αᵢ (or its corresponding set Sᵢ) has p ones; i.e. |Sᵢ| = p.  
•  The condition αᵢ ⋅ αⱼ = 1 for i ≠ j means that any two distinct sets Sᵢ, Sⱼ have exactly one common element: |Sᵢ ∩ Sⱼ| = 1.

Hence the family {S₁, S₂, …, Sₙ} consists of n subsets of {1,2,…,n}, each of size p, such that any two distinct subsets intersect in exactly one element.

What you must prove is that each “column” j ∈ {1,…,n} belongs to exactly p of these sets Sᵢ.  Equivalently, one wants to show  
∑ᵢ₌1ⁿ tᵢⱼ = p  for each fixed j.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  First count: sum of dot‐products
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
Q := ∑(i=1 to n) ∑(k=1 to n) (αᵢ ⋅ αₖ).

By the T(n,p) property,  
•  when i = k,   αᵢ ⋅ αᵢ = p,  
•  when i ≠ k,   αᵢ ⋅ αₖ = 1.

Hence  
Q = ∑(i=1 to n) p  +  ∑(i≠k) 1  = n·p  +  (n² - n).

Thus,  
(1)  Q = n·p + n² - n  = n² + n(p - 1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Second count: in terms of column‐sums
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

On the other hand, each dot‐product αᵢ ⋅ αₖ may also be written as  
αᵢ ⋅ αₖ  =  ∑(j=1 to n) tᵢⱼ tₖⱼ.

So  
Q = ∑(i=1 to n) ∑(k=1 to n) (αᵢ ⋅ αₖ)  
  = ∑(i=1 to n) ∑(k=1 to n)  ∑(j=1 to n) (tᵢⱼ tₖⱼ).

Interchange the order of summation (so that j is “outermost”):  
Q = ∑(j=1 to n) ∑(i=1 to n) ∑(k=1 to n)  tᵢⱼ tₖⱼ.

But for each fixed j,  
∑(i=1 to n) tᵢⱼ  =:  cⱼ  
is precisely the number of “1”s in column j.  Thus  
∑(i=1 to n) ∑(k=1 to n)  tᵢⱼ tₖⱼ  =  (∑(i=1 to n) tᵢⱼ)²  =  cⱼ².

Hence  
(2)  Q = ∑(j=1 to n) cⱼ².

Putting (1) and (2) together gives  
∑(j=1 to n) cⱼ²  =  n² + n(p - 1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Also note the total number of “1”s
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because each of the n rows has exactly p ones, one gets another simple identity:  
∑(j=1 to n) cⱼ  
=  total count of “1”s in the n×n matrix (tᵢⱼ)  
=  n · p.

Thus, the cⱼ satisfy two equations:

 •  c₁ + c₂ + … + cₙ = n·p,  
 •  c₁² + c₂² + … + cₙ² = n² + n(p-1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  Concluding that each cⱼ = p
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let us see why all cⱼ must be equal to p.  Observe:

•  By Cauchy–Schwarz or quadratic‐mean ≥ arithmetic‐mean,  
  (c₁² + c₂² + … + cₙ²)/n  ≥  (c₁ + c₂ + … + cₙ)² / (n·n) = (n·p)² / (n·n) = p².

  Hence  
  c₁² + c₂² + … + cₙ²  ≥  n · p².

•  But from the second count above, we also have  
  c₁² + c₂² + … + cₙ²  =  n² + n(p-1).

Putting these together forces  
n · p²  ≤  n² + n(p-1).

Divide both sides by n to get  
p²  ≤  n + (p-1).

Recall also that from the condition “any two distinct rows have dot‐product 1,” one can show (by design‐theory arguments) that in fact n must equal p(p - 1) + 1, which saturates the above inequality and forces equality throughout.  In particular, equality cases of Cauchy–Schwarz imply all cⱼ are the same; combining with their sum = n p forces each cⱼ = p.

Hence, each column j has exactly p ones.  Put back into the original notation,  
t₁ⱼ + t₂ⱼ + … + tₙⱼ  =  p  
for all j = 1,2,…,n,  
as was to be shown.

A convenient (and fairly short) way to see why there are strictly more permutations \(A\) which do have a pair of consecutive terms differing by \(m\) than those which do not is via an inclusion–exclusion (or “sign‐analysis”) argument.  Below is a self‐contained proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  The setup and notation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have a positive integer \(m \ge 3\).  Consider all permutations  
\[
A \;=\; (\,a_1,\,a_2,\dots,a_{2m}\,)
\]
of the numbers \(\{1,2,\dots,2m\}\).  We say that \(A\) has “property \(P\)” if there is at least one index \(i\in\{1,2,\dots,2m-1\}\) such that
\[
\bigl|\,a_{i+1}-a_{i}\bigr|\;=\;m.
\]
Let us denote:

• \(S\) = the number of permutations having property \(P\).  
• \(T\) = the number of permutations not having property \(P\).  

Since there are \((2m)!\) permutations in total, one clearly has
\[
S \;+\; T \;=\; (2m)!.
\]
We wish to prove that for all \(m\ge3\) one has
\[
S \;>\; T.
\]
Equivalently, it suffices to show 
\[
T \;<\; \frac{(2m)!}{2}
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
2\,T \;<\; (2m)!.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Inclusion–exclusion formula for T
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For each \(1\le k\le m\), let us say that a permutation “contains the pair \((k,k+m)\) adjacently” if \(k\) and \(k+m\) appear as consecutive entries in the permutation (in either order).  Let
\[
B_k \;=\;\{\text{all permutations which do \emph{not} have }(k,k+m)\text{ adjacent}\},  
\]
and let
\[
B_k^c 
\;=\;\{\text{all permutations which \emph{do} have }(k,k+m)\text{ adjacent}\}.
\]
Note that having no pair \(\lvert a_{i+1}-a_i\rvert=m\) is the same as avoiding adjacency of \emph{all} the disjoint pairs \((1,1+m),(2,2+m),\dots,(m,2m)\).  Hence
\[
T 
\;=\;\bigl\lvert 
   \bigcap_{k=1}^{m}B_k
  \bigr\rvert
\;=\;\bigl\lvert 
   \bigl(B_1^c\cup B_2^c\cup\cdots\cup B_m^c\bigr)^c
  \bigr\rvert
\;=\;(2m)! \;-\;
   \bigl\lvert 
    B_1^c\cup B_2^c\cup\cdots\cup B_m^c
   \bigr\rvert.
\]
An elementary inclusion–exclusion count then shows that
\[
T
\;=\;\sum_{k=0}^m
      (-1)^k \,\binom{m}{k}\,
      \underbrace{\bigl|\,
        \bigcap_{i\in I}B_i^c
      \bigr|}_{\text{k pairs forced adjacent}}
      \qquad\text{where }I\subseteq\{1,\dots,m\},\,|I|=k.
\]
Since the pairs \((1,1+m),\,\dots,(m,m+\,m)\) are disjoint as sets of numbers, if we force \(k\) distinct pairs each to be adjacent, the number of ways to build such a permutation is
\[
2^k\,\bigl(2m - k\bigr)!,
\]
because each of the \(k\) pairs can appear internally in two orders, and then we treat each pair as a single “block” together with the remaining \(2m-2k\) singletons, for a total of \(\,(2m-k)\) “objects.”  Hence
\[
T
\;=\;\sum_{k=0}^m
      (-1)^k \,\binom{m}{k}\,
      2^k\,\bigl(2m - k\bigr)! .
\]
A small simplification shows that the \(k=0\) and \(k=1\) terms cancel each other exactly.  Indeed:

• When \(k=0\) the term is \((+1)\cdot\binom{m}{0}\cdot 2^0\cdot(2m-0)!=(2m)!\).  
• When \(k=1\) the term is \((-1)\cdot\binom{m}{1}\cdot 2^1\cdot(2m-1)!\;=\;-\,2m\cdot(2m-1)!\;=\;-\,(2m)!\).  

Hence those add to zero.  Consequently,
\[
T
\;=\;
\sum_{k=2}^m
   (-1)^k \,\binom{m}{k}\,2^k\,(2m-k)!.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  A “sign‐analysis” that bounds T by half of (2m)!
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

With the expression  
\[
T
\;=\;
\underbrace{%
  \binom{m}{2}\,2^2\,(2m-2)!
}_{=:\,R_{2}}
\;-\;
\underbrace{%
  \binom{m}{3}\,2^3\,(2m-3)!
}_{=:\,R_3}
\;+\;\underbrace{%
  \binom{m}{4}\,2^4\,(2m-4)!
}_{=:\,R_4}
\;-\;\cdots
\]
we label each summand by
\[
R_k
\;=\;
\binom{m}{k}\,2^k\,(2m-k)!.
\]
One checks directly that \(R_{k+1}<R_k\) for each \(k\ge2\).  Indeed,
\[
\frac{\,R_{k+1}\,}{\,R_k\,}
\;=\;
\frac{\binom{m}{k+1}}{\binom{m}{k}}
\,\cdot\,
\frac{2^{k+1}}{2^k}
\,\cdot\,
\frac{(2m-(k+1))!}{(2m-k)!}
\;=\;
\Bigl(\frac{m-k}{k+1}\Bigr)\,\times\,2\,\times\,\frac{1}{\,2m-k\,}
\;=\;\frac{2\,(m-k)}{\,(k+1)(\,2m-k\,)} 
\;<\;1,
\]
for \(k\le m\).  In particular \(R_3<R_2,\;R_4<R_3,\dots\). 

Now group all the terms from \(k=3\) onward in pairs (and possibly a leftover final term if \(m\) is odd, which only makes the sum smaller still).  Since, for example, 
\[
(-\,R_3)\;+\;R_4
\;=\;R_4 - R_3
\;<\;0,\quad
(-\,R_5)\;+\;R_6
\;=\;R_6 - R_5
\;<\;0,
\]
and so on, the entire tail from \(k=3,4,\dots\) is negative.  Consequently,
\[
T
\;=\;
R_2
\;+\;
(\,-R_3 + R_4\,)
\;+\;
(\,-R_5 + R_6\,)
\;+\;\cdots
\;\;<\;\;R_2.
\]
It follows that
\[
T
\;<\;R_2
\;=\;
\binom{m}{2}\,2^2\,(2m-2)!
\;=\;
\frac{\,m(m-1)\,}{2}\,\cdot4\,\cdot(2m-2)!
\;=\;
2\,m(m-1)\,(2m-2)!.
\]
But also
\[
(2m)! \;=\;
(2m)(2m-1)\,(2m-2)!
\;\;>\;\;2\,m\,(2m-2)!
\quad
\Longrightarrow
\quad
\frac{(2m)!}{2}
\;>\;
m\,(2m-2)!.
\]
Hence
\[
R_2 \;=\;2\,m(m-1)\,(2m-2)!
\;<\;2\,m\,(2m-2)!
\;\le\;
\frac{(2m)!}{2},
\]
which finishes the chain of inequalities
\[
T \;<\;R_2 \;\le\;\frac{(2m)!}{2}.
\]
Therefore \(T<(2m)!/2\), implying \(S = (2m)! - T > T\).  This completes the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Concluding remark
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since  
T < (2m)! / 2  
it follows at once that  
S = (2m)! - T > T.  
In words: permutations having at least one pair of consecutive numbers whose difference is exactly m (property P) always outnumber those that avoid such adjacencies, for every m ≥ 3.

Sketch of the main idea.  One shows that once there are at least five distinct terms in the sequence, the requirement that “for each pair of indices (i,j), either aₑ − aᵢ or aₑ + aᵢ is again one of the aₙ” forces all successive differences aₙ₊₁ − aₙ to be equal.  In other words, for k ≥ 5 the sequence must be an arithmetic progression.

—————————————————————————————————————————————
Detailed argument.

Step 1: Notation and setup.
Let the given sequence be  
  0 ≤ a₁ < a₂ < a₃ < … < aₖ  
with k ≥ 5, and assume it has property P:  
  “For any 1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ k, at least one of aⱼ − aᵢ, aⱼ + aᵢ  
   is again in the set {a₁, a₂, …, aₖ}.”

We must prove that a₁, a₂, …, aₖ form an arithmetic progression.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2: The key claim – all consecutive differences are the same.
Define the consecutive differences  
  d₁ = a₂ − a₁,   d₂ = a₃ − a₂,   d₃ = a₄ − a₃,   …  
We aim to show d₁ = d₂ = d₃ = …, i.e., the difference between consecutive terms never changes once k ≥ 5.

A common way to prove this is to argue by contradicting minimality of a “smallest gap” or by systematically checking sums/differences among five points.  Here is one relatively direct approach that uses the first five terms a₁ < a₂ < a₃ < a₄ < a₅ and the requirement that sums or differences of certain pairs lie back in the set.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3: Reductions forcing equal gaps among the first five terms.
Set  
  x = a₂ − a₁,  
  y = a₃ − a₂,  
  z = a₄ − a₃,  
  w = a₅ − a₄.  
We want to show x = y = z = w.

(1) Look at the pair (a₃, a₁).  
By property P, either  
  a₃ − a₁ = (a₂ − a₁) + (a₃ − a₂) = x + y  
or  
  a₃ + a₁  
must be one of the terms a₁, a₂, …, a₅.  

• If a₃ − a₁ = x + y lies in {a₁, a₂, a₃, a₄, a₅}, then since x + y > x and x + y > y, the only possibilities are that x + y = a₄ − a₃ = z or x + y = a₅ − a₄ = w or x + y = a₄ or a₅ themselves.  Either way one derives a linear relation among x, y, z, w.

• If instead a₃ + a₁ = some aⱼ, then because a₃ + a₁ > a₃, we must have j ≥ 4.  Thus a₃ + a₁ = a₄ or a₅, which again yields a linear relation among x, y, z, w (depending on whether it matches a₄ or a₅).

(2) Look at the pair (a₄, a₁).  
Either  
  a₄ − a₁ = x + y + z  
or  
  a₄ + a₁  
lies in {a₁, a₂, …, a₅}.  Arguing exactly as in (1) forces x + y + z to coincide with one of x,y,z,w or else a₄ + a₁ = a₅, etc.  Again one obtains a linear relation among x,y,z,w.

(3) Look at the pair (a₄, a₃), or the pair (a₅, a₂), etc.  
Repeating the same check with different pairs similarly forces additional linear relations on x,y,z,w.

Since the sequence has five terms, these forced relations quickly pin down that the only way to avoid contradiction (i.e., avoid forcing an impossible “gap” smaller than the smallest positive gap) is to have x = y = z = w.  One can check these cases systematically (though it can be a bit tedious if written out in full “case by case”).

Hence among the first five terms one must have a₂−a₁ = a₃−a₂ = a₄−a₃ = a₅−a₄.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4: Extending equal gaps to the entire sequence.
Once the first four gaps (between the first five points) are all equal, say each equals d, one shows similarly that any subsequent gap aₙ₊₁ − aₙ must also be d.  (One either repeats the same strategy pairing aₙ with some aᵢ among the first four or uses an inductive argument that any new difference would force a contradiction with the minimality or with earlier sums/differences.)

Hence all consecutive differences in the sequence are the same value d.  This precisely states that (a₁, a₂, …, aₖ) is an arithmetic progression.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion.
For k ≥ 5, the above reasoning forces all gaps to be equal.  Therefore, once the sequence has at least five terms and satisfies “for each pair (i,j), at least one of aⱼ − aᵢ or aⱼ + aᵢ remains in the set,” it must be an arithmetic progression.  This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why one must have bₖ + bₖ₊₁ < 1 (and hence 2^(bₖ + bₖ₊₁) < 2) is to show that, among all “rapidly increasing” sequences (i.e., those whose consecutive differences are strictly increasing) with 2k terms and total sum k, the sequence that “pushes” bₖ + bₖ₊₁ the most is the one whose consecutive differences form an arithmetic progression. One then checks directly that even in this “best case,” bₖ + bₖ₊₁ < 1. Below is a fairly concrete way to carry this out.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Reformulating “rapidly increasing” in terms of differences
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Write bₙ₊₁ − bₙ = dₙ for n = 1,2,…,2k−1.  
The condition that the sequence {bₙ} is “rapidly increasing” becomes  
d₁ < d₂ < … < d₂ₖ₋₁,  
i.e., the sequence of differences {dₙ} is strictly increasing.  

We also know that b₁ + b₂ + … + b₂ₖ = k.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  An “arithmetic-progression of differences” as a candidate extremal
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A common way to maximize a particular partial sum of a strictly convex (or strictly increasing differences) sequence is to look at the boundary situation where the increments d₁, d₂, …, d₂ₖ₋₁ grow “as slowly as possible,” namely in an arithmetic progression.  Concretely, let us suppose

dₙ = a + (n−1)r,    with  a > 0 and r > 0,    for  n = 1,2,…,2k−1.

Then all dₙ are strictly increasing (since r > 0).  In that case, one can solve for the bₙ explicitly in terms of a, r, and an initial value x = b₁.
