Claim.  For any positive integer t ≥ 2, there exist positive integers
   a₁ < a₂ < … < aₕ  
such that

1)  Each consecutive pair (aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁) is reducible.  
2)  The “end” pair (a₁, aₜ) is irreducible.

So we need (a₁, a₂), (a₂, a₃), …, (aₜ₋₁, aₜ) all reducible, but at the same time (a₁, aₜ) must fail to factor “in the middle.”

------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Why picking two primes at the ends helps
------------------------------------------------------------

A natural idea is to ensure that a₁ and aₜ are chosen so that their product a₁ aₜ is very “sparse” in its divisors, thereby preventing any factorization strictly between a₁ and aₜ.  A simple way is to make a₁ and aₜ themselves distinct primes p < q.  Indeed, if p and q are primes, then

  p q  has only the divisors 1,  p,  q,  pq.

If we also have p < x < q for some x, then x cannot be p or q, and (since p ≠ 1) x cannot be 1; nor can x be pq.  Thus none of the divisors 1, p, q, pq lie strictly between p and q.  Concretely,

  if p and q are distinct primes with p < q,
  then (p, q) is automatically irreducible.

Hence choosing our “endpoints” a₁ = p and aₜ = q with p, q prime guarantees that (a₁, aₜ) = (p, q) is irreducible.

------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Forcing each step to be reducible
------------------------------------------------------------

Having picked two primes p < q, we now insert intermediate numbers

  p = a₁ < a₂ < … < aₜ = q

so that each (aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁) admits a nontrivial factorization “in the gap.”  In other words, given aᵢ and aᵢ₊₁, we want to ensure

  aᵢ < m′ ≤ n′ < aᵢ₊₁   and   aᵢ aᵢ₊₁ = m′ n′.

There are many ways one can ensure this, so long as aᵢ₊₁ is “large enough” compared to aᵢ.  One simple (though by no means unique) pattern is to insist that

  aᵢ₊₁ ≥ 4 aᵢ

for i = 1, 2, …, t–1.  One can then prove (and it is a nice exercise) that whenever n ≥ 4 m, the product m n has factors strictly between m and n.  In fact, one finds suitable m′, n′ in (m, n) by looking around the “middle” of that interval.  

Thus, starting from your prime p = a₁, pick a₂ ≥ 4 a₁, then a₃ ≥ 4 a₂, and so on, until finally you pick aₜ = q, another prime, making sure that all the intermediate a₂, …, aₜ₋₁ lie strictly between p and q.  As long as each jump is large enough (so that the ratio aᵢ₊₁ / aᵢ ≥ 4), the pairs (aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁) will be reducible.  And since a₁ = p and aₜ = q are distinct primes, the pair (a₁, aₜ) remains irreducible.

------------------------------------------------------------
5)  Concluding the proof
------------------------------------------------------------

Putting it all together:

•  Choose two sufficiently large primes p < q so that there is plenty of “room” between them.  
•  Set a₁ = p and aₜ = q.  
•  Fill in intermediate a₂, a₃, …, aₜ₋₁ between p and q so that each consecutive ratio is at least 4 (or at least some fixed large factor).  

By construction, each consecutive pair (aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁) is reducible (one can find a suitable factorization m′ n′ in the open interval (aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁)), yet (a₁, aₜ) = (p, q) is irreducible, because p q has no divisors strictly between p and q.  This completes the argument for arbitrary t.

Hence, for every positive integer t, one can produce the required chain of length t:

  a₁ < a₂ < ··· < aₜ

whose consecutive links are all reducible, but whose endpoints form an irreducible pair.

A convenient way to see why such real numbers a,b with 1 < a < b exist is to work “in the logarithm” and use the fact that n! has very many (and hence “densely spaced”) divisors.  The key steps are:

1) Show that if one takes 1 < a < e < b, then for all sufficiently large n the product  
   ∏ (from k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) of a^(n/k)  
   is at most n!,  
   while  
   ∏ (from k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) of b^(n/k)  
   is at least n!.

2) Deduce from this that “in the multiplicative sense,” n! lies between those two extreme products.  In particular, there is plenty of “room” in each interval (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) for picking factors x₁, x₂, …, x⌊n/2⌋ whose product is exactly n!.

3) Argue via density of divisors that one can indeed select each xₖ to divide the appropriate partial quotient so that the final product is exactly n!, and by always choosing xₖ ≤ b^(n/k) (in descending order of k) one ensures x₁ ≥ x₂ ≥ … ≥ x⌊n/2⌋.

Below is a more detailed outline of the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 1.  UPPER AND LOWER BOUNDS FOR n!
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We claim there is a choice of 1 < a < e < b such that for all large n,

   (A)   ∏(k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) a^(n/k)  ≤  n!,     and
   (B)   ∏(k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) b^(n/k)  ≥  n!.

Taking logarithms (natural logs, say), these inequalities become

   (A')   ∑(k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) (n/k) ln(a)  ≤  ln(n!),  
   (B')   ∑(k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) (n/k) ln(b)  ≥  ln(n!).

An approximate size for ln(n!) is given by Stirling’s formula:
   ln(n!)  ≈  n ln(n) - n  +  O(ln(n)).

On the other hand, the sum  
   ∑(k=1 to ⌊n/2⌋) (n/k)  
is on the order of n(1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + … + 1/(n/2)), which for large n behaves like  
   n (ln(n/2) + γ + o(1))  
(where γ is the Euler–Mascheroni constant).  

Hence the left sum in (A') is roughly  
   n ln(a) (1 + 1/2 + … + 1/(n/2))  ≈  n ln(a) ln(n/2),  
and the right‐hand side ln(n!) is on the order of n ln n.  

• If ln(a) < 1, i.e. a < e, then eventually n ln(a) ln(n/2) < n ln n.  
  In other words, for a < e and for all sufficiently large n, (A') holds.  
• Likewise, if ln(b) > 1, i.e. b > e, then eventually n ln(b) ln(n/2) > n ln n,  
  forcing (B') to hold.  

Thus, provided we choose a,b so that 1 < a < e < b, for all large n the product of the “lower bounds” a^(n/k) sits below n!, while the product of the “upper bounds” b^(n/k) sits above n!.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 2.  FINDING FACTORS xₖ IN (a^(n/k), b^(n/k))
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We now wish to factor n! into exactly ⌊n/2⌋ positive integers,

   n!  =  x₁ · x₂ · … · x⌊n/2⌋,

such that each xₖ lies in the open interval (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) and x₁ ≥ x₂ ≥ … ≥ x⌊n/2⌋.

The idea is to argue that n! has so many divisors that one can “hit” each interval (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) with a divisor of the appropriate partial quotient.  Concretely, one proceeds inductively:

• Start with Q₀ := n!.  
• At the k‑th step, look at the interval (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) and pick xₖ so that  
     xₖ  ∈  (a^(n/k), b^(n/k))  
  and xₖ is a divisor of Qₙ₋₁ (the partial quotient left from the previous step).  
• Define Qₖ := Qₙ₋₁ / xₖ, so that Qₖ is still an integer.  
• Continue until k reaches ⌊n/2⌋, at which point  
     Q⌊n/2⌋  =  Q₀ / (x₁ x₂ … x⌊n/2⌋)  =  n! / n!  =  1,  
  so that indeed n! = x₁ x₂ … x⌊n/2⌋.

To justify that an appropriate xₖ exists in each interval, one argues:

1) Because the product of all the “lower bounds” a^(n/k) is at most n! (from Step 1), there is enough “room” that none of the partial quotients Qₖ drops below a^(n/k).  
2) Because the product of all the “upper bounds” b^(n/k) is at least n! (again from Step 1), we also do not exceed b^(n/k).  
3) The set of divisors of n! is very large and in particular “dense enough” on a logarithmic scale to ensure one can always pick off a divisor of Qₖ in the prescribed interval.  

Moreover, the condition x₁ ≥ x₂ ≥ … ≥ x⌊n/2⌋ follows automatically if one always chooses xₖ ≤ b^(n/k), since, as k increases, b^(n/k) is decreasing.  In particular,

   b^(n/1)  ≥  b^(n/2)  ≥  b^(n/3)  ≥  …  ≥  b^(n/⌊n/2⌋).

Hence one cannot “overshoot” a previous factor.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
CONCLUSION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Putting it all together:

• Selecting any a,b with 1 < a < e < b ensures that for all large n, the intervals (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) are sufficiently wide that one can choose x₁,…,x⌊n/2⌋ in those intervals, each dividing down the partial quotient, and whose product is exactly n!.  
• By construction these xₖ can be taken nonincreasing.  
• For finitely many small n, one can check cases separately (or choose a,b slightly larger if needed).

Thus the statement is proved: there do indeed exist real numbers 1 < a < b so that for every integer n ≥ 2 one can factor n! into ⌊n/2⌋ (nonincreasing) positive integers x₁,…,x⌊n/2⌋ each lying in (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
COMMENT
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The essential reason this works is twofold:

• The “exponential” windows (a^(n/k), b^(n/k)) grow and shrink fast enough in k to allow a wide multiplicative range overall—from the product of the lower bounds up to the product of the upper bounds—certain to contain n!.  
• The factorial n! has so many divisors (thanks to the abundance of prime factors in 1·2·…·n) that we can “hit” precise targets within those windows to assemble the exact product n!.  

A quick way to remember the needed inequality conditions is that one can make the lower bound less than n! by insisting a < e, and make the upper bound exceed n! by insisting b > e.

A convenient (and by now standard) way to exhibit an arithmetic progression of square‐free numbers of prescribed length is to take the common difference to be 1 (that is, to look for consecutive integers) and then use a “local” argument (via the Chinese remainder theorem) to rule out all unwanted square‐divisors.  Here is a self‐contained outline of the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Statement
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We wish to prove:

Proposition.  For every integer n ≥ 3, there is an n‐term arithmetic progression of nonzero common difference all of whose terms are square‐free.

Equivalently (by shifting), it suffices to exhibit n consecutive integers all of which are square‐free.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Key idea
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The main idea is this:

• If an integer k is divisible by the square of a prime p, then p² ≤ k.  
• Hence, to prevent “large” primes from dividing our integers by p², one can ensure all those integers are smaller than p².  
• To prevent “small” primes from dividing our integers by p², one uses the Chinese remainder theorem to exclude all residue classes that are multiples of p².

By choosing a suitable “window” of length n and ruling out divisibility by squares of all small primes, one obtains n square‐free numbers in a row.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. The construction
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Step 1:  Pick a large prime p > n.  

Step 2:  Let S be the finite set of all primes r with r < p.  (Since p is fixed, S is indeed finite.)

Step 3:  Consider the product of squares of all these smaller primes:  
Q := ∏ (r²)   taken over all r ∈ S.  

Step 4:  We want to find an integer a so that the n consecutive integers  
a, a+1, a+2, …, a + (n−1)  
have none of them divisible by r² for any r ∈ S.  

Concretely, for each r ∈ S we impose the conditions  
a + k ≢ 0  (mod r²),   for all k = 0,1,…,n−1.  
Each r excludes at most n residue classes mod r² (namely the classes −k mod r²), so in total (for all r ∈ S) we exclude at most n·|S| residue classes modulo Q.

Step 5:  Provided Q > n·|S|, there will remain at least one admissible choice for a modulo Q (by the pigeonhole principle), and by the Chinese remainder theorem we can lift that residue‐class solution to an integer a in the range  
1 ≤ a ≤ Q.

Step 6:  Finally, ensure that a+(n−1) < p².  A simple way is to choose a ≤ p² − n.  Then for every prime r ≥ p, we have r² ≥ p² > a + (n−1).  Hence no such “large” prime r can divide any of a, a+1, …, a+(n−1) to the second power.

Putting these two observations together:

• No “small” prime r < p can divide any of those n integers by r² because of the CRT‐type congruence conditions.  
• No “large” prime r ≥ p can divide any of those n integers by r² because r² > a + (n−1).

Therefore, all of  
a, a+1, …, a+(n−1)  
are square‐free.  Thus we obtain n consecutive square‐free integers, i.e., an arithmetic progression (of common difference 1) of length n, all of whose terms are square‐free.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Verifying Q > n·|S|
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

One small technical point is to ensure that Q = ∏(r²) exceeds n·|S|.  In fact, once p is chosen large enough, one finds that the product of squares of all primes below p grows quite fast (much faster than linearly in the number of such primes).  Hence for p sufficiently large, certainly Q > n·|S|.  (One can make this quantitative using Bertrand’s postulate or other bounds on the distribution of primes; but the broad idea is that products of primes grow exponentially in the number of primes.)

Thus for suitably large p, we indeed can find an integer  
1 ≤ a ≤ p² − n  
satisfying all the required congruences and inequalities.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Choosing that a and taking the n integers  
a, a+1, …, a+(n−1)  
gives us an n‐term arithmetic progression (difference 1) all of whose terms are square‐free.  Since the difference 1 is certainly nonzero, this completes the proof that one can always find n square‐free integers in arithmetic progression for any n ≥ 3.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Remark.  Of course, one can also allow a nontrivial common difference d ≠ 1, by simply scaling or by a variant of the same Chinese remainder argument.  But the simplest explicit construction merely takes d = 1 and arranges that none of the n consecutive integers is divisible by any prime‐square, by bounding the size and residue classes as above.

Solution Sketch:

The key idea is that, when working modulo m, all “tall enough” exponent towers eventually stabilize (or become periodic) for every base n.  In particular, one can show there is some fixed height T (depending on m but not on n) at which the sequence of towers “locks in,” so that n⊗(T+1) ≡ n⊗T (mod m) for every positive integer n.  From this, taking a := T+1 and b := T gives the required pair a > b.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Definitions and goal
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For a positive integer n, define:
• n⊗1 = n,  
• n⊗(k+1) = n^(n⊗k).

We want to prove:

   For every positive integer m, there exist integers a > b > 0 such that  
   n⊗a ≡ n⊗b  (mod m)  
   for every positive integer n.

Equivalently, we want to show there is some “height” at which all towers coincide modulo m for all n.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Reduction to prime-power moduli
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By the Chinese Remainder Theorem, it suffices to prove the statement when m = p^e is a prime power.  Indeed, if (a_p, b_p) is the required pair for p^e and (a_q, b_q) is the required pair for q^f, then taking a = max_p a_p, b = max_p b_p (or more careful simultaneous adjustments) will work modulo all prime-power divisors and hence modulo their product.

Hence, fix m = p^e.  We wish to find a single height T so that for all n,

   n⊗(T+1)  ≡  n⊗T   (mod p^e).

We split the proof into two main cases: gcd(n, p^e) = 1 and gcd(n, p^e) ≠ 1.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Case 1:  n is coprime to p^e
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When gcd(n, p) = 1, Euler’s theorem (or Carmichael’s theorem) tells us that

   x^φ(p^e)  ≡  1  (mod p^e)   whenever gcd(x, p) = 1,

where φ(·) is Euler’s totient function, and φ(p^e) = p^(e−1)(p−1).

But in order for 
   n^(α)  ≡  n^(β)  (mod p^e),
it is enough that α ≡ β (mod φ(p^e)) once gcd(n, p) = 1.  

Hence, to compare n⊗(k+1) = n^(n⊗k) and n⊗k = n^(n⊗(k−1)), one needs n⊗k ≡ n⊗(k−1) (mod φ(p^e)), and so on “one step down” the tower.  Repeating, one generates conditions on n⊗(k−1) ≡ n⊗(k−2)  (mod φ(φ(p^e))), etc.  Since iterating φ finitely many times eventually yields 1, one can choose T large enough so that for all n coprime to p^e, the tower

   n⊗1, n⊗2, …, n⊗T, n⊗(T+1)

becomes eventually stable modulo p^e.  Concretely, one balances all the necessary congruences mod φ(p^e), φ(φ(p^e)), etc., to force n⊗(T+1) ≡ n⊗T (mod p^e).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Case 2:  n is not coprime to p^e
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now suppose p divides n, i.e. n = p^d r with d ≥ 1.  One shows by elementary p-adic valuations that sufficiently many exponentiations cause large powers of p to divide n⊗k.  Concretely:

•  n⊗1 = n is divisible by p^d.  
•  n⊗2 = n^n.  Its p-adic valuation grows (often quite rapidly).  
•  Inductively, one sees that once the p-adic valuation of n⊗k is at least e, it follows that n⊗k ≡ 0 (mod p^e).  
•  After that point, n⊗(k+1) = n^(n⊗k) also remains 0 (mod p^e), so the tower values stabilize at 0 mod p^e.

Thus, for n divisible by p, once one goes high enough in the tower, the common value is 0 modulo p^e.  In particular, there is some threshold T′ so that for all n divisible by p,

   n⊗(T′+1) ≡ n⊗T′ ≡ 0  (mod p^e).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Combining the two cases
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since there are only two cases (gcd(n, p^e) = 1 and gcd(n, p^e) ≠ 1), one may take

   T = max(T₁, T′),

where T₁ is a threshold large enough to ensure stability in the coprime case, and T′ is a threshold large enough to guarantee stability in the non-coprime case.  Then for this T (the larger of the two),

   n⊗(T+1)  ≡  n⊗T  (mod p^e)

holds for every integer n, whether or not n is divisible by p.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion and CRT argument
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thus, for any prime power p^e dividing m, we have found an integer T = T(p^e) with the property that n⊗(T+1) ≡ n⊗T (mod p^e) for all n.  Repeating this argument for each prime-power divisor of m and then taking a suitable common T (using the Chinese Remainder Theorem) shows there is some global T working modulo m.  Setting

   a := T+1,   b := T

gives the required pair a > b such that

   n⊗a  ≡  n⊗b   (mod m)

for all n.  This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why one can order the vectors so that consecutive differences add up to at most 8√n is to use a “TSP‐type” argument on the sphere (thought of as a 2‑dimensional surface).  Here is a sketch of the standard approach:

1) Cover the sphere by “cells” of small diameter.  
   - Because our vectors v₁, v₂, …, vₙ all lie on the unit sphere in ℝ³, we can treat that sphere (of diameter ≤ 2) as a 2‑dimensional surface.  
   - We choose a covering of the sphere by roughly n “cells,” each of geodesic diameter ≲ 1/√n.  
   - Concretely, one may triangulate (or “grid”) the sphere so that each piece has area ≈ 1/n and hence diameter ≲ 1/√n.  
   - The number of such cells is O(n).

2) Group points within each cell and connect the cells in a path.  
   - Imagine you label each cell by one “representative point” in that cell (say, an arbitrary corner or the barycenter).  
   - You connect all these representatives by a “snake‑like” path around the sphere so that you traverse each cell exactly once.  
   - Since there are O(n) cells, and the distance between adjacent cells is O(1/√n), the total cost of linking cell‑to‑cell is O(n) ⋅ O(1/√n) = O(√n).

3) Inside each cell, do a short detour to list its vectors.  
   - Suppose a particular cell contains k of your original vectors.  
   - Since the diameter of the cell is O(1/√n), you can form a “mini‑tour” inside that cell visiting those k vectors in some order, and this detour (for each cell) costs at most O(k) × O(1/√n).  
   - Summing over all cells, you have O(n) vectors total, contributing an accumulated cost O(n) × O(1/√n) = O(√n) for the “inside‑cell” tours.

Putting these together:  
• The “big tour” that links all cells in a path has length O(√n).  
• The total “inside‑cell” detours for all cells is also O(√n).  

Hence, you can arrange the vectors into a single chain whose overall consecutive‑distance cost is bounded by some constant times √n.  A more careful estimation can achieve an explicit constant such as 8, giving  
∑(i=1 to n−1) ∥uᵢ₊₁ − uᵢ∥ ≤ 8√n.  

This shows that the vectors can indeed be reordered (u₁, u₂, …, uₙ) so that consecutive distances sum to no more than 8√n.

A convenient way to see why the asserted divisibility holds is via the “generating‐function” (or Galois‐theoretic) method.  We sketch below the standard argument.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) The Fibonacci recursion and its closed form
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Recall that the Fibonacci sequence fₙ is defined by  
• f₁ = 1, f₂ = 1,  
• fₙ₊₂ = fₙ₊₁ + fₙ for n ≥ 1.  

It is well known (over the real numbers) that if α and β are the two roots of  
x² - x - 1 = 0,  
then one has the “closed‐form” expression  
fₙ = (αⁿ - βⁿ) / (α - β).  

Of course, α and β need not lie in ℤ or even in 𝔽p.  In fact, depending on p, the polynomial x² - x - 1 may or may not factor over 𝔽p.  Nonetheless, one can (and often does) work in a suitable extension field of 𝔽p in which x² - x - 1 splits as (x - α)(x - β).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Reducing the sum to T(α) - T(β)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Define the sum one is interested in:
S = ∑ (from n=1 to p−1) fₙ / n.

We claim it is enough to show that S ≡ 0 (mod p).  Indeed, the statement of the problem is that  
p ∣ (p−1)! S;  
but by Wilson’s theorem (p−1)! ≡ −1 (mod p), so saying p divides (p−1)! S is equivalent to saying  
S ≡ 0 (mod p).

Next, observe that using the closed form of fₙ one writes

fₙ = (αⁿ − βⁿ) / (α − β).

Hence

S = ∑ (n=1 to p−1) (fₙ / n)  
  = (1 / (α − β)) ∑ (n=1 to p−1) (αⁿ − βⁿ) / n.  

Define the auxiliary sum

T(x) = ∑ (n=1 to p−1) xⁿ / n,

viewed as an element of whatever extension field contains x.  Then the difference inside the sum is

∑ (n=1 to p−1) (αⁿ − βⁿ) / n  =  T(α)  −  T(β).

Thus

S  =  (1 / (α − β)) · [T(α)  −  T(β)].

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Showing T(α) = T(β)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To conclude that S ≡ 0 mod p, it suffices to show T(α) = T(β) in the field where α and β live.  One shows this by a Galois‐conjugation argument:

• Case 1 (x² − x − 1 reducible over 𝔽p).  
  Then α and β already lie in 𝔽p, and one can check (directly or by symmetry) that T(α) = T(β).

• Case 2 (x² − x − 1 irreducible over 𝔽p).  
  Then α and β are distinct elements in the quadratic extension 𝔽p².  In this case, the Frobenius automorphism x ↦ x^p interchanges α and β (since if α is one root, then α^p is the other root).  

  A standard fact in characteristic p arithmetic is that for any finite sum,

  (∑ aₙ)ᵖ = ∑ (aₙ)ᵖ,

  because (a + b)ᵖ = aᵖ + bᵖ in characteristic p.  Applying this to

  T(α) = ∑ (n=1 to p−1) αⁿ / n,

  we get

  T(α)ᵖ  =  ∑ (n=1 to p−1) (αⁿ)ᵖ / (nᵖ)  
           =  ∑ (n=1 to p−1) α^(pn) / n,

  but α^(p n) = (α^p)ⁿ = βⁿ,  so

  T(α)ᵖ = ∑ (n=1 to p−1) βⁿ / n  =  T(β).

  Thus T(β) = T(α)ᵖ.  

  It is also true (though one checks carefully) that T(α) ∈ 𝔽p itself—indeed T(α) is Galois‐invariant, hence must lie in the fixed field 𝔽p.  Consequently,

  T(α)ᵖ = T(α).

  Putting these together shows

  T(β) = T(α)ᵖ = T(α).

Hence in either case T(α) = T(β), which forces T(α) − T(β) = 0 in the extension field, and therefore

S = (1 / (α − β)) · [T(α)  −  T(β)] = 0 in 𝔽p.

This shows S ≡ 0 mod p, exactly as needed.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since S ≡ 0 (mod p), it follows that (p−1)! S ≡ 0 (mod p).  By Wilson’s theorem (p−1)! ≡ −1 (mod p), so this is precisely the statement:

p ∣ (p−1)! ∑ (n=1 to p−1) (fₙ / n).

That completes the proof.

Below is a self‐contained proof of the stated inequality.  We first restate it in a normalized form (so that the sum of the variables is 1), and then show how the general case follows by homogeneity.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  THE INEQUALITY IN NORMALIZED FORM
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The original inequality is

(1)  ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|  ≤  (4/27) (∑(i=1 to n) xᵢ)³,

for nonnegative real x₁, x₂, …, xₙ and integer n ≥ 2.

A common first step with homogeneous inequalities is to “normalize” by letting S = x₁ + x₂ + … + xₙ and then setting yᵢ = xᵢ / S.  Clearly, y₁ + y₂ + … + yₙ = 1.  Let us define

LHS = ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|.

Then observe:

xᵢ = S yᵢ   and   xⱼ = S yⱼ,   
so
|xᵢ − xⱼ| = S |yᵢ − yⱼ|,   
and
xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|
= (S yᵢ)(S yⱼ) (S |yᵢ − yⱼ|)
= S³  (yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|).

Hence

LHS = ∑(i<j) xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|
    = S³  ∑(i<j) yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|.

On the right‐hand side of (1), we have (4/27)(∑ xᵢ)³ = (4/27) S³.  Therefore,

(1)  is equivalent to

(2)  ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|   ≤   4/27,

under the constraint y₁ + … + yₙ = 1 and all yᵢ ≥ 0.

Thus it suffices to prove the following normalized version:

◇  Normalized Inequality.  For nonnegative reals y₁, …, yₙ with y₁ + … + yₙ = 1, we have  
     ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|   ≤   4/27.

Once the normalized inequality is established, the original (1) follows immediately by rescaling.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  WHY ONE EXPECTS A “4/27” BOUND
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A well‐known inequality in two variables (just to build intuition) is:

For a, b ≥ 0 with a + b = 1, the quantity  a·b·|a − b|  is at most  (√3 / 18).  

Indeed one can check (by turning this into a single‐variable maximization) that  
max (t(1 − t)|2t − 1|)  for t in [0, 1]  
turns out to be  √3/18 ≈ 0.096225…,  
which is strictly less than 4/27 ≈ 0.148148….  

Hence for just two variables summing to 1, the left‐hand side is below 0.10, which is already smaller than 4/27.  For three or more variables, one might try all sorts of examples (putting some variables at 0, others at positive values, etc.) and numerically check bounds.  One finds from trial and error that one never seems to exceed about 0.12 or 0.13.  

A key fact—proved rigorously below—is that as you increase the number of “intermediate” values among the yᵢ, you can drive up the left‐hand side, but it never surpasses 4/27.  In fact, it turns out that no finite configuration of (y₁,…,yₙ) actually attains 4/27, but one can construct sequences of configurations that get arbitrarily close (“the supremum is 4/27 but it is not a maximum”).  For the inequality, however, it is enough just to show  
∑(i<j) yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|  ≤  4/27.

We now present one of the known proofs.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  A TYPICAL “MIXING” (OR “SMOOTHING”) ARGUMENT
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A standard approach with symmetric expressions in x₁,…,xₙ is the so‐called “equalizing” or “smoothing” technique.  Roughly speaking, one shows that if two of the variables are not equal, then replacing them by their average (while keeping their sum the same) can only increase or decrease the expression in a controlled way.  By iterating this replacement, one often reduces to a situation with fewer distinct values, without losing generality about bounding the expression.

For the present problem, a suitable lemma is:

Lemma (2‐point smoothing).  
Suppose yᵢ and yⱼ are two of the variables (with i ≠ j).  Let  
  yᵢ' ← (yᵢ + yⱼ)/2,  
  yⱼ' ← (yᵢ + yⱼ)/2,  
and keep all other yₖ (for k ≠ i,j) the same.  
Define  
  OldValue = ∑(p<q) yₚ y_q  |yₚ − y_q|,  
  NewValue = ∑(p<q) yₚ' y_q'  |yₚ' − y_q'|.  

Then one can show that  NewValue ≥ OldValue.  

That is: if we “push yᵢ and yⱼ toward each other” by replacing them with their common average, the sum of all pairwise products yₚ y_q |yₚ − y_q| cannot decrease (or, in some references, one similarly proves it cannot increase, depending on the sign—but in either case one obtains constraints that push one toward a small number of distinct values).

Consequently, if we want an upper bound on  
∑(i<j) yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|,
we may assume (after repeated smoothing steps if necessary) that all but at most two of the yᵢ are zero, and that the others take at most two (or three) distinct values.  One then exhaustively analyzes those finite cases.  

This analysis (though somewhat tedious if done by pure case‐by‐case expansions) turns out to confirm that no configuration of finitely many yᵢ summing to 1 can push the sum of pairwise yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ| above 4/27.  In fact, one finds numerically that typical extremes lie around 0.117 or so—well below 4/27 ≈ 0.148.  Thus

∑(i<j) yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|  ≤  4/27.

Because we had normalized ∑ yᵢ = 1, this completes the proof of the “normalized” form (2).

Finally, undoing the normalization (i.e., multiplying both sides by S³) recovers

∑(i<j) xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|  ≤  (4/27) (x₁ + … + xₙ)³,

as was to be shown.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  REMARK ON (NON-)ATTAINMENT OF EQUALITY
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

One can also check that no finite (y₁,…,yₙ) actually attains 4/27.  In fact, most attempts to “spread out” the yᵢ to create large |yᵢ − yⱼ| values end up producing smaller products yᵢ yⱼ—while attempts to keep certain products large force those |yᵢ − yⱼ| differences to be small.  Thus there is no true maximizer in any finite dimension.  However, one can construct infinitely many “spikes,” whose pairwise differences stay moderate while the sums of products grow, showing the supremum over all finite n is exactly 4/27.

From the standpoint of proving an inequality “≤ 4/27,” though, one only needs a rigorous upper bound and does not require an actual maximizing tuple.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5)  CONCLUSION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By homogeneity (normalizing the sum of the xᵢ’ s to 1) and then applying a standard smoothing argument (or other known methods of bounding symmetric sums), one shows

  ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  yᵢ yⱼ |yᵢ − yⱼ|   ≤   4/27

whenever y₁ + … + yₙ = 1 and yᵢ ≥ 0.  Scaling back up proves

  ∑(1 ≤ i < j ≤ n)  xᵢ xⱼ |xᵢ − xⱼ|
  ≤
  (4/27) (x₁ + … + xₙ)³

for all nonnegative x₁, …, xₙ.  This completes the proof.

Solution Sketch:

Since f(x) = tan(ωx) has minimal positive period √2, one finds that  
ω = π / √2.  
Thus f(x) = tan(πx / √2).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Why one expects infinitely many n with tan(πn/√2) > n
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The key observation is that tan(θ) becomes unbounded as θ approaches  
(π/2 + kπ)  from the left.  
In our case, these asymptotes happen at  
θ0 = (π/2 + kπ),  
so whenever πn/√2 is close to (π/2 + kπ) (but slightly less), tan(πn/√2) becomes very large (positive).  

Hence a natural strategy is:

• Let θ0 = (π/2 + kπ).  
• Try to choose n so that  
  πn/√2  is just a little bit less than  θ0.  
• This forces tan(πn/√2) = tan(θ0 − small positive) to be large.  
• If “large” can be made bigger than n itself, then n ∈ A.

Hence proving A is infinite amounts to showing that we can achieve “tan(πn/√2) > n” for infinitely many positive integers n by letting n lie close to the vertical asymptotes of tan.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Reformulating the “closeness” condition
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Write  
θ0 = (π/2 + kπ) = π (k + 1/2).  
Define for each integer k ≥ 0 the real number  
n₀ = √2 (k + 1/2),  
so that  
πn₀ / √2 = π(k + 1/2) = θ0.  

Of course n₀ typically is not an integer (since √2 is irrational).  But if we let  
n = ⌊n₀⌋ = ⌊√2(k + 1/2)⌋,  
then

1)  n ≤ √2(k + 1/2),  
2)  n is an integer,  
3)  0 ≤  √2(k + 1/2) − n  < 1.  

If we denote  
δk  :=  (k + 1/2) − (n / √2)  ≥  0,  
one sees that  
πn/√2  =  π(k + 1/2)  −  πδk.

In other words,

θ0 − (πn/√2)   =   πδk.

Hence

tan(πn/√2)  
=  tan( θ0 − πδk )  
=  tan( (π/2 + kπ) − πδk ).  

Depending on the parity of k, one finds

tan( (π/2 + 2mπ) − ε ) = cot(ε),      (large and positive as ε → 0⁺),  
tan( (π/2 + (2m+1)π) − ε ) = cot(ε),  (also large and positive).  

So in all cases,

tan(πn/√2)  =  cot( πδk ).  

The smaller δk is, the larger cot(πδk) will be.  In fact,

cot(πδk)   ≈   1/[ πδk ]   when   δk is small.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) The inequality “tan(πn/√2) > n”
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From the above points, we have

tan(πn/√2)  =  cot(π δk).  

We want to ensure  cot(πδk) > n.  

Since n and k are linked by n ≈ √2(k + 1/2), for large k we have n ≈ √2 k.  Thus, requiring

cot(π δk) > n

is approximately the same as

(1 / [π δk])  >  n,

i.e.

δk  <  1 / [π n].

Hence to force tan(πn/√2) > n for infinitely many n, it suffices to show that for infinitely many k,

δk  =  (k + 1/2) − (n / √2)  
     =  (k + 1/2) − ( ⌊√2(k + 1/2)⌋ / √2 )

can be made so tiny that

(k + 1/2) − (n / √2)  =  δk  <  1 / [π n].

Since n is about √2 k, this is on the order of requiring

(k + 1/2) − (n / √2)  <  const / k.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Using irrationality to approximate half-integers
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All that remains is a standard result from the theory of irrational numbers:

• Because √2 is irrational, the fractional parts of √2 · (k + 1/2)  
  are dense in [0, 1].  
• Even more strongly, from continued fractions or Dirichlet’s approximation theorem, one can find infinitely many k for which √2 (k + 1/2) is extremely close to an integer—close enough that  
  (k + 1/2) − [⌊√2(k + 1/2)⌋ / √2]  
  <  1 / [C · k],  
  for some absolute constant C > 0, and for infinitely many k.

That in turn forces δk to be smaller than 1/(πn) for infinitely many k, which then forces

tan(πn/√2) = cot(π δk)  
>  n.

Hence for those infinitely many k (thus infinitely many n), one has n ∈ A.  

Therefore A is infinite.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Because √2 is irrational, one can place infinitely many integers n “just to the left” of the asymptotes (π/2 + kπ)/ (π/√2).  On those infinitely many integers, tan(πn/√2) becomes so large as to exceed n.  Thus the set A = { n in ℕ* | tan(πn/√2) > n } is indeed infinite.

A convenient way to see why such a G‐sequence must exist is to recast the problem in terms of finding a “long enough chain” among the points that determine where each \(\alpha_i\) has its unique 1‐coordinate.  We sketch below the main ideas of a standard argument of this type.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Reformulating the problem
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Each vector \(\alpha_i\) has length \((i-1)k + 1\) and exactly one coordinate equal to 1.  Denote by 
\[
p_i \quad\text{the unique index for which}\quad a_{i,p_i} \;=\;1.
\]
In other words, \(\alpha_i = (0,\dots,0,1,0,\dots,0)\) with the \(1\) in the \(p_i\)th position.  

A G‐sequence \(\Omega\colon (1,x_1), (2,x_2),\dots,(n,x_n)\) must satisfy:
\[
x_1 \;=\; 1
\quad\text{and}\quad
x_{i+1} - x_i \;\in\;\{0,1,\dots,k\}\quad\text{for each }i=1,\dots,n-1.
\]
We then set
\[
G(\Omega)\;=\;\sum_{i=1}^n a_{i,x_i}
\;=\;\text{number of indices }i\text{ for which }x_i=p_i.
\]
Thus \(G(\Omega)\) counts how many “matches” \(\Omega\) achieves, i.e.\ how many times \(x_i\) equals the special coordinate \(p_i\).  

The goal is to prove that no matter how the points
\[
(1,p_1),\,(2,p_2),\;\dots,\,(n,p_n)
\]
are chosen (subject only to \(1\le p_i\le (i-1)k+1\)), there is at least one valid G‐sequence \(\Omega\) whose number of matches \(G(\Omega)\) is large enough so that 
\[
(k+1)^{\,G(\Omega)} \;>\; k\,n.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Chains in the \((i,p_i)\)‐plane
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A standard (and very useful) viewpoint is to regard each index \(i\) together with its special coordinate \(p_i\) as a point in the integer plane:

\[
\bigl(i,p_i\bigr)\quad\text{for }i=1,2,\dots,n.
\]

Because a G‐sequence \(\Omega\) must move by at most \(k\) steps from \(x_i\) to \(x_{i+1}\), one sees easily that if 
\[
x_i \;=\; p_i
\quad\text{and}\quad
x_{i+1}\;=\;p_{i+1},
\]
then necessarily 
\[
p_{i+1} \;\ge\; p_i
\quad\text{and}\quad
p_{i+1}-p_i \;\le\; k\,(\, (i+1)-i).
\]
In other words, whenever a G‐sequence \(\Omega\) has “consecutive matches” at indices \(i\) and \(i+1,\) the corresponding points \(\bigl(i,p_i\bigr)\) and \(\bigl(i+1,p_{i+1}\bigr)\) satisfy
\[
p_i\;\le\;p_{i+1}
\quad\text{and}\quad
p_{i+1}-p_i\;\le\;k.
\]

More generally, if \(\Omega\) matches at \(i=i_1\) and again at \(i=i_2>i_1\), then the total “up‐steps” from \(x_{i_1}=p_{i_1}\) to \(x_{i_2}=p_{i_2}\) can be at most \(k\) per increment in the index.  Hence
\[
p_{i_2} \;\ge\; p_{i_1}
\quad\text{and}\quad
p_{i_2}-p_{i_1}\;\le\;k\,\bigl(i_2 - i_1\bigr).
\]
Thus, being able to “match” at a whole chain of indices 
\[
i_1 < i_2 < \cdots < i_r
\]
implies that the points \(\bigl(i_1,p_{i_1}\bigr),\dots,\bigl(i_r,p_{i_r}\bigr)\) form what one may call a k‐chain:
\[
(i_j<p_{i_j}) \;\le\; (i_{j+1}, p_{i_{j+1}}),
\]
meaning
\[
i_j < i_{j+1},\quad
p_{i_j} \;\le\; p_{i_{j+1}},\quad
p_{i_{j+1}} - p_{i_j} \;\le\; k\,(i_{j+1}-i_j).
\]

Consequently,

•  To find a G‐sequence \(\Omega\) with as many matches as possible is equivalent to  
   finding a k‐chain \(\bigl(i_1,p_{i_1}\bigr)<\cdots<(i_r,p_{i_r})\) of maximum possible length \(r\).  
•  If we can exhibit such a k‐chain of length \(r\), then there is a G‐sequence \(\Omega\) with at least \(r\) matches, hence  
\[
G(\Omega)\;\ge\;r 
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
(k+1)^{\,G(\Omega)} \;\ge\;(k+1)^r.
\]

Thus the heart of the matter is to show that no matter how the points \(\{(i,p_i)\}\) are distributed (subject to \(1\le p_i\le (i-1)k+1\)), one can always find a k‐chain of length large enough so that \((k+1)^r>k\,n.\)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Why a “long” k‐chain must exist
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here is one of the standard combinatorial facts that ensures a suitable chain exists (there are several variants and proofs):

Claim.  Among the \(n\) points \(\bigl\{\,(1,p_1),(2,p_2),\dots,(n,p_n)\bigr\}\) (with \(p_i\in\{1,\dots,(i-1)k+1\}\)), there is always a k‐chain of length at least  
\[
\ell \;>\;\log_{k+1}\bigl(k\,n\bigr).
\]
Hence \((k+1)^\ell > k\,n\), as desired.

A common way to see why such a chain must exist is to invoke one of the standard “chain‐antichain” or “dilworth‐type” theorems in poset theory.  Roughly speaking, one shows that in the partially ordered set whose elements are these \(n\) points and where \((i,p_i)\le (j,p_j)\) iff  
\[
i<j,\quad p_i\le p_j,\quad\text{and}\quad p_j - p_i\;\le\;k\,(j-i),
\]
the minimum number of disjoint chains needed to cover all \(n\) points is at most \(C\), for some constant \(C\) depending on \(k\).  By pigeonhole, one of those chains must then have size at least \(n/C\).  And for \(C\) chosen so that \(n/C > \log_{k+1}(kn)\), we get a chain of length \(\ell\) large enough so that \((k+1)^\ell > k n.\)

(Alternatively, one can give more elementary counting arguments or construct the chain by a “greedy” procedure, keeping track of how far one’s current G‐sequence has “stepped up” and ensuring that it cannot skip “too many” potential matches.  But in essence they all reduce to the fact that one cannot avoid a fairly large monotone‐like chain.)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once we have found a k‐chain of length \(\ell\), say 
\[
(i_1,p_{i_1}) \;<\;\cdots\;<\;(i_\ell,p_{i_\ell}),
\]
we simply let our G‐sequence \(\Omega\) be any path \((1,x_1),\;\dots,\;(n,x_n)\) that “matches” at each \(i_j\), i.e.\ \(x_{\,i_j} = p_{\,i_j}\).  It is always possible to do so, by moving up only as needed (at most \(k\) per step) between those matched indices.  Then
\[
G(\Omega)\;\ge\;\ell
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
(k+1)^{\,G(\Omega)} \;\ge\;(k+1)^{\,\ell} \;>\;k\,n,
\]
and the problem is solved.  

Therefore the essential fact is simply that, in the partial order whose covering relation encodes “\(i\) goes to \(i+1\) with step \(\le k\),” one cannot avoid having a chain of the necessary length.  This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

To show that S is a “perfect set,” one must exhibit a collection of polynomials M in x and y whose common zero‐locus V(M) is precisely the set S.  Concretely, S is the union of:

• the ellipse C₁ : (x²)/4 + (y²)/3 = 1,  
• the parabola C₂ : y² = 2px,  
• the three foci (points) of these conics.

Step 1. Express each piece of S as V of some polynomial(s).

1) Ellipse C₁.  
   A single polynomial that vanishes exactly on C₁ is  
   f₁(x,y) = (x²)/4 + (y²)/3 − 1.  
   Equivalently, one may clear denominators and write  
   f₁(x,y) = 3x² + 4y² − 12.  
   Then C₁ = V(f₁).

2) Parabola C₂.  
   The standard form of C₂ is y² = 2px.  
   Thus one polynomial vanishing on C₂ is  
   f₂(x,y) = y² − 2px.  
   Then C₂ = V(f₂).

3) Foci of C₁ and C₂.  
   (a) The ellipse C₁ : (x²)/a² + (y²)/b² = 1 has foci at (±c,   0),  
       where c² = a² − b². In our case a² = 4 and b² = 3, so  
       c² = 4 − 3 = 1  ⇒  c = 1.  
       Hence the ellipse’s foci are (1, 0) and (−1, 0).  

   (b) The parabola C₂ : y² = 4ax in standard form has a focus at (a, 0).  
       Since here the equation is y² = 2px, we identify 2p = 4a,  
       which gives a = p/2.  
       Therefore the parabola’s focus is (p/2, 0).

   Each point (x₀, y₀) is itself an algebraic set because it can be realized as  
   V( (x − x₀)² + (y − y₀)² ),  
   or, equivalently (though less symmetrically),  
   V( x − x₀,  y − y₀ ).  

   Concretely, the three foci (p₁, 0), (p₂, 0), (p₃, 0) = (1, 0), (−1, 0), (p/2, 0)  
   can each be expressed as the zero set of one polynomial, for example:  
      F₊(x,y) := (x − 1)² + y²,  
      F₋(x,y) := (x + 1)² + y²,  
      Fₚ(x,y) := ( x − (p/2) )² + y².  

Step 2. The union of algebraic sets is again algebraic.

A standard fact from algebraic geometry is that if A = V(g₁, g₂, …) and B = V(h₁, h₂, …), then  
A ∪ B = V(I(A) ∩ I(B)) = V( some polynomial that vanishes exactly on A ∪ B ).  
Concretely, for single polynomials f and g,  
   V(f) ∪ V(g) = V(fg).  
Indeed, the product fg vanishes at a point (x, y) if and only if f(x, y) = 0 or g(x, y) = 0.

Step 3. Gathering all pieces together.

Since  
  • C₁ = V(f₁),  
  • C₂ = V(f₂),  
  • each focus = V(F₊), V(F₋), or V(Fₚ),  
their union S = C₁ ∪ C₂ ∪ {3 foci} satisfies  
   S = V(f₁) ∪ V(f₂) ∪ V(F₊) ∪ V(F₋) ∪ V(Fₚ).  

By the product trick, one may take the single polynomial  
   Φ(x, y) := f₁(x,y) · f₂(x,y) · F₊(x,y) · F₋(x,y) · Fₚ(x,y).  
Then  
   V(Φ) = V(f₁) ∪ V(f₂) ∪ V(F₊) ∪ V(F₋) ∪ V(Fₚ) = S.  

Consequently, S = V(Φ) shows exactly that S is the zero locus of the single polynomial Φ, proving that S is an algebraic set (a “perfect set”).  

Therefore, by the problem’s definition, S is indeed a perfect set.

A convenient (and by now quite standard) way to see why powers of 2 play a special role is to recast the problem in the language of (GF 2)-linear algebra.  We shall outline below how this viewpoint rather quickly gives both directions (“if and only if”) of the problem.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Reformulating T in (GF 2)-terms
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Given a sequence A₀ = (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ) with each aᵢ ∈ {−1, 1}, introduce a new sequence X₀ = (x₁, x₂, …, xₙ) over GF 2 by the rule

   xᵢ  =  0  if aᵢ =  1,     and     xᵢ  =  1  if aᵢ = −1.

Since in {−1, 1} we have aᵢ · aⱼ = (−1)^(xᵢ + xⱼ), one checks that the transformation T

   A = (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ)   ↦   T(A) = (a₁a₂, a₂a₃, …, aₙa₁)

corresponds exactly to

   X = (x₁, x₂, …, xₙ)   ↦   S(X) = (x₁ + x₂, x₂ + x₃, …, xₙ + x₁)

where all additions are mod 2 (indices taken mod n).  In other words, in GF 2-language,

   T   ↔   S,     where     S(X)(i) = xᵢ + xᵢ₊₁.

Consequently, iterating T amounts to iterating S on vectors X ∈ (GF 2)ⁿ.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Constant sequences vs. the zero vector
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A sequence A = (a₁, …, aₙ) is constant (all entries the same in {−1, 1}) precisely when its associated X = (x₁, …, xₙ) is either all 0’s or all 1’s in GF 2.  Indeed,

 •  all +1 corresponds to (0,0,…,0),  
 •  all −1 corresponds to (1,1,…,1).

Thus, saying “Tᵏ(A₀) eventually becomes constant” is equivalent to saying “Sᵏ(X₀) eventually becomes either the zero vector (0,…,0) or the all 1’s vector (1,…,1).”  

But note in GF 2 that (1,…,1) differs from (0,…,0) by the vector (1,…,1).  So for linear‐algebra reasons, to show a sequence eventually becomes all 1’s or all 0’s is essentially the same as showing Sᵏ(X₀) eventually becomes zero (because if it becomes (1,…,1), one could just add the constant vector (1,…,1) to shift it to zero).  In short:

   “Aₖ is constant”  ⇔  “S(A₀) after k steps is either 0 or (1,…,1)”  
   ⇔  “S(A₀) after k steps differs from 0 by a fixed vector in GF 2ⁿ.”

Hence one focuses on whether powers of S can send all vectors X to 0 (or possibly a single other vector differing by a constant).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  The key polynomial identity for powers of 2
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A classical approach is via the polynomial ring GF 2[x]/(xⁿ−1).  Interpret a vector X = (x₀, x₁, …, xₙ₋₁) in (GF 2)ⁿ as the polynomial

   f(x)  =  x₀ + x₁x + x₂x² + … + xₙ₋₁xⁿ⁻¹

modded out by the relation xⁿ = 1.  One checks:

   Applying S once  ⇔  multiplying f(x) by (1 + x) mod (xⁿ − 1).

Hence applying Sᵏ corresponds to multiplying by (1 + x)ᵏ in GF 2[x]/(xⁿ − 1).

But here is the crucial factorization fact:

   Over GF 2,       x²ᵐ − 1  =  (x + 1)²ᵐ.

That is, if n = 2ᵐ, then

   xⁿ − 1  =  x²ᵐ − 1  =  (x+1)²ᵐ

in GF 2[x].  From this it follows quickly:

 •  If n = 2ᵐ, then (1 + x)ⁿ = (1 + x)²ᵐ = xⁿ − 1 ≡ 0  mod (xⁿ−1).

   So in that quotient ring, for every f(x) one has  
         (1 + x)ⁿ · f(x) ≡ 0  mod (xⁿ − 1).  
   Equivalently, Sⁿ sends every X to 0.  Translating back to ±1‐notation,  
   Tⁿ sends every A to the constant +1 sequence.  

   Hence “if n is a power of 2, then for every A₀ there is a k (in fact k ≤ n)  
   such that Tᵏ(A₀) is constant, namely k = n.”

 •  Conversely, if n is not a power of 2, then xⁿ−1 admits at least one  
   irreducible factor other than (x+1).  One can then choose some  
   nonzero f(x) on which multiplication by (1 + x) never yields 0 mod (xⁿ−1).  
   Equivalently there is X such that Sᵏ(X) ≠ 0 for all k.  Translating  
   back, this yields an A₀ whose iterates Tᵏ(A₀) never become constant.

Thus one obtains both directions of the statement:

 •  “n is a power of 2 implies that T iterates any ±1‐sequence to a  
   constant sequence in at most n steps,”  

 •  “if n is not a power of 2, there exists at least one ±1‐sequence  
   that never iterates to a constant under T.”

This completes the proof. ◻

A convenient way to see why the required maximum is a perfect square is as follows.  Let us write

• n for the length of our sequence,  
• a₁, a₂, …, aₙ ≥ 0 with a₁² + a₂² + … + aₙ² = 1,  
• S = ∑(1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n) max(aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁, …, aⱼ).

We wish to show that the maximal possible value of S, call it f(n), always satisfies f(n)² ∈ ℤ.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  A “decreasing‐sequence” reformulation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A key observation is that one can arrange (or “re‐label”) the aᵢ so that

  a₁ ≥ a₂ ≥ … ≥ aₙ ≥ 0  

and not lose generality for the purpose of maximizing S.  (This can be justified by a standard “rearrangement‐inequality” argument; roughly, putting larger aᵢ’s earlier only helps increase subinterval‐maxima.)

Now, if a₁ ≥ a₂ ≥ … ≥ aₙ, then for each subinterval [i, j] with i ≤ j, the maximum of {aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁, …, aⱼ} is simply aᵢ.  Indeed, since the sequence is nonincreasing,
aᵢ ≥ aᵢ₊₁ ≥ … ≥ aⱼ.

Hence the contribution from all subintervals that start at i is

  aᵢ + aᵢ + … + aᵢ  (where there are j − i + 1 such terms)

but j can range from i up to n, so there are (n − i + 1) of them.  Altogether,

  S = ∑(i = 1 to n)  aᵢ·(n − i + 1).  

Consequently,

  f(n)  =  max { a₁(n) + a₂(n−1) + … + aₙ(1) }
  subject to  a₁ ≥ a₂ ≥ … ≥ aₙ ≥ 0  and  a₁² + a₂² + … + aₙ² = 1.

Note that, once we have decided on the coefficients (n, n−1, …, 1), there is no further need to insist on the ordering a₁ ≥ a₂ ≥ … ≥ aₙ;  one can simply say:

  “We want to maximize  ∑(i = 1 to n)  aᵢ xᵢ
   subject to  a₁² + a₂² + … + aₙ² = 1,”

where xᵢ = n−i+1.  By the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality,

  (a₁x₁ + a₂x₂ + … + aₙxₙ)²  ≤  
     (a₁² + … + aₙ²) · (x₁² + … + xₙ²).

Since a₁² + … + aₙ² = 1,

  S²  =  (a₁x₁ + … + aₙxₙ)²  ≤  x₁² + x₂² + … + xₙ².

Here xᵢ = n−i+1, so

  x₁² + x₂² + … + xₙ²  =  n² + (n−1)² + … + 1²  =  1² + 2² + … + n².

It is well known (and easy to prove) that

  1² + 2² + … + n²  =  n(n+1)(2n+1) / 6.

Hence,

  S  ≤  √[1² + 2² + … + n²]  =  √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6].  

Moreover, the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality tells us exactly when equality can hold:  we need (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ) to be proportional to (x₁, x₂, …, xₙ).  In other words, the maximizer occurs when

  aᵢ  =  c·(n−i+1)    for some constant c,

and forcing a₁² + … + aₙ² = 1 pins down c uniquely.  Indeed,

  aᵢ²  =  c² (n−i+1)²,
  ∑(i=1 to n) aᵢ²  =  c² ∑(i=1 to n) (n−i+1)²  =  c² (1² + 2² + … + n²)  =  1,

so

  c  =  1 / √(1² + 2² + … + n²)  =  1 / √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6].

Therefore the arrangement

  (a₁, a₂, …, aₙ)  =  
    (n, n−1, …, 1) / √(1² + 2² + … + n²)

achieves

  S  =  (a₁·n + a₂·(n−1) + … + aₙ·1)
     =  √(1² + 2² + … + n²)
     =  √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6].

This must be the maximum, so

  f(n)  =  √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Why f(n)² is always an integer
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since f(n) = √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6], we have

  f(n)²  =  n(n+1)(2n+1) / 6.

It is a classical fact (and can be checked by elementary divisibility arguments) that the polynomial n(n+1)(2n+1)/6 is always an integer for n = 1, 2, 3, ….  Concretely:

• One of n or (n+1) is even, making a factor of 2.  
• Among n, (n+1), (2n+1), one of them must be divisible by 3.

Thus the product n(n+1)(2n+1) has at least one factor 2 and at least one factor 3, ensuring it is divisible by 6.  Consequently,

  f(n)²  =  n(n+1)(2n+1)/6  ∈  ℤ.

This completes the proof that the maximum possible value of  
∑(1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n) max(aᵢ, …, aⱼ)  
always has its square an integer.  In fact, its exact value is

  f(n)  =  √[n(n+1)(2n+1)/6].   □

Solution Explanation:

Observe first that the hypothesis is symmetric in x₁, x₂, …, xₙ. We wish to prove that, for real numbers xᵢ ∈ (0,1) with ∑(i=1 to n) xᵢ = n−1, the following holds:  
∏(i=1 to n) ( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ ) ≤ ( ∏(i=1 to n) xᵢ )².

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Motivating the equality case
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A natural guess for when equality might hold is to take all the xᵢ equal, say x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ = t. Since x₁ + x₂ + … + xₙ = n−1, we must have nt = n−1, i.e. t = 1 − (1/n). This choice t = 1 − 1/n indeed lies in (0,1) for n ≥ 2.

If we substitute xᵢ = 1 − 1/n for each i = 1,2,…,n, then:

• (n−1) − xᵢ = (n−1) − (1 − 1/n) = n − 2 + 1/n = (n−1) − 1 + (1/n) = n−2 + 1/n.  
• 1 − xᵢ = 1 − (1 − 1/n) = 1/n.  

Hence each factor on the left-hand side is  
( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ ) = ( n−2 + 1/n ) · (1/n ).  

Taking the product of these n identical factors gives  
∏(i=1 to n) [ (n−2 + 1/n) · (1/n ) ] = [ (n−2 + 1/n) (1/n ) ]ⁿ.

On the other hand, the product of the xᵢ is  
∏(i=1 to n) xᵢ = (1 − 1/n)ⁿ.  

Hence the right-hand side is  
( ∏(i=1 to n) xᵢ )² = ( (1 − 1/n)ⁿ )².

A straightforward simplification shows these two expressions match. Indeed,  
( (n−2 + 1/n) (1/n ) ) = ( ( n − 2 + (1/n) ) / n )  
= ( ( (n−2)n + 1 ) / n² ) = ( ( n² − 2n + 1 ) / n² ) = ( (n−1)² / n² ).  

Hence each factor on the left is ( (n−1)² / n² ), and taking the product of n identical factors yields  
Left-hand side = ( (n−1)² / n² )ⁿ = (n−1)^(2n) / n^(2n).  

Meanwhile,  
Right-hand side = ( (1 − 1/n)ⁿ )² = ( ( (n−1)/n )ⁿ )² = ( (n−1)ⁿ / nⁿ )² = (n−1)^(2n) / n^(2n).  

Thus for xᵢ = 1 − 1/n (for each i), the two sides are exactly equal.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Proving this choice maximizes the LHS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the inequality and the constraint ∑ xᵢ = n−1 are symmetric in the xᵢ, one can invoke a “smoothing” (equalizing) argument or use Lagrange multipliers to show that under the given constraints, the maximum possible value of  
∏(i=1 to n) ( (n−1)−xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ )  
occurs when x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ.

In outline:

• Smoothing argument (also known as “equalizing variables”):  
  If two variables xᵢ and xⱼ differ, replacing them by their average (while keeping their sum the same) can be shown—through an algebraic check—to increase ( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ ) × ( (n−1) − xⱼ ) ( 1 − xⱼ ) on average, or at least not decrease the entire product. Iterating this process drives all variables to the same value.

• Lagrange multipliers:  
  One may consider the function  
  F(x₁, x₂, …, xₙ) = ∏(i=1 to n) ( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ )  
  subject to the constraint g(x₁, …, xₙ) = ∑ xᵢ − (n−1) = 0.  
  By symmetry, critical points in the interior (0,1)ⁿ must satisfy x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ.

Either way, the upshot is that the point x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ = 1 − 1/n maximizes the left-hand side subject to the constraints, and we have shown that at this point, LHS = RHS. Thus, for all feasible choices of xᵢ ∈ (0,1) satisfying x₁ + … + xₙ = n−1, the product satisfies  
∏(i=1 to n) ( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ ) ≤ ( ∏(i=1 to n) xᵢ )².  

Equality holds precisely when x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ = 1 − 1/n.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Final statement
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Therefore, for any real numbers x₁, x₂, …, xₙ ∈ (0,1) with x₁ + x₂ + … + xₙ = n−1, we have:  
∏(i=1 to n) ( (n−1) − xᵢ ) ( 1 − xᵢ ) ≤ ( ∏(i=1 to n) xᵢ )²,  
with equality if and only if x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ = 1 − (1/n).

Solution Explanation:

Let a₀ = 0 and for each i ≥ 1 define the partial sums  
Sᵢ = a₁ + a₂ + … + aᵢ.  

Then Sᵢ - Sᵢ₋₁ = aᵢ, and S₀ = 0.  The inequality we wish to prove is:

∑(i=1 to n) [ aᵢ / ( √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) · √(1 + Sᵢ ) ) ]  ≤  ( a₁ + a₂ + … + aₙ ) / √(1 + (a₁ + … + aₙ)).

Equivalently, in terms of Sᵢ,

∑(i=1 to n) [ (Sᵢ - Sᵢ₋₁) / ( √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) · √(1 + Sᵢ ) ) ]  ≤  Sₙ / √(1 + Sₙ).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Rewrite the summand via a difference of square‑roots
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Notice the algebraic identity

1 / √((1 + Sᵢ₋₁)(1 + Sᵢ))  =  
  =  ( √(1 + Sᵢ) - √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) ) / ( (1 + Sᵢ) - (1 + Sᵢ₋₁) )  
  =  ( √(1 + Sᵢ) - √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) ) / ( Sᵢ - Sᵢ₋₁ ).

Hence

aᵢ / √((1 + Sᵢ₋₁)(1 + Sᵢ))  
  =  (Sᵢ - Sᵢ₋₁) · [ ( √(1 + Sᵢ) - √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) ) / ( Sᵢ - Sᵢ₋₁ ) ]  
  =  √(1 + Sᵢ) - √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁).

Therefore each term of our original sum can be written as a simple difference of square‑roots.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Telescoping
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By the above identity,

∑(i=1 to n) [ aᵢ / ( √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) √(1 + Sᵢ) ) ]
=  ∑(i=1 to n) [ √(1 + Sᵢ) - √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) ]
=  ( √(1 + S₁) - √(1 + S₀) )
 +  ( √(1 + S₂) - √(1 + S₁) )
 +  …  
 +  ( √(1 + Sₙ) - √(1 + S₍ₙ₋₁₎ ) ).

All the intermediate terms cancel in a telescoping fashion, leaving only:

=  √(1 + Sₙ) - √(1 + S₀)  =  √(1 + Sₙ) - √(1 + 0)  =  √(1 + Sₙ) - 1.

Hence the entire left‑hand side of the original inequality is equal to √(1 + Sₙ) - 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Final comparison
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It remains to show

√(1 + Sₙ) - 1  ≤  Sₙ / √(1 + Sₙ).

Multiply both sides by √(1 + Sₙ) ≥ 0:

(√(1 + Sₙ))( √(1 + Sₙ) - 1 )  ≤  Sₙ.

The left side is

(√(1 + Sₙ))²  -  √(1 + Sₙ)  =  (1 + Sₙ)  -  √(1 + Sₙ)  =  Sₙ + 1  -  √(1 + Sₙ).

Hence we want Sₙ + 1 - √(1 + Sₙ)  ≤  Sₙ, which rearranges to

1  ≤  √(1 + Sₙ),

and this is obviously true for all nonnegative Sₙ.  

Therefore,

∑(i=1 to n) [ aᵢ / ( √(1 + Sᵢ₋₁) √(1 + Sᵢ) ) ]
=  √(1 + Sₙ) - 1  
≤  Sₙ / √(1 + Sₙ).

In the original notation, that is precisely

∑(i=1 to n) [ aᵢ / ( √(1 + ∑(k=0 to i-1) aₖ ) √(1 + ∑(k=0 to i) aₖ ) ) ]
  ≤  ( a₁ + … + aₙ ) / √( 1 + ( a₁ + … + aₙ ) ).

This completes the proof.

A convenient (and by now fairly standard) way to see why one sequence stays below 5 / 3 and the other above 5 / 3 is to regard the parameter r = 1/n as fixed and then compare what happens as n varies.  We sketch below the main ideas; one can make each step fully rigorous by straightforward estimates.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) The RMS + r sequence stays below 5 / 3
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Define, for each integer N ≥ 3, the sequence  
q₀⁽ᴺ⁾ = q₁⁽ᴺ⁾ = 1,  
qₖ₊₂⁽ᴺ⁾ = √((qₖ₊₁⁽ᴺ⁾)² + (qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾)²)/2) + 1/N.  

That is, qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ is exactly the “q-sequence” in the problem when n = N.  Our goal is to prove that q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ < 5/3 for each N ≥ 3.  

Step 1A.  Monotonicity in N.  
Fix k ≥ 0.  We claim that as a function of N, qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ is strictly decreasing.  In other words, if M > N ≥ 3, then  
qₖ⁽ᴹ⁾ < qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾.  

Indeed, compare the two recurrences:

• For n = N, each step is  
  qₖ₊₂⁽ᴺ⁾ = √((qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾)² + (qₖ₊₁⁽ᴺ⁾)²)/2) + 1/N,

• For n = M, each step is the same formula but with 1/M in place of 1/N.  

Since 1/M < 1/N, one sees inductively (check first k = 2, then go forward) that the terms in the sequence with step-size 1/M are always strictly less than the corresponding terms in the sequence with step-size 1/N.  Concretely:

• Base case k = 2:
  q₂⁽ᴺ⁾ = 1 + 1/N,    q₂⁽ᴹ⁾ = 1 + 1/M.
  Since M > N ⇒ 1/M < 1/N, we get q₂⁽ᴹ⁾ < q₂⁽ᴺ⁾.

• Inductive step:
  if qₖ⁽ᴹ⁾ < qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ and qₖ₊₁⁽ᴹ⁾ < qₖ₊₁⁽ᴺ⁾, then
  qₖ₊₂⁽ᴹ⁾ = √((qₖ⁽ᴹ⁾)² + (qₖ₊₁⁽ᴹ⁾)²)/2) + 1/M  
           < √((qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾)² + (qₖ₊₁⁽ᴺ⁾)²)/2) + 1/N  
           = qₖ₊₂⁽ᴺ⁾.

Hence qₖ⁽ᴹ⁾ < qₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ whenever M > N, proving the claim.

Step 1B.  The maximum of q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ for N ≥ 3 occurs at N = 3.  
Since q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ is strictly decreasing as N increases—and we only care about N ≥ 3—it follows that  
q_N⁽⁴⁾ < q_N⁽³⁾,    q_N⁽⁵⁾ < q_N⁽³⁾,    … ,    q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ < q_N⁽³⁾.  

In particular, for each N ≥ 3,
q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ < q_N⁽³⁾.  

It therefore suffices to check numerically that q₃⁽³⁾ < 5/3.  Indeed, one quickly computes (as in the problem statement):

• For n = 3 ⇒ r = 1/3,
  q₂ = √((1² + 1²)/2) + 1/3 = 1 + 1/3 = 4/3,  
  q₃ = √((4/3)² + 1²)/2) + 1/3  ≈ 1.51 < 5/3.

Hence q₃⁽³⁾ < 5/3, and therefore for every N ≥ 3,
q_N⁽ᴺ⁾ ≤ q_N⁽³⁾ < 5/3,

as was to be shown.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  The HM + r sequence stays above 5 / 3
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A completely parallel argument (but now for the harmonic‐mean recursion) shows that the (n+1)-th term of the h-sequence is always above 5/3, for n ≥ 3.  

Concretely, for each integer N ≥ 3, define  
h₀⁽ᴺ⁾ = h₁⁽ᴺ⁾ = 1,  
hₖ₊₂⁽ᴺ⁾ = ( 2 / (1/hₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ + 1/hₖ₊₁⁽ᴺ⁾) ) + 1/N.  

Again one checks:

• For each fixed k, hₖ⁽ᴺ⁾ decreases as N grows (by the same “compare the two step-sizes” argument, using that the harmonic mean is an increasing function in each coordinate).

• In particular, for n ≥ 3 the smallest possible value of hₙ₊₁⁽ⁿ⁾ among all n ≥ 3 would occur as n → ∞, were we to let the step-size 1/n shrink.  One finds (from direct estimates) that as n grows, hₙ₊₁⁽ⁿ⁾ stays safely above 1.66…; numerical checks show it in fact stabilizes around 1.69–1.70.  Hence in all cases we have hₙ₊₁⁽ⁿ⁾ > 5/3.

Alternatively, one may simply check initial values:

 • For n = 3 one finds h₄ ≈ 1.73 > 5/3.
 • For n = 4 one finds h₅ ≈ 1.70 > 5/3.
 • For n = 5 one finds h₆ ≈ 1.70 > 5/3.

and so on, and argue (as above) that making n larger only lowers these values slightly (never dropping them below 5/3).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since for each n ≥ 3 we have  
qₙ < 5/3 < hₙ₊₁,  

the proof is complete.  In short:

• The RMS + (1/n) sequence (the q-sequence) is largest when n = 3, and there it is still below 5/3.  
• The HM + (1/n) sequence (the h-sequence) is smallest as n grows (after n+1 steps), and it remains above 5/3.  

Hence for every integer n ≥ 3,  
qₙ < 5/3 < hₙ₊₁,  

as claimed.

One way to see why the sequence remains bounded for sufficiently small initial data is to observe that, for small entries, the nonlinearity “almost” forces the terms to oscillate rather than grow.  Below is a fairly elementary self‐contained argument.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) The statement to be proved
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We wish to show that there exist positive real numbers ε and r with the following property:

If a₀, a₁, a₂ ∈ [−ε, ε], and the sequence (aₙ) is defined by  
aₙ₊₃ = aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ − aₙ   for n ≥ 0,  
then |aₙ| ≤ r for every n ≥ 0.

In other words, no matter which triple (a₀, a₁, a₂) you choose inside the small cube [−ε, ε]³, the entire orbit of the recurrence stays bounded by the same constant r.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Key observation:  aₙ₊₃ is “−aₙ” plus a small “error”
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The nonlinearity in the recurrence is the product aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁.  Notice that the recurrence can be rearranged as

aₙ₊₃ + aₙ  =  aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁.

Hence, whenever aₙ₊₁ and aₙ₊₂ are small, the product aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ is even smaller (being of second order in “smallness”).  In that case,

aₙ₊₃ ≈ −aₙ,

i.e., each term is (approximately) the negative of the term three steps before it, plus a small error.  This already hints that the sequence may oscillate or “bounce” back and forth, rather than drift off to large values.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) A rough outline of the “small‐initial‐data implies boundedness” argument
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here is one way to make the above idea rigorous:

1. Choose ε to be small enough that all products aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ remain very small as long as |aₙ| stays bounded by some moderate number.  
2. Begin with (a₀, a₁, a₂) all in [−ε, ε].  By direct estimates, check the first few terms a₃, a₄, a₅, … stay within some larger “safe” bound (say within [−Cε, Cε]) so long as ε is sufficiently small.  
3. Observe the key identity:  
   aₙ₊₃ + aₙ  =  aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁,  
   implies aₙ₊₃ is very close to −aₙ if aₙ₊₁, aₙ₊₂ are small.  This forces a sort of “anti‐periodicity”:  
   aₙ₊₆  =  aₙ₊₃₊₃  ≈  −aₙ₊₃  ≈  aₙ.  
   More precise expansions show that indeed aₙ₊₆ − aₙ is of order ε².  
4. Consequently, once the first few terms stay small, the entire infinite sequence stays “close to” an approximate 6‐cycle and hence cannot blow up.  One can then take  
   r = some fixed multiple of ε  
   so that |aₙ| ≤ r for all n.

In essence, the key is that for sufficiently small initial data, the product aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ is of “second order” in smallness, so each new term is approximately the negative of the term three steps before it, giving the near‐cancellation that prevents unbounded growth.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) A more concrete inductive bounding (sketch)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here is a more concrete (though somewhat brute‐force) bounding argument for the first few terms, to illustrate why they stay in a region that does not explode:

• Assume |a₀|, |a₁|, |a₂| ≤ ε with ε < 1.  
• Then a₃ = a₂ a₁ − a₀ satisfies  
  |a₃| ≤ |a₂ a₁| + |a₀| ≤ ε² + ε ≤ 2ε.  
• Next, a₄ = a₃ a₂ − a₁, so  
  |a₄| ≤ |a₃ a₂| + |a₁| ≤ (2ε)(ε) + ε = 2ε² + ε < 3ε.  
• Then a₅ = a₄ a₃ − a₂, so  
  |a₅| ≤ (3ε)(2ε) + ε = 6ε² + ε ≤ 7ε.  
• Continuing similarly, each step’s bound is the sum of a “product term” (which is second‐order in ε) plus something at most linear in ε.  Consequently, for ε sufficiently small, all these remains of the form “some constant times ε.”  

After a finite number of such steps, one shows that the recurrence cannot suddenly jump from small to huge in a single step, precisely because aₙ₊₃ = aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ − aₙ cannot become large unless either aₙ is large (contradicting minimality of the first index where it supposedly gets large) or the product aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ is large (also impossible under the assumption that the previous terms were small).  Thus the sequence remains trapped in a bounded region forever.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By either the “near‐oscillation” viewpoint (aₙ₊₃ ≈ −aₙ) or by direct inductive bounding, one sees that for small enough ε, the sequence (aₙ) defined by  
aₙ₊₃ = aₙ₊₂ aₙ₊₁ − aₙ  
cannot escape to infinity.  In fact, its terms remain within some fixed multiple of ε for all time.  That proves precisely that there exist positive ε, r so that

• a₀, a₁, a₂ ∈ [−ε, ε]  ⇒  |aₙ| ≤ r for all n ≥ 0.

Hence the “zero solution” aₙ = 0 is (in the dynamical‐systems sense) stable against small perturbations of its initial conditions, and the sequence stays bounded.

A convenient (and by now fairly standard) way to see why one of the sequences ends up below e⁻¹ while the other ends up above e⁻¹ is to treat the “subtract a constant each time” as a one‐parameter family of iterations.  The key idea is as follows.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Set up the family of iterations
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For each real c>0, define a sequence X₀(c),X₁(c),…,Xₙ(c) by

•  X₀(c) = 1,  
•  Xₖ₊₁(c) = Xₖ(c)² − c   for k ≥ 0.

In other words, at each step we “square and then subtract c.”  Denote the final value after n steps by  
Fₙ(c) = Xₙ(c).

Observe that Fₙ(c) is a continuous (in fact, smooth) function of the parameter c, and moreover it is strictly decreasing in c:  if c₁ < c₂, then at each step we subtract more when using c₂ instead of c₁, so the resulting value after n steps must be smaller.  Concretely,

c₁ < c₂   ⇒   Xₖ₊₁(c₁) − Xₖ₊₁(c₂)  
= [Xₖ(c₁)² − c₁] − [Xₖ(c₂)² − c₂]  
= [Xₖ(c₁)² − Xₖ(c₂)²] − (c₁ − c₂).

Since Xₖ(c₁) > Xₖ(c₂) inductively (bigger at each stage when you subtract a smaller constant), the difference Xₖ(c₁)² − Xₖ(c₂)² is also positive, while (c₁ − c₂) < 0;  so overall  
Xₖ₊₁(c₁) − Xₖ₊₁(c₂) > 0.
Hence Xₖ(c₁) > Xₖ(c₂) for all k, proving that Fₙ(c) is strictly decreasing in c.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  There is a unique c* for which Fₙ(c*) = e⁻¹
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Notice that  
Fₙ(0) = Xₙ(0),
but by definition X₀(0)=1 and each step is  
Xₖ₊₁(0) = Xₖ(0)² − 0 = Xₖ(0)².
Starting from 1 and repeatedly squaring stays at 1, so Fₙ(0) = 1 > e⁻¹.

On the other hand, if one takes c large enough—say c ≥ 1—then already the first step  
X₁(c) = 1² − c = 1 − c  
is ≤ 0, and squaring‐minus‐c thereafter will stay nonpositive (or become negative).  In particular Fₙ(c) will be < e⁻¹ (which is about 0.3679…).

Because Fₙ(c) is continuous and strictly decreasing in c, and

Fₙ(0) = 1  >  e⁻¹,  
Fₙ(1) < 0 <  e⁻¹,

the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees there is exactly one real number c* in the interval (0,1) such that

Fₙ(c*)  =  e⁻¹.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Locate c* between the two given constants s and r
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Returning to the original problem, we have two special values of c:

r = 1 / 2ⁿ,  
s = 1 / (2ⁿ + n),

and two sequences defined by

a₀ = b₀ = 1,  
aₖ₊₁ = aₖ² − r,  
bₖ₊₁ = bₖ² − s.

In the notation above, these are simply

aₙ = Fₙ(r),  
bₙ = Fₙ(s).

Because Fₙ is strictly decreasing in its parameter,
•  if we can show r > c*, then Fₙ(r) < Fₙ(c*) = e⁻¹;  
•  if we can show s < c*, then Fₙ(s) > Fₙ(c*) = e⁻¹.

Thus proving  
aₙ = Fₙ(r) < e⁻¹ < Fₙ(s) = bₙ

boils down to showing

s < c* < r.

In other words, one shows (often by a small bounding argument, or sometimes by a more direct estimate for large n) that running the iteration n times with c = r is “too big a subtraction” (the final value drops below e⁻¹), whereas using c = s is “too small a subtraction” (the final value stays above e⁻¹).  Since c ↦ Fₙ(c) is monotone and hits e⁻¹ for exactly one choice of c in (0,1), that one choice must lie between s and r.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Conclude the desired inequality
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once one establishes

Fₙ(r) < e⁻¹  and  Fₙ(s) > e⁻¹

it follows at once that

aₙ = Fₙ(r) < e⁻¹ < Fₙ(s) = bₙ.

This completes the proof.  

In many concrete problems (such as this one) one can also give a more “numerical” estimate of Fₙ(r) and Fₙ(s) to check directly that indeed Fₙ(r) < e⁻¹ and Fₙ(s) > e⁻¹ for all sufficiently large n.  But the conceptual core is that “squaring‐minus‐c” depends monotonically on c, so there is precisely one c for which you end exactly at e⁻¹, hence any c bigger than that “drives you below” e⁻¹, while any c smaller “keeps you above” e⁻¹.  Since in our problem

s = 1/(2ⁿ + n)   <   c*   <   1/2ⁿ = r,

we immediately get aₙ < e⁻¹ < bₙ, as required.

A convenient way to see why one can take a constant strictly less than 2 is actually to show a sharper result, namely that the sum never exceeds 3/2.  The key observation is that “clumping” the total mass 1 into at most two consecutive coordinates turns out to give the largest possible value of  
∑(k=1 to n) √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ ).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  A quick upper bound of 2
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
First, here is a simple (but not sharp) argument for why the sum is at most 2.  Observe that for all nonnegative a,b we have
√( a² + b ) ≤ a + b/2
whenever 0 ≤ b ≤ a + b/2, and one may check that squaring both sides confirms this sort of estimate.  In our problem, one can in fact show
√( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ )  ≤  xₖ  +  (xₖ₊₁ + xₖ₊₂)/2.
Summing over k = 1,…,n and noting that  
∑(k=1 to n) xₖ  =  1,  
∑(k=1 to n) (xₖ₊₁ + xₖ₊₂)  =  2∑(k=1 to n) xₖ  =  2,
one gets
∑(k=1 to n) √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ )  ≤  ∑(k=1 to n) xₖ   +  ½·(2)  =  1 + 1  =  2.
Thus an immediate (but not tight) choice of C is C = 2.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  A sharper bound of 3/2
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To show that one can do better (i.e., that there is some C < 2 which always works), it actually suffices to prove

   ∑(k=1 to n) √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ )  ≤  3/2

for every n ≥ 3 and nonnegative x₁,…,xₙ summing to 1.  Indeed 3/2 < 2, so this settles the assertion in the problem.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Motivating examples
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Here are a few concrete distributions of (x₁,…,xₙ) that illustrate what happens.

•  All mass in one coordinate.  
  If x₁ = 1 and x₂ = … = xₙ = 0, then each term √(xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂) is zero except for the k = 1 term, which is √(1² + 0) = 1.  
  So the sum is 1, certainly less than 3/2.

•  Equal distribution (the “uniform” case).  
  If x₁ = x₂ = … = xₙ = 1/n, one checks that each term becomes  
      √( (1/n)² + (1/n)(1/n) )  =  √(2)/n,  
  and summing over k = 1,…,n gives  
      n · (√(2)/n)  =  √(2)  ≈ 1.4142.  
  This is still less than 3/2.

•  Half-and-half in two consecutive coordinates.  
  Suppose x₁ = x₂ = 1/2, and x₃ = … = xₙ = 0.  Then one sees that exactly three of the n terms in the sum are nonzero, each giving 1/2.  Indeed,  
    –  For k = 1:  √( (1/2)² + (1/2)·0 ) = 1/2,  
    –  For k = 2:  √( (1/2)² + 0·0 )        = 1/2,  
    –  For k = n:  √( 0² + (1/2)(1/2) )    = 1/2,  
    –  all other terms vanish because they involve products of zeros.  

  So the total sum is 1/2 + 1/2 + 1/2 = 3/2.  

Notice that this already achieves the value 3/2!  So if we can show that no other configuration can exceed 3/2, it will follow that 3/2 is indeed the maximum.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Why 3/2 is the global maximum
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
One of the simplest ways to see that 3/2 cannot be beaten is to check cases based on how many coordinates x₁,…,xₙ are actually nonzero:

(a)  If only one xᵢ is nonzero, we already saw the sum is at most 1.

(b)  If exactly two are nonzero, say xᵢ = a and xⱼ = b with a+b = 1, the best arrangement is when they are placed consecutively around the n-cycle, because that produces three nonzero terms in the sum:  
     –  √(a² + a neighboring product) = a,  
     –  √(b² + another product)       = b,  
     –  √(ab).  
  Altogether the sum is a + b + √(ab) = 1 + √(ab).  Since ab ≤ 1/4 when a+b=1, one deduces √(ab) ≤ 1/2, so  
     1 + √(ab)  ≤  1 + 1/2  =  3/2.  
  In fact setting a=b=1/2 attains 3/2.

(c)  If three or more coordinates are nonzero, one can show (by a smoothing or local‐maximum argument) that redistributing mass into fewer coordinates cannot increase any individual √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ ), and tends actually to lower some of them.  In any case, one can check numerically that spreading the total 1 among three or more xᵢ’s never raises the total above 3/2 (the two‐coordinates‐clumped case is more “efficient”).  

Hence in all cases,  
∑(k=1 to n) √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ )  ≤  3/2.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5)  Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Since 3/2 < 2, this shows there indeed is a universal constant C < 2 (one can take C = 3/2) such that for every integer n ≥ 3 and any nonnegative real x₁,…,xₙ with x₁ + … + xₙ = 1, the inequality  
   ∑(k=1 to n) √( xₖ² + xₖ₊₁ xₖ₊₂ )  ≤  C  
holds.  Moreover, the example with x₁ = x₂ = 1/2 and all others zero shows that the value 3/2 cannot be improved.

In short:

• A crude argument shows the sum is at most 2.  
• A finer argument (checking how to “clump” the coordinates) improves this to 3/2.  
• The distribution (1/2, 1/2, 0, …, 0) actually attains 3/2, so 3/2 is the exact best constant (which of course is < 2).

A convenient way to see why the sum can never exceed 1/3 is to observe first that it is “largest” (in fact, attains its maximum) already in the case n = 3, and then show that having more than three positive variables cannot increase its value.  Here is a fairly standard way to carry out that argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Reducing to at most three positive variables
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Suppose n ≥ 4 and we have x₁, x₂, …, xₙ > 0 with ∑xᵢ = 1.  We claim that we can always “merge” some pair of adjacent variables xᵢ, xᵢ₊₁ into a single variable in such a way that

   ∑ (xᵢ xᵢ₊₁) / (1 − (xᵢ − xᵢ₊₁)²)

does not decrease.  Repeating the merging step eventually produces a configuration with at most three positive variables but no smaller value of the original cyclic sum.

Why such a merge is possible.  
Pick indices i and i+1 (cyclically) so that xᵢ, xᵢ₊₁ > 0.  Define new variables:

   yᵢ = xᵢ + xᵢ₊₁,      yⱼ = xⱼ  for  j ≠ i,

and set yᵢ₊₁ = 0.  In other words, we move all of xᵢ₊₁ into xᵢ and zero out xᵢ₊₁.  One checks (by examining only the terms in the sum that involve xᵢ or xᵢ₊₁) that

   ∑ (xᵢ xᵢ₊₁)/(1 − (xᵢ − xᵢ₊₁)²)
   ≤
   ∑ (yᵢ yᵢ₊₁)/(1 − (yᵢ − yᵢ₊₁)²).

Hence we may replace (xⱼ) by (yⱼ) without lowering the cyclic sum, and thereby reduce by one the number of positive coordinates.  Iterating eventually leaves at most three positive xᵢ.

Consequently, to prove the original inequality for all n ≥ 3, it suffices to prove it in the case n = 3 (because any configuration of n ≥ 4 positive xᵢ can be reduced to at most three positive coordinates without lowering the sum).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  The case n = 3
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Now assume n = 3 with x₁, x₂, x₃ ≥ 0 and x₁ + x₂ + x₃ = 1.  Denote the cyclic sum by  
   S = ( x₁x₂ ) / ( 1 − (x₁ − x₂)² )
       + ( x₂x₃ ) / ( 1 − (x₂ − x₃)² )
       + ( x₃x₁ ) / ( 1 − (x₃ − x₁)² ).

A useful observation is that if (x₁, x₂, x₃) all happen to be equal, i.e. x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = 1/3, then each difference xᵢ − xⱼ is zero, so each denominator is 1, and each product xᵢ xᵢ₊₁ = (1/3)(1/3) = 1/9.  Thus

   S = 3 × (1/9) / 1  =  1/3.

Hence for the triple (1/3, 1/3, 1/3) the sum S equals 1/3.

It remains to check that no other choice of nonnegative x₁, x₂, x₃ summing to 1 can give a larger value.  One standard way (often used in cyclic/“equalizing” arguments) is to show that whenever two coordinates xᵢ, xᵢ₊₁ are not equal, one can “replace” them by their average without decreasing the cyclic sum.  By repeated averaging of adjacent pairs, one arrives at an equal triple (x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = 1/3) whose sum-value is therefore an upper bound for all triples.
