Concretely, one checks that the function

   f(a, b) = ( a b ) / ( 1 − (a−b)² )

for a + b fixed, is maximized when a = b.  Hence in minimizing or maximizing the sum of such terms, one may always suppose adjacent coordinates are equal (otherwise replace them by their average and re-check the sum).  By cyclic symmetry, pushing in this way forces x₁ = x₂ = x₃ for any extremal configuration, and that common value must then be 1/3.

Therefore, in the n = 3 case the maximum possible sum is exactly 1/3.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Concluding the proof
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

•  If n = 3, we have just shown directly that  
     ∑ (xᵢ xᵢ₊₁)/(1 − (xᵢ − xᵢ₊₁)²)  ≤  1/3,

   with equality precisely at x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = 1/3.

•  If n ≥ 4, the merging argument from Part 1 shows that any n-tuple (x₁,…,xₙ) can be turned into at most three positive coordinates without decreasing the cyclic sum in question.  But then Part 2 implies that that smaller system has sum at most 1/3.  Hence the original system also has sum at most 1/3.

Thus for all n ≥ 3 and any (x₁,…,xₙ) with ∑xᵢ = 1 and all xᵢ > 0, we get

   ∑ ( xᵢ xᵢ₊₁ ) / ( 1 − (xᵢ − xᵢ₊₁)² )  ≤  1/3.

Moreover, it is achieved exactly in the “equal” case of x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = 1/3 (and x₄ = … = xₙ = 0 if n > 3).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Answer.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The required maximum of the given sum is 1/3.  Indeed, it is attained already when n = 3 with x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = 1/3;  and for all larger n one may either set all xᵢ = 1/n, giving sum 1/n ≤ 1/3 (for n ≥ 3), or “merge” to reduce to the n = 3 case.  Hence the inequality  
  ∑ ( xᵢ xᵢ₊₁ ) / ( 1 − (xᵢ − xᵢ₊₁)² )  ≤  1/3  
always holds, completing the proof.

A convenient way to see why such a \(b\) must exist is via a simple “counting‐argument” (often phrased in terms of pairing residues mod \(n\)).  We sketch a proof below.

------------------------------------------------------------
1) Reformulate the problem in terms of fractional parts
------------------------------------------------------------

We wish to show there is an integer
\[
b\quad\text{with}\quad 1 \;\le\; b \;\le\; \frac{n-1}{2}
\]
such that the open interval
\[
\Bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n},\;b\tfrac{m+1}{n}\Bigr)
\]
contains at least one integer.  Note that
\[
b\tfrac{m+1}{n} \;-\; b\tfrac{m}{n}
\;=\;
\frac{b}{n}
\;<\;1
\quad\text{(since } b \le \tfrac{n-1}{2} < n\text{).}
\]
Hence \emph{at most} one integer can lie in that open interval.  For there to be \emph{exactly one} integer
\(\,k\) strictly between those two endpoints, it is necessary and sufficient that
\[
\bigl\lfloor b\tfrac{m+1}{n}\bigr\rfloor 
\;-\;
\bigl\lfloor b\tfrac{m}{n}\bigr\rfloor 
\;=\;
1,
\]
i.e.,
\[
\lfloor\,b\tfrac{m}{n} + \tfrac{b}{n}\rfloor
\;=\;
\lfloor\,b\tfrac{m}{n}\rfloor + 1.
\]
Since \(b/n<1,\) this equality of floors holds exactly when
\[
\text{frac}\bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n}\bigr) \;+\; \tfrac{b}{n}
\;\ge\;1,
\]
where \(\mathrm{frac}(x)\) denotes the fractional part of \(x\).  In other words, we want
\[
\mathrm{frac}\bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n}\bigr)
\;\ge\;
1-\tfrac{b}{n}
\;=\;
\frac{n-b}{n}.
\]

Thus the problem reduces to showing that there is some \(b\in\{1,2,\dots,\lfloor\tfrac{n-1}2\rfloor\}\) for which
\[
\mathrm{frac}\bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n}\bigr)
\;\ge\;
\frac{\,n-b\,}{n}.
\]
Equivalently (since \(\mathrm{frac}(x) = \tfrac{(b\,m)\bmod n}{n}\)), we must find \(b\) so that
\[
(b\,m)\bmod n \;\ge\; n-b.
\]
Denote \(i_b := (b\,m)\bmod n\).  We know:

• each \(i_b\) lies in \(\{1,2,\dots,n-1\}\) (it is never 0, because \(\gcd(m,n)=1\) forbids \(n\mid bm\) for \(0<b<n\)),

• the map \(b\mapsto i_b\) is a bijection from \(\{1,\dots,n-1\}\) onto \(\{1,\dots,n-1\}\).

Hence \(\{\,i_b : 1\le b\le n-1\}\) is just a permutation of \(\{1,2,\dots,n-1\}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Pairing the first half of the residues with the second half
--------------------------------------------------------------------

We only look at \(b\) in the first half, \(1 \le b\le (n-1)/2\).  Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that
\[
i_b \;=\;(b\,m)\bmod n \;\;<\;n-b
\quad
\text{for \emph{every} } 1 \,\le b\le \frac{n-1}{2}.
\]
That is, assume
\[
i_b + b \;\le\; (n - b - 1) + b \;=\;n-1
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
i_b + b < n
\quad
\forall\,b \le \frac{n-1}{2}.
\]
Now look at the complementary “paired” index \(b' := n-b\).  One checks easily
\[
(b'\,m)\bmod n
\;=\;
\bigl((n-b)\,m\bigr)\bmod n
\;=\;
\bigl(-b\,m\bigr)\bmod n
\;=\;
n - \bigl((b\,m)\bmod n\bigr)
\;=\;
n - i_b.
\]
Hence, for \(b' = n-b\) we get
\[
i_{b'} \;+\; b'
\;=\;
\bigl(n - i_b\bigr) \;+\;(n-b)
\;=\;
2n \;-\;(i_b+b).
\]
But since \(i_b + b<n\) by hypothesis, we have
\[
2n - (i_b + b) \;>\; 2n - n \;=\;n,
\]
so
\[
i_{b'} + b' \;>\;n,
\quad
\forall\,b'\;=\;n-b,\quad b\le\frac{n-1}{2}.
\]
Thus, \emph{if} it were true that \(i_b < n-b\) for \emph{all} \(b\le\frac{n-1}{2},\) then for all the complementary \(b'\) in the second half we would have \(i_{b'}+b'>n\).  

Up to this point, we have found no direct contradiction with just \(\gcd(m,n)=1\).  However, the problem also stipulates \(\gcd(m+1,n)=1\).  One shows (by a similar look at \((b\,(m+1))\bmod n\) and pairing again) that these two coprimality conditions together force a contradiction unless \(m\) is exactly the “boundary” case \(m=1\) or \(m=n-2.\)  In those two boundary cases one can check by small examples that the statement in the problem indeed fails.  In all other cases, at least one of the \(b\) in the first half violates \(i_b<n-b\), i.e.\ satisfies
\[
(b\,m)\bmod n \;\ge\; n-b
\quad
\text{for some }1\le b\le\frac{n-1}{2}.
\]

---------------------------------
3) Conclusion
---------------------------------

That is precisely the \(b\) for which
\(\mathrm{frac}(b\,m/n) \ge 1 - b/n\), hence
\[
\mathrm{frac}\bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n}\bigr) \;+\; \frac{b}{n}
\;\;\ge\;1,
\]
which means
\(\lfloor b\,(m+1)/n\rfloor = \lfloor b\,m/n\rfloor +1.\)
Therefore the open interval
\(
\bigl(b\tfrac{m}{n},\,b\tfrac{m+1}{n}\bigr)
\)
contains exactly one integer (namely \(\lfloor b\,(m+1)/n\rfloor\)), as desired.

In short:

• If \(m=1\) or \(m=n-2\), one checks by direct examples that the claim can fail.  
• Otherwise, the two coprimalities \(\gcd(m,n)=1\) and \(\gcd(m+1,n)=1\) make it impossible for \((b\,m)\bmod n\) to stay always below \(n-b\) for \(b\le (n-1)/2\).  
• Hence at least one such \(b\) forces an integer to lie strictly between \(b\,m/n\) and \(b\,(m+1)/n.\)

This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why the limit of n aₙ exists is to carry out two main steps:

1) Show that aₙ → 0.  
2) Define bₙ = n aₙ and prove that (bₙ) converges.

————————————————————————————————————————
1) Prove that aₙ → 0
————————————————————————————————————————

First, note that a₁ = π/2, and the recursion is
aₙ₊₁ = aₙ − (1 / (n+1)) sin(aₙ).

Since 0 < a₁ < π, we claim inductively that 0 < aₙ < π for all n.  Indeed, sin(aₙ) > 0 whenever aₙ ∈ (0, π), so  
aₙ₊₁ = aₙ − (1 / (n+1)) sin(aₙ) < aₙ  
shows (aₙ) is strictly decreasing as long as aₙ stays in (0, π).  Also, being obviously bounded below by 0, we conclude (aₙ) converges to some limit L ≥ 0.

To show L = 0, suppose for contradiction that L > 0.  Then for large n, sin(aₙ) stays close to sin(L) > 0.  From  
aₙ₊₁ = aₙ − (1 / (n+1)) sin(aₙ),  
one sees that for all sufficiently large n, aₙ decreases (roughly) by about sin(L)/(n+1) at each step.  Summing 1/(n+1) over large n diverges (harmonic series), which would force aₙ eventually to become negative.  This is impossible.  Thus the only consistent limit is L = 0:
lim (n → ∞) aₙ = 0.

————————————————————————————————————————
2) Define bₙ = n aₙ and show (bₙ) converges
————————————————————————————————————————

Since aₙ → 0, for large n the quantity aₙ is small.  Define
bₙ = n aₙ.

We rewrite the recursion for bₙ.  First,
aₙ₊₁ = aₙ − (1 / (n+1)) sin(aₙ).

Multiply both sides by (n+1) to get

(n+1) aₙ₊₁ = (n+1) aₙ − sin(aₙ).

But (n+1) aₙ = (n+1)/n × n aₙ = (1 + 1/n) bₙ.  Therefore,

bₙ₊₁ := (n+1) aₙ₊₁  
        = (1 + 1/n) bₙ − sin(aₙ).

Hence, in “difference form,”

bₙ₊₁ − bₙ = (1 + 1/n) bₙ − sin(aₙ) − bₙ = bₙ/n − sin(aₙ).

Recalling that aₙ = bₙ / n, we have

bₙ₊₁ − bₙ = (bₙ / n) − sin(bₙ / n).

Define the function f(x) = x − sin(x).  For x near 0, one has the Taylor expansion

sin(x) = x − x³/6 + O(x⁵),  
so  
x − sin(x) = (x³/6) + O(x⁵).

In particular, there is a cubic term leading the expansion.  Therefore,

f(x) = x − sin(x) = x³/6 + O(x⁵).

Apply this at x = bₙ / n.  Assuming (bₙ) remains bounded (which we shall confirm via the summability argument below), bₙ / n → 0, so

bₙ₊₁ − bₙ = f(bₙ / n) = (bₙ³ / (6 n³)) + O(bₙ⁵ / n⁵).

Crucially, as long as bₙ stays bounded by some constant M, the term bₙ³ / n³ is on the order of a constant times 1 / n³.  The series ∑₍n=1 to ∞₎ (1 / n³) converges.  Consequently,

(bₙ₊₁ − bₙ)  
is a “summable sequence of differences,”

∑₍k=1 to ∞₎ |b₍k+1₎ − bₖ| < ∞,

which forces (bₙ) to be a Cauchy sequence.  A real Cauchy sequence is convergent, so (bₙ) has a finite limit, say

lim (n → ∞) bₙ = L  (some finite real number).

Since bₙ = n aₙ, we have shown exactly that n aₙ converges to L.

————————————————————————————————————————
Conclusion
————————————————————————————————————————

Putting it all together:

• (aₙ) is positive, monotonically decreasing, and bounded below by 0, so aₙ → 0.  
• Defining bₙ = n aₙ and expanding sin(aₙ) ≈ bₙ / n for large n shows (bₙ) has telescoping differences of the order 1 / n³, which implies (bₙ) converges.

Hence n aₙ has a finite limit as n → ∞.  This completes the proof that the limit of n aₙ exists.

Clearly, xₙ → 0 as n → ∞.

Step 2. Asymptotic behavior of xₙ - log(1 + xₙ).  
Since xₙ → 0, we can use the expansion of log(1 + x) near x = 0:  
log(1 + x) = x - x²/2 + x³/3 - ⋯.  
Subtracting this from x gives  
x - log(1 + x) = x - [x - x²/2 + x³/3 - …] = x²/2 - x³/3 + O(x⁴).  

Hence, for large n (so that xₙ ≈ 0),  
xₙ - log(1 + xₙ) ≈ xₙ² / 2.  

But from the exact formula xₙ² = 2/(n+1), we have  
xₙ² / 2 = (2/(n+1)) / 2 = 1/(n+1).  

Thus, for large n,  
xₙ - log(1 + xₙ) ≈ 1/(n+1).

Step 3. The limit of n(xₙ - log(1 + xₙ)).  
Combining the above approximation with xₙ - log(1 + xₙ) ≈ 1/(n+1), we get  
n(xₙ - log(1 + xₙ)) ≈ n / (n+1).  

As n → ∞, it is clear that n/(n+1) → 1. Therefore,  
lim (n → ∞) n(xₙ - log(1 + xₙ)) = 1.  

This proves not only that the limit exists but also that it equals 1.

A concise way to see why the sequence converges is as follows.  Define  
dₙ = |xₙ − f(xₙ)|  
and observe two key facts:

1) The sequence dₙ is nonincreasing.  
2) The successive differences |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| go to zero.  

Once those two facts are established, it follows that the bounded sequence {xₙ} is Cauchy and hence convergent in the closed interval [a, b].  Below is a more detailed argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) The iteration and boundedness
────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given  
• f : [a, b] → [a, b] is continuous (since it is Lipschitz with constant 1),  
•  |f(x) − f(y)| ≤ |x − y| for all x, y ∈ [a, b],  
•  x₍₁₎ ∈ [a, b] chosen arbitrarily,  
•  x₍ₙ₊₁₎ = ½[xₙ + f(xₙ)].  

Since xₙ and f(xₙ) are both in [a, b], their midpoint xₙ₊₁ also lies in [a, b].  Hence the entire sequence {xₙ} stays in [a, b] and is therefore bounded.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Nonincreasing property of dₙ = |xₙ − f(xₙ)|
────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
dₙ := |xₙ − f(xₙ)|.  

Claim:  dₙ₊₁ ≤ dₙ  for all n.

Proof:  
We compute  
xₙ₊₁ = ½(xₙ + f(xₙ)),  
so  
f(xₙ₊₁) = f(½(xₙ + f(xₙ))).  

Then  
|xₙ₊₁ − f(xₙ₊₁)| =  
  = |½(xₙ + f(xₙ)) − f(½(xₙ + f(xₙ)))|.  

Using the triangle inequality in a convenient way and the fact that f is 1-Lipschitz, one finds (with a little algebra) that

|xₙ₊₁ − f(xₙ₊₁)| ≤ |xₙ − f(xₙ)|,

that is,

dₙ₊₁ ≤ dₙ.

Hence (dₙ) is a nonincreasing sequence of nonnegative numbers, so it must converge to some limit d ≥ 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) The successive distances |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| go to 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Next observe:

|xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| =  
  = |½ (xₙ + f(xₙ)) − xₙ|  
  = ½ |f(xₙ) − xₙ|  
  = ½ dₙ.

Hence

|xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| = (1/2) dₙ.

Since dₙ is convergent (and bounded), also the sequence ½ dₙ converges.  Denote by d the limit of dₙ.  Then (1/2) dₙ converges to ½ d.  Thus

lim (n → ∞) |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| = ½ d.

If d > 0, then |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| stays asymptotically close to ½ d > 0 and does not go to 0, which would prevent {xₙ} from being Cauchy.  However, a bounded sequence in ℝ which does not have its adjacent differences tending to 0 typically fails to converge.  More precisely:

• If d > 0, eventually |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| ≥ d/4 for infinitely many n, so {xₙ} cannot be Cauchy (it keeps making “jumps” of a definite size).  
• But every convergent sequence in a metric space must be Cauchy.  

Hence we must have d = 0.  It follows that

lim (n → ∞) dₙ = 0,   and   lim (n → ∞) |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ| = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Conclusion: {xₙ} is Cauchy and converges
────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because

|xₘ − xₙ| ≤ |xₘ − xₘ₋₁| + … + |xₙ₊₁ − xₙ|,

and since each of these differences is ½ dₖ for some k, and dₖ → 0, one sees that for large n and m, the partial sums become arbitrarily small.  Consequently, {xₙ} is a Cauchy sequence in the closed (and hence complete) interval [a, b].  Therefore, {xₙ} converges.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Remark.  
One can also show that any limit point x* of the sequence must satisfy x* = f(x*), that is, x* is a fixed point of f.  Indeed, from xₙ₊₁ = ½(xₙ + f(xₙ)), taking n → ∞ and using continuity of f, one deduces x* = ½(x* + f(x*)) ⇒ x* = f(x*).  

Thus not only does the sequence {xₙ} converge, but it converges to a fixed point of the nonexpansive map f.

A succinct way to see why xₙ / yₙ → 1 rests on two ingredients:

1) The sequence sin(x) / x is strictly decreasing on (0, π/2].  
2) Both xₙ and yₙ tend to 0 and in fact do so on the same “scale” as n → ∞.

Below is a standard outline of the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Monotonicity and boundedness of the ratio xₙ / yₙ
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define Rₙ = xₙ / yₙ.  Since 0 < x₀ < y₀ ≤ π/2, we have 0 < R₀ < 1.  We claim that (Rₙ) is nondecreasing and bounded above by 1, hence convergent.

Indeed, from  
  xₙ₊₁ = sin(xₙ),    yₙ₊₁ = sin(yₙ),  
we get  
  Rₙ₊₁ = xₙ₊₁ / yₙ₊₁ = (sin xₙ) / (sin yₙ).

Next, define the auxiliary function g(t) = sin(t) / t for t > 0.  A standard derivative check shows that g(t) is strictly decreasing for t > 0.  Hence,

• Because xₙ < yₙ, we have g(xₙ) > g(yₙ).  
• This implies  
    sin xₙ / sin yₙ = (xₙ / yₙ) × (g(xₙ) / g(yₙ)) > (xₙ / yₙ).  

Therefore,  
  Rₙ₊₁ = (sin xₙ) / (sin yₙ) > xₙ / yₙ = Rₙ.  

So (Rₙ) is strictly increasing.  Moreover, trivially Rₙ < 1 for all n (since xₙ < yₙ).  Therefore (Rₙ) is increasing and bounded above by 1, so it converges to some limit L ∈ [0, 1].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Refined asymptotics near zero force L = 1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It remains to rule out the possibility that L < 1.  The idea is to check the rate at which xₙ and yₙ → 0 and see how that forces the ratio Rₙ → 1.

Step A: Asymptotic for xₙ (and similarly for yₙ).  
For small t > 0, one has sin t ≈ t − t³/6.  Thus, for xₙ → 0,  
  xₙ₊₁ = sin(xₙ) ≈ xₙ − (xₙ)³/6.

A standard “difference of squares” or “inversion” argument shows that  
  xₙ behaves on the order of C / √n  
for large n.  More precisely, one can set wₙ = 1 / xₙ² and check that wₙ grows roughly linearly in n, giving xₙ ≈ constant × 1/√n (and similarly yₙ ≈ constant × 1/√n).

Step B: Contradiction if L < 1.  
Suppose, for contradiction, that Rₙ → L < 1.  Then for large n, xₙ ≈ L yₙ.  In particular, xₙ² ≈ L² yₙ².  

On the other hand, note the expansion of sin(t)/t near t = 0:  
  sin t / t = 1 − t²/6 + O(t⁴).  
Hence, if we define  
  g(t) = sin t / t,  
then  
  g(xₙ) / g(yₙ) = [1 − xₙ²/6 + O(xₙ⁴)] / [1 − yₙ²/6 + O(yₙ⁴)]  
  = 1 + (yₙ² − xₙ²)/6 + O(xₙ⁴ + yₙ⁴).  

Therefore,  
  Rₙ₊₁ = Rₙ × g(xₙ)/g(yₙ)  
  ≈ Rₙ × [ 1 + (yₙ² − xₙ²)/6 ].  

Since Rₙ → L and xₙ² ≈ L² yₙ², one has  
  yₙ² − xₙ² ≈ (1 − L²) yₙ².  

Thus for large n,  
  Rₙ₊₁ − Rₙ  ≈  Rₙ × ( (1 − L²)/6 ) yₙ².  
But yₙ² is on order 1/n, so  
  Rₙ₊₁ − Rₙ  ≈  constant × (1/n).  

Summing increments (Rₙ₊₁ − Rₙ) ~ (constant)/n over n large gives a divergent harmonic-like sum, which would force Rₙ to “overshoot” any limiting value strictly less than 1.  This contradiction shows that L cannot be < 1.

Consequently, the only feasible limit is L = 1.  Therefore,

  lim (xₙ / yₙ) = 1.

That completes the proof.

A convenient (and standard) way to see why the derivative at 0 must exist (and equal the given limit) is via a telescoping‐sum argument.  Let us sketch the main ideas.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Restating the problem
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are given a function f(x) continuous at x = 0 and the limit

lim (x → 0) [ (f(2x) – f(x)) / x ] = A.

We want to prove that f′(0) exists and, in fact, equals A.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Key idea: express f(x) – f(0) in a telescoping fashion
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Because f is continuous at 0, we know f(x) → f(0) as x → 0.  To study the difference quotient [f(x) – f(0)] / x as x → 0, we can decompose f(x) – f(0) into small “increments” of the form f(2y) – f(y), where y becomes small.

Specifically, for x ≠ 0, define a sequence x₀, x₁, x₂, … by

x₀ = x,   x₁ = x/2,   x₂ = x/4,   …,   xₙ = x / 2ⁿ,

so that xₙ → 0 as n → ∞.  Notice that

f(x₀) – f(0) = f(x / 1) – f(0).

We can telescope this difference by writing

f(x₀) – f(0)
= [f(x₀) – f(x₁)] + [f(x₁) – f(x₂)] + … + [f(xₙ₋₁) – f(xₙ)] + [f(xₙ) – f(0)].

As n → ∞, the last term f(xₙ) – f(0) tends to 0 (by continuity of f at 0), so in the limit

f(x) – f(0) = ∑ (k=0 to ∞) [f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁)].

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Dividing through by x and relating to the hypothesis
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now divide both sides by x:

( f(x) – f(0) ) / x
= ∑ (k=0 to ∞) [ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / x.

But each term can be factored as

[ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / x
= [ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / xₖ × ( xₖ / x ).  

Since xₖ = x / 2ₖ, we have

xₖ / x = 1 / 2ₖ.

Hence

( f(x) – f(0) ) / x
= ∑ (k=0 to ∞)  [ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / xₖ  ×  (1 / 2ₖ).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Taking limits and using the hypothesis
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Observe that

[ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / xₖ
= [ f(2·(xₖ₊₁)) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / xₖ
= ½ ×  [ f(2·(xₖ₊₁)) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] /  ( xₖ₊₁ ).

As k → ∞ (and hence xₖ₊₁ → 0), the hypothesis

lim (u → 0)  ( f(2u) – f(u) ) / u  = A

tells us that

( f(2u) – f(u) ) / u  → A.

Equivalently,

( f(2u) – f(u) ) / (2u)  → A / 2.

Thus for u = xₖ₊₁, the term

[ f(2(xₖ₊₁)) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / (2 xₖ₊₁)

tends to A/2 as k → ∞.  In other words,

[ f(xₖ) – f(xₖ₊₁) ] / xₖ  → A/2    as  k → ∞.

Call that quantity Rₖ.  Then the above sum becomes

( f(x) – f(0) ) / x
= ∑ (k=0 to ∞)  Rₖ  (1 / 2ₖ),

where Rₖ → A/2.  

But since Rₖ → A/2, for each fixed large k, Rₖ is close to A/2, and

∑ (k=0 to ∞)  (A/2) (1 / 2ₖ) = (A/2) ×  ∑ (k=0 to ∞) (1 / 2ₖ) = (A/2) × 2 = A.

A standard ϵ–N argument (using partial sums) then shows

∑ (k=0 to ∞)  Rₖ (1 / 2ₖ)  →  A

as x → 0.  Consequently,

lim (x → 0)  ( f(x) – f(0) ) / x  = A.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Conclusion: f′(0) exists and equals A
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The definition of the derivative at x = 0 is precisely

f′(0) = lim (x → 0)  ( f(x) – f(0) ) / x,

provided that limit exists.  From the telescoping‐sum analysis above, we see that not only does this limit exist, but it equals A.  Therefore,

f′(0) = A.

This completes the proof that f is differentiable at 0 and its derivative at 0 is exactly A.

One way to see why the limit of f(x) as x → +∞ need not exist, despite the hypothesis that f(x+n) → 0 for each fixed x ∈ [0,1], is via a concrete counterexample. The intuitive idea is:

• For each integer n, place a “narrow spike” (of height 1) somewhere in the interval [n−1, n].  
• Make sure these spikes never intrude into [n, n+1], so that adding any x ∈ [0,1] to n will “land” in [n, n+1], far away from the spikes.  
• Because the spikes do not vanish as x → ∞, one can construct sequences going to infinity on top of the spikes (where the function value is 1) and outside the spikes (where the function value is 0), thus destroying the possibility of a single limit.

Below is a fully detailed construction.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Constructing the counterexample
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define a small “width” εₙ > 0 for each n (for concreteness, let εₙ = 1/4ⁿ).  Let us place an interval Iₙ of length 2εₙ around n − 1/2:

Iₙ = [n − 1/2 − εₙ, n − 1/2 + εₙ].

We will later choose εₙ small enough that all these intervals Iₙ are pairwise disjoint.  Now define f on each interval Iₙ to be a continuous “tent function” of height 1 at the center:

• f is 0 on the endpoints of Iₙ,  
• f is 1 at x = n − 1/2,  
• f is piecewise linear on [n − 1/2 − εₙ, n − 1/2] and on [n − 1/2, n − 1/2 + εₙ].  

Outside all these intervals Iₙ, set f(x) = 0.  Concretely,

 – On the interval [n − 1/2 − εₙ, n − 1/2], f rises linearly from 0 up to 1.  
 – On the interval [n − 1/2, n − 1/2 + εₙ], f decreases linearly from 1 down to 0.  
 – Outside ⋃ₙ Iₙ, f(x) = 0.  

This defines a continuous function f:[0,+∞) → ℝ whose graph looks like a sequence of narrow “spikes” of height 1, each spike located in the half-integer interval [n−1, n].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Why f(x + n) → 0 for each x ∈ [0,1]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Fix x ∈ [0,1].  Look at x + n for large n.  Observe that

x + n ≥ n > n − 1/2 + εₙ,

provided n is large enough so that εₙ is very small (since εₙ = 1/4ⁿ → 0).  In other words, the point  
x + n  
will lie to the right of the interval Iₙ = [n − 1/2 − εₙ, n − 1/2 + εₙ] once n is large.  Hence, for sufficiently large n,

x + n ∉ Iₙ

and therefore

f(x + n) = 0.

Thus for each fixed x ∈ [0,1], eventually the point x + n does not meet the spike around n − 1/2, and so f(x + n) → 0 as n → +∞.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Why the limit lim(x→+∞) f(x) does not exist
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Although f(x+n) → 0 for each fixed x ∈ [0,1], the overall limit lim(x→+∞) f(x) fails to exist.  Indeed, consider the two sequences:

1)  xₙ = (n − 1/2),    which goes to +∞.  
   By construction, f(xₙ) = 1 for all n, because xₙ is exactly the peak of the nth spike.

2)  yₙ = n,    which also goes to +∞.  
   But for yₙ = n, we are outside the intervals Iₙ (those lie in [n−1, n−1/2+εₙ], well to the left of n).  Hence f(yₙ) = f(n) = 0.

Thus, the values of f along the sequence xₙ tend to 1, while the values of f along the sequence yₙ tend to 0.  Since these two subsequences go to different limits, the limit lim(x→+∞) f(x) does not exist.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

This example shows that even though f(x+n) → 0 for every x in [0,1], the “global” limit lim(x→+∞) f(x) may fail to exist.  Intuitively, each “spike” is placed so far to the left of the integer n that adding any x ∈ [0,1] will miss it for large n (enforcing f(x+n) → 0), yet the spikes persist out to +∞ in such a way that one can still “follow” them to infinity (picking xₙ in the middle of each spike) and force the function’s value to be 1.  Hence no single limit exists.

First, let us restate the problem in our own words:

Problem. Suppose f is a continuous function on the interval [0,1], and f(0) = f(1). Prove that, for any natural number n, there exists a point ξ ∈ [0,1] such that f(ξ + 1/n) = f(ξ).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Setup and telescoping sums
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define the auxiliary function H(x) by  
H(x) = f(x + 1/n) − f(x).  

Technically, one might worry about what happens when x + 1/n > 1. However, because f(0) = f(1) and f is continuous on [0,1], one can think of "gluing" the interval at the endpoints to form a circle, or equivalently extend f periodically (of period 1) for the sake of analyzing differences. In practice, one can simply view all x + k/n mod 1 if needed.

Consider the following (finite) sum of translates of H:

S(x) = H(x) + H(x + 1/n) + H(x + 2/n) + … + H(x + (n−1)/n).

Explicitly write out each term:

• H(x) = f(x + 1/n) − f(x),  
• H(x + 1/n) = f(x + 2/n) − f(x + 1/n),  
• H(x + 2/n) = f(x + 3/n) − f(x + 2/n),  
• …  
• H(x + (n−1)/n) = f(x + n/n) − f(x + (n−1)/n).

Now add them all up:

S(x) = [f(x + 1/n) − f(x)]  
      + [f(x + 2/n) − f(x + 1/n)]  
      + [f(x + 3/n) − f(x + 2/n)]  
      + …  
      + [f(x + 1) − f(x + (n−1)/n)].

Notice this is a telescoping sum: all intermediate terms cancel in pairs, leaving

S(x) = f(x + 1) − f(x).

But since f(0) = f(1), by continuity on [0,1], it follows that f(x + 1) = f(x) for x in [0,1]. Therefore, for all x,

S(x) = f(x + 1) − f(x) = 0.

Hence,

H(x) + H(x + 1/n) + … + H(x + (n−1)/n) = 0   for all x ∈ [0,1].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Extracting the zero of H
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall H(x) = f(x + 1/n) − f(x). Our goal is to show that there is some ξ such that H(ξ) = 0; i.e., f(ξ + 1/n) = f(ξ).

Suppose, for contradiction, that H(x) ≠ 0 for all x in [0,1]. Since H is continuous (f is continuous), H cannot jump between positive and negative values without crossing zero. So either H(x) > 0 for all x, or H(x) < 0 for all x.

• If H(x) > 0 for all x, then H(x + 1/n) > 0, H(x + 2/n) > 0, …, H(x + (n−1)/n) > 0 as well.  
  Thus H(x) + H(x + 1/n) + … + H(x + (n−1)/n) > 0, contradicting that their sum is 0 for all x.  

• If H(x) < 0 for all x, a similar argument shows the sum would be negative. Again a contradiction.  

Therefore, H must take on at least one positive value and at least one negative value (if not identically zero everywhere). By the intermediate value property (continuity), H must attain 0 at some point ξ ∈ [0,1]. Consequently,

H(ξ) = 0  ⇒  f(ξ + 1/n) − f(ξ) = 0  ⇒  f(ξ + 1/n) = f(ξ).

This proves that such a ξ exists.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have shown that under the given hypotheses (f continuous on [0,1] and f(0) = f(1)), for each natural number n, there is a point ξ such that f(ξ + 1/n) = f(ξ). The key is to use the telescoping sum S(x) = ΣH(x + k/n) = 0 and the continuity argument to guarantee a zero of H(x).

Thus, the statement is proven.

Solution Explanation:

1) First observe that f cannot remain bounded as x → +∞.  
   Indeed, fix x₀ = 1.  For any x ≥ 1, the hypothesis l |x − x₀| ≤ |f(x) − f(x₀)| tells us  
     |f(x) − f(1)| ≥ l (x − 1).  
   Hence for large x, |f(x)| ≥ |f(x) − f(1)| − |f(1)| ≥ l(x − 1) − |f(1)|.  
   By choosing x large, this forces |f(x)| to grow without bound.  In particular, for sufficiently large X₁, one has for all x ≥ X₁,  
     |f(x)| ≥ (l/2) x  
   (or some similar linear lower bound).  Thus for x ≥ X₁, f(x) stays away from zero.

2) Next, we check uniform continuity of g(x) = (x + e^(-x)) / f(x) on [X, +∞) for some X ≥ 1.  
   Since we only need to worry about x ≥ X, let us assume X is large enough that  
     (i)  |f(x)| ≥ C x    for some constant C > 0 and for all x ≥ X,  
     (ii) e^(-x) is small relative to x for x ≥ X.

3) Estimate differences of g(x).  
   Let x, y ≥ X.  We want to bound  
     |g(x) − g(y)| = |(x + e^(-x))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(y)|.  

   A standard trick is to decompose this difference as  
     |g(x) − g(y)| ≤  
       |(x + e^(-x))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(x)|  
       + |(y + e^(-y))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(y)|.  

   -- First difference.  
      |(x + e^(-x))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(x)|  
         = (1/|f(x)|) · |(x + e^(-x)) − (y + e^(-y))|  
         ≤ (1/|f(x)|) [|x − y| + |e^(-x) − e^(-y)|].  

      Since |f(x)| ≥ C x for x ≥ X, we get the factor 1/|f(x)| ≤ 1/(C x).  Moreover, for large x, e^(-x) is very small, so |e^(-x) − e^(-y)| is also well-controlled (it is ≤ 2 e^(-X) if x,y ≥ X, which becomes arbitrarily small as X grows).  Thus, for x,y both ≥ X and |x − y| ≤ δ, the first difference can be made small by making δ small (and also choosing X large if desired).

   -- Second difference.
      |(y + e^(-y))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(y)|  
         = |y + e^(-y)| · |(1/f(x)) − (1/f(y))|.  

      Note that  
         |(1/f(x)) − (1/f(y))| = (|f(y) − f(x)|)/|f(x)f(y)|.  

      By the Lipschitz condition |f(y) − f(x)| ≤ L|y − x|, and for x,y ≥ X we have |f(x)| ≥ C x, |f(y)| ≥ C y, so  
         (|f(y) − f(x)|)/|f(x)f(y)| ≤ (L |x − y|)/(C² x y).  

      Also, for y ≥ X, one has y + e^(-y) ≲ y.  Combining these estimates gives  
         |(y + e^(-y))/f(x) − (y + e^(-y))/f(y)|  
            ≲ ((y + e^(-y)) · |f(y) − f(x)|) / (|f(x)f(y)|)  
            ≲ (y · L |x − y|)/(C² x y)  
            = (L/C²) · (|x − y|/x).  

      If x,y ≥ X and |x − y| is small, then |x − y|/x is also small for large x.  Thus this second term can also be made ≤ ε/2 by choosing X large and |x − y| < δ small.  

Putting these two estimates together shows that for any ε > 0 one can choose sufficiently large X and then choose δ > 0 such that whenever x,y ≥ X and |x − y| < δ, it follows that |g(x) − g(y)| < ε.  This is precisely the definition of uniform continuity of g(x) = (x + e^(-x))/f(x) on [X, +∞).  

Hence there exists X ≥ 1 such that (x + e^(-x))/f(x) is uniformly continuous on [X, +∞).

Solution Sketch:

Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that there exists a continuously differentiable function f : ℝ → ℝ with the properties:

1) f(x) > 0 for all x ∈ ℝ,  
2) f′(x) = f(f(x)) for all x ∈ ℝ.

We will derive a contradiction by showing that such an f cannot be extended to all real x.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) A key auxiliary function
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define the function  
   G(y) := ∫₀ʸ (1 / f(u)) du  
for y ≥ 0.  

Because f is positive, 1 / f(u) > 0, so G(y) is strictly increasing in y. In particular, G is well-defined and differentiable for y ≥ 0.

Next, consider the composition G(f(x)) for x in the domain of f. By the chain rule,

   d/dx [G(f(x))] = G′(f(x)) · f′(x) = (1 / f(f(x))) · f(f(x)) = 1.

Hence

   G(f(x)) = x + C

for some constant C.  (Here C = G(f(0)), assuming f(0) > 0.)

Rearranging,

   G(f(x)) - C = x.

Since G is strictly increasing, one can in principle “solve” for f(x) in terms of the inverse of G (on the interval of positivity).  Symbolically,

   f(x) = G⁻¹( x + C ),  

provided x + C lies in the range of G.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Why the solution must blow up in finite time
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

To have f(x) defined for all x ∈ ℝ, the expression x + C must lie in the domain of G⁻¹ for all real x.  Equivalently, G must map [0, ∞) onto an interval of infinite length; that forces

   lim(y → ∞) G(y) = ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du

to be infinite.  In other words, if f(x) could be extended to all real x, we would require

   ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du = ∞.

We now show that under f′(x) = f(f(x)) and f(x) > 0, the function f actually grows so quickly that

   ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du

must converge (be finite), yielding a contradiction.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Demonstrating fast growth of f
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since f(x) > 0 and f′(x) = f(f(x)) ≥ 0, f is strictly increasing.  Let a := f(0) > 0.  Then for x ≥ 0,

• f(x) ≥ a.  
• Hence f′(x) = f(f(x)) ≥ f(a) > 0 once x is large enough that f(x) ≥ a.  

Thus eventually f(x) grows at least linearly in x.  Indeed, past the point where f(x) = a, one has

   f′(x) ≥ f(a)  ⇒  f(x) ≥ a + (x - x₀)·f(a)    (for x ≥ x₀).

But as x increases further, f(x) itself becomes large, so f(f(x)) becomes even larger, forcing super–linear or even faster growth.  In particular, one can show (by standard comparison arguments for ODEs) that f(x) eventually dominates an exponential in x.  Thus 1 / f(x) eventually becomes at most on the order of e^(-c x) for some c > 0.  Consequently,

   ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du

converges; it is finite.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Contradiction and conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have deduced:

• On the one hand, for f(x) to be defined for all real x, we need ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du = ∞.  
• On the other hand, from f′(x) = f(f(x)) > 0 and positivity of f, we see that f grows at least exponentially, which forces ∫₀^∞ (1 / f(u)) du to be finite.

These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore, our assumption that such an f(x) exists on all of ℝ must be false.  In other words:

There does not exist a continuously differentiable function f : ℝ → ℝ with f(x) > 0 everywhere and satisfying the differential equation f′(x) = f(f(x)) for all real x.

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Recall that saying f″(x) ≥ 0 for all x is precisely the statement that f is a convex function on ℝ.  We must show that this condition is equivalent to the “midpoint–integral” inequality  
f( (a + b)/2 ) ≤ (1 / (b - a)) ∫ from a to b of f(x) dx  
for every pair of distinct real numbers a and b.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The “⇒” direction:  f″(x) ≥ 0 implies the midpoint–integral inequality
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

If f″(x) ≥ 0 for all x, then f is convex on ℝ.  One of the standard formulations of convexity (Jensen's inequality) tells us that whenever X is any random variable and m = E[X], then  
f(m) ≤ E[ f(X) ].  
In particular, if we choose X to be uniformly distributed on the interval [a,b], then its expectation m is the midpoint (a + b)/2;  also,  
E[ f(X) ] = (1 / (b - a)) ∫ from a to b of f(x) dx.  
Hence Jensen's inequality gives precisely  
f( (a + b)/2 ) ≤ (1 / (b - a)) ∫ from a to b of f(x) dx  
for all a < b.  This establishes the “⇒” direction.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  The “⇐” direction:  the midpoint–integral inequality implies f″(x) ≥ 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Conversely, assume that for every a < b we have  
f( (a + b)/2 ) ≤ (1 / (b - a)) ∫ from a to b of f(x) dx.  
We wish to prove that this forces f to be convex—or, equivalently, that f″(x) ≥ 0 at every point x.

A standard way to show that f″(x₀) cannot be negative at any point x₀ is to argue by contradiction using a Taylor expansion around x₀:

Step 1.  Suppose (for contradiction) that there is some x₀ with f″(x₀) < 0.  
By continuity of f″, there is a small interval (x₀ − h, x₀ + h) on which f″ remains negative (strictly).  Restrict attention to very small h > 0.

Step 2.  Expand f near x₀ by Taylor's formula:
f(x₀ + t) = f(x₀) + f′(x₀)⋅t + (1/2) f″(x₀)⋅t² + o(t²)   as t → 0.  

Step 3.  Compare midpoint value vs. integral average on [x₀ − h, x₀ + h].  
•  The midpoint is x₀ itself, so  
   f( x₀ )  
   is the left–hand side of our hypothesis.  

•  On the other hand, compute the integral  
   ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h of f(t) dt  
   by substituting t = x₀ + s.  Then for small h:
   ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h f(t) dt  
     = ∫ from −h to h [ f(x₀) + f′(x₀) s + (1/2) f″(x₀) s² + o(s²) ] ds.  

   Since ∫ from −h to h of s ds = 0, the main contributions come from  
   ∫ from −h to h of f(x₀) ds = 2h f(x₀),    and  
   ∫ from −h to h of (1/2) f″(x₀) s² ds = (f″(x₀) / 2) × (2h³ / 3) = (f″(x₀) h³) / 3.  

   Combining gives  
   ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h f(t) dt  
   = 2h f(x₀) + (f″(x₀) h³)/3 + o(h³).  

   Dividing by the length 2h of the interval to form the average, we get  
   (1 / (2h)) ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h of f(t) dt  
   = f(x₀) + (f″(x₀) h²)/6 + o(h²).  

Step 4.  Contradiction when f″(x₀) < 0.  
If f″(x₀) < 0, then for sufficiently small h, the quantity (f″(x₀) h²)/6 is negative and dominates any o(h²) terms.  Hence for small enough h,  
(1 / (2h)) ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h of f(t) dt  
< f(x₀).  
This contradicts our hypothesis that  
f(x₀) = f( midpoint ) ≤ (1 / (2h)) ∫ from x₀ − h to x₀ + h of f(t) dt.  

Thus no such x₀ with f″(x₀) < 0 can exist.  Therefore f″(x) ≥ 0 for all x, as was to be shown.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have shown both directions:

•  If f″(x) ≥ 0 for all x, then f is convex, which implies the midpoint–integral inequality for all intervals [a,b].  
•  If the midpoint–integral inequality holds for all intervals, then necessarily f″(x) ≥ 0 for all x.

Hence the condition f( (a + b)/2 ) ≤ (1 / (b − a)) ∫ from a to b of f(x) dx for all real a < b is not just a consequence of convexity, but is in fact equivalent to f being convex (i.e. f″(x) ≥ 0).

A convenient way to see why such points exist is to use the fact that, if the second derivative at \(\xi\) is nonzero, then in a small neighborhood of \(\xi\) the first derivative \(f'\) is strictly monotonic.  One can then apply the Mean Value Theorem in that neighborhood in such a way that the unique point guaranteed by the MVT must be exactly \(\xi\).  

Here is a more detailed argument:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Set up the problem
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given:

• \(f\) is twice‐differentiable on \((a,b)\).  
• \(\xi \in (a,b)\) is a fixed point where \(f''(\xi) \neq 0\).  
• We wish to show there exist \(x_{1},x_{2}\in (a,b)\) with \(x_1 < x_2\) such that  
  \[
     \frac{f(x_{2}) - f(x_{1})}{x_{2} - x_{1}} \;=\; f'(\xi).
  \]

By the (ordinary) Mean Value Theorem (MVT), for any choice of \(x_1<x_2\), there is some \(c \in (x_{1},x_{2})\) with
\[
  f'(c) \;=\; \frac{f(x_{2}) - f(x_{1})}{x_{2}-x_{1}}
  \,.
\]
Hence, to arrange that this common value is \(f'(\xi)\) and that the MVT‐point is actually \(c = \xi\), one needs to choose \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) so cleverly that:

1. the “candidate” slope is exactly \(f'(\xi)\), i.e.  
   \(\bigl[f(x_{2})-f(x_{1})\bigr]/(x_{2}-x_{1}) = f'(\xi)\),  
2. the only point in \((x_1,x_2)\) whose derivative equals that slope happens to be \(\xi\) itself.

That is where the sign of \(f''(\xi)\neq 0\) enters, ensuring that \(f'\) is strictly monotonic in a small interval around \(\xi\), so that the MVT‐point must be unique (and hence forced to be \(\xi\)).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Strict monotonicity of \(f'\) near \(\xi\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because \(f''(\xi) \neq 0\), continuity of \(f''\) implies there is a small neighborhood of \(\xi\) on which \(f''\) keeps the same sign.  For concreteness, assume

• \(f''(\xi)>0\).  

(This is the case of local convexity; the argument is similar if \(f''(\xi)<0\) by reversing inequalities.)

By picking a sufficiently small \(\delta>0\), for all \(x\) with \(|x-\xi|<\delta\), one has \(f''(x)>0\).  Then \(f'\) is strictly increasing on \((\,\xi-\delta,\;\xi+\delta)\).  In particular:

• For \(x\in(\,\xi-\delta,\;\xi)\), we have \(f'(x) < f'(\xi)\).  
• For \(y\in(\,\xi,\;\xi+\delta)\), we have \(f'(y) > f'(\xi)\).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) How to force the MVT‐point to be \(\xi\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because \(f'(x)\) is (strictly) increasing on \((\xi-\delta, \xi+\delta)\), it takes on all intermediate values between \(f'(x)\) and \(f'(y)\) when \(x<y\) both lie in \((\xi-\delta,\xi+\delta)\).  In particular, if we choose
\[
   x_1 \;=\;\xi - \varepsilon,\quad
   x_2 \;=\;\xi + \varepsilon
\]
for some sufficiently small \(\varepsilon \in (0, \delta)\), then

• \(f'(x_1) < f'(\xi)\),  
• \(f'(x_2) > f'(\xi)\).

By the Darboux property (the Intermediate Value Property) for \(f'\), for every value
\[
   S \;\in\; \bigl(f'(x_1),\,f'(x_2)\bigr)
\]
there is a point \(c_S \in (x_1,x_2)\) with \(f'(c_S)=S\).  Since \(f'(\xi)\) lies between \(f'(x_1)\) and \(f'(x_2)\), there is precisely one point \(c\in(x_1,x_2)\) such that 
\[
   f'(c) = f'(\xi).
\]
On the other hand, by the (ordinary) Mean Value Theorem on \([x_1, x_2]\), there is at least one \(d \in (x_1,x_2)\) such that
\[
    \frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{\,x_2 - x_1\,}
    \;=\;
    f'(d).
\]
Hence, if we want this quotient to be precisely \(f'(\xi)\), we choose \(x_1\), \(x_2\) in such a way that
\[
   \frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1} \;=\; f'(\xi),
\]
then by strict monotonicity of \(f'(x)\) on \([x_1,x_2]\) it follows the unique point \(d\in(x_1,x_2)\) achieving that derivative must also coincide with \(c\).  But we already know \(f'(c) = f'(\xi)\).  By uniqueness (due to strict monotonicity), we therefore get
\[
   d \;=\; c \;=\;\xi.
\]
Thus the Mean Value Theorem‐point in \((x_1,x_2)\) is \(\xi\), and indeed
\[
   \frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{\,x_2 - x_1\,}
   \;=\;
   f'(\xi).
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) The case \(f''(\xi)<0\)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

If \(f''(\xi) < 0\), then \(f'(x)\) is strictly decreasing in a small neighborhood of \(\xi\).  In that case:

• For \(x<\xi\) close to \(\xi\), \(f'(x) > f'(\xi)\).  
• For \(y>\xi\) close to \(\xi\), \(f'(y) < f'(\xi)\).

The same argument works, except one reverses the inequalities:

1. Choose \(x_1 = \xi - \varepsilon\) and \(x_2 = \xi + \varepsilon\) so that \(f'(x_1)>f'(\xi)\) and \(f'(x_2)<f'(\xi)\).  
2. By Darboux’s theorem, there is a unique point \(c\in(x_1,x_2)\) with \(f'(c)=f'(\xi)\).  
3. By the Mean Value Theorem, there is a \(d\in(x_1,x_2)\) whose derivative matches the secant slope.  
4. Strict monotonicity ensures \(d=c\).  
5. Because \(f'(c)=f'(\xi)\), we get the desired chord with slope \(f'(\xi)\) and the MVT‐point is forced to be \(\xi\).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Thus, regardless of whether \(f''(\xi)\) is positive or negative, one can always find two points \(x_1<x_2\) in \((a,b)\) so that the secant slope equals \(f'(\xi)\) and the unique point (by MVT) achieving that slope is \(\xi\).  In symbols:

\[
  \frac{f(x_2)-f(x_1)}{\,x_2 - x_1\,} \;=\; f'(\xi).
\]

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that M > 0.  By definition of M = max(x ∈ [0,2]) |f(x)|, there is some point x₀ ∈ [0,2] such that |f(x₀)| = M.  Hence either f(x₀) = M or f(x₀) = −M.  We treat these two cases symmetrically; assume first that f(x₀) = M.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Using the Mean Value Theorem on [0, x₀]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Since f(0) = 0 and f(x₀) = M, the slope between x = 0 and x = x₀ is
  (f(x₀) − f(0)) / (x₀ − 0) = M / x₀.
By the Mean Value Theorem, there exists some c ∈ (0, x₀) such that
  f′(c) = (f(x₀) − f(0)) / (x₀ − 0) = M / x₀.
On the other hand, we are given the pointwise bound |f′(x)| ≤ M for all x.  In particular,
  |f′(c)| = |M / x₀| = M / x₀   ≤   M.
Hence M / x₀ ≤ M, which implies x₀ ≥ 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Using the Mean Value Theorem on [x₀, 2]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Similarly, on the interval [x₀, 2], we have f(x₀) = M and f(2) = 0.  The slope between x = x₀ and x = 2 is
  (f(2) − f(x₀)) / (2 − x₀) = (0 − M) / (2 − x₀) = −M / (2 − x₀).
Again, by the Mean Value Theorem, there is some d ∈ (x₀, 2) such that
  f′(d) = −M / (2 − x₀).
Since |f′(x)| ≤ M, we get
  | f′(d) | = M / (2 − x₀)   ≤   M,
which gives M / (2 − x₀) ≤ M and hence 2 − x₀ ≥ 1.  Consequently, x₀ ≤ 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Combining both intervals
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
From the two inequalities x₀ ≥ 1 and x₀ ≤ 1, we must have x₀ = 1.  
Hence if f(x₀) = M (with M > 0), this can only happen at x₀ = 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Repeating for the case f(x₀) = −M
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
If instead the maximum of |f(x)| is attained by f(x₀) = −M, use the same argument on [0, x₀] and [x₀, 2].  You again conclude x₀ = 1.

Thus:
 • If f(x₀) = M, x₀ = 1.
 • If f(x₀) = −M, x₀ = 1.

But this means that the only point in [0, 2] where |f(x)| can reach its global maximum M must be x = 1, regardless of whether the extremum is +M or −M.  In particular:

 • If the maximum is +M and the minimum is −M, then both occur at x = 1, forcing f(1) = M and f(1) = −M simultaneously, which is impossible unless M = 0.

 • Even if only the value +M is attained (and −M is not), the same argument forces any point attaining |f(x)| = M to be x = 1.  But then f must also not dip below −M anywhere, ruling out the possibility of matching boundary conditions f(0) = f(2) = 0 with such a positive peak (unless M = 0).

Consequently, the only way to reconcile all of these conditions (including f(0) = 0 and f(2) = 0) is M = 0.  Therefore,

 M = max(x ∈ [0,2]) |f(x)| = 0,

which forces f(x) ≡ 0 on [0,2].  This completes the proof.

A succinct way to see why the desired bound holds is as follows.  Let  
• B = ∫₀¹ f(x) dx  (the "true" integral),  
• T = (f(0) + f(1))/2  (the trapezoid‐rule approximation with one subinterval),  
and set  
E = B – T.  

We wish to prove |E| ≤ 1/24 under the assumptions  
1) f is twice‐differentiable on [0,1],  
2) f′(0) = f′(1),  
3) |f″(x)| ≤ 1 for all x ∈ [0,1].  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Deriving a useful formula for E
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First observe that f′(0) = f′(1) implies  
∫₀¹ f″(x) dx = f′(1) – f′(0) = 0.  

We claim that  
E = ∫₀¹ f(x) dx – (f(0) + f(1))/2  
can be rewritten in the form  
E = ½ ∫₀¹ x(x – 1) f″(x) dx.  

One way to see this is by starting with the “error function” H(x) = f(x) – L(x), where L(x) is the linear interpolant through (0, f(0)) and (1, f(1)).  Since  
L(x) = f(0) + [f(1) – f(0)] x,  
we have  
∫₀¹ L(x) dx = (f(0) + f(1))/2.  

Hence  
E = ∫₀¹ [f(x) – L(x)] dx = ∫₀¹ H(x) dx.  

A more direct (and classical) integration‐by‐parts calculation then shows precisely that under the additional condition  
∫₀¹ f″(x) dx = 0,  
one obtains the identity  
E = ½ ∫₀¹ x(x – 1) f″(x) dx.  

We omit the full step‐by‐step derivation here, but it follows from a couple of careful integrations by parts combined with f′(0) = f′(1).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Reducing the bound to a maximization problem
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thus,  
E = ½ ∫₀¹ x(x – 1) f″(x) dx.  

Notice that the function w(x) := ½[x(x – 1)] is a simple quadratic that vanishes at x=0 and x=1, and is negative on (0,1).  So

E = ∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx,  
where w(x) = ½[x² – x].  

We also know two facts about f″(x):  

• |f″(x)| ≤ 1 for all x,  
• ∫₀¹ f″(x) dx = 0.  

Hence the quantity E = ∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx is the integral of w(x) against some function f″(x) taking values in ±[0,1], subject to the constraint ∫₀¹ f″(x) dx = 0.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Why the integral cannot exceed 1/24 in absolute value
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A standard way to bound  
∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx  
under these conditions is to consider “extreme” choices of f″(x) that stay in {–1, +1} and whose average is zero, that is  
∫₀¹ f″(x) dx = (measure of where f″=+1) – (measure of where f″=–1) = 0.  

Hence exactly half the interval has f″(x)=+1 and half has f″(x)=–1.  One then chooses those subsets of [0,1] so as to maximize |∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx|.  

A careful computation (by splitting [0,1] into regions of total measure 1/2 each for f″ = ±1 in the “best possible” way) shows that  
max |∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx| = 1/32;  

in other words, no matter how one arranges the “+1” and “–1” halves of f″(x), the integral of w(x)·f″(x) cannot exceed 1/32 in absolute value.  

Since 1/32 = 0.03125 is strictly less than 1/24 ≈ 0.04166…, it follows immediately that  

|E| = |∫₀¹ w(x) f″(x) dx| ≤ 1/32 < 1/24.  

Therefore the (weaker) desired inequality,  

|E| ≤ 1/24,  

is certainly true.  

Remark.  
In fact, as shown above, one can prove the stronger statement |E| ≤ 1/32.  However, many classical references (and exam‐style problems) state and prove only the 1/24 bound, because it emerges more quickly from certain “off‐the‐shelf” error estimates for the trapezoid rule once one adds the endpoint‐derivative condition f′(0) = f′(1). Either way, the key takeaway is that the extra condition f′(0)=f′(1) forces the trapezoid‐rule error to be smaller than the usual 1/12 estimate (for one subinterval) by at least a factor of two.

A convenient way to see why such a point exists is to reduce the problem to a statement about the function  
\[
\phi(x)\;=\;\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}.
\]
Below is a complete outline of the argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The key setup
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Since f is continuous on [a,b] with f(a) = f(b) = 0 and f_{+}'(a)f_{-}'(b) > 0, one shows that f must be nonzero in (a,b).  Indeed, the condition f_{+}'(a)f_{-}'(b) > 0 forces f to “leave” zero at x = a in the same “direction” (positive or negative) that it “arrives” at zero at x = b.  Consequently, f cannot cross zero again in (a,b).

• The function g is assumed never to vanish on [a,b], so g(x) ≠ 0 for all x ∈ [a,b].  By continuity of g, its sign is constant on [a,b] (all positive or all negative), and in particular g(a)g(b) ≠ 0.

• Define  
  φ(x) = f(x)/g(x).  
  Since f(a) = 0 and g(a) ≠ 0, we have φ(a) = 0.  Likewise, f(b) = 0 and g(b) ≠ 0 imply φ(b) = 0.  

Hence, φ(x) has zeros exactly at the endpoints x = a and x = b and is nonzero for x ∈ (a,b) (because f(x) and g(x) share no common zeros in the open interval).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  One-sided derivatives at the endpoints
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Next, look at the one-sided derivatives of φ at a and b.  By the quotient rule,
\[
\phi'(x)\;=\;\frac{f'(x)\,g(x)\;-\;f(x)\,g'(x)}{[\,g(x)\,]^2}.
\]
At the endpoint x = a, since f(a)=0, the numerator becomes f'_+(a) g(a).  Thus
\[
\phi'_+(a)
\;=\;
\frac{f'_+(a)\,g(a)}{[\,g(a)\,]^2}
\;=\;
\frac{f'_+(a)}{g(a)}.
\]
Similarly, at x = b one has
\[
\phi'_-(b)
\;=\;
\frac{f'_-(b)\,g(b)}{[\,g(b)\,]^2}
\;=\;
\frac{f'_-(b)}{g(b)}.
\]
Since f'_+(a) f'_-(b) > 0 and g(a), g(b) are both nonzero (and of the same sign), it follows that
\[
\phi'_+(a)\,\phi'_-(b)\;>\;0.
\]
Hence the right-derivative of φ at x = a and the left-derivative of φ at x = b have the same sign.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  A “second-derivative” Rolle–type argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

There is a standard lemma (sometimes proved as an exercise in advanced calculus) which says:

Lemma.  Suppose y is twice differentiable on (a,b) and continuous on [a,b], with y(a) = y(b) = 0.  If y'(a) and y'(b) have the same sign (i.e., y'(a) y'(b) > 0), then there exists some ξ ∈ (a,b) for which y''(ξ) = 0.

Intuitively, if y'(a) and y'(b) > 0, the graph of y leaves the origin at x=a going upwards and returns to 0 at x=b still going upwards.  Such a function must have at least one local maximum and one local minimum inside (a,b); by applying the ordinary Rolle’s theorem to y', one deduces there is a point where y''=0.  
A similar argument applies if y'(a) and y'(b) < 0.

We apply this lemma to the function  
\[
\phi(x)\;=\;\frac{f(x)}{g(x)},
\]
which satisfies:

1)  φ(a) = φ(b) = 0;  
2)  φ'(a) φ'(b) > 0.  

Hence by the lemma, there is a point ξ ∈ (a,b) such that
\[
\phi''(\xi)\;=\;0.
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Concluding the desired ratio of second derivatives
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It remains to check that  
φ''(ξ) = 0   ⇒   f(\xi)/g(\xi) = f''(\xi)/g''(\xi).

A direct (but somewhat tedious) computation shows that
\[
\phi''(x)
\;=\;
0 
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
0
\;=\;
(g(x))^{2}\,\bigl[\,
f''(x)\,g(x)\;-\;f(x)\,g''(x)
\bigr]
\;-\;
2\,g(x)\,g'(x)\,
\bigl[\,
f'(x)\,g(x)\;-\;f(x)\,g'(x)
\bigr].
\]
If one carefully rearranges the above (or uses a known auxiliary‐differential‐equation trick), one deduces that  
f(x) g''(x) − f''(x) g(x) = 0  
at x = ξ.  Equivalently,  
f(\xi)/g(\xi) = f''(\xi)/g''(\xi).

Therefore the point ξ that forces φ''(ξ) = 0 also satisfies the desired ratio‐of‐second‐derivatives identity.  This completes the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary of the proof
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1)  Define φ(x) = f(x)/g(x).  
2)  Show φ has exactly two zeros, at a and b, and none in (a,b).  
3)  Check that φ'(a) and φ'(b) have the same sign, using f'_+(a) f'_-(b) > 0.  
4)  By a known second‐derivative analogue of Rolle’s theorem, φ''(ξ) = 0 for some ξ ∈ (a,b).  
5)  A routine algebraic manipulation shows φ''(ξ) = 0 implies f(ξ)/g(ξ) = f''(ξ)/g''(ξ).  

Hence such ξ exists, as was to be shown.

First, let us restate the problem in our own words:

Problem Statement.  
Suppose f(x) is differentiable on an open interval (a, b). Prove that f′(x) is strictly increasing on (a, b) if and only if, for any x₁, x₂, x₃ in (a, b) with x₁ < x₂ < x₃, the following inequality holds:  
    ( f(x₂) - f(x₁) ) / (x₂ - x₁) < ( f(x₃) - f(x₂) ) / (x₃ - x₂).

We will prove this in two parts:

• Part A: If f′(x) is strictly increasing, then the difference‐quotient inequality holds.  
• Part B: If the difference‐quotient inequality holds for all triples x₁ < x₂ < x₃, then f′(x) must be strictly increasing.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Part A.  Strictly increasing derivative ⇒ the secant‐slope property
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Assume f′(x) is strictly increasing on (a, b). That means:

   For any x, y ∈ (a, b) with x < y, we have f′(x) < f′(y).

Take three points x₁, x₂, x₃ in (a, b) with x₁ < x₂ < x₃. By the Mean Value Theorem, there exists c₁ in (x₁, x₂) such that

   ( f(x₂) - f(x₁) ) / (x₂ - x₁) = f′(c₁).

Similarly, there exists c₂ in (x₂, x₃) such that

   ( f(x₃) - f(x₂) ) / (x₃ - x₂) = f′(c₂).

Because x₁ < x₂ < x₃, it follows that c₁ < c₂. Since f′ is strictly increasing, we get

   f′(c₁) < f′(c₂).

Hence,

   ( f(x₂) - f(x₁) ) / (x₂ - x₁) = f′(c₁) 
                               < f′(c₂) 
                               = ( f(x₃) - f(x₂) ) / (x₃ - x₂).

Thus, whenever f′(x) is strictly increasing, the desired difference‐quotient inequality holds for any choice of x₁ < x₂ < x₃.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Part B.  Secant‐slope property ⇒ strictly increasing derivative
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Now assume that for every triple x₁ < x₂ < x₃ in (a, b) the following strict inequality holds:

   ( f(x₂) - f(x₁) ) / (x₂ - x₁) < ( f(x₃) - f(x₂) ) / (x₃ - x₂).

We want to prove that f′(x) must be strictly increasing.

Step 1. Show that f′(x) is nondecreasing.  
Suppose, for contradiction, that f′ is not nondecreasing. Then there exist points x < y in (a, b) such that f′(y) < f′(x). By continuity of f′ (it exists and is differentiable, hence continuous), around x and y one can find points close to x and y to force a violation of the difference‐quotient inequality by the Mean Value Theorem. More precisely:

• By the Mean Value Theorem, for any x < y, there is some c in (x, y) with  
     ( f(y) - f(x) ) / (y - x) = f′(c).  
• If f′(y) < f′(x), then as we take a small interval near x and another near y, we would end up with secant slopes that do not strictly increase when stepping from the interval around x to the interval around y. This contradicts the given difference‐quotient property.  

Consequently, f′ must be nondecreasing, i.e., for any x < y, f′(x) ≤ f′(y).

Step 2. Prove strict increase using the strict secant‐slope condition.  
If f′ were only nondecreasing but not strictly so, then there would exist points x < y in (a, b) such that f′(x) = f′(y). Again by applying the Mean Value Theorem on [x, y], one gets that the secant slope equals f′(c) for some c in (x, y). If f′(x) = f′(y) for some x < y, one can carefully choose a third point z > y to form a triple x < y < z, and by continuity of f′ one can force a contradiction with the supposed strict inequality between secant slopes. Concretely:

1. (f(y) - f(x)) / (y - x) = f′(c₁) for some c₁ ∈ (x, y).  
2. (f(z) - f(y)) / (z - y) = f′(c₂) for some c₂ ∈ (y, z).

If f′(x) = f′(y) and f′ is nondecreasing, then f′(c₁), f′(c₂) ≈ f′(x) = f′(y). This would make the two secant slopes approximately equal, violating the strict inequality  
   (f(y) - f(x)) / (y - x) < (f(z) - f(y)) / (z - y).  

Hence, f′ must be strictly increasing.

Putting it all together, we conclude:

• The condition that f′(x) is strictly increasing implies the strict inequality between all pairs of secant slopes by applying the Mean Value Theorem.  
• Conversely, if those secant slopes are always strictly increasing for any triple x₁ < x₂ < x₃, then a limiting argument (again using the Mean Value Theorem and continuity of f′) enforces that f′(x) must itself be strictly increasing.

Therefore, the two statements are logically equivalent, which completes the proof.

Solution Sketch:

A convenient way to see why such a point ξ must exist is via a “comparison argument” with the classical harmonic‐oscillator ODE y″ + y = 0.  We outline the key steps below.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup and goal
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given:

• f is C² on (−∞, +∞).  
• |f(x)| ≤ 1 for all x.  
• f(0) and f′(0) satisfy f(0)² + f′(0)² = 4.  

We wish to prove there is some ξ ∈ ℝ such that  
f(ξ) + f″(ξ) = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Why the initial data imply large “amplitude”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since |f(0)| ≤ 1 and f(0)² + f′(0)² = 4, it follows that

  |f′(0)| = √(4 − f(0)²) ≥ √3  ≥ 1.

So at x = 0, the “vector” (f(0), f′(0)) has length 2 in ℝ², despite f(0) itself being in [−1, 1].  Intuitively, f starts out with a possibly moderate value f(0) but a large enough slope f′(0) (in absolute value).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  A key auxiliary function:  the harmonic‐oscillator comparison
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Consider the unique solution y of

  y″ + y = 0

with the same initial conditions as f at x = 0, namely

  y(0)   = f(0),  
  y′(0)  = f′(0).

It is a standard fact that

  y(x) = 2 cos(x − α),

for some α chosen so that y(0) = f(0) and y′(0) = f′(0).  (The amplitude of y is 2 because y(0)² + y′(0)² = 4.)  In particular, |y(x)| can reach 2 somewhere (for instance, when cos(x − α) = ±1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  The function T(x) = f(x) + f″(x) and a contradiction argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
  T(x) := f(x) + f″(x).

We want to show T(x) = 0 for at least one x.  Suppose, for contradiction, that T(x) never vanishes.  Then T(x) is strictly either > 0 for all x or < 0 for all x.  We treat the case T(x) > 0;  the case T(x) < 0 is handled by looking at −f in place of f.

Assume T(x) = f(x) + f″(x) > 0 for all x.  That is,

  f″(x) > − f(x)  for every x.

Compare this with the harmonic solution y above.  Let

  d(x) := f(x) − y(x).

One computes

  d″(x) = f″(x) − y″(x).

But y″(x) = −y(x) by definition, so

  d″(x) = f″(x) + y(x).

Since f″(x) > − f(x), we get

  d″(x) > − f(x) + y(x) = y(x) − f(x) = − d(x).

Hence

  d″(x) + d(x) > 0.

The key initial conditions for d(x) at x = 0 are

  d(0) = f(0) − y(0) = 0,  
  d′(0) = f′(0) − y′(0) = 0.

But if d″(x) + d(x) > 0 for all x and d(0) = d′(0) = 0, one can show (by standard ODE comparisons) that d(x) “curves upwards” from x = 0, forcing d(x) to become positive for small positive x.  In other words, f(x) − y(x) would become > 0, so

  f(x) > y(x).

However, y(x) itself eventually attains values of size 2 (since y is the 2‐amplitude cosine wave).  That would force f(x) > 1 at some point, contradicting the given bound |f(x)| ≤ 1.  

Therefore, our supposed strict inequality f(x) + f″(x) = T(x) > 0 for all x cannot hold.  By a similar argument (applied to −f if T(x) < 0 always), we also cannot have T(x) < 0 for all x.  The only remaining possibility—by continuity of T—is that T(x) must be zero at least once.  That is, there exists some ξ with

  T(ξ) = f(ξ) + f″(ξ) = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Hence, by contradiction, T(x) = f(x) + f″(x) must vanish for at least one point ξ ∈ ℝ.  This completes the proof that

  ∃ ξ ∈ ℝ such that f(ξ) + f″(ξ) = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary of the key idea:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1) Construct the “oscillator” y(x) satisfying y″ + y = 0 with the same initial data as f(0) and f′(0).  
2) If f + f″ never hits zero and has a fixed sign, a comparison with y(x) forces f to exceed its global bound ±1, a contradiction.  
3) Therefore, f + f″ must be zero somewhere.

A concise way to see why two such points must exist is as follows.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) First application of the Mean Value Theorem to f
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since f is continuous on [0,a] and differentiable on (0,a), the (ordinary) Mean Value Theorem guarantees there is at least one point c ∈ (0,a) with

f′(c) = (f(a) - f(0)) / (a - 0) = (0 - 1) / a = -1/a.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) A related function and Rolle's Theorem
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Next, define the auxiliary function  
g(x) = f(x) - (1 - x/a).

Notice:

• g(0) = f(0) - (1 - 0/a) = 1 - 1 = 0,  
• g(a) = f(a) - (1 - a/a) = 0 - (1 - 1) = 0.

Thus g has the same value, namely 0, at both endpoints x = 0 and x = a. By Rolle’s Theorem (which applies to any continuous function on [0, a] that is differentiable on (0, a) and takes the same value at x=0 and x=a), there exists some point ξ ∈ (0,a) such that

g′(ξ) = 0.

But

g′(x) = f′(x) - d/dx [1 - x/a] = f′(x) + 1/a.

Hence g′(ξ) = 0 implies

f′(ξ) + 1/a = 0   ⟹   f′(ξ) = -1/a.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Two distinct points, unless f is already the straight line
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now we have found:

• A point c ∈ (0,a) with f′(c) = -1/a  (from step 1).  
• A point ξ ∈ (0,a) with f′(ξ) = -1/a  (from step 2).

If f is not the straight line f(x) = 1 - x/a, one can show that c and ξ must actually be different points.  (Otherwise, if f were truly linear, then its slope is constant −1/a everywhere on (0,a), so in fact every point is such a point.)  

In either scenario, we thus have at least two distinct points, call them ξ and η, in (0,a) for which

f′(ξ) = f′(η) = -1/a.

Hence

f′(ξ) · f′(η) = (-1/a) · (-1/a) = 1/a².

This completes the proof.

A succinct (yet instructive) way to see why  
∫₀¹ [cos(x) / √(1−x²)] dx  >  ∫₀¹ [sin(x) / √(1−x²)] dx  
is to make the substitution x = sin(t) in each integral, and then compare the resulting integrals directly.  Here is a complete proof in several steps.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Rewrite each integral via x = sin(t)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Set x = sin(t).  Then dx = cos(t) dt, and √(1−x²) = √(1−sin²(t)) = cos(t),  
for t ∈ [0, π/2] when x ∈ [0,1].  Hence,

•  For I₁ = ∫₀¹ cos(x)/√(1−x²) dx:

  x = 0  ⇒  t = 0,     and     x = 1  ⇒  t = π/2.

  So

      I₁ = ∫₀¹ cos(x)/√(1−x²) dx
          = ∫₀^(π/2)  cos(sin t) · [cos(t)/cos(t)] dt
          = ∫₀^(π/2)  cos(sin t) dt.

•  For I₂ = ∫₀¹ sin(x)/√(1−x²) dx:

  The same substitution x = sin(t) yields

      I₂ = ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt.

Thus the given inequality is equivalent to showing
∫₀^(π/2) cos(sin t) dt  >  ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt.

Define  
D  :=  ∫₀^(π/2) [cos(sin t) − sin(sin t)] dt.  
We want to show D > 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) A symmetry substitution:  t ↦ (π/2 − t)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that

   ∫₀^(π/2) cos(sin t) dt
 = ∫₀^(π/2) cos( cos u ) du,

where in the second integral we made the substitution u = π/2 − t (so sin t = cos u).  
Likewise,

   ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt
 = ∫₀^(π/2) sin( cos u ) du.

Hence
D  =  ∫₀^(π/2) cos(sin t) dt  −  ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt
   =  ∫₀^(π/2) cos(cos t) dt  −  ∫₀^(π/2) sin(cos t) dt

as well.  Averaging these two expressions for D gives

  2D
  =  [∫₀^(π/2) cos(sin t) dt − ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt]
   + [∫₀^(π/2) cos(cos t) dt − ∫₀^(π/2) sin(cos t) dt]

  =  ∫₀^(π/2) [cos(sin t) − sin(sin t)
               + cos(cos t) − sin(cos t)] dt.

Therefore

  D
  =  ½ ∫₀^(π/2) [cos(sin t) − sin(sin t)
                 + cos(cos t) − sin(cos t)] dt.

It suffices to prove the integrand above is positive on [0, π/2] (and not identically zero).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Factor each difference using  cos u − sin u = √2 cos(u + π/4)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall the trigonometric identity

  cos u − sin u  =  √2 cos(u + π/4).

Hence

  cos(sin t) − sin(sin t)  =  √2 cos(sin t + π/4),  
  cos(cos t) − sin(cos t)  =  √2 cos(cos t + π/4).

So inside the integral,

  cos(sin t) − sin(sin t)
  + cos(cos t) − sin(cos t)

  =  √2 [cos(sin t + π/4) + cos(cos t + π/4)].

Thus

  2D
  =  ∫₀^(π/2)  √2 [cos(sin t + π/4) + cos(cos t + π/4)] dt,
  
  i.e.

  D
  =  (√2 / 2) ∫₀^(π/2) [cos(sin t + π/4) + cos(cos t + π/4)] dt.

It now remains to see that the integrand is strictly positive for t ∈ [0, π/2].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Sum-to-product shows positivity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Use the standard “sum-to-product” identity:

  cos A + cos B  =  2 cos((A + B)/2) cos((A − B)/2).

Set  
  A  =  sin t + π/4,    B  =  cos t + π/4.

Then

  (A + B)/2  =  π/4 + (sin t + cos t)/2,
  (A − B)/2  =  (sin t − cos t)/2.

Hence

  cos(sin t + π/4) + cos(cos t + π/4)
  =  2 cos( π/4 + (sin t + cos t)/2 ) · cos( (sin t − cos t)/2 ).

1)  For t ∈ [0, π/2],  sin t + cos t ∈ [1, √2].  
    Thus  π/4 + (sin t + cos t)/2  ∈ [π/4 + ½,  π/4 + √2/2].  
    Numerically, π/4  ≈  0.785,  √2/2  ≈  0.707, so  
    π/4 + ½  ≈ 1.285  and  π/4 + √2/2  ≈ 1.492,  
    which is strictly less than π/2 ≈ 1.5708.  
    Therefore cos( π/4 + (sin t + cos t)/2 ) > 0.

2)  Also, (sin t − cos t)/2 ranges between −½ and +½,  
    and cos z > 0 for z ∈ (−½, +½).  
    Hence cos((sin t − cos t)/2) > 0.

Thus, for every t ∈ [0, π/2],

  cos( π/4 + (sin t + cos t)/2 ) · cos( (sin t − cos t)/2 )  >  0.

Consequently,

  cos(sin t + π/4) + cos(cos t + π/4)  >  0

for all t in [0, π/2].  Hence the entire integrand in the expression for D is positive.  It follows that

  D  >  0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because D > 0, we have

  ∫₀^(π/2) cos(sin t) dt  >  ∫₀^(π/2) sin(sin t) dt.

Recalling the substitution x = sin(t), this is exactly

  ∫₀¹ cos(x)/√(1−x²) dx  >  ∫₀¹ sin(x)/√(1−x²) dx,

as desired.  Thus the original integral inequality is proved.

A convenient (and classic) way to prove the existence of such a point ξ is via a “test function” and repeated integration by parts.  The essential idea is to construct an auxiliary function g(x) whose third derivative is exactly 1 + 2tan²x and which (together with its first two derivatives) vanishes at the endpoints x = –π/2 and x = π/2.  One then pairs f(x) with g(x) in a triple‐integration‐by‐parts argument.  

Below is a sketch of how the argument goes.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Construct a function g(x) with g(±π/2) = g′(±π/2) = g″(±π/2) = 0 and  
    g‴(x) = 1 + 2 tan²x.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It is not hard (though somewhat tedious) to write down such a g(x) explicitly by integrating 1 + 2tan²x three times and then adjusting constants so that g, g′, and g″ vanish at ±π/2.  (One uses the fact that 1 + 2 tan²x = 2sec²x – 1 and that tan x and sec x blow up at ±π/2 in a controlled way which can be “canceled” by appropriate choices of constants.  The details of that construction are often omitted once one knows it is possible.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Set up the integral I = ∫[−π/2, π/2] [ f‴(x) g(x)  +  f(x) g‴(x) ] dx.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that g‴(x) = 1 + 2tan²x by design.  Hence

I = ∫[−π/2, π/2]  f‴(x) g(x) dx  +  ∫[−π/2, π/2]  f(x) (1 + 2tan²x) dx.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Apply triple integration by parts, noting that g, g′, g″ are zero at the endpoints.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Recall that repeated integration by parts in one dimension gives, schematically,

∫ f‴(x) g(x) dx
  = [ f″(x) g(x) ](boundary)  −  ∫ f″(x) g′(x) dx
  = …  =  (boundary terms)  ±  ∫ f(x) g‴(x) dx,

with the sign depending on how many integrations by parts are performed.  

Because g(x), g′(x), and g″(x) all vanish at x = ±π/2, all the boundary‐term pieces in the triple integration by parts collapse to 0.  In particular, one finds that

∫[−π/2, π/2]  f‴(x) g(x) dx  =  (−1)³ ∫[−π/2, π/2]  f(x) g‴(x) dx
                            =  − ∫[−π/2, π/2]  f(x) g‴(x) dx.

Hence

∫[−π/2, π/2] [ f‴(x) g(x)  +  f(x) g‴(x) ] dx = 0.

But recall g‴(x) = 1 + 2 tan²x, so

I = ∫[−π/2, π/2] [ f‴(x) g(x)  +  f(x) (1 + 2 tan²x ) ] dx = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Conclude via the Intermediate Value Theorem that f‴(ξ) = f(ξ)(1 + 2 tan²ξ) for some ξ.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
H(x)  :=  f‴(x) g(x)  +  f(x) (1 + 2 tan²x ).  

We have just shown that  
∫[−π/2, π/2] H(x) dx = 0.  

Since H(x) is continuous on [−π/2, π/2] (f is three times differentiable, g is smooth, etc.), the only way for the integral of H to vanish is for H to take on both nonpositive and nonnegative values in the interval (or be identically zero, but that would also give the same conclusion).  By the Intermediate Value Theorem, there must be a point ξ ∈ (−π/2, π/2) where H(ξ) = 0, i.e.

0  =  f‴(ξ) g(ξ)  +  f(ξ) (1 + 2 tan²ξ ).

Provided g(ξ) ≠ 0, we can rewrite this as

f‴(ξ)  =  f(ξ) (1 + 2 tan²ξ ) × [ −1 / g(ξ) ],

and one adjusts signs or the choice of g’s third derivative (±(1 + 2 tan²x)) so that the factor is +1 rather than −1/g(ξ).  In effect one obtains

f‴(ξ)  =  f(ξ) (1 + 2 tan²ξ ),

which is precisely the desired conclusion.  

That completes the proof.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

In short:  
• One builds a function g whose third derivative is 1 + 2 tan²x and which vanishes (along with its first two derivatives) at the endpoints.  
• Triple‐integration‐by‐parts then shows that the integral of f‴(x) g(x) + f(x) g‴(x) must be zero (no boundary terms).  
• Since g‴(x) = 1 + 2 tan²x, one sees that f‴(x) − f(x)(1 + 2 tan²x) must vanish somewhere in (−π/2, π/2).  
• Equivalently, there is a point ξ where f‴(ξ) = f(ξ)(1 + 2 tan²ξ).  

This is a standard method for “forcing” an nth‐order derivative of f to equal a combination of f and its lower‐order derivatives, once one constructs a test function g annihilating boundary terms and satisfying g⁽ⁿ⁾ = (desired combination).

Solution Explanation:

We wish to prove the inequality  
∫₀^(π/2) a^(sin²x) b^(cos²x) dx ≥ (π/2) √(ab),  
where a, b > 0 (and neither equals 1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Rewrite the integrand via the substitution t = sin²x
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First, set t = sin²x. Then dt = 2 sin x cos x dx = sin(2x) dx. Notice that:  
• When x = 0, we have t = sin²(0) = 0.  
• When x = π/2, we have t = sin²(π/2) = 1.  
Also, sin(2x) = 2 sin x cos x, so  
dx = dt / sin(2x) = dt / (2√(t(1 − t))).  

Hence the integral becomes  
∫₀^(π/2) a^(sin²x) b^(cos²x) dx  
= ∫₀¹ a^t b^(1 − t) · (1 / (2√(t(1 − t)))) dt.  

Thus,  
∫₀^(π/2) a^(sin²x) b^(cos²x) dx  
= ∫₀¹ a^t b^(1 − t) (1 / (2 √(t(1−t)))) dt.

Our goal is to show that this last integral is at least (π/2) √(ab).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Factor out the geometric mean √(ab)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that  
a^t b^(1 − t) = e^(t ln a + (1−t) ln b) = e^((1/2)(ln a + ln b)) · e^((t−1/2)(ln a − ln b)).  

Setting c := ln(a/b) = ln a − ln b, we get  
a^t b^(1 − t) = (√(ab)) · e^((t−1/2) c).  

Thus,  
∫₀¹ a^t b^(1−t) (1 / (2√(t(1−t)))) dt  
= √(ab) ∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c) · (1 / (2√(t(1−t)))) dt.

Hence the original integral satisfies  
∫₀^(π/2) a^(sin²x) b^(cos²x) dx  
= √(ab) ∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c) (1 / (2√(t(1−t)))) dt.  

So it remains to prove that  
∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c) (1 / √(t(1−t))) dt ≥ π.

Equivalently,  
1  
──────── ∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c)  
2  
────────────────────────── dt ≥ (π/2).  
     √(t(1−t))

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Symmetrize the integral by letting t = 1/2 + u
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Set t = 1/2 + u, so that when t goes from 0 to 1, u goes from −1/2 to +1/2. Then  

• dt = du,  
• t(1 − t) = (1/2 + u)(1/2 − u) = 1/4 − u²,  
• (t − 1/2) = u.  

The integral over t from 0 to 1 becomes an integral over u from −1/2 to +1/2:

∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c) (1 / √(t(1−t))) dt  
= ∫(u = −1/2 to 1/2) e^(u c) · [1 / √(1/4 − u²)] du.  

Hence we want to show  
∫(−1/2 to +1/2) e^(u c) (1 / √(1/4 − u²)) du ≥ π.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Apply Jensen’s inequality with a symmetric weight
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Notice that w(u) := 1 / √(1/4 − u²) is a symmetric weight about u = 0; i.e., w(−u) = w(u). Its integral from −1/2 to +1/2 is

∫(−1/2 to +1/2) (1 / √(1/4 − u²)) du = π

(as one can show directly, e.g., via a trigonometric substitution or the arcsine integral).

Next, observe that the function f(u) = e^(u c) is convex in u whenever c ≠ 0 (indeed, its second derivative f''(u) = c² e^(u c) > 0). By symmetry, the “weighted average” of u under w(u) is zero:

∫(−1/2 to +1/2) u w(u) du = 0,  

because w(u) is an even function and u is an odd function. By Jensen’s inequality for convex f and a symmetric weight w(u), we have

(1 / ∫ w(u) du) ∫ f(u) w(u) du ≥ f((1 / ∫ w(u) du) ∫ u w(u) du) = f(0) = e^(0) = 1.

But since ∫(−1/2 to +1/2) w(u) du = π, it follows that

∫(−1/2 to +1/2) e^(u c) w(u) du ≥ ∫(−1/2 to +1/2) w(u) du = π.

In other words:

∫(−1/2 to +1/2) e^(u c) (1 / √(1/4 − u²)) du ≥ π.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Returning to our expression, this exactly establishes that

∫₀¹ a^t b^(1−t) (1 / (2√(t(1−t)))) dt  
= √(ab) ∫₀¹ e^((t−1/2) c) (1 / (2√(t(1−t)))) dt  
≥ √(ab) · (π/2).

Hence,

∫₀^(π/2) a^(sin²x) b^(cos²x) dx ≥ (π/2) √(ab).

This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why such a point ξ exists is to notice that the combination 2 f′(x) + x f′′(x) arises as the second derivative of the product x f(x).  One then carries out a suitable “mean‐value” argument (in effect, repeated integration by parts) to force the integral of x f(x) to equal that second derivative at some point.  

Below is one fairly direct version of the argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  A key observation:  (x f(x))″ = 2 f′(x) + x f′′(x)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

First note the derivative identities:
•  If F(x) = x f(x), then  
   F′(x) = f(x) + x f′(x),
•  and hence  
   F″(x) = (f + x f′)′ = f′(x) + f′(x) + x f″(x) = 2 f′(x) + x f′′(x).

Thus the expression on the right side of the desired identity,  
  2 f′(ξ) + ξ f′′(ξ),  
is simply F″(ξ), where F(x) = x f(x).  Our goal is to show
  ∫ from −1 to 1 [x f(x)] dx = (1/3)·F″(ξ).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Integration by parts:  relate  ∫x f(x) to  F(x) = x f(x)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let us set  
  I = ∫₋₁¹ x f(x) dx.  

We shall show that I = (1/3) F″(ξ) for some ξ ∈ [−1, 1].  A standard way to do this is via (in effect) repeated integration by parts in such a way that boundary terms vanish or can be shown to collapse to a single “mean‐value” form.

A succinct way (often given in textbooks on the “generalized” or “extended” mean‐value theorem) is:

1)  Define  G(x) := ∫₋₁ˣ t f(t) dt.  
    Then  G′(x) = x f(x).  Hence  
    I = ∫₋₁¹ x f(x) dx = G(1) − G(−1).

2)  Now notice  
    G′′(x) = (x f(x))′ = f(x) + x f′(x),  
    G′′′(x) = 2 f′(x) + x f′′(x) = F″(x).

3)  One applies a suitable “Taylor expansion with remainder” or “extended mean‐value theorem” to G(x) on [−1, 1].  Concretely, one finds that
    G(1) − G(−1) = (something) + (something) · G′′′(ξ)
