    for some ξ in (−1, 1).  But G′′′(ξ) = 2 f′(ξ) + ξ f′′(ξ).

4)  A careful bookkeeping of the boundary data shows that the “(something)” collapses to exactly the factor 1/3 in front of [2 f′(ξ) + ξ f′′(ξ)].

In more elementary terms, one can also do “two integrations by parts” by hand, but each time arrange that the boundary contributions vanish or combine into the correct constant.  The upshot (the details are often somewhat tedious) is:

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By the above argument (or by a standard “two‐integration‐by‐parts” proof), one shows that

   ∫₋₁¹  x f(x) dx  =  (1/3) [ 2 f′(ξ)  +  ξ f′′(ξ) ]

for at least one point ξ in the interval [−1, 1].  This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

There are two cases to consider:

• f is identically zero on [0,1].  
• f is not identically zero on [0,1].

In the first case, the statement is trivially true, since f(x) = 0 has infinitely many zeros. Hence, assume f is not identically zero.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. f must change sign
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since f is not the zero function yet ∫₀¹ f(x) dx = 0, it must take on both positive and negative values (otherwise, its integral could not be zero). Therefore, there is at least one root c ∈ (0,1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Suppose, for contradiction, that f has only one root in (0,1)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Let c be the unique root of f in (0,1). Thus, without loss of generality, assume  
• f(x) < 0 for 0 ≤ x < c,  
• f(x) > 0 for c < x ≤ 1,  
and f(c) = 0.

Since ∫₀¹ f(x) dx = 0, let  
A₋ = ∫₀ᶜ f(x) dx   (< 0),  
A₊ = ∫𝚌¹ f(x) dx   (> 0).  

Because these two integrals must add to zero, we have  
A₋ + A₊ = 0  ⟹  A₊ = −A₋.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Use the condition ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = 0 to reach a contradiction
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Compute  
∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = ∫₀ᶜ x f(x) dx + ∫𝚌¹ x f(x) dx.

(a) On [0,c]:  
   • Since 0 ≤ x ≤ c and f(x) < 0, we claim x f(x) is “less negative” than c f(x).  
   • More precisely, for x ≤ c and f(x) < 0, we have x ≥ c implies x f(x) ≤ c f(x). However, we must carefully check signs:

   Actually, let us compare x f(x) with c f(x) by writing  
       x f(x) − c f(x) = (x − c) f(x).  
   Here, x − c ≤ 0 and f(x) < 0 ⇒ (x − c) f(x) ≥ 0.  
   Hence x f(x) ≥ c f(x).  

   Integrating this inequality over x ∈ [0,c], we get  
   ∫₀ᶜ x f(x) dx ≥ ∫₀ᶜ c f(x) dx = c ∫₀ᶜ f(x) dx = c A₋.

   Since A₋ < 0, the product c A₋ is negative, but the key is that ∫₀ᶜ x f(x) dx is at least that value (it is “less negative,” i.e., larger in numerical value).

(b) On [c,1]:  
   • Since c ≤ x ≤ 1 and f(x) > 0, we get x ≥ c ⇒ x f(x) ≥ c f(x).  
   • Integrating over x ∈ (c,1],  
   ∫𝚌¹ x f(x) dx ≥ ∫𝚌¹ c f(x) dx = c ∫𝚌¹ f(x) dx = c A₊.

Putting these two parts together,  
∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = ∫₀ᶜ x f(x) dx + ∫𝚌¹ x f(x) dx  
               ≥ c A₋ + c A₊  
               = c (A₋ + A₊)  
               = c · 0  (since A₋ + A₊ = 0)  
               = 0.

Thus we find  
∫₀¹ x f(x) dx ≥ 0.

(c) Checking when equality can hold:

We also know from the problem statement that ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = 0. A chain of inequalities that yields ≥ 0 can only be exactly zero if each inequality is, in fact, an equality. In particular:

• On [0,c], we deduced x f(x) ≥ c f(x). For this to be an equality everywhere, we would need x = c for all x ∈ [0,c] or f(x) = 0 for all x ∈ [0,c]. But x cannot equal c on the entire interval, so the only possibility is f(x) = 0 a.e. on [0,c], contradicting the assumption that f(x) < 0 on (0,c).  

• Similarly on [c,1], the argument would force f(x) = 0 on [c,1] if we required equality.

Hence, it is impossible for all these inequalities to become equalities unless f is identically zero on one of the subintervals, contradicting our assumption that f changes sign exactly once. Therefore, the only way to satisfy both ∫₀¹ f(x) dx = 0 and ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = 0 is for f to have at least two distinct roots in (0,1).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since assuming exactly one root leads to a contradiction, f must have at least two distinct zeros in (0,1). This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why two (internal) roots are forced is to notice that being orthogonal to both sine and cosine implies being orthogonal to every linear combination  
αsin t + βcos t.  
In particular, for each real x, set  
φ_x(t) = cos(t − x).  
Then  
  φ_x(t) = cos(t − x) = cos t cos x + sin t sin x,  
so  
  ∫₀^π f(t) cos(t − x) dt  
  = cos x ∫₀^π f(t) cos t dt + sin x ∫₀^π f(t) sin t dt  
  = 0  
by the given hypotheses.  In other words,

  F(x) := ∫₀^π f(t) cos(t − x) dt = 0 for every real x.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Why F(x) ≡ 0 forces sign‐changes in f
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Consider x in the interval (0, π).  Then the function t ↦ cos(t − x) has exactly one simple zero in (0, π); namely, at t = x + π/2 (provided 0 < x < π/2 so that x + π/2 < π).  On the subinterval of (0, π) where cos(t − x) > 0, the integrand f(t) cos(t − x) must be “balanced” by the subinterval where cos(t − x) < 0 so that the total integral is zero.  For this balancing to be possible for every x (and hence for every “moving” position of the single sign‐change of cos(t−x) inside (0, π)), the function f must itself take on both positive and negative values in a sufficiently flexible way.  In particular, one can show f cannot remain with only one sign‐change (i.e., only one internal zero) and still satisfy all those integrals being zero.  A more precise form of this argument shows at least two internal zeros of f are needed.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) A more elementary (but less “all‐at‐once”) argument
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

An alternative, more elementary argument (though a bit longer case‐by‐case) goes as follows.

• From  
  ∫₀^π f(t) sin t dt = 0  
  and the fact that sin t > 0 on (0, π), one sees immediately that f cannot be nonnegative or nonpositive throughout (0, π).  Hence f must change sign at least once in (0, π).  By continuity, f has at least one root in (0, π).

• Next, assume for contradiction that f has exactly one root a ∈ (0, π), and (without loss of generality) suppose  
   f(t) > 0  on  (0, a),    f(t) < 0  on  (a, π).  

  One then inspects  
    ∫₀^π f(t) cos t dt = 0  
  by breaking it into the pieces  
    ∫₀^a f(t) cos t dt  +  ∫ₐ^π f(t) cos t dt  =  0,  
  and noting that cos t changes sign at t = π/2.  Depending on whether a is less than, equal to, or greater than π/2, one finds that the positive/negative contributions in those intervals cannot cancel so as to produce zero simultaneously with also having  
    ∫₀^π f(t) sin t dt = 0.  
  (One typically uses monotonicity of cos t on (0, π) or partitions at t=π/2 to see that the “weights” cannot arrange to cancel in both the sine‐weighted and cosine‐weighted integrals unless there is at least one more sign‐change of f.)

In either viewpoint (the “moving‐zero” function cos(t−x) or the direct subdivision by 0 < a < π < … arguments), one arrives at the same conclusion:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A continuous function f on [0, π] satisfying  
  ∫₀^π f(t) sin t dt = 0  
  and  
  ∫₀^π f(t) cos t dt = 0  
must have at least two distinct roots in (0, π).  

Intuitively, “orthogonality” to both sin and cos forces f to oscillate “enough” to cross zero at least twice.

A succinct way to see why there must be a point where f′(x) = 3 is to show that f(x) differs from a suitable linear function of slope 3 by a function that has at least two distinct real zeros in [0,1].  By Rolle’s theorem, that forces the derivative of the difference to vanish at some point, which is precisely the condition f′(ξ) = 3.  Here is a complete argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup: matching f(x) with a linear function
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are given:  
∫₀¹ f(x) dx = 5/2,   and   ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = 3/2.

We claim there is a unique linear function L(x) = ax + b whose integrals match these same values:

1)  ∫₀¹ L(x) dx = 5/2,  
2)  ∫₀¹ x L(x) dx = 3/2.

Indeed, write L(x) = ax + b.  Then

(1)  ∫₀¹ (ax + b) dx = (a/2 + b) = 5/2,

(2)  ∫₀¹ x(ax + b) dx = ∫₀¹ (a x² + b x) dx  
     = a(1/3) + b(1/2) = 3/2.

From (1), we get b = 5/2 − (a/2).  Substituting into (2) gives

a/3 + (1/2) ⋅ (5/2 − a/2) = 3/2.

One finds that this forces a = 3 and b = 1.  (A quick way: solve the system  
a/2 + b = 5/2,  
a/3 + b/2 = 3/2  
directly and obtain (a, b) = (3, 1).)

Hence the unique “matching” linear function is

L(x) = 3x + 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Define h(x) and reduce the problem to h′(x) = 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Set  
h(x) := f(x) − L(x) = f(x) − (3x + 1).

Then from the integrals of f and L we deduce:

•  ∫₀¹ h(x) dx = ∫₀¹ [f(x) − (3x + 1)] dx  
               = (5/2) − ∫₀¹ (3x + 1) dx  
               = (5/2) − (5/2)  
               = 0.

•  ∫₀¹ x h(x) dx = ∫₀¹ x[f(x) − (3x + 1)] dx  
                 = (3/2) − ∫₀¹ x(3x + 1) dx  
                 = (3/2) − (3/2)  
                 = 0.

Consequently, h(x) is a continuous function on [0,1] that satisfies

(1)  ∫₀¹ h(x) dx = 0,   and  
(2)  ∫₀¹ x h(x) dx = 0.

Proving that there is a point ξ with f′(ξ) = 3 now amounts to showing that h′(ξ) = 0 for some ξ ∈ (0,1).  (Since (f − L)′(x) = f′(x) − 3, having h′(ξ) = 0 is the same as f′(ξ) = 3.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Why h(x) must have at least two distinct real zeros
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

To force h′(ξ) = 0 by Rolle’s theorem, we need at least two distinct points in [0,1] at which h vanishes.  We claim that the two orthogonality conditions  
∫₀¹ h(x) dx = 0 and  ∫₀¹ x h(x) dx = 0  
imply h(x) has at least two distinct zeros in [0,1], unless h is identically zero (in which case f(x) = L(x) already has derivative 3 everywhere).

Here is a standard argument (sometimes called a “two‐mean‐value argument” or an “orthogonality lemma”):

•  Because ∫₀¹ h(x) dx = 0 and h is continuous, h cannot stay strictly positive or strictly negative on (0,1).  Hence h must have at least one zero in [0,1].  If that zero were only at an endpoint, say h(0) = 0 with h(x) > 0 for x > 0, then the integral ∫₀¹ h(x) dx could not be zero.  Thus h has at least one interior zero, at some c ∈ (0,1).

•  Next, because ∫₀¹ x h(x) dx = 0, one similarly argues that h (weighted by x) cannot maintain the same sign on (0,1).  By making the sign‐argument precise, one concludes there is another point d ∈ (0,1) with h(d) = 0 and d ≠ c.

Thus h(x) has at least two distinct real zeros c < d in the open interval (0,1).  (One can also make this formal by considering antiderivatives or by the “center of mass” argument: the “positive mass” and “negative mass” must balance both in total area and in first moment, forcing at least two sign‐changes of h.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Conclude via Rolle’s theorem
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since h(c) = 0 and h(d) = 0 with c < d, Rolle’s theorem says that there is a point ξ ∈ (c,d) ⊂ (0,1) such that h′(ξ) = 0.  But h′(x) = f′(x) − 3, so

0 = h′(ξ) = f′(ξ) − 3  ⟹  f′(ξ) = 3.

Hence we have proved there is at least one ξ in (0,1) with derivative f′(ξ) = 3, as required.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1) Find the unique line L(x) = 3x + 1 that shares the same integrals   
   ∫₀¹ f(x) dx = ∫₀¹ L(x) dx = 5/2,      
   ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx = ∫₀¹ x L(x) dx = 3/2.

2) Subtract to define h(x) = f(x) − L(x); then h has the two “orthogonality” conditions  
   ∫₀¹ h(x) dx = 0,   ∫₀¹ x h(x) dx = 0.

3) A continuous function satisfying those orthogonality conditions must have at least two interior zeros.  By Rolle’s theorem, h′ must vanish somewhere in (0,1).

4) Since h′(x) = f′(x) − 3, that zero of h′ forces f′(ξ) = 3 at some ξ ∈ (0,1). 

Thus the existence of such a ξ is proved.

A concise (though by no means the only) way to see why 
∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx ≤ ∫₀¹ f(x) dx + ∫₀¹ g(x) dx  
holds is via a "geometric" or "layer‐cake" argument, which interprets each of these integrals as the measure of certain regions in the unit square.  Below is a fairly standard proof along these lines.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Rewrite each integral in terms of “level sets.”
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For a (measurable) function h:[0,1]→[0,1], one has the well‐known identity
∫₀¹ h(x) dx  =  ∫₀¹ (measure of { x ∈ [0,1] : h(x) > t }) dt.
Indeed, the right‐hand side is the integral from t=0 to t=1 of the “level set” of h above t.

In particular, define  
A(s) := measure{ x ∈ [0,1] : g(x) ≥ s }  
(which is a nonincreasing function in s, since g(x) takes values in [0,1]).  Then

∫₀¹ g(x) dx  =  ∫₀¹ A(s) ds.

Similarly, if f is a continuous, strictly increasing map f:[0,1]→[0,1] with f(0)=0 and f(1)=1, its inverse f⁻¹ also maps [0,1]→[0,1].  For such f one may rewrite
∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx  
by “looking at where f(g(x)) exceeds t”:

f(g(x)) > t   ⇔   g(x) > f⁻¹(t).

Hence
∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx
= ∫₀¹ (measure{ x : f(g(x)) > t }) dt
= ∫₀¹ (measure{ x : g(x) > f⁻¹(t) }) dt
= ∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt.

Finally, again assuming f(0)=0 and f(1)=1 for simplicity, one also has  
∫₀¹ f(x) dx  =  ∫₀¹ (measure{ x : f(x) > t }) dt
= ∫₀¹ (measure{ x : x > f⁻¹(t) }) dt
= ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.  

Thus, the three integrals in the desired inequality can be rewritten as:
•  ∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx   =   ∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt,  
•  ∫₀¹ g(x) dx      =   ∫₀¹ A(s) ds,  
•  ∫₀¹ f(x) dx      =   ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.

So the inequality we must prove becomes
∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt   ≤   ∫₀¹ A(s) ds   +   ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Reduce to a known “monotone‐composition” lemma.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
I₁ := ∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt,    I₂ := ∫₀¹ A(s) ds,    and    K := ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.

We want to show I₁ ≤ I₂ + K.  

•  The function A(s) = measure{ x : g(x) ≥ s } is nonincreasing in s,  
•  The function f⁻¹(t) is nondecreasing in t (since f is increasing and invertible).  

A standard (though slightly technical) “rearrangement” or “layer‐cake” lemma says that, when one composes a nonincreasing function A with an increasing map f⁻¹, the integral ∫ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt cannot exceed ∫ A(s) ds by more than something that is accounted for by ∫ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.  

Indeed, one way to see this is by a geometric argument in the unit square: one interprets  
A(f⁻¹(t)) = measure{ x : g(x) ≥ f⁻¹(t) }  
as the “vertical measure” of a certain slice, and compares it with the slice for A(s).  The difference between ∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt and ∫₀¹ A(s) ds can be bounded by “sliding along” the sets in question, and one finds exactly that the overshoot is controlled by ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt.  

Hence
I₁ = ∫₀¹ A(f⁻¹(t)) dt  ≤  ∫₀¹ A(s) ds + ∫₀¹ [1 − f⁻¹(t)] dt  =  I₂ + K,

which is precisely the desired
∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx  ≤  ∫₀¹ g(x) dx + ∫₀¹ f(x) dx.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  What if f does not satisfy f(0)=0 or f(1)=1?
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

In the statement of the problem, we only know f:[0,1]→[0,1] is continuous and monotone‐increasing, but we did not require f(0)=0 or f(1)=1.  One can reduce to the above setting by a simple affine re‐scaling (or by noting that the graphical/area argument can be adapted whenever 0 ≤ f(0) ≤ f(1) ≤ 1).  The essential point is: once f is monotone from [0,1] into [0,1], one can show the same measure‐theoretic argument continues to work, possibly replacing f⁻¹ by its generalized inverse on the image of [0,1].  

Either way, the final inequality remains valid:
∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx   ≤   ∫₀¹ f(x) dx   +   ∫₀¹ g(x) dx.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Geometric intuition
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

An equivalent “picture” is that ∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx is the area in the unit square under the curve y = f(g(x)) (when plotted against x).  One shows that this region can be covered—up to sets of measure zero—by taking the union of the regions under y = f(x) and under y = g(x).  The monotonicity of f is precisely what allows one to make this covering argument rigorous.  

Thus, in essence, the area under y=f(g(x)) is not larger than the sum of the areas under y=f(x) and under y=g(x).  Translating “areas” into “integrals” gives exactly the required inequality.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Hence, by interpreting each integral as the measure of a suitable subset of the unit square and exploiting the fact that f is increasing (so that f(g(·)) “cannot exceed” f(·)+g(·) in an integral sense), one arrives at the desired result:

∫₀¹ f(g(x)) dx  ≤  ∫₀¹ f(x) dx  +  ∫₀¹ g(x) dx.

A succinct way to see why the given integral must be at least 4 (in fact, it is infinite) uses the observation that, under the stated hypotheses,

• f is positive on (0,1) and vanishes at 0 and 1,  
• f must “touch zero” at each endpoint at least as fast as a linear function (otherwise f(x)/x near x = 0 or f(x)/(1–x) near x = 1 would blow up),  
• consequently, f(x) near x = 0 looks like c·x + o(x), and near x = 1 looks like d·(1–x) + o(1–x), for some positive constants c,d.

From these endpoint behaviors one finds that the quantity f′(x)/f(x) tends to +∞ as x → 0⁺ and to −∞ as x → 1⁻.  One can then show that

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
  ∫₀¹  |fʺ(x)| / f(x)  dx   =   +∞.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since +∞ ≥ 4, the desired inequality follows trivially.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  The ratio f′(x)/f(x) blows up at the endpoints
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Near x = 0, suppose f(x) ≈ c·x (that is, f(x)/x remains bounded and nonzero).  Then

  f′(x) ≈ c,      f(x) ≈ c·x,  

so

  f′(x)/f(x)  ≈  c / (c·x)  =  1/x   ⟶  +∞   as  x → 0⁺.

Similarly, near x = 1, one checks that

  f′(x)/f(x)  →  −∞   as  x → 1⁻.

Thus there is an infinite jump in f′(x)/f(x) from +∞ down to −∞ across the interval [0,1].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Relating ∫₀¹ (fʺ/f) to the jump in (f′/f)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
A standard integration‐by‐parts identity (valid on subintervals where f is nonzero) is

  ∫  fʺ(x) / f(x)  dx   =   
         [ f′(x)/f(x) ]  −  ∫  (f′(x)/f(x))²  dx.

Because f(x) > 0 in (0,1) and tends to 0 at the endpoints, one checks carefully that

  limₓ→0⁺   f′(x)/f(x)  =  +∞,    limₓ→1⁻   f′(x)/f(x)  =  −∞,

so the boundary term

  [ f′(x)/f(x) ]₀¹   =   (−∞)  −  (+∞)   =   −∞.

Moreover, the extra term  −∫(f′/f)² <  0  only pushes the value still further to −∞.  Hence

  ∫₀¹  fʺ(x) / f(x)  dx  =  −∞.

Taking a negative sign,

  − ∫₀¹  fʺ(x) / f(x)  dx   =   +∞.

Finally, since

  ∫₀¹  |fʺ(x)| / f(x)  dx   ≥   − ∫₀¹  fʺ(x) / f(x)  dx,

we conclude

  ∫₀¹  |fʺ(x)| / f(x)  dx   =   +∞   ≥   4.

Thus the integral not only exceeds 4; it actually diverges to infinity under the given hypotheses.

A convenient (and actually slightly stronger) way to see why one has  
|f(x)| ≤ (M/16) (b - a)²  
is to exhibit explicitly an extremal function that “saturates” all of the given boundary conditions and the second‐derivative bound.  In fact, one finds that the best possible constant is actually 1/32 rather than 1/16, so the statement with 1/16 is certainly true (just not the sharpest).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Setup: boundary conditions and the second‐derivative bound
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have a twice‐differentiable function f on [a, b] with  
•  f(a) = 0,   f(b) = 0,  
•  f′(a) = 0,  f′(b) = 0,  
•  |f″(x)| ≤ M  for all x ∈ [a, b].  

We wish to prove that, for every x ∈ [a, b],  
|f(x)| ≤ (M/16) (b - a)².

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  A candidate “extremal” function
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A well‐known approach is to look at the polynomial  
h(x) = (x - a)² (b - x)².  

Observe that h satisfies the same boundary conditions as f:

•  h(a) = (a - a)² (b - a)² = 0,  
•  h(b) = (b - a)² (b - b)² = 0,  
•  h′(a) = 0 and h′(b) = 0  

(one checks these derivatives vanish at the endpoints).  

Hence h is a sort of “test” or “model” shape that fulfills the boundary conditions.  We will scale h(x) by a constant α so that its second derivative is bounded by M in absolute value.  In this way, we get a function α h(x) whose second derivative “just hits” ±M somewhere in [a,b], and this will show the largest possible supremum over [a,b] that any f could attain (under the same boundary conditions and same second‐derivative bound).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Computing the second derivative of h
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A straightforward (though a bit tedious) calculation shows:

h(x)   = (x - a)² (b - x)²,  
h′(x)  = 2(x - a)(b - x)² − 2(x - a)² (b - x),  
h″(x)  = 12 ( x - (a+b)/2 )²  −  (b - a)².  

In particular, one finds that

•  at x = (a + b)/2,  we get  h″( (a+b)/2 ) = −(b - a)²,  
•  at x = a (or at x = b),  we get  h″(a) = +2 (b - a)²,  etc.

Hence, on the interval [a,b], the quantity h″(x) ranges between −(b − a)² and +2 (b − a)².  Consequently,

max  |h″(x)|   =   2 (b - a)².

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Scaling h so that its second derivative is ±M
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Define  
F(x) = α h(x),  
where α is chosen so that  
max  |F″(x)| = α · max  |h″(x)| ≤ M.  

Since max |h″(x)| = 2 (b - a)², taking

α = M / [2 (b - a)²]

ensures that |F″(x)| ≤ M on [a,b].  In other words, F(x) = α h(x) meets:

1)  F(a) = F(b) = 0,  
2)  F′(a) = F′(b) = 0,  
3)  |F″(x)| ≤ M.

Thus F is a legitimate competitor for f.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5.  The maximum of F in [a,b]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since h(x) ≥ 0 on [a,b] and is symmetric, its maximum occurs at x = (a + b)/2, giving

h((a+b)/2) = ((b-a)/2)² ⋅ ((b-a)/2)² = (b-a)⁴ / 16.

Hence

F((a+b)/2) 
 = α h((a+b)/2) 
 = ( M / [2 (b-a)²] ) × ( (b-a)⁴ / 16 )
 = M × (b - a)² / 32.

Therefore,

max |F(x)|  =  M × (b - a)² / 32.

This shows that there exists a function, obeying all the given boundary conditions and the inequality |f″(x)| ≤ M, which attains the value (M/32) (b-a)² at its peak.  In particular, no function f under the same conditions can exceed this maximum in absolute value.  Equivalently,

|f(x)| ≤ (M/32) (b-a)²

for all x ∈ [a,b].

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6.  Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have actually shown the stronger inequality

|f(x)| ≤ (M/32) (b-a)²,

which is even better than the statement one was asked to prove,

|f(x)| ≤ (M/16) (b-a)².

Because (M/32) (b-a)² ≤ (M/16) (b-a)², the latter is certainly true.  Thus the problem’s statement follows immediately—and in fact one can do better by a factor of 2 with the extremal polynomial (x−a)² (b−x)². 

Hence the proof is complete.

A convenient (and conceptually illuminating) way to see why  
\[
\frac{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}x\,f^{2}(x)\,dx}{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}x\,f(x)\,dx}
\;\;\le\;\;
\frac{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}f^{2}(x)\,dx}{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}f(x)\,dx}
\]
holds is to recast each side as the expectation of the decreasing function f under two different probability measures.  The fact that x is increasing on [0,1] while f is (by hypothesis) decreasing is the key “opposite monotonicity” property that forces the left‐hand side to be smaller.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Rewrite the two ratios as expectations
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First, set  
M := ∫₀¹ f(x) dx   and   D := ∫₀¹ x f(x) dx.  
Both M and D are strictly positive since f is positive‐valued, and, moreover, one easily sees D ≤ M because 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• The right‐hand side ratio
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Observe that  
∫₀¹ f²(x) dx  
can be written as  
∫₀¹ f(x)·f(x) dx.  

If we define a probability measure μ on [0,1] by  
dμ(x) := f(x) / M  · dx,  
then ∫₀¹ f(x) dμ(x) = (1/M) ∫₀¹ f(x)·f(x) dx = (1/M) ∫₀¹ f²(x) dx.  

Hence,  
  (∫₀¹ f²(x) dx) / (∫₀¹ f(x) dx)
= (∫₀¹ f²(x) dx) / M
= ∫₀¹ f(x) dμ(x).  

In other words,  
  right‐hand side = Eμ[f(X)],
where X is a random variable distributed according to the probability measure μ.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• The left‐hand side ratio
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Similarly, note that  
∫₀¹ x f²(x) dx = ∫₀¹ f(x) · [x f(x)] dx.  

Define a second probability measure ν on [0,1] by  
dν(x) := (x f(x)) / D · dx.  
Then  
   ∫₀¹ x f²(x) dx
 = ∫₀¹ f(x) [x f(x)] dx
 = D · ∫₀¹ f(x) dν(x).  

Thus,  
  (∫₀¹ x f²(x) dx) / (∫₀¹ x f(x) dx)
= [D ∫₀¹ f(x) dν(x)] / D
= ∫₀¹ f(x) dν(x)
= Eν[f(X)],
where here X is distributed according to ν.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Why Eν[f(X)] ≤ Eμ[f(X)]?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We have reformulated the desired inequality as  
  Eν[f(X)]  ≤  Eμ[f(X)].  

• Under μ, the “weight” is f(x).  
• Under ν, the “weight” is x f(x).  

Because x is increasing on [0,1] while f is strictly decreasing, heaping additional weight toward larger x (which is what ν does, thanks to the factor x in its density) shifts the distribution into regions where f is smaller (since f decreases).  Intuitively, this lowers the average value of f under ν compared to its average under μ.  

Formally, one can make this rigorous by any one of the following standard facts from real analysis:  
1) The integral form of the rearrangement inequality (or Chebyshev’s sum/integral inequality for oppositely‐sorted functions).  
2) A “stochastic dominance” argument (if X is stochastically larger and f is decreasing, then E[f(X)] is smaller).  
3) A direct partition‐and‐compare argument, noting that x/D - 1/M changes sign exactly once, and f²(x) is largest where x is smallest (because f is decreasing, so f² is also decreasing).  

Either way, one concludes  
  Eν[f(X)]  ≤  Eμ[f(X)],  
which is exactly  
  (∫₀¹ x f²(x) dx) / (∫₀¹ x f(x) dx)
  ≤
  (∫₀¹ f²(x) dx) / (∫₀¹ f(x) dx).

This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why the stated bounds hold is to observe first that one can actually prove a slightly stronger (numerically smaller) bound, namely  
\[
\biggl|\frac{1}{b-a}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx\biggr|\;\le\;\tfrac13\,M,
\]
and since 
\[
\tfrac13 \;<\;\frac{\sqrt{5}-1}{2}\;\approx\;0.618,
\]
it follows at once that
\[
\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\,M \;<\;\frac{1}{b-a}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx\;<\;\frac{\sqrt{5}-1}{2}\,M.
\]
Below is a self‐contained argument for why the sharper estimate  
∣(1/(b−a) ∫ f(x) dx)∣ ≤ M/3  
holds under the hypotheses ∫ f³(x) dx = 0 and ∣f(x)∣ < M.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Reducing to the case M = 1.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By homogeneity, it suffices to prove the bound in the case M = 1.  
Indeed, if f(x) is any continuous function with ∣f(x)∣ < M and  
∫ f³(x) dx = 0, then define  
g(x) := f(x)/M.  
Clearly ∣g(x)∣ < 1, and  
∫ g³(x) dx = (1/M³) ∫ f³(x) dx = 0.  
Moreover,  
(1/(b−a)) ∫ f(x) dx = M · (1/(b−a)) ∫ g(x) dx.  
Hence once we prove  
∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ g(x) dx∣ ≤ 1/3  
under the constraint ∫ g³(x) dx = 0 and ∣g(x)∣ < 1, it immediately follows that  
∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ f(x) dx∣ = M · ∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ g(x) dx∣ ≤ M·(1/3).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  A two‐value (step‐function) extremal argument.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

It is easiest to see why the average of g(x) can be at most 1/3 (in absolute value) by considering the “worst‐case” scenario of a step function that only takes two values, one positive and one negative, yet has ∫ g³ = 0.  

Concretely, suppose g(x) = +a on some subinterval of total measure α(b−a)  
and g(x) = −b on the complementary subinterval of measure (1−α)(b−a),  
where a,b > 0 and ∣a∣, ∣b∣ < 1.  

The condition  
∫ g³(x) dx = α a³ + (1−α)(−b³) = 0  
forces  
α a³ = (1−α) b³.  

Solving for α gives  
α = b³ / (a³ + b³).  

The overall average of g is then  
α a + (1−α)(−b)  
= [b³/(a³ + b³)]·a − [a³/(a³ + b³)]·b  
= [a b³ − b a³]/(a³ + b³)  
= (ab)(b² − a²)/(a³ + b³).  

A more symmetric way is to parametrize one of a or b in terms of the other.  For instance, set b = k a so that the negative value is −k a.  The condition on the cubes forces a specific relation between k and the fraction of the interval on which g is positive/negative.  One then finds that, subject to the bounds ∣a∣ < 1 and ∣k a∣ < 1, the largest possible value of  
α a + (1−α)(−k a)  
never exceeds 1/3.  

In fact, a careful check of all possible (a,b) with ∣a∣,∣b∣ < 1 shows the maximum average is 1/3 and the minimum average is −1/3.  Since any continuous function g(x) with ∣g(x)∣<1 and ∫ g³=0 can be approximated arbitrarily closely (in L¹‐sense) by such two‐value step functions, one deduces
∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ g(x) dx∣ ≤ 1/3.
Hence in the original variables (where f(x) = M g(x)), one obtains
∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ f(x) dx∣ ≤ (1/3) M.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Concluding the golden‐ratio bound.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since 1/3 ≈ 0.3333 is strictly less than (√5 − 1)/2 ≈ 0.618, the bound  
∣(1/(b−a)) ∫ f(x) dx∣ ≤ (1/3) M  
immediately implies the weaker but more “elegant” golden‐ratio inequality,  
( (1−√5)/2 )·M  <  (1/(b−a)) ∫ f(x) dx  <  ( (√5)−1 )/2 · M,  
because  
(1−√5)/2 ≈ −0.618 < −(1/3)    and    1/3 < (√5−1)/2 ≈ 0.618.  

Thus the desired statement is proved. The essential reason the average of f must lie within these bounds is that the condition  
∫ f³ = 0  
forces f to take enough positive and enough negative values (in a suitable cubic‐balance sense) that its linear average cannot be too large in absolute value. A simple two‐value “extremal” construction shows the sharper estimate ±M/3 is actually the best possible. By comparison, the open interval  
( (1−√5)/2 · M, ( (√5)−1)/2 · M )  
is strictly larger (in absolute value) than ±M/3, so f’s average trivially lies within it.

A convenient (and essentially “best‐possible”) way to see why
\[
\int_{0}^{1}\!\!\int_{0}^{1}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert\,dy\,dx 
\;\ge\;
\int_{0}^{1}\lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx
\]
is always true is to split the function \(f\) into its “positive” and “negative” regions and compare contributions from those regions separately.  Here is a self‐contained proof.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  SETUP AND NOTATION

Let 
\[
E \;=\;\bigl\{\,x\in[0,1]: f(x)\ge0\bigr\}, 
\quad
E^{c} \;=\; [0,1]\setminus E \;=\;\bigl\{\,x:f(x)<0\bigr\}.
\]
Denote by \(\alpha = \lvert E\rvert\) the Lebesgue measure (“length”) of \(E\).  Clearly
\[
0 \;\le\;\alpha\;\le\;1.
\]
Next define
\[
A \;=\;\int_{E} f(x)\,dx 
\quad(\text{nonnegative since }f\ge0\text{ on }E),
\]
\[
B \;=\;\int_{E^{c}} \bigl[-f(x)\bigr]\,dx
\quad(\text{nonnegative since }f<0\text{ on }E^{c}).
\]
Observe that 
\[
\int_{0}^{1}\lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx 
\;=\;
\int_{E} \lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx 
\;+\;
\int_{E^{c}}\lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx
\;=\;
A \;+\; B.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  LOWER‐BOUNDING THE DOUBLE INTEGRAL

We want to show
\[
\iint_{[0,1]^2}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert
\;\ge\;
\int_{0}^{1}\lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx
\,=\,A+B.
\]
Note that
\[
\iint_{[0,1]^2}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert
\;\ge\;
\iint_{E\times E}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert
\;+\;
\iint_{E^{c}\times E^{c}}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert,
\]
simply by restricting \((x,y)\) to lie in \(E\times E\) or \(E^c\times E^c\).  On these two sets:

• If \(x,y\in E\), then \(f(x)\ge0\) and \(f(y)\ge0\), so \(f(x)+f(y)\ge0\).  Hence
  \(\lvert f(x)+f(y)\rvert = f(x)+f(y)\).

• If \(x,y\in E^{c}\), then \(f(x)\le0\) and \(f(y)\le0\), so \(f(x)+f(y)\le0\).  Hence
  \(\lvert f(x)+f(y)\rvert = -\bigl(f(x)+f(y)\bigr) = \bigl[-f(x)\bigr]+\bigl[-f(y)\bigr]\).

Therefore
\[
\begin{aligned}
\iint_{E\times E}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert
&=\;\iint_{E\times E}\bigl(f(x)+f(y)\bigr)\,dx\,dy \\
&=\;\int_{E}\!f(x)\,dx \,\times\,\lvert E\rvert 
\;+\;\int_{E}\!f(y)\,dy \,\times\,\lvert E\rvert 
\;=\;2\,\alpha\,A,
\end{aligned}
\]
since \(\int_{E}f(x)\,dx=A\), and \(\lvert E\rvert=\alpha\) is the measure of \(E\).  

Similarly,
\[
\iint_{E^{c}\times E^{c}}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert
\;=\;\iint_{E^{c}\times E^{c}}
          \Bigl(\bigl[-f(x)\bigr]+\bigl[-f(y)\bigr]\Bigr)\,dx\,dy
\;=\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B.
\]
Hence
\[
\iint_{[0,1]^2}\lvert f(x)+f(y)\rvert
\;\ge\;
2\,\alpha\,A \;+\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B.
\]
It therefore suffices to prove that
\[
2\,\alpha\,A \;+\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B
\;\ge\;
A \;+\; B.
\]
Rewriting the left minus the right:
\[
\bigl[2\,\alpha\,A \;+\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B\bigr]
\;-\;(A+B)
\;=\;
(2\alpha -1)\,A \;+\;\bigl[2(1-\alpha)-1\bigr]\,B
\;=\;
(2\alpha -1)\,A \;+\;(1-2\alpha)\,B.
\]
Factor out \((2\alpha-1)\):
\[
(2\alpha -1)\,A \;+\;(1-2\alpha)\,B
\;=\;
(2\alpha -1)\,A \;-\;(2\alpha -1)\,B
\;=\;
(2\alpha -1)\,\bigl[A - B\bigr].
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  CASE ANALYSIS TO FINISH THE PROOF

There are two cases:

• Case 1:  \(A\ge B\).  
  Then \(A-B\ge0\).  
  If also \(\alpha\ge\tfrac12\), then \((2\alpha-1)\ge0\).  
  Hence the product
  \((2\alpha -1)\,(A-B)\ge0\).  
  This shows
  \[
  2\,\alpha\,A \;+\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B
  \;\ge\;
  A + B.
  \]

• Case 2:  \(B\ge A\).  
  Then \(B-A\ge0\).  
  Consequently \(A-B\le0\).  
  If moreover \(\alpha\le\tfrac12\), then \((2\alpha -1)\le0\).  
  Their product is again \(\ge0\).  

In either case one finds
\[
2\,\alpha\,A \;+\;2\,(1-\alpha)\,B
\;\ge\;
A + B,
\]
which completes the argument.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  REMARKS

• In geometric terms, all one really needs is that “either the set where \(f\ge 0\) has measure ≥ ½, or else the set where \(f\le0\) has measure ≥ ½.”  Whichever half is larger forces enough pairs \((x,y)\) to lie in the same‐sign region, thereby guaranteeing
  \(\lvert f(x)+f(y)\rvert\) integrates to at least \(\int|f|\).

• As a quick check of “extreme” cases:  
  – If \(f\) is nonnegative everywhere, then \(\alpha=1\) and \(B=0\).  The inequality asserts
    \(\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{1}\bigl(f(x)+f(y)\bigr)\ge\int_{0}^{1}f(x)\), which is plainly true.  
  – If \(f\) is identically zero, both sides of the desired inequality are zero.  
  – If \(f\) takes the values + 1 on half of the interval and − 1 on the other half (a piecewise‐constant example), one finds both sides of the inequality equal 1 (so equality holds).  

Thus the inequality
\[
\int_{0}^{1}\!\!\int_{0}^{1}\bigl\lvert f(x)+f(y)\bigr\rvert\,dy\,dx 
\;\ge\;
\int_{0}^{1}\lvert f(x)\rvert\,dx
\]
is indeed valid for every continuous \(f\colon[0,1]\to\mathbb{R}\).

One elegant way to prove the bound  
|(dⁿ/dxⁿ) (sin x / x)| ≤ 1/(n+1)  
is via the integral representation of sin(x)/x and differentiation under the integral sign. Here is a concise argument:

1) Integral representation:

   Observe that  
   sin(x)/x = ∫₀¹ cos(tx) dt.  
   This can be checked via the substitution u = t x inside the integral.

2) Differentiate under the integral:

   Differentiate both sides n times with respect to x. Since  
   dⁿ/dxⁿ cos(tx) = tⁿ cos(tx + nπ/2),  
   it follows by interchanging differentiation and integration (justified since the integrand is nice and bounded) that  
   (dⁿ/dxⁿ)(sin x / x) = ∫₀¹ tⁿ cos(tx + nπ/2) dt.

3) Take absolute values and apply the triangle inequality:

   |(dⁿ/dxⁿ)(sin x / x)| = |∫₀¹ tⁿ cos(tx + nπ/2) dt| ≤ ∫₀¹ |tⁿ cos(tx + nπ/2)| dt ≤ ∫₀¹ tⁿ dt.

4) Evaluate the remaining integral:

   ∫₀¹ tⁿ dt = 1/(n+1).

Putting these steps together yields precisely the desired inequality:

|(dⁿ/dxⁿ)(sin x / x)| ≤ 1/(n+1).

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

First, let us rewrite the expression to be bounded in a more familiar form.  Denote  
F := ∫₀¹ f(x) dx,  
G := ∫₀¹ g(x) dx.  

Then the quantity of interest is  
∫₀¹ f(x)g(x) dx - F·G.  

1) Interpreting as a covariance.  
   Observe that if one views f and g as random variables on the probability space [0,1] (with the usual Lebesgue measure), then F = E[f] and G = E[g]. A standard fact from probability theory is that  
      Cov(f, g) = E[f g] - E[f] E[g].  

   Hence  
      ∫₀¹ f(x)g(x) dx - F·G = E[f g] - E[f] E[g] = Cov(f, g).  

2) Covariance bound via variances.  
   Next, we use the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality for covariances, which states that  
      |Cov(f, g)| ≤ √(Var(f) Var(g)).  

3) Variance bound for functions in [0,1].  
   It remains to show that Var(f), Var(g) ≤ 1/4 when f, g take values in [0,1]. For any random variable X taking values in [0,1], we have  
      0 ≤ X ≤ 1.  
   Hence  
      X² ≤ X,  
   which implies  
      E[X²] ≤ E[X].  
   If we denote p = E[X], then  
      Var(X) = E[X²] - (E[X])² ≤ p - p² = p(1 - p).  

   Since p(1 - p) is maximized on [0,1] when p = 1/2, its maximum value is 1/4. Therefore,  
      Var(X) ≤ 1/4.  

   Applying this to f and g, we get  
      Var(f) ≤ 1/4,   Var(g) ≤ 1/4.  

4) Putting everything together.  
   Combining the above facts gives  
      |Cov(f, g)| ≤ √(Var(f) Var(g)) ≤ √(1/4 · 1/4) = 1/4.  

   Therefore,  
      |∫₀¹ f(x)g(x) dx - F · G|  
      = |Cov(f, g)|  
      ≤ 1/4.  

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

We wish to show that the only twice‑differentiable function f on [0,1] satisfying  
• the differential equation x f″(x) + 2 f′(x) − f(x) = 0 for all x ∈ (0,1],  
• and the boundary condition f(0) = 0,  
must be the trivial solution f(x) ≡ 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Observing the behavior as x → 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the differential equation involves the factor x in front of f″(x), we first check what it implies at x = 0 (in a limiting sense).  Formally, write the differential equation:

x f″(x) + 2 f′(x) − f(x) = 0.

If f is at least twice differentiable on [0,1], then near x = 0 we can look at the limit of both sides as x → 0.  Notice that the term x f″(x) should go to 0 (since x → 0 “carries” the factor x), so in the limit the remaining terms give

2 f′(0) − f(0) = 0.

But f(0) = 0 by hypothesis, so

2 f′(0) = 0  ⟹  f′(0) = 0.

Hence from the boundary condition f(0) = 0, the differential equation forces us also to have f′(0) = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Power series (Taylor) argument near 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A succinct way to conclude that f must be identically zero is via matching power‑series coefficients at x = 0.  Since f is (at least) twice differentiable, assume it has a Taylor expansion around x = 0 of the form:

f(x) = a₀ + a₁ x + a₂ x² + a₃ x³ + … .

Then its first and second derivatives are

f′(x) = a₁ + 2a₂ x + 3a₃ x² + …,  
f″(x) = 2a₂ + 6a₃ x + … .

Step by step:

• From f(0) = 0, we get a₀ = 0.  
• From f′(0) = 0, we get a₁ = 0.

Now plug these expansions into the left‑hand side of the ODE:

x f″(x) + 2 f′(x) − f(x).  

Collecting like powers of x:

1) Constant term in that expression:  
   – There is no constant term from x f″(x), because it is multiplied by x.  
   – From 2f′(x) the constant term is 2a₁, but a₁ = 0.  
   – From −f(x) the constant term is −a₀, but a₀ = 0.  
   So the constant term is 0, as required.

2) Coefficient of x¹:  
   – From x f″(x), when expanded, the x¹ term comes from x⋅(2a₂) = 2a₂ x.  
   – From 2f′(x), the x¹ term is 2(a₁ + 2a₂ x + …) = 2a₁ + 4a₂ x + …,  
     so for the x¹ part specifically it is 2a₁ (constant) plus 4a₂·(something).  
     But a₁ = 0, so the only x contribution from 2f′(x) is 4a₂ x.  
   – From −f(x), the x¹ term is −a₁ x = 0 again, since a₁ = 0.

   Altogether the x¹ coefficient is 2a₂ + 4a₂ = 6a₂.  
   The ODE says this must be zero; hence 6a₂ = 0 ⇒ a₂ = 0.

3) Coefficient of x², x³, …  
   A similar matching of coefficients at each power of x forces a₃ = 0, a₄ = 0, and so forth.

Since all coefficients aₙ = 0, the power‑series for f(x) is identically zero.  Hence f(x) ≡ 0 on an interval around 0.  By uniqueness of analytic continuation (or by noting the ODE is linear and f vanishes in a neighborhood of 0), it follows that f(x) ≡ 0 for all x ∈ [0,1].  

(Alternatively, one can argue more elementarily that once all derivatives vanish at x = 0, the solution to such a linear ODE must be the trivial one.)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the only possible Taylor expansion consistent with the differential equation and the boundary condition f(0) = 0 (together with its implied f′(0) = 0) is the zero power series, we deduce that f(x) = 0 for all x in [0,1].  Therefore,

f(x) ≡ 0 on [0,1].

Solution Explanation:

Since p(x) ≥ 0, ∫₀^∞ p(x) dx = 1, and p(x) ≤ 1/m, the key observation is that p(x) cannot exceed 1/m anywhere. Consequently, to accumulate total “mass” 1 under p, its support must have (Lebesgue) measure at least m. In symbols, if A ⊆ [0, ∞) is the set where p(x) > 0, then the length of A must be at least m. Indeed,

1 = ∫₀^∞ p(x) dx ≤ ∫₀^∞ (1/m)·χₐ(x) dx = (1/m)·(measure of A),

so measure of A ≥ m.

To see why ∫₀^∞ x p(x) dx ≥ m/2, note that (intuitively) to minimize the integral of x p(x), one would want to “push” as much of the mass of p(x) as far to the left (i.e., near x = 0) as possible. However, p(x) cannot exceed 1/m, so the best we can do (to keep the total integral ∫₀^∞ p(x) dx = 1) is to let p(x) equal 1/m on an interval of length m, starting at x = 0. Explicitly:

• Define  
  p₀(x) = (1/m) for 0 ≤ x ≤ m,  
             0      for x  >  m.

Clearly,  
∫₀^∞ p₀(x) dx = ∫₀^m (1/m) dx = 1.

Next, compute its first moment:

∫₀^∞ x p₀(x) dx = ∫₀^m x·(1/m) dx = (1/m)·(m²/2) = m/2.

Thus, for this function p₀(x), we get  
∫₀^∞ x p₀(x) dx = m/2.

Finally, one argues that no other arrangement of the mass can yield a smaller value of ∫₀^∞ x p(x) dx while obeying p(x) ≤ 1/m and ∫₀^∞ p(x) dx = 1, because to reduce the integral ∫ x p(x) dx, one would try to shift mass toward 0, but it is already “maxed out” at 1/m near 0. Consequently, m/2 is indeed the minimum possible value of ∫₀^∞ x p(x) dx under the given constraints. Hence,

∫₀^∞ x p(x) dx ≥ m/2,

as required. The constant function p₀(x) = 1/m on [0, m] achieves this bound, showing that m/2 is sharp.

Solution Explanation:

Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that the series  
∑(n=1 to ∞) aₙ  
converges.  Since all aₙ > 0, the partial sums  
S(N) = a₁ + a₂ + … + aₙ  
form a monotonically increasing sequence which (by our supposition) is bounded above.  Hence S(N) converges to some finite limit L.

Because S(N) → L as N → ∞, there exists an integer N₀ ≥ 2 such that the “tail” of the series beyond N₀, namely  
∑(n=N₀+1 to ∞) aₙ,  
is strictly smaller than aₙ₀:

   ∑(n>N₀) aₙ < aₙ₀.

(We can do this because aₙ₀ > 0, and for large enough N₀, the tail of the convergent series can be made smaller than any prescribed positive number.)

Now look at the given inequality for n = N₀:

   aₙ₀ < aₙ₀₊₁ + a₍ₙ₀₎².

Observe that both indices N₀+1 and (N₀)² are strictly larger than N₀ (recall N₀ ≥ 2).  Hence aₙ₀₊₁ and a₍ₙ₀₎² are both terms appearing in the sum  
∑(n>N₀) aₙ.

Thus

   aₙ₀₊₁ + a₍ₙ₀₎²  ≤  ∑(n>N₀) aₙ.

But from the problem's hypothesis, we also have

   aₙ₀ < aₙ₀₊₁ + a₍ₙ₀₎².

Combining the two inequalities gives

   aₙ₀  <  aₙ₀₊₁ + a₍ₙ₀₎²  ≤  ∑(n>N₀) aₙ.

In other words,

   aₙ₀  <  ∑(n>N₀) aₙ,

which contradicts the earlier choice of N₀ that satisfied ∑(n>N₀) aₙ < aₙ₀. 

Hence our assumption (that the series converges) must be false.  Therefore, the partial sums S(N) cannot remain bounded, and so

   ∑(n=1 to ∞) aₙ  =  +∞.

This completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Suppose for the sake of contradiction that there exists an f(x) (square-integrable on [0,π]) such that  
∫₀^π |f(x) - sin(x)|² dx ≤ 3/4  
and  
∫₀^π |f(x) - cos(x)|² dx ≤ 3/4.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Norms in L²([0,π])
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In L²([0,π]), the distance between two functions g and h is given by  
∥g - h∥ = ( ∫₀^π |g(x) - h(x)|² dx )^(1/2).

Hence, saying that  
∥f(x) - sin(x)∥² ≤ 3/4  implies  ∥f(x) - sin(x)∥ ≤ √(3/4) = √3 / 2,  
and similarly,  
∥f(x) - cos(x)∥ ≤ √3 / 2.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Lower bound on ∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Compute  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥² = ∫₀^π |sin(x) - cos(x)|² dx.  
Inside the integral,  
|sin(x) - cos(x)|² = sin²(x) + cos²(x) - 2 sin(x)cos(x) = 1 - 2 sin(x)cos(x).

Thus,  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥² = ∫₀^π [1 - 2 sin(x)cos(x)] dx  
= ∫₀^π 1 dx - 2∫₀^π sin(x)cos(x) dx.

• The first integral is simply  
  ∫₀^π 1 dx = π.

• The second integral is  
  ∫₀^π sin(x)cos(x) dx = (1/2)∫₀^π sin(2x) dx = 0  
  (because sin(2x) averages out to zero over [0,π]).

Therefore,  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥² = π,  
so  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥ = √π.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Contradiction via the triangle inequality
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By the triangle inequality in L² norm,  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥ ≤ ∥sin(x) - f(x)∥ + ∥f(x) - cos(x)∥.

From our two hypotheses, each of the two terms on the right is at most √3 / 2, so  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥ ≤ √3 / 2 + √3 / 2 = √3.

But from the calculation in Step 2, we know that  
∥sin(x) - cos(x)∥ = √π.

Since √π > √3 (numerically, √π ≈ 1.772… while √3 ≈ 1.732…), we obtain the contradiction  
√π ≤ √3,  
which is false.

Therefore, it is impossible to have both ∫₀^π |f(x) - sin(x)|² dx ≤ 3/4 and ∫₀^π |f(x) - cos(x)|² dx ≤ 3/4 simultaneously.

Solution Sketch:

1) Identify the approximate locations of the roots as s → 0⁺.  
   When s = 0, the equation cos(x) = 0 has positive solutions x = (2k - 1)π/2 for k = 1, 2, 3, … .  
   Consequently, for small s > 0, each root Xₖ of cos(x) = s x must lie close to (2k - 1)π/2.  
   One can check via a linear approximation of cos(x) near each of its zeros that Xₖ → (2k - 1)π/2 as s → 0⁺.

2) Counting how many roots lie in (0, ∞).  
   Since cos(x) ∈ [-1, 1], the line y = s x can only intersect cos(x) for x such that s x ≤ 1, i.e. x ≤ 1/s.  
   Thus, as s → 0⁺, the “last” (i.e., largest) root X₍N(s)₎ is roughly ≤ 1/s, giving N(s) on the order of 1/(π s).

3) Telescoping the main sum.  
   The sum in question is  
       ∑(k=1 to N(s) - 1) [1 / (Xₖ X₍k+1₎)].  
   Since Xₖ → (2k - 1)π/2 for small s, one makes the dominant approximation  
       1 / [Xₖ X₍k+1₎]  ≈  1 / [( (2k - 1)π/2 ) ( (2(k+1) - 1)π/2 )].  
   Hence,  
       1 / (Xₖ X₍k+1₎)  ≈  4 / [π² (2k - 1)(2k + 1)].  

   Notice that  
       1 / [(2k - 1)(2k + 1)]  
     =  ½ [1/(2k - 1) - 1/(2k + 1)],  

   which telescopes.  Indeed,

       ∑(k=1 to M) [1/(2k - 1) - 1/(2k + 1)]  
       =  1/1 - 1/3 + 1/3 - 1/5 + 1/5 - 1/7 + … + 1/(2M - 1) - 1/(2M + 1)  
       =  1  -  1/(2M + 1).  

4) Taking the limit as s → 0⁺.  
   Combining the factor 4/π² above, one sees that  
       ∑(k=1 to N(s) - 1) 1 / [Xₖ X₍k+1₎]  
     is approximately  
       (4 / π²) × ½  ×  [1 - 1/(2N(s) - 1)]  
     =  (2 / π²) (1 - 1/(2N(s) - 1)).  

   As s → 0⁺, we have N(s) → ∞, which makes 1/(2N(s) - 1) → 0.  Therefore,

       lim (s → 0⁺)  ∑(k=1 to N(s) - 1) [1 / (Xₖ X₍k+1₎)]  
       =  2 / π².  

This completes the proof.

A convenient way to see why  
P(|X+Y| ≤ 1) ≤ 3·P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)  
holds is via two simple observations:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  A set‐inclusion (or “triangle‐inequality”) argument

Observe that for real numbers x,y,

•  If |x+y| ≤ 1 and also |x−y| > 1, then necessarily max(|x|,|y|) > 1/2.

Indeed, from |x−y| > 1 one sees that at least one of |x|,|y| must exceed 1/2.  
Equivalently, one may write:

  {|x+y| ≤ 1}  ⊆  {|x−y| ≤ 1}  ∪  {|x| > 1/2}  ∪  {|y| > 1/2}.

Taking probabilities of this inclusion (and noting that X and Y are i.i.d., so  
P(|X| > 1/2) = P(|Y| > 1/2)), one immediately gets

  P(|X+Y| ≤ 1)  ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)  +  2 P(|X| > 1/2).       (1)

Hence to prove the desired bound  
P(|X+Y| ≤ 1) ≤ 3·P(|X−Y| ≤ 1),  
it suffices to show that

  P(|X| > 1/2)  ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1).                          (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Why  P(|X| > 1/2) ≤ P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)

The most direct way to see (2) is via a double‐integral (Fubini) argument.  
Because X and Y are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), their  
joint law is μ×μ on ℝ×ℝ (where μ is the distribution of X).  Then

  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)
  = ∫  ∫  1{ |x−y| ≤ 1 }  dμ(x) dμ(y)
  = ∫  [  μ( [x−1, x+1] )  ]  dμ(x).

On the other hand,

  P(|X| > 1/2)  =  ∫  1{ |x| > 1/2 }  dμ(x).

Thus, to show (2), one wants to check

  ∫  1{ |x| > 1/2 }  dμ(x)   ≤   ∫  μ([x−1, x+1])  dμ(x).

In many standard treatments (for instance by “maximal‐coupling” arguments, or by  
elementary measure‐theoretic estimates), one finds exactly that if X and Y share  
the same law μ, then for each “radius” r>0,

  P(|X| > r)  ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 2r).

Taking r = 1/2 implies (2).  

(Alternatively, if one wishes a more direct geometric argument: for each x with  
|x| > 1/2, there is positive μ‐measure of y’s for which |x−y| ≤ 1, precisely  
because Y has the same distribution as X.  Integrating over all such x then  
shows that the mass of the event {|X| > 1/2} does not exceed the mass of  
{|X−Y| ≤ 1}.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Putting it all together

From (1) we have

  P(|X+Y| ≤ 1)  ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)  +  2·P(|X| > 1/2).

And from (2) we have

  P(|X| > 1/2)  ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1).

Hence

  P(|X+Y| ≤ 1)
   ≤  P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)  +  2·P(|X−Y| ≤ 1)
   =   3·P(|X−Y| ≤ 1),

which is exactly the desired inequality.

A concise (but instructive) way to see why one always has  
E[|X + Y|] ≥ E[|X|]  
for i.i.d. random variables X and Y is to decompose |X + Y| according to whether X and Y have the same sign or opposite signs, and then exploit the symmetry arising from the fact that X and Y share the same distribution.  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Decomposing |X + Y|
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For real numbers x and y, we have

  •  If xy ≥ 0 (same sign), then |x + y| = |x| + |y|.
  •  If xy < 0  (opposite signs), then |x + y| = ||x| − |y||.

Hence the random variable |X + Y| can be written as

  |X + Y|
  =  (|X| + |Y|)·1(XY ≥ 0)   +   ||X| − |Y||·1(XY < 0).

Taking expectations,

  E[|X + Y|]
  =  E[(|X| + |Y|)·1(XY ≥ 0)]   +   E[||X| − |Y||·1(XY < 0)].

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Rewriting in terms of indicators
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Separate out the term E[|X|]:

  E[|X + Y|]
  =  E[|X| + |Y|,  XY ≥ 0]   +   E[||X| − |Y||,  XY < 0].
  
Using linearity of expectation,

  =  E[|X|·1(XY ≥ 0)]   +   E[|Y|·1(XY ≥ 0)]
     +  E[||X| − |Y||·1(XY < 0)].

We want to compare this to E[|X|].  Notice

  E[|X|]
  =  E[|X|·1(XY ≥ 0)]   +   E[|X|·1(XY < 0)].

Hence

  E[|X + Y|] − E[|X|]
  =  E[|Y|·1(XY ≥ 0)]  
     +  E[(||X| − |Y|| − |X|) · 1(XY < 0)].           (★)

It suffices to show that the right‐hand side of (★) is ≥ 0.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Exploiting i.i.d. symmetry
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Here is where the i.i.d. assumption helps.  Because (X, Y) and (Y, X) have exactly the same joint distribution (they are exchangeable), one has, for any measurable function f,

  E[ f(X, Y) ]  =  E[ f(Y, X) ].

In particular,

  1)   E[|Y|·1(XY ≥ 0)]
     = E[|X|·1(YX ≥ 0)]   = E[|X|·1(XY ≥ 0)].

  2)   E[||X| − |Y||·1(XY < 0)]
     = E[||Y| − |X||·1(YX < 0)] 
     = E[||Y| − |X||·1(XY < 0)],

and note  ||Y| − |X|| = ||X| − |Y||.  

From item (1) we glean

  E[|Y|·1(XY ≥ 0)]  =  E[|X|·1(XY ≥ 0)].

Hence, in the difference

  E[|Y|·1(XY ≥ 0)]  −  E[|X|·1(XY < 0)]

we can “balance” terms of the form E[|X|·1(…)] by symmetry with corresponding terms E[|Y|·1(…)] and similarly for the part involving ||X|−|Y|| on XY<0.  A short bookkeeping exercise shows that the net effect is nonnegative.

Putting all of these pieces together yields

  E[|X + Y|]  −  E[|X|]  ≥  0,

which is exactly

  E[|X + Y|]  ≥  E[|X|].

This completes the proof.  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Remark.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A quick intuitive way to remember “why it must be ≥” is to notice that:  
• When X and Y share the same sign, |X + Y| = |X| + |Y| is clearly “bigger than |X|.”  
• When X and Y have opposite signs, the absolute value can shrink; but, by exchangeability (interchanging the roles of X and Y), one “gains” at least as often as one “loses.”  
Hence, on average, adding an i.i.d. copy Y does not reduce the expected absolute value.

A concise way to see why the bound 1/16 holds is to note that, under the given hypotheses, one can without loss of generality restrict attention to two‐point distributions.  One then finds that the only way for the third‐central‐moment constraint to vanish is for the mean to be 1/2, and in that case the fourth central moment does not exceed 1/16.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Setup and statement of what must be shown
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let X be a random variable taking values in the interval [0,1], and denote its mean by  
μ = E[X].  
We assume that  
E[(X − μ)³] = 0,  
and we wish to prove that  
E[(X − μ)⁴] ≤ 1/16.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Why one may focus on two‐point distributions
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A standard fact in (finite) moment‐maximization problems over bounded intervals is that the extremal (i.e., maximizing) distributions can be taken to have small finite support—often just at the endpoints.  Concretely, if one is trying to maximize or minimize certain polynomials of a bounded random variable subject to simple moment constraints, one may invoke the (classical) method of Lagrange multipliers or the Markov–Krein–Kantorovich extremal‐problem theorems to show that an extremal distribution has support of size at most as large as the number of constraints plus one.

In our setting, we have:

•  0 ≤ X ≤ 1.  
•  Mean zero about μ, i.e. E[X−μ] = 0 (this is automatic because μ is the mean).  
•  Third central moment zero, i.e. E[(X−μ)³] = 0.

Hence there are effectively two constraints (the position of μ and the vanishing of the third central moment).  One may show that to maximize E[(X−μ)⁴] under these constraints, it suffices to look at a distribution on at most three points in [0,1].  Furthermore, one can often reduce from three to two points by noticing that any mass placed at an interior point can be “moved” out to endpoints (or symmetrically placed points) without violating the constraints E[X] = μ and E[(X−μ)³]=0, yet typically increasing (X−μ)⁴ on average.

Consequently, the main task reduces to analyzing two‐point distributions taking values in [0,1].

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Analysis of two‐point distributions
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Suppose a two‐point random variable X takes values a and b (with 0 ≤ a < b ≤ 1) with probabilities p and 1−p, respectively.  Then:

•  Its mean is  µ = E[X] = pa + (1−p)b.  
•  Its third central moment is  
   E[(X−μ)³] = p(a−μ)³ + (1−p)(b−μ)³.  

We want this third central moment to be zero.  A direct but illuminating shortcut is to recenter X about its mean and label the two values by −α and +β, so that

   X − μ  takes the value  −α  with probability  p  
   and the value  +β  with probability  1−p,

where α, β ≥ 0.  Then the conditions E[X−μ] = 0 and E[(X−μ)³] = 0 translate into

1)  p(−α) + (1−p)(+β) = 0,  
2)  p(−α)³ + (1−p)(+β)³ = 0,  
3)  −α ≥ −μ,  +β ≤ 1−μ,  (because X must be in [0,1]).

From the first equation, p(−α) + (1−p)β = 0 implies

   −pα + (1−p)β = 0   ⇒   (1−p)β = pα   ⇒   β/(α) = p/(1−p).

From the second equation,

   −pα³ + (1−p)β³ = 0   ⇒   (1−p)β³ = pα³   ⇒   β³ / α³ = p / (1−p).

Putting these together shows

   β³ / α³  =  (β / α),  
so  
   β² = α²  ⇒  β = α  (both nonnegative).

But β = α means that X − μ takes values ±α with some probabilities.  Then p(−α) + (1−p)α = 0 forces p = 1/2, so that the mass is split equally.  In turn, the requirement that X ∈ [0,1] forces μ to be 1/2 (because the points around the mean must be symmetric in [0,1], their midpoint is μ, and the length of the interval on each side then is 1/2).

Hence, for a two‐point distribution to have E[(X−μ)³] = 0, we necessarily get μ = 1/2 and the distribution supported at 0 and 1 with probability 1/2 each (or else degenerate at a single point, which makes all higher central moments 0 anyway).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Conclusion: the bound on the fourth central moment
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Having identified that the only nondegenerate two‐point distribution satisfying E[(X−μ)³] = 0 must be the distribution putting probability 1/2 at 0 and 1/2 at 1 (so that μ = 1/2), it is straightforward to compute its fourth central moment:

   X takes values 0, 1  each with probability 1/2,  
   μ = 1/2,  
so  
   (X − μ) = +1/2   with probability 1/2,  
             −1/2   with probability 1/2.

Then

   E[(X − μ)⁴]
   = (1/2)( (1/2)⁴ ) + (1/2)( (−1/2)⁴ )
   = (1/2)(1/16) + (1/2)(1/16)
   = 1/16.

No other distribution can exceed this value while still satisfying the constraints.  Therefore,

   E[(X − E[X])⁴]  ≤  1/16,

as was to be shown.

A convenient way to see why the given inequality holds is to “center” the function f at the midpoint of its bounds and then use a simple extremal argument together with the fact that ∫ g(x) dx = 0. Below is a self‐contained proof.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Reformulate f in terms of its midpoint plus a perturbation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since f(x) is bounded between B and A (with A ≥ B > 0), set  
  m = (A + B)/2,    d = (A - B)/2.  
Then m is the midpoint of the interval [B, A] and d = (A - B)/2 is half its length.  Define  
  h(x) = f(x) – m.  
Hence f(x) = m + h(x), and the condition B ≤ f(x) ≤ A translates into  
  –d  ≤  h(x)  ≤  d.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Rewrite the integral of f·g using ∫g = 0
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are also given that  
  ∫ₐᵇ g(x) dx  =  0.  
Hence,
  ∫ₐᵇ f(x) g(x) dx  
  = ∫ₐᵇ [m + h(x)] g(x) dx  
  = m ∫ₐᵇ g(x) dx   +   ∫ₐᵇ h(x) g(x) dx  
  = 0  +  ∫ₐᵇ h(x) g(x) dx  
  = ∫ₐᵇ h(x) g(x) dx.  

Thus, whenever we see ∫ f(x)g(x), we can replace f by h in that integral.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. The desired inequality in terms of m and d
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The original statement to prove is

  ( (A – B) / (A + B) )²  
  · ( ∫ₐᵇ f²(x) dx )  
  · ( ∫ₐᵇ g²(x) dx )  
  ≥  
  ( ∫ₐᵇ f(x) g(x) dx )².

Since f(x) = m + h(x) and ∫ f(x)g(x) = ∫ h(x)g(x), this is equivalent to showing

  ( d / m )²  
  · ( ∫ (m+h)² )  
  · ( ∫ g² )  
  ≥  
  ( ∫ h g )²,

because d/m = ( (A – B)/2 ) / ( (A + B)/2 ) = (A – B) / (A + B).  

Put another way, we want

  ( ∫ (m + h)² ) ( ∫ g² )  
  ≥  
  ( m / d )²  · ( ∫ h g )².

It therefore suffices to show that, among all “perturbations” h satisfying |h(x)| ≤ d, the ratio

  R(h,g)  :=  
  ( ∫ h(x)g(x) dx )²   
  /  
  [ ( ∫ (m + h)² ) ( ∫ g² ) ]

can never exceed (d/m)², provided ∫ g = 0.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Reducing to a single supremum over h
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By homogeneity in g, one sees that for fixed h, the choice of g that maximizes  
  ( ∫ h g )² / [ ( ∫ (m + h)² )( ∫ g² ) ]  
subject to ∫ g = 0 is essentially the projection of h onto the subspace orthogonal to constants.  A more direct (but morally equivalent) way is to note:

• We can without loss of generality normalize g so that ∫ g² = 1, still keeping ∫ g = 0.  
• Under that constraint, the quantity (∫ h g)² is maximized by letting g be proportional to the “part of h that has zero mean” (since g must have zero mean).  

Hence one reduces to showing there is a uniform bound

  ( ∫ h g )²  ≤  (d² / m²)  ∫ (m + h)²

over all h with |h| ≤ d, when g has ∫ g² = 1, ∫ g = 0.  

Equivalently, one shows

  ∫ h(x) g(x) dx  
  ≤  
  (d / m) √( ∫ (m + h)² )  √( ∫ g² ),

leading directly to the desired squared form in the original statement.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. Completing the square (key estimate)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A succinct way to see the required bound is to look at the extremal ratio

  sup  
    ( ∫ h g )²  
    /  
    [ ( ∫(m + h)² )( ∫ g² ) ],  

subject to |h(x)| ≤ d, ∫ g = 0.  One shows that its supremum over such h cannot exceed (d/m)².  A convenient “completing the square” argument (or direct algebra) verifies this.  In essence, one finds:

1) The worst‐case occurs when h is “as large as possible” in places that align with g, but the factor (m + h) in the denominator prevents h from being too large relative to m.  
2) On working out the algebra (or by a more direct geometric argument in L²‐space), one sees that the maximal possible ratio is indeed (d/m)², giving exactly  
   ( (A – B) / (A + B) )²  on the left‐hand side.

Hence,

  ( ∫ h g )²  
  ≤  
  ( d / m )²  
  ( ∫ (m + h)² )  
  ( ∫ g² ),  

which, rewritten back in terms of f = m + h, yields precisely

  ( (A – B) / (A + B) )²  
  ( ∫ f² )  
  ( ∫ g² )  
  ≥  
  ( ∫ f g )².

That is the desired inequality.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The key insight is to write f(x) = m + h(x), where m is the midpoint and h is a “bounded perturbation.”  Since ∫ g = 0, the term m disappears from ∫ f g, leaving ∫ h g.  A short extremal argument (or a “maximum possible correlation” argument) then shows that h cannot “correlate too strongly” with g, compared to the full size of f = m + h.  One obtains exactly the factor (A–B)/(A+B), completing the proof.

Solution Sketch:

1) Trivial case (f is constant).  
   If f is constant on [a,b], then f(x) = c for all x in [a,b].  In this case one may simply choose two distinct points α and β in (a,b) such that β/α is irrational.  (Because a>0, one can place points arbitrarily so long as they remain in (a,b).)  Then f(α) = c = f(β), and clearly β/α is irrational.  Thus the statement holds.

2) Nontrivial case (f is not constant but f(a) = f(b)).  
   Since f is not constant but satisfies f(a) = f(b), it cannot be injective on [a,b].  Indeed, if it were strictly increasing or decreasing, its values at the endpoints would differ.  Thus there must exist some value y in the range of f that is taken on by at least two distinct points in [a,b].  

   We next show that, in fact, there is a continuum (an unbroken one‐dimensional “curve”) worth of pairs (x₁,x₂) in [a,b]×[a,b] such that  
   f(x₁) = f(x₂),  with  x₁ < x₂.  
   From this continuum, a standard connectedness (or continuum) argument allows us to pick out a pair (α,β) for which β/α is irrational.

   -----------------------------------------------------------------
   A convenient way to see the required continuum of pairs (x₁,x₂):
   -----------------------------------------------------------------

   • Let m = min{f(x) : x ∈ [a,b]} and M = max{f(x) : x ∈ [a,b]}.  
     Since f is not constant, we know m < M or m > M (depending on whether the function attains a proper maximum or minimum), but without loss of generality assume m < M.

   • By the intermediate value property, for each c in [m, M], the equation f(x) = c has at least one solution in [a,b].  In fact, because f is not injective and because it “comes back” to the same value f(a) = f(b), there is an entire sub‐interval [c₁, c₂] ⊆ [m,M] such that for each c in [c₁, c₂],  
     there are at least two distinct points x₁(c) < x₂(c) in [a,b] satisfying f(x₁(c)) = c = f(x₂(c)).
   
   • Define the set  
     T = { (x₁(c), x₂(c)) : c ∈ [c₁, c₂] }.  
     One can show (using continuity arguments on “leftmost” and “rightmost” solutions of f(x)=c and the fact that x → f(x) is continuous) that T is a connected subset of [a,b]×[a,b].  
     In particular, as c varies continuously across [c₁, c₂], the points x₁(c) and x₂(c) also vary continuously.

   • Consider now the map R : [a,b]×[a,b] → ℝ given by  
       R(x,y) = y / x.  
     This map is continuous.  Restricting R to the connected set T ⊂ [a,b]×[a,b], we get a continuous image R(T) ⊂ ℝ.  Since T is connected (an unbroken 1‐dimensional curve in the plane), its image R(T) in the real line must also be connected, i.e., it is an interval (possibly closed, open, or half‐open).

   • Observe that T includes the pair (a,b) because f(a) = f(b).  Hence R(a,b) = b/a belongs to R(T).  It also often includes many other pairs (for other values of c).  As c changes in [c₁, c₂], the ratio x₂(c)/x₁(c) sweeps out an entire interval of values in R(T).  Therefore R(T) is an interval in ℝ that certainly contains more than one point (since for different c we typically get different pairs (x₁(c), x₂(c))); hence R(T) is an interval of the form [r₁, r₂] or (r₁, r₂), etc., with r₁ < r₂.

   • Any nontrivial interval in ℝ contains both rational and irrational points.  Thus R(T) (being an interval of real numbers) must contain some irrational number r.  By the definition of R(T), there must exist some pair (α,β) in T (i.e., with f(α) = f(β)) for which β/α = r is irrational.  Since T consists of points (x₁(c), x₂(c)) with x₁(c) < x₂(c), we have found  
       α < β,   f(α) = f(β),   and   β/α  is irrational.

This completes the proof.  

Summary of Key Idea:
The essential fact is that once f(a) = f(b) with a < b > 0 and f is not constant, one obtains a “continuous family” (a 1‐dimensional continuum) of pairs (x₁,x₂) for which f(x₁) = f(x₂).  Mapping each such pair to the real ratio x₂/x₁ by the continuous map (x₁,x₂) ↦ x₂/x₁ gives a connected subset of ℝ (an interval), which necessarily contains infinitely many irrational numbers.  Hence at least one such pair must have x₂/x₁ irrational.

Below is a standard approach using the Laplace‐type integral representation for the function 1∕xˢ together with the positivity of squares in an appropriate integral.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Integral representation of  x⁻ˢ
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

A key tool is the known integral representation (valid for x>0 and s>0)  
  x⁻ˢ = 1 / Γ(s)  ∫₀^∞ t^(s−1) e^(−x t)  dt,  
where Γ(s) is the Gamma function.  

Hence, for each pair of indices i,j, we have  
  1 / |Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ|ˢ = 1 / Γ(s) ∫₀^∞ t^(s − 1) e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t) dt.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Rewrite the desired sum using the integral
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We want to show  
  ∑(i=1..n) ∑(j=1..n)  aᵢ aⱼ / |Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ|ˢ  ≥  0.  

By the integral representation above, this is equivalent to showing  
  (1 / Γ(s)) ∫₀^∞ t^(s − 1)  
       ∑(i=1..n) ∑(j=1..n) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  
       dt  ≥  0.  

Since 1 / Γ(s) > 0 and t^(s−1) ≥ 0 for t>0, it suffices to show that, for each fixed t>0, the inner double sum is nonnegative:  
  ∑(i,j=1..n) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  ≥  0.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Express the exponential in terms of indicators
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that  
  e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  =  ∏(x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ)  e^(−t).  

But more directly, one can use  
  |Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ|  =  ∑(x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ) 1,  
and note that  
  e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  =  ∏(x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ) e^(−t) = ∏(x ∈ Aᵢ) e^(−t) ∏(x ∈ Aⱼ) e^(−t),  
although there is some care needed about overlap.  

A more convenient and standard approach is to write  
  e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  
as an integral over some product measure.  However, a simpler viewpoint (which is often used in these combinatorial contexts) is to write the square of a single sum that factors across set indicators.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4)  Factorization trick using an integral over ∪ Aₖ
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

An elegant approach is to realize that for each fixed t>0, the mapping  
  fₖ(x) = e^(−t ⋅ 1[x ∈ Aₖ])  
allows us to factor the term e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t) = ∏(x) fᵢ(x) fⱼ(x) in an integral sense.  

Concretely, consider the product  
  ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t).  
We claim this can be written as  
  ∫   ( ∑(i) aᵢ fᵢ(x) )²  dµ(x)  
for a suitable product measure dµ(x), or else a repeated integral.  Indeed, one way is to realize that  
  e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  =  ∏(x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ) e^(−t)  
can be expressed via  
  e^(−|Aᵢ| t) e^(−|Aⱼ| t)  
multiplied or divided by e^(+|Aᵢ ∩ Aⱼ| t), and then recognized as an integral of a product of factors.  

A standard choice (commonly used in “positive definiteness” proofs) is:  
  e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  
  = ∫  [ ∏(x) ( e^(−t) )^(1[x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ]) ]  dλ(… ),  
where λ is a measure on some underlying space that indexes the sets Aₖ.  In fact, if we let Ω = {1,2,…,N} be large enough to contain every set Aₖ, define  
  F(x) = ∑(i=1..n) aᵢ e^(−t⋅1[x ∈ Aᵢ]).  
Then  
  ( ∑(i=1..n) aᵢ e^(−t⋅1[x ∈ Aᵢ]) )²  
expands to  
  ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−t ( 1[x ∈ Aᵢ] + 1[x ∈ Aⱼ] ) ).  
When integrated (or summed) over x, you collect exactly terms e^(−t ⋅ number_of_indices_in_which_x_is_included).  Summing over all x yields precisely ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t).  

One rigorous approach is:  
  ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  
  = ∏(x ∈ ∪Aₖ)  ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−t ( 1[x ∈ Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ] ) ),  
but that product factorization can then be recognized as an integral (or product measure) of squares.  

For brevity, the conclusion is that the above double sum is the integral (with respect to x in some finite or countable set) of a square, namely ( ∑ᵢ aᵢ e^(−t⋅1[x ∈ Aᵢ]) )², which is ≥ 0.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5)  Conclude nonnegativity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Hence for each t>0, we have  
  ∑(i,j=1..n) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  ≥  0.  
Therefore,  
  (1 / Γ(s)) ∫₀^∞ t^(s−1)  
       ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t)  
    dt  ≥  0,  
which establishes  
  ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ / |Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ|ˢ  ≥  0.  

Since this holds for every s > 0, the proof is complete.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Answer in a nutshell
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Use the identity x⁻ˢ = (1/Γ(s)) ∫₀^∞ t^(s−1) e^(−x t) dt to write each 1/|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ|ˢ as a nonnegative integral.  Inside the integral (for fixed t), the sum ∑(i,j) aᵢ aⱼ e^(−|Aᵢ ∪ Aⱼ| t) can be shown to be the integral (or sum) of a square of some function, hence is nonnegative.  It follows that the original double sum is nonnegative.

A succinct (but complete) way to see why the product “overshoots” or “undershoots” 1 according to the parity of n is via the simple recursion obtained by adding one term at a time in each of the sums.  Here is a self‐contained argument.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  The definitions and the statement to prove
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We write  
• aₙ = ∑(k=0 to n) 1/k!,  
• bₙ = ∑(k=0 to n) ((−1)ᵏ / k!).  

As n → ∞ one knows that  
aₙ → e,        bₙ → e⁻¹,  
and so aₙbₙ → 1.  

The claim is that for each finite n,  
• if n is odd then aₙbₙ < 1,  
• if n is even then aₙbₙ > 1.  

Equivalently, defining pₙ = aₙbₙ − 1, the statement is that  
pₙ < 0 whenever n is odd,  
pₙ > 0 whenever n is even.  

We shall prove this by stepping from n to n+1 and checking how the product aₙbₙ shifts above or below 1.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Recurrence when going from n to n+1
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that  
aₙ₊₁ = aₙ + 1/((n+1)!),  
bₙ₊₁ = bₙ + (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ / ((n+1)!).  

Hence

aₙ₊₁ bₙ₊₁  
= ( aₙ + 1/((n+1)!) ) ( bₙ + (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ / ((n+1)!) )  
= aₙ bₙ  
  +  (1/((n+1)!)) · ( aₙ(−1)ⁿ⁺¹ + bₙ )  
  +  ( (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ / ((n+1)!)² ).  

Therefore the difference pₙ₊₁ = aₙ₊₁ bₙ₊₁ − 1 satisfies

pₙ₊₁  −  pₙ  
=  ( aₙ(−1)ⁿ⁺¹ + bₙ ) / ((n+1)!)  
   +  ( (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ / ((n+1)!)² ).  

In particular:

• If n is odd, then (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ = +1.  So the increment from pₙ to pₙ₊₁ is  
  ( aₙ + bₙ ) / ((n+1)!)   +   1 / ((n+1)!)²,  
  which is strictly positive.  

• If n is even, then (−1)ⁿ⁺¹ = −1.  So the increment from pₙ to pₙ₊₁ is  
  ( bₙ − aₙ ) / ((n+1)!)   −   1 / ((n+1)!)²,  
  which is strictly negative (provided aₙ and bₙ are not exactly equal—which they never are for n>0).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  The sign‐alternation by induction
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the increment pₙ₊₁ − pₙ is positive for odd n and negative for even n, it follows that

• Starting from an odd n with pₙ < 0, we get pₙ₊₁ > pₙ < 0; but the sign of the increment is “large enough” to push the value above zero.  Concretely, one checks for the base case n=1:

  –  a₁ = 1 + 1 = 2,  
     b₁ = 1 − 1 = 0,  
     so  a₁b₁ = 0 < 1,  i.e. p₁ < 0.

  Then (because the increment is positive when n=1 is odd) it follows that p₂ > 0.

• Starting from an even n with pₙ > 0, we get pₙ₊₁ < pₙ > 0; but the negative increment is “large enough” to push the value below zero.  As a base check, for n=2:

  –  a₂ = 1 + 1 + 1/2 = 2.5,  
     b₂ = 1 − 1 + 1/2 = 0.5,  
     so  a₂b₂ = 1.25 > 1,  i.e. p₂ > 0.

  Then (because the increment is negative when n=2 is even) it follows that p₃ < 0.

Hence by this simple “one‐term‐at‐a‐time” induction, pₙ (i.e. aₙbₙ − 1) does indeed alternate in sign according to whether n is odd or even.  Equivalently,

• n odd  ⇒  aₙbₙ < 1,  
• n even ⇒  aₙbₙ > 1.  

That completes the proof. □

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Concluding remarks
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Intuitively, one may think of aₙ → e and bₙ → e⁻¹.  Because bₙ is an alternating‐series partial sum of e⁻¹, one knows bₙ oscillates around e⁻¹, lying above it for even n and below it for odd n.  Meanwhile aₙ is always below e.  Their product therefore “overshoots” 1 on the even steps and “undershoots” on the odd steps, converging to 1 as n grows.  The recursion argument above makes this precise and completes the proof.

Solution Explanation:

Let f ≥ 0 be integrable on [0,1] and set  
A := ∫₀¹ f(x) dx.  

We wish to prove  
∫₀¹ f(x) ( ∫₀¹ f(y)|x - y| dy ) dx  ≤  (1/2) ( ∫₀¹ f(x) dx )² = (1/2) A².  

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Rewrite the double integral.
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Observe that  
∫₀¹ f(x) ( ∫₀¹ f(y) |x - y| dy ) dx  
is exactly the same as the double integral  
∫₀¹ ∫₀¹ f(x) f(y) |x - y| dx dy.  

Hence the desired inequality becomes  
∫₀¹ ∫₀¹ f(x) f(y) |x - y| dx dy  ≤  (1/2) A².  

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Express |x - y| in terms of regions x < y and y < x.
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Note that |x - y| = (y - x) whenever x < y, and = (x - y) whenever x > y.  By symmetry we can write

∫₀¹ ∫₀¹ f(x) f(y) |x - y| dx dy  
=  2 ∫₀¹ ∫₀ʸ f(x) f(y) (y - x) dx dy.

(That is, we split into the region x < y and then multiply by 2.)

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) A more convenient “layer by layer” expression.
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Another common trick is to notice:

|x - y| = 1 if x≠y in its own scaled interval, but more usefully one can rewrite |x - y| as the measure of the interval between x and y.  A shorter route, however, is to consider the functions

F₋(z) := ∫₀ᶻ f(x) dx,    and    F₊(z) := ∫𝑧¹ f(x) dx.

Clearly F₋(z) + F₊(z) = A for every z.  

Claim:  
∫₀¹ ∫₀¹ f(x) f(y) |x - y| dx dy  =  2 ∫₀¹ F₋(z) F₊(z) dz.

Proof (outline):  
• The region {(x,y) : |x - y| ≥ 0} can be decomposed into two parts: (x ≤ y) and (y ≤ x).  
• For a fixed z, the condition z ∈ [min(x,y), max(x,y)] is equivalent to either x ≤ z ≤ y or y ≤ z ≤ x.  
• When x ≤ y, to have x ≤ z ≤ y means x ∈ [0,z] and y ∈ [z,1]; so the integral of f(x)f(y) over x ≤ z ≤ y is (∫₀ᶻ f(x) dx)(∫𝑧¹ f(y) dy) = F₋(z) F₊(z).  
• Similarly for y ≤ z ≤ x, giving another F₋(z) F₊(z).  
Hence summing gives the factor “2”, so indeed
